Colorimeter: An instrument for measuring the depth of the color of anything, especially of a liquid, by comparison with a standard liquid.
Cosmoline: A substance obtained from the residues of the distillation of petroleum, essentially the same as vaseline, but of somewhat stiffer consistency, and consisting of a mixture of the higher paraffines; a kind of petroleum jelly.
Calamar: A cephalopod, belonging to the genus Loligo and related genera. There are many species. They have a sack of inklike fluid which they discharge from the siphon tube, when pursued or alarmed, in order to confuse their enemies. Their shell is a thin horny plate, within the flesh of the back, shaped very much like a quill pen. In America they are called squids. See Squid.
Creaze: The tin ore which collects in the central part of the washing pit or buddle.
Crunode: A point where one branch of a curve crosses another branch. See Double point, under Double, a.
Contemplate: To consider or think studiously; to ponder; to reflect; to muse; to meditate.
Christmasberry: a spiny evergreen shrub of southeastern U. S. (Lycium carolinianum) having spreading branches with usually blue or mauve flowers and red berries.
Craziness: The state of being broken down or weakened; as, the craziness of a ship, or of the limbs.
Chiliad: A thousand; the aggregate of a thousand things; especially, a period of a thousand years.
Climbing: p. pr. & vb. n. of Climb.
Chilian: The commander or chief of a thousand men.
Columelliform: Shaped like a little column, or columella.
Chinquapin: A branching, nut-bearing tree or shrub (Castanea pumila) of North America, from six to twenty feet high, allied to the chestnut. Also, its small, sweet, edible nat.
Crustaceologist: One versed in crustaceology; a crustalogist.
Cheeringly: In a manner to cheer or encourage.
Casement: A window sash opening on hinges affixed to the upright side of the frame into which it is fitted. (Poetically) A window.
Charitable: Full of love and good will; benevolent; kind.
Contemper: To modify or temper; to allay; to qualify; to moderate; to soften.
Cuttoo plate: A hood over the end of a wagon wheel hub to keep dirt away from the axle.
Confederative: Of or pertaining to a confederation.
Castalian: Of or pertaining to Castalia, a mythical fountain of inspiration on Mt. Parnassus sacred to the Muses.
Chippendale: Designating furniture designed, or like that designed, by Thomas Chippendale, an English cabinetmaker of the 18th century. Chippendale furniture was generally of simple but graceful outline with delicately carved rococo ornamentation, sculptured either in the solid wood or, in the cheaper specimens, separately and glued on. In the more elaborate pieces three types are recognized: French Chippendale, having much detail, like Louis Quatorze and Louis Quinze; Chinese Chippendale, marked by latticework and pagodalike pediments; and Gothic Chippendale, attempting to adapt medieval details. The forms, as of the cabriole and chairbacks, often resemble Queen Anne. In chairs, the seat is widened at the front, and the back toward the top widened and bent backward, except in Chinese Chippendale, in which the backs are usually rectangular.
Carbanil: A mobile liquid, CO.N.C6H5, of pungent odor. It is the phenyl salt of isocyanic acid.
Coly: Any bird of the genus Colius and allied genera. They inhabit Africa.
Capillaceous: Having long filaments; resembling a hair; slender. See Capillary.
courgette: a marrow squash plant whose fruit are eaten when small; -- called also zucchini.
Cradling: The act of using a cradle.
Colonialism: The state or quality of, or the relationship involved in, being colonial.
Conventional: Formed by agreement or compact; stipulated.
Contract tablet: A clay tablet on which was inscribed a contract, for safe keeping.  Such tablets were inclosed in an outer case (often called the envelope), on which was inscribed a duplicate of the inscription on the inclosed tablet.
Chintz: Cotton cloth, printed with flowers and other devices, in a number of different colors, and often glazed.
conjuring: invoking a spirit or devil.  See conjure, v..
Canonship: Of or pertaining to Canopus in Egypt; as, the Canopic vases, used in embalming.
Corticifer: One of the Gorgoniacea; -- so called because the fleshy part surrounds a solid axis, like a bark.
Charade: A verbal or acted enigma based upon a word which has two or more significant syllables or parts, each of which, as well as the word itself, is to be guessed from the descriptions or representations.
Counterpoint: A coverlet; a cover for a bed, often stitched or broken into squares; a counterpane.  See 1st Counterpane.
Chamisal: A California rosaceous shrub (Adenostoma fasciculatum) which often forms an impenetrable chaparral.
Cobaea: A genus of climbing plants, native of Mexico and South America. Cobaea scandens (called cup-and-saucer vine, monastery bells, or Mexican ivy) is a conservatory climber with large bell-shaped flowers.
Chain pump: A pump consisting of an endless chain, running over a drum or wheel by which it is moved, and dipping below the water to be raised. The chain has at intervals disks or lifts which fit the tube through which the ascending part passes and carry the water to the point of discharge.
cooking: the practice or manner of preparing food or the food so prepared; cookery.
Cantabrigian: A native or resident of Cambridge; esp. a student or graduate of the university of Cambridge, England.
Confated: Fated or decreed with something else.
Companion: To be a companion to; to attend on; to accompany.
Crystallogenic: Pertaining to the production of crystals; crystal-producing; as, crystallogenic attraction.
Cranage: The liberty of using a crane, as for loading and unloading vessels.
Chrysophyllum: a genus of tropical American evergreen trees or shrubs.
Capableness: The quality or state of being capable; capability; adequateness; competency.
Chaff: To make fun of; to turn into ridicule by addressing in ironical or bantering language; to quiz.
Cummerbund: A sash for the waist; a girdle.
Conterranean: Of or belonging to the same country.
Chih hsien: An official having charge of a hsien, or administrative district, in China; a district magistrate, responsible for good order in his hsien (which see), and having jurisdiction in its civil and criminal cases.
Car wheel: A flanged wheel of a railway car or truck.
Controversialist: One who carries on a controversy; a disputant.
Coquimbite: A mineral consisting principally of sulphate of iron; white copperas; -- so called because found in the province of Coquimbo, Chili.
chino: a coarse, tough, twilled cotton fabric used for uniforms or sports clothes.
chimneysweep: someone who cleans soot from chimneys, usually as a profession.
Camlet: A woven fabric originally made of camel's hair, now chiefly of goat's hair and silk, or of wool and cotton.
Catastrophic: Of a pertaining to a catastrophe.
Crampon: An aërial rootlet for support in climbing, as of ivy.
Crankness: Liability to be overset; -- said of a ship or other vessel.
Carbamic: Pertaining to an acid so called.
Cluck: The call of a hen to her chickens.
Chimango: A south American carrion buzzard (Milvago chimango). See Caracara.
Concern: That which relates or belongs to one; business; affair.
Cosmogonist: One who treats of the origin of the universe; one versed in cosmogony.
Contemner: One who contemns; a despiser; a scorner.
Carrageen: A small, purplish, branching, cartilaginous seaweed (Chondrus crispus), which, when bleached, is the Irish moss of commerce.
Canaille: The lowest class of people; the rabble; the vulgar.
Colleague: To unite or associate with another or with others.
Cribbing: The act of inclosing or confining in a crib or in close quarters.
Carangidae: large family of narrow-bodied marine food fishes allied to the mackerels, with widely forked tails; chiefly of warm seas; it includes the caranx, American bluefish, and the pilot fish.
Conjure: To practice magical arts; to use the tricks of a conjurer; to juggle; to charm.
Chekmak: A turkish fabric of silk and cotton, with gold thread interwoven.
Calcareous: Partaking of the nature of calcite or calcium carbonate; consisting of, or containing, calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime.
Cardiidae: a natural family of somewhat heart-shaped sand-burrowing bivalve mollusks.
Chausses: The garment for the legs and feet and for the body below the waist, worn in Europe throughout the Middle Ages; applied also to the armor for the same parts, when fixible, as of chain mail.
Chiastolite: A variety of andalusite; -- called also macle. The tessellated appearance of a cross section is due to the symmetrical arrangement of impurities in the crystal.
Calver: To bear, or be susceptible of, being calvered; as, grayling's flesh will calver.
Creeping: Crawling, or moving close to the ground.
Criminology: A treatise on crime or the criminal population.
Cropsick: Sick from excess in eating or drinking.
Circumdenudation: Denudation around or in the neighborhood of an object.
Centinody: A weed with a stem of many joints (Illecebrum verticillatum); also, the Polygonum aviculare or knotgrass.
Cumidine: A strong, liquid, organic base, C3H7.C6H4.NH2, homologous with aniline.
Cryohydrate: A substance, as salt, ammonium chloride, etc., which crystallizes with water of crystallization only at low temperatures, or below the freezing point of water.
Corrugent: Drawing together; contracting; -- said of the corrugator.
Calcigenous: Tending to form, or to become, a calx or earthlike substance on being oxidized or burnt; as magnesium, calcium. etc.
Cicely: Any one of several umbelliferous plants, of the genera Myrrhis, Osmorrhiza, etc.
Culture features: The artificial features of a district as distinguished from the natural.
Chessy copper: The mineral azurite, found in fine crystallization at Chessy, near Lyons; called also chessylite.
cryostat: a thermostat that operates at very low temperatures.
cirio: the candlewood of Mexico and couthwestern California (Idria columnaris or Fouquieria columnaris), having tall columnar stems and bearing honey-scented creamy yellow flowers; -- called also the boojum tree.
Creosote: To saturate or impregnate with creosote, as timber, for the prevention of decay.
counseling: direction or advice as to a decision or course of action.
Court-cupboard: A movable sideboard or buffet, on which plate and other articles of luxury were displayed on special ocasions.
cocksucker: a worthless or despicable person; -- intended as disparaging and invariably offensive.
Cenotaph: An empty tomb or a monument erected in honor of a person who is buried elsewhere.
Cobiron: An andiron with a knob at the top.
cutback: a reduction in quantity or rate; a reduction in the amount of an activity or the funding for an activity; as, cutbacks in government research funding increased unemployment among scientists; the recession caused a cutback in auto production.
Chesstree: A piece of oak bolted perpendicularly on the side of a vessel, to aid in drawing down and securing the clew of the mainsail.
Chelydridae: a natural family comprising the snapping turtles.
Clatter: A rattling noise, esp. that made by the collision of hard bodies; also, any loud, abrupt sound; a repetition of abrupt sounds.
Cabbage: Cloth or clippings cabbaged or purloined by one who cuts out garments.
Constrainedly: By constraint or compulsion; in a constrained manner.
Correspondent: One with whom intercourse is carried on by letter.
cabbage worm: the larva of several species of moths and butterflies, which attacks cabbages. The most common is the toxic green larva of a white butterfly, the cabbage butterfly, (Pieris rapæ).  The cabbage cutworms, which eat off the stalks of young plants during the night, are the larvæ of several species of moths, of the genus Agrotis. See Cutworm.  larva of a cabbage butterfly.
Cretinous: Having the characteristics of a cretin.
Calcify: To become changed into a stony or calcareous condition, in which lime is a principal ingredient, as in the formation of teeth.
Copyhold: A tenure of estate by copy of court roll; or a tenure for which the tenant has nothing to show, except the rolls made by the steward of the lord's court.
Clomb: imp. & p. p. of Climb (for climbed).
Cooly: An East Indian porter or carrier; a laborer transported from the East Indies, China, or Japan, for service in some other country.
Chromatophore: A contractile cell or vesicle containing liquid pigment and capable of changing its form or size, thus causing changes of color in the translucent skin of such animals as possess them. They are highly developed and numerous in the cephalopods.
Culpa: Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit, fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect of intellect, dolus to defect of heart.
Commemoration: The act of commemorating; an observance or celebration designed to honor the memory of some person or event.
centriole: one of two small cylindrical cell organelles composes of nine triplet microtubules, which form the asters during mitosis.
Champignon: An edible species of mushroom (Agaricus campestris).
Cavetto: A concave molding; -- used chiefly in classical architecture.  See Illust. of Column.
Cribration: The act or process of separating the finer parts of drugs from the coarser by sifting.
Conditionate: To qualify by conditions; to regulate.
Crincum: A twist or bend; a turn; a whimsey.
Cacodylic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, cacodyl.
Cream: To form or become covered with cream; to become thick like cream; to assume the appearance of cream; hence, to grow stiff or formal; to mantle.
corncockle: a European annual (Agrostemma githago) having large trumpet-shaped reddish-purple flowers and poisonous seed; a common weed in grainfields and beside roadways; naturalized in America.
Contrahent: Entering into covenant; contracting; as, contrahent parties.
Cyclo-: A combining form meaning circular, of a circle or wheel.
Capitalize: To convert into capital, or to use as capital.
Chout: An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue.
Cardo: The basal joint of the maxilla in insects.
Conferva: Any unbranched, slender, green plant of the fresh-water algae. The word is frequently used in a wider sense.
Crown-imperial: A spring-blooming plant (Fritillaria imperialis) of the Lily family, having at the top of the stalk a cluster of pendent bell-shaped flowers surmounted with a tuft of green leaves.
Commonly: Usually; generally; ordinarily; frequently; for the most part; as, confirmed habits commonly continue through life.
Cyclopedic: Belonging to the circle of the sciences, or to a cyclopedia; of the nature of a cyclopedia; hence, of great range, extent, or amount; as, a man of cyclopedic knowledge.
Contumacious: Exhibiting contumacy; contemning authority; obstinate; perverse; stubborn; disobedient.
Catharsis: A natural or artificial purgation of any passage, as of the mouth, bowels, etc.
Casuistic: Of or pertaining to casuists or casuistry; as, casuistic thinking.
Carditis: Inflammation of the fleshy or muscular substance of the heart. See Endocarditis and Pericarditis.
Cobble: To make or mend coarsely; to patch; to botch; as, to cobble shoes.
Callimorpha: a genus of insects comprising the cinnabar moths.
Cachou: A silvered aromatic pill, used to correct the odor of the breath.
Calorisator: An apparatus used in beet-sugar factories to heat the juice in order to aid the diffusion.
Curse: An invocation of, or prayer for, harm or injury; malediction.
caboodle: The whole collection; the entire quantity or number; -- usually in the phrase the whole caboodle or the whole kit and caboodle.
Cashierer: One who rejects, discards, or dismisses; as, a cashierer of monarchs.
Chiefage: A tribute by the head; a capitation tax.
Celandine: A perennial herbaceous plant (Chelidonium majus) of the poppy family, with yellow flowers. It is used as a medicine in jaundice, etc., and its acrid saffron-colored juice is used to cure warts and the itch; -- called also greater celandine and swallowwort.
Clarino: A reed stop in an organ.
Circumambient: Surrounding; inclosing or being on all sides; encompassing.
contracting: the act or process of acquiring an infectious disease; contraction; as, the contracting of a serious illness can be financially catastrophic.
Cranial: Of or pertaining to the cranium.
Crowdy: A thick gruel of oatmeal and milk or water; food of the porridge kind.
Chamaedaphne: a genus consisting of only one species, the leatherleaf.
Checkrein: A short rein looped over the check hook to prevent a horse from lowering his head; -- called also a bearing rein.
Courtyard: A court or inclosure attached to a house.
combinatorial: able to combine; tending to combine.
Curiosity: The state or quality or being curious; nicety; accuracy; exactness; elaboration.
Condemnatory: Condemning; containing or imposing condemnation or censure; as, a condemnatory sentence or decree.
Cochin fowl: A large variety of the domestic fowl, originally from Cochin China (Anam).
Compotier: A dish for holding compotes, fruit, etc.; a compote dish, or compote{2}.
Culvert: A transverse drain or waterway of masonry under a road, railroad, canal, etc.; a small bridge.
Ceruse: White lead, used as a pigment. See White lead, under White.
Corinne: The common gazelle (Gazella dorcas). See Gazelle.
Colliquate: To change from solid to fluid; to make or become liquid; to melt.
Caledonite: A hydrous sulphate of copper and lead, found in some parts of Caledonia or Scotland.
Cham: The sovereign prince of Tartary; -- now usually written khan.
Char: To reduce to coal or carbon by exposure to heat; to reduce to charcoal; to burn to a cinder.
Canonist: A professor of canon law; one skilled in the knowledge and practice of ecclesiastical law.
Capitate: Headlike in form; also, having the distal end enlarged and rounded, as the stigmas of certain flowers.
Chat: A twig, cone, or little branch. See Chit.
Crannog: One of the stockaded islands in Scotland and Ireland which in ancient times were numerous in the lakes of both countries. They may be regarded as the very latest class of prehistoric strongholds, reaching their greatest development in early historic times, and surviving through the Middle Ages. See also Lake dwellings, under Lake.
Camisade: A shirt worn by soldiers over their uniform, in order to be able to recognize one another in a night attack.
Coscinomancy: Divination by means of a suspended sieve.
Chihuahua: an old breed of tiny short-coated dogs with protruding eyes, originating in Mexico, believed to antedate Aztec civilization.
Countervote: To vote in opposition to; to balance or overcome by voting; to outvote.
Chop-logic: One who bandies words or is very argumentative.
Crepitate: To make a series of small, sharp, rapidly repeated explosions or sounds, as salt in fire; to crackle; to snap.
Culicid: Like or pertaining to the Mosquito family (Culicidæ).
Carburization: The act, process, or result of carburizing.
Coranach: A lamentation for the dead; a dirge.
critter: Any animal; as, lots of critters come out only at night.
Capillary: A tube or vessel, extremely fine or minute.
Chattelism: The act or condition of holding chattels; the state of being a chattel.
carousel: a continuous belt oriented horizontally or near-horizontally around a central structure, driven in a circular motion by some mechanism, which carries luggage delivered from the luggage hold of an airplane to air travelers; -- used at airports.
Corporeity: The state of having a body; the state of being corporeal; materiality.
Chthonian: Designating, or pertaining to, gods or spirits of the underworld; esp., relating to the underworld gods of the Greeks, whose worship is widely considered as more primitive in form than that of the Olympian gods. The characteristics of chthonian worship are propitiatory and magical rites and generalized or euphemistic names of the deities, which are supposed to have been primarily ghosts.
cornflour: a flour or starch prepared from the grains of corn; it is used in cooking as a thickener.
crate: To pack in a crate or case for transportation; as, to crate a sewing machine; to crate peaches.
Continual: Proceeding without interruption or cesstaion; continuous; unceasing; lasting; abiding.
Correlative: One who, or that which, stands in a reciprocal relation, or is correlated, to some other person or thing.
chairwoman: a female officer who presides at the meetings of a committee, meeting, or organization; a female chairperson.
Consonantize: To change into, or use as, a consonant.
Continently: In a continent manner; chastely; moderately; temperately.
circa: Approximately; about; commonly abbreviated ca.; -- used especially before dates and numerical measures; as, he was born circa 1650; ca. 50 feet high.
Ceratopsidae: an extinct family of American ceratopsian dinosaurs.
Coda: A few measures added beyond the natural termination of a composition.
Castanets: Two small, concave shells of ivory or hard wood, shaped like spoons, fastened to the thumb, and beaten together with the middle finger; -- used by the Spaniards and Moors as an accompaniment to their dance and guitars.
Cymose: Having the nature of a cyme, or derived from a cyme; bearing, or pertaining to, a cyme or cymes.
Croydon: A kind of carriage like a gig, orig. of wicker-work.
Conjugate: To unite in a kind of sexual union, as two or more cells or individuals among the more simple plants and animals.
Cuirass: A piece of defensive armor, covering the body from the neck to the girdle
Chasable: Capable of being chased; fit for hunting.
Canopus: A star of the first magnitude in the southern constellation Argo.
Commoration: The act of staying or residing in a place.
Corregidor: The chief magistrate of a Spanish town.
Counterdraw: To copy, as a design or painting, by tracing with a pencil on oiled paper, or other transparent substance.
Contortion: A twisting; a writhing; wry motion; a twist; as, the contortion of the muscles of the face.
Counterpoise: A weight sufficient to balance another, as in the opposite scale of a balance; an equal weight.
Canter: One who cants or whines; a beggar.
Conspiration: Agreement or concurrence for some end or purpose; conspiracy.
credentialed: having an official document certifying fitness for a particular task.
Cucujo: The fire beetle of Mexico and the West Indies.
Convexness: The state of being convex; convexity.
Canted: Having angles; as, a six canted bolt head; a canted window.
Cruciation: The act of torturing; torture; torment.
Caledonia: The ancient Latin name of Scotland; -- still used in poetry.
Costermonger: An apple seller; a hawker of, or dealer in, any kind of fruit or vegetables; a fruiterer.
cypre: a large tropical American tree (Cordia alliodora) grown for its abundant creamy white flowers and valuable wood.
Chloralum: An impure aqueous solution of chloride of aluminium, used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.
Calamistrate: To curl or friz, as the hair.
Chablis: A white wine made near Chablis, a town in France.
Centralize: To draw or bring to a center point; to gather into or about a center; to bring into one system, or under one control.
Cablet: A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.
Cuprous: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper; -- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is present in its highest proportion.
Communicability: The quality of being communicable; capability of being imparted.
Cosmologist: One who describes the universe; one skilled in cosmology.
Ch\u00e6topoda: A very extensive order of Annelida (segmented worms), characterized by the presence of lateral setæ, or spines, on most or all of the segments.  They are divided into two principal groups: Oligochæta, including the earthworms and allied forms, and Polychæta, including most of the marine species.
Candock: A plant or weed that grows in rivers; a species of Equisetum; also, the yellow frog lily (Nuphar luteum).
Civilized: Reclaimed from savage life and manners; instructed in arts, learning, and civil manners; refined; cultivated.
Cirrate: Having cirri along the margin of a part or organ.
came: A slender rod of cast lead, with or without grooves, used, in casements and stained-glass windows, to hold together the panes or pieces of glass.
Chlorous: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of three, the next lower than in chloric compounds; as, chlorous acid, HClO2.
Christocentric: Making Christ the center, about whom all things are grouped, as in religion or history; tending toward Christ, as the central object of thought or emotion.
Cephalic: A medicine for headache, or other disorder in the head.
Composure: The act of composing, or that which is composed; a composition.
Caulocarpous: Having stems which bear flowers and fruit year after year, as most trees and shrubs.
Cordy: Of, or like, cord; having cords or cordlike parts.
Congressional: Of or pertaining to a congress, especially, to the Congress of the United States; as, congressional debates.
Clarendon: A style of type having a narrow and heave face. It is made in all sizes.
Catacomb: A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used for the burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.
Compline: The last division of the Roman Catholic breviary; the seventh and last of the canonical hours of the Western church; the last prayer of the day, to be said after sunset.
Capsule: a dry fruit or pod which is made up of several parts or carpels, and opens to discharge the seeds, as, the capsule of the poppy, the flax, the lily, etc.
Cheroot: A kind of cigar, originally brought from Manila, in the Philippine Islands; now often made of inferior or adulterated tobacco.
Crappie: A kind of fresh-water bass of the genus Pomoxys, found in the rivers of the Southern United States and Mississippi valley. There are several species.
Compound control: A system of control in which a separate manipulation, as of a rudder, may be effected by either of two movements, in different directions, of a single lever, etc.
Clemency: Disposition to forgive and spare, as offenders; mildness of temper; gentleness; tenderness; mercy.
cronel: The iron head of a tilting spear.
Cometographer: One who describes or writes about comets.
Chanfrin: The fore part of a horse's head.
Childlike: Resembling a child, or that which belongs to children; becoming a child; meek; submissive; dutiful.
Cash register: A device for recording the amount of cash received, usually having an automatic adding machine and a money drawer and exhibiting the amount of the sale.
Consecute: To follow closely; to endeavor to overtake; to pursue.
Capric: Of or pertaining to capric acid or its derivatives.
Cavitary: Containing a body cavity; as, the cavitary or nematoid worms.
curly-heads: a shrubby clematis (Clematis ochreleuca) of eastern US having curly foliage.
cabbage butterfly: a white butterfly (Pieris rapæ of both Europe and America, and the allied Pieris oleracea, a native American species) which, in the larval state, devours the leaves of the cabbage and the turnip. See also Cabbage worm, below.
Compte rendu: A report of an officer or agent.
chromatograph: a piece of equipment used to perform chromatography{2}.
Cenanthy: The absence or suppression of the essential organs (stamens and pistil) in a flower.
compact disc: a disk-shaped optical data storage medium approximately 4-3/4 in. in diameter, which stores binary data as microscopic nonreflective holes or pits in an otherwise reflective surface, and is recorded and played back by rotation in an electronic device containing a laser.  It is often referred to by its abbreviation CD.  It is a type of optical data storage medium.  Compact disks are used for recordings of music as well as of data for computer applications.
Croat: A native or resident of Croatia.
Collodion: A solution of pyroxylin (soluble gun cotton) in ether containing a varying proportion of alcohol. It is strongly adhesive, and is used by surgeons as a coating for wounds; but its chief application is as a vehicle for the sensitive film in photography.
Cusp: To furnish with a cusp or cusps.
credit-worthy: having an acceptable credit rating; worthy of having credit extended; as, a credit-worthy customer.
Cross-reading: The reading of the lines of a newspaper directly across the page, instead of down the columns, thus producing a ludicrous combination of ideas.
Convocation: The act of calling or assembling by summons.
Cypseliform: Like or belonging to the swifts (Cypselidæ.)
Cockshy: A game in which trinkets are set upon sticks, to be thrown at by the players; -- so called from an ancient popular sport which consisted in “shying” or throwing cudgels at live cocks.
Cusk: A large, edible, marine fish (Brosmius brosme), allied to the cod, common on the northern coasts of Europe and America; -- called also tusk and torsk.
Cage: To confine in, or as in, a cage; to shut up or confine.
Cloud-burst: A sudden copious rainfall, as if the whole cloud had been precipitated at once.
Cohune: A Central and South American pinnate-leaved palm (Attalea cohune), the very large and hard nuts of which are turned to make fancy articles, and also yield an oil used as a substitute for coconut oil.
Consultatory: Formed by, or resulting from, consultation; advisory.
Clownishness: The manners of a clown; coarseness or rudeness of behavior.
coralberry: a North American deciduous shrub (Symphoricarpos orbiculatus) cultivated for its abundant clusters of coral-red berrylike fruits.
Classificatory: Pertaining to classification; admitting of classification.
Contenement: That which is held together with another thing; that which is connected with a tenement, or thing holden, as a certain quantity of land adjacent to a dwelling, and necessary to the reputable enjoyment of the dwelling; appurtenance.
Celibacy: The state of being unmarried; single life, esp. that of a bachelor, or of one bound by vows not to marry.
Capella: A brilliant star in the constellation Auriga.
Capelle: The private orchestra or band of a prince or of a church.
crottal: any of several lichens of the genus Parmelia from which reddish brown or purple dyes are made.
Cometology: The branch of astronomy relating to comets.
Cleek: To seize; clutch; snatch; catch; pluck.
Constrained: Marked by constraint; not free; not voluntary; embarrassed; as, a constrained manner; a constrained tone.
Comet-finder: A telescope of low power, having a large field of view, used for finding comets.
Conchoidal: Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of a bivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced by fracture.
Cockler: One who takes and sells cockles.
Cynoscephalae: the battle that ended the second Macedonian War (197 BC); the Romans defeated King Philip of Macedon.
Corsair: A pirate; one who cruises about without authorization from any government, to seize booty on sea or land.
Closer: One who, or that which, closes; specifically, a boot closer. See under Boot.
Chelyabinsk: a city in the Asian part of Russia.
crownbeard: any plant of the genus Verbesina having clustered white or yellow flower heads.
Congo snake: An amphibian (Amphiuma means) of the order Urodela, found in the southern United States. See Amphiuma.
Calking: The act or process of making seems tight, as in ships, or of furnishing with calks, as a shoe, or copying, as a drawing.
Crustily: In a crusty or surly manner; morosely.
Calomel: Mild chloride of mercury, Hg2Cl2, a heavy, white or yellowish white substance, insoluble and tasteless, much used in medicine as a mercurial and purgative; mercurous chloride. It occurs native as the mineral horn quicksilver.
Cotta: A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and less full than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimes none.
Clarence: A close four-wheeled carriage, with one seat inside, and a seat for the driver.
Camarasaurus: A genus of gigantic American Jurassic dinosaurs, having large cavities in the bodies of the dorsal vertebræ.
Cornsheller: A machine that separates the kernels of corn from the cob.
Circumcenter: The center of a circle that circumscribes a triangle.
Candidacy: The position of a candidate; state of being a candidate; candidateship.
Coleopterist: One versed in the study of the Coleoptera.
Chalky: Consisting of, or resembling, chalk; containing chalk; as, a chalky cliff; a chalky taste.
Compulsive: Having power to compel; exercising or applying compulsion.
Chippy: A small American sparrow (Spizella socialis), very common near dwelling; -- also called chipping bird and chipping sparrow, from its simple note.
Canopy: To cover with, or as with, a canopy.
Contraries: Propositions which directly and destructively contradict each other, but of which the falsehood of one does not establish the truth of the other.
cunt: The female pudenda; specifically the vagina.
Corradiation: A conjunction or concentration of rays in one point.
Circumlocution: The use of many words to express an idea that might be expressed by few; indirect or roundabout language; a periphrase.
Catechin: One of the tannic acids (C15H14O6), extracted from catechu as a white, crystalline substance; -- called also catechuic acid, catechinic acid, cyanidol, and catechuin.  It is a flavonoid found generally in higher woody plants, and is used in dyeing and tanning.
coralwood: an East Indian tree (Adenanthera pavonina) with racemes of yellow-white flowers; cultivated as an ornamental.
Cinchonize: To produce cinchonism in; to poison with quinine or with cinchona.
Call: The act of calling; -- usually with the voice, but often otherwise, as by signs, the sound of some instrument, or by writing; a summons; an entreaty; an invitation; as, a call for help; the bugle's call.
Cr\u00e8che: A public nursery, where the young children of poor women are cared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
Chiasm: A commissure; an intersection or crossing of two tracts; especially, the optic commissure, or crucial union of the optic nerves.
canoeing: The act or art of using a canoe.
Carduus: a genus of annual or perennial Old World prickly thistles.
Caparison: An ornamental covering or housing for a horse; the harness or trappings of a horse, taken collectively, especially when decorative.
campaigning: The campaign of a candidate to be elected.
Cockleshell: One of the shells or valves of a cockle.
Colonizationist: A friend to colonization, esp. (U. S. Hist) to the colonization of Africa by emigrants from the colored population of the United States.
Conation: The power or act which directs or impels to effort of any kind, whether muscular or psychical.
Calcispongi\u00e6: An order of marine sponges, containing calcareous spicules. See Porifera.
Correctness: The state or quality of being correct; as, the correctness of opinions or of manners; correctness of taste; correctness in writing or speaking; the correctness of a text or copy.
Cookroom: A room for cookery; a kitchen; the galley or caboose of a ship.
Cogitation: The act of thinking; thought; meditation; contemplation.
Cyanuric acid: an organic acid, C3O3N3H3, first obtained by heating uric acid or urea, and called pyrouric acid; afterwards obtained from isocyanic acid. It is a white crystalline substance, odorless and almost tasteless; -- called also tricarbimide.
Cro-magnon: a race of human-like hominids of the Upper Paleolithic in Europe, considered of the same species as modern humans (Homo sapiens).  Their skeletal remains were found mostly in southern France.
Chaenopsis: a genus of clinid fishes consisting of the pikeblennies.
Cosinage: Collateral relationship or kindred by blood; consanguinity.
Conservable: Capable of being preserved from decay or injury.
Contrary: To contradict or oppose; to thwart.
Cornhusker: a resident of Nebraska; -- a nickname.
Complimentary: Expressive of regard or praise; of the nature of, or containing, a compliment; as, a complimentary remark; a complimentary ticket.
Cosier: A tailor who botches his work.
Crusading: Of or pertaining to a crusade; as, a crusading spirit.
Corroboree: A nocturnal festivity with which the Australian aborigines celebrate tribal events of importance. Symbolic dances are given by the young men of the tribe, while the women act as musicians.
centavo: a fractional monetary unit of several countries such as El Salvador, St. Thomas and Principe, Brazil,  Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Peru, the Philippines, and Portugal.
Circumfluence: A flowing round on all sides; an inclosing with a fluid.
Calendulin: A gummy or mucilaginous tasteless substance obtained from the marigold or calendula, and analogous to bassorin.
Commensality: Fellowship at table; the act or practice of eating at the same table.
Corundum: The mineral alumina (Al2O3), as found native in a crystalline state.  Transparent varieties are used as gemstones, including sapphire, which is the fine blue variety; the oriental ruby, or red sapphire; the oriental amethyst, or purple sapphire; and adamantine spar, the hair-brown variety. It is the hardest substance found native, next to the diamond.
Coquet: To trifle in love; to stimulate affection or interest; to play the coquette; to deal playfully instead of seriously; to play (with); as, we have coquetted with political crime.
Coupure: A passage cut through the glacis to facilitate sallies by the besieged.
Coatless: Not wearing a coat; also, not possessing a coat.
Conspectus: A general sketch or outline of a subject; a synopsis; an epitome.
Circumgestation: The act or process of carrying about.
Cottidae: a natural family of fish including the sculpins.
Credendum: A thing to be believed; an article of faith; -- distinguished from agendum, a practical duty.
cellophane: a transparent paper-like product made of regenerated cellulose, produced in sheets and rolls, which is impervious to moisture and germs, and which is used to wrap candy, cigarettes, and a wide variety of other products for distribution and retail sale; as, a pack of cigarettes in a cellophane wrapper.
Currentness: The quality of being current; currency; circulation; general reception.
Co\u00f6rdination: The act of coördinating; the act of putting in the same order, class, rank, dignity, etc.; as, the coördination of the executive, the legislative, and the judicial authority in forming a government; the act of regulating and combining so as to produce harmonious results; harmonious adjustment; as, a coördination of functions.
Cantonize: To divide into cantons or small districts.
Confluence: The act of flowing together; the meeting or junction of two or more streams; the place of meeting.
Compositor: One who composes or sets in order.
Counter brace: The brace of the fore-topsail on the leeward side of a vessel.
Chelerythrine: An alkaloidal principle obtained from the celandine, and named from the red color of its salts. It is a colorless crystalline substance, and acts as an acrid narcotic poison. It is identical with sanguinarine.
Craggedness: The quality or state of being cragged; cragginess.
Claviceps: a genus of fungi parasitic upon the ovaries of various grasses.
Convexly: In a convex form; as, a body convexly shaped.
Consistory: Of the nature of, or pertaining to, a consistory.
Cirsocele: The varicose dilatation of the spermatic vein.
clustered: growing close together but not in dense mats; -- of plants.
Creatureship: The condition of being a creature.
Calciferous: Bearing, producing, or containing calcite, or carbonate of lime.
Converging: Tending to one point; approaching each other; convergent; as, converging lines.
Catonian: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the stern old Roman, Cato the Censor; severe; inflexible.
clawlike: having a base shaped like a claw; -- of flower petals.
Circumlocutional: Relating to, or consisting of, circumlocutions; periphrastic; circuitous.
Corruptless: Not susceptible of corruption or decay; incorruptible.
Cantharidal: Of or pertaining to cantharides or made of cantharides; as, cantharidal plaster.
Chapeau: A hat or covering for the head.
Chromolithographic: Pertjining tj, or maoe by, coromolithography.
Cloop: The sound made when a cork is forcibly drawn from a bottle.
Conchoid: A curve, of the fourth degree, first made use of by the Greek geometer, Nicomedes, who invented it for the purpose of trisecting an angle and duplicating the cube.
Cloot: One of the divisions of a cleft hoof, as in the ox; also, the whole hoof.
Congruous: Suitable or concordant; accordant; fit; harmonious; correspondent; consistent.
Cheerer: One who cheers; one who, or that which, gladdens.
Croton bug: A small, active, winged species of cockroach (Ectobia Germanica), the water bug. It is common aboard ships, and in houses in cities, esp. in those with hot-water pipes; -- called also the German cockroach.
Conservation: The act of preserving, guarding, or protecting; the keeping (of a thing) in a safe or entire state; preservation.
Carpeting: The act of covering with carpets.
Calocedrus: a genus of tall evergreens of West North America and East Asia; formerly included in genus Libocedrus.
comeuppance: An unpleasant experience a person endures, which is viewed by others as a just retribution for bad behavior; just deserts; as, the Senator took bribes for years, and finally got his comeuppance when he was caught in a sting operation.
Caddish: Like a cad; lowbred and presuming.
Crisscross: In opposite directions; in a way to cross something else; crossing one another at various angles and in various ways.
Cylindriform: Having the form of a cylinder.
Cassiopeia: A constellation of the northern hemisphere, situated between Cepheus and Perseus; -- so called in honor of the wife of Cepheus, a fabulous king of Ethiopia.
Cruels: Glandular scrofulous swellings in the neck.
Corrosive: That which has the quality of eating or wearing away gradually.
Convertible: Capable of being converted; susceptible of change; transmutable; transformable.
Celebration: The act, process, or time of celebrating.
curvaceous: having a pronounced womanly shape; having a slender waist with prominent breasts and hips.
Corymbose: Consisting of corymbs, or resembling them in form.
clorella: any alga of the genus Chlorella.
chin-up: an arm exercise performed by pulling oneself up on a horizontal bar until the chin is level with or above the bar.
Calla: A genus of plants, of the order Araceæ.
Cerebrin: A nonphosphorized, nitrogenous substance, obtained from brain and nerve tissue by extraction with boiling alcohol. It is uncertain whether it exists as such in nerve tissue, or is a product of the decomposition of some more complex substance.
Cynanche: Any disease of the tonsils, throat, or windpipe, attended with inflammation, swelling, and difficulty of breathing and swallowing.
Cavalierism: The practice or principles of cavaliers.
Chambranle: An ornamental bordering or framelike decoration around the sides and top of a door, window, or fireplace. The top piece is called the traverse and the side pieces the ascendants.
Cerebric: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the brain.
Cancridae: a natural family including many of the best known edible crabs.
Captaincy: The rank, post, or commission of a captain.
Controversial: Relating to, or consisting of, controversy; disputatious; polemical; as, controversial divinity.
Covenantee: The person in whose favor a covenant is made.
Cleverness: The quality of being clever; skill; dexterity; adroitness.
Cankered: Affected with canker; as, a cankered mouth.
Cauterism: The use or application of a caustic; cautery.
Calculate: To make a calculation; to forecast consequences; to estimate; to compute.
Capture: To seize or take possession of by force, surprise, or stratagem; to overcome and hold; to secure by effort.
Concerned: Disturbed; troubled; solicitous; as, to be much concerned for the safety of a friend.
Cydonin: A peculiar mucilaginous substance extracted from the seeds of the quince (Cydonia vulgaris), and regarded as a variety of amylose.
Cress: A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaves have a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad and antiscorbutic.
caseful: the quantity contained in a case.
Caballeria: An ancient Spanish land tenure similar to the English knight's fee; hence, in Spain and countries settled by the Spanish, a land measure of varying size.  In Cuba it is about 33 acres; in Puerto Rico, about 194 acres; in the Southwestern United States, about 108 acres.
Cloudily: In a cloudy manner; darkly; obscurely.
Coraciiformes: an order of birds including the rollers; kingfishers; hornbills; hoopoes; motmots; bee-eaters; todies.
Cimex: A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the best known example. See Bedbug.
CO2 extinguisher: a device for suppressing fire, consisting of a steel cylinder containing compressed carbon dioxide, which may be released by pressing on a handle.  The release of the gas is usually accomplished through a hose attached to a funnel-shaped vent which is directed at the base of the fire, and when released, part of the carbon dioxide is chilled sufficiently to solidify into a powder.  The large quantity of inert carbon dioxide released on top of a small fire is usually sufficient to exinguish the flame by excluding oxygen, and the cooling effect also helps drive the temperature of the combustible material below that required to support compustion.  It is used in situations where putting water on the fire might cause undesirable damage.
Compressed: Pressed together; compacted; reduced in volume by pressure.
Cascade system: A system or method of connecting and operating two induction motors so that the primary circuit of one is connected to the secondary circuit of the other, the primary circuit of the latter being connected to the source of supply; also, a system of electric traction in which motors so connected are employed. The cascade system is also called tandem system, or concatenated system; the connection a cascade connection, tandem connection, or concatenated connection, or a concatenation; and the control of the motors so obtained a tandem control, or concatenation control.
Column: A kind of pillar; a cylindrical or polygonal support for a roof, ceiling, statue, etc., somewhat ornamented, and usually composed of base, shaft, and capital. See Order.
Chondritic: Granular; pertaining to, or having the granular structure characteristic of, the class of meteorites called chondrites.
canopied: covered with or as with a canopy; as, a canopied bed; streets canopied by stately trees.
Countermove: A movement in opposition to another.
Churlishness: Rudeness of manners or temper; lack of kindness or courtesy.
Cronian: Saturnian; -- applied to the North Polar Sea.
comradely: like a comrade; heartily friendly and congenial.
Cernuous: Inclining or nodding downward; pendulous; drooping; -- said of a bud, flower, fruit, or the capsule of a moss.
Cant hook: A wooden lever with a movable iron hook. hear the end; -- used for canting or turning over heavy logs, etc.
Corallorhiza: a genus of leafless root-parasitic orchids having small purplish or yellowish racemose flowers with lobed lips; it is widely distributed in temperate regions.
Cyclostyle: A contrivance for producing manifold copies of writing or drawing. The writing or drawing is done with a style carrying a small wheel at the end which makes minute punctures in the paper, thus converting it into a stencil. Copies are transferred with an inked roller.
Caucasia: a large mountainous region between the Black and Caspian seas.
Consignificant: Having joint or equal signification; synonymous.
Circumvent: To gain advantage over by arts, stratagem, or deception; to decieve; to delude; to get around.
Catenate: To connect, in a series of links or ties; to chain.
Calibration: The process of estimating the caliber a tube, as of a thermometer tube, in order to graduate it to a scale of degrees; also, more generally, the determination of the true value of the spaces in any graduated instrument.
Crust: To gather or contract into a hard crust; to become incrusted.
Crater: The basinlike opening or mouth of a volcano, through which the chief eruption comes; similarly, the mouth of a geyser, about which a cone of silica is often built up.
Crush: A violent collision or compression; a crash; destruction; ruin.
Carduelis: the type genus of a subfamily Carduelinae of the Fringillidae, used in some classifications.  It includes the goldfinches (such as the American goldfinch, Cardulis tristis, and the European goldfinch, Carduelis carduelis); siskins; redpolls; and linnets, as well as the common northern cardinal (Carduelis cardinalis, also called the cardinal bird).
Consumers surplus: The excess that a purchaser would be willing to pay for a commodity over that he does pay, rather than go without the commodity; -- called also consumer's rent.
Clavus: A callous growth, esp. one the foot; a corn.
Chatty: A porous earthen pot used in India for cooling water, etc.
cassie: a type of tropical American thorny shrub or small tree (Acacia farnesiana); it bears fragrant yellow flowers used in making perfumery.
Consociate: To be allied, confederated, or associated; to coalescence.
Cyclophorus: a genus of tropical Old World ferns having closely crowded circular sori and no indusia.
Categorically: Absolutely; directly; expressly; positively; as, to affirm categorically.
Czechs: The most westerly branch of the great Slavic family of nations, numbering now more than 6,000,000, and found principally in Bohemia and Moravia.
Ceramics: The art of making things of baked clay; as pottery, tiles, etc.
Ceremonially: According to rites and ceremonies; as, a person ceremonially unclean.
Concho-spiral: A kind of spiral curve found in certain univalve shells.
Colatitude: The complement of the latitude, or the difference between any latitude and ninety degrees.
Cafeteria: A restaurant or café at which the patrons serve themselves with food kept at a counter, typically paying a cashier at the end of the counter and taking the food to tables to eat.
Case-bay: The space between two principals or girders
Confidential: Enjoying, or treated with, confidence; trusted in; trustworthy; as, a confidential servant or clerk.
Cossack: One of a warlike, pastoral people, skillful as horsemen, inhabiting different parts of the Russian empire and furnishing valuable contingents of irregular cavalry to its armies, those of Little Russia and those of the Don forming the principal divisions.
Climax: Upward movement; steady increase; gradation; ascent.
Clamorous: Speaking and repeating loud words; full of clamor; calling or demanding loudly or urgently; vociferous; noisy; bawling; loud; turbulent.
Crustaceology: That branch of Zoölogy which treats of the Crustacea; malacostracology; carcinology.
Cnidocil: The fine filiform process of a cnidoblast.
Confectionery: Sweetmeats, in general; things prepared and sold by a confectioner; confections; candies.
Castor: A variety of the mineral called petalite, from Elba.
Consumptive: One affected with consumption; as, a resort for consumptives.
casebook: a book in which detailed written records of cases are kept and which are a source of information for subsequent work.  Such books are often used as supplements to texts in law schools.
Clicky: Resembling a click; abounding in clicks.
Chiasmus: An inversion of the order of words or phrases, when repeated or subsequently referred to in a sentence
Chinook: One of a tribe of North American Indians now living in the state of Washington, noted for the custom of flattening their skulls. Chinooks also called Flathead Indians.
Chorion: The outer membrane which invests the fetus in the womb; also, the similar membrane investing many ova at certain stages of development.
Catheretic: A mild kind caustic used to reduce warts and other excrescences.
cynodont: any member of the Cynodontia, a group of small carnivorous reptiles.
Countenance: To encourage; to favor; to approve; to aid; to abet.
Curtailment: The act or result of curtailing or cutting off.
connecting: forming a connection; as, a connecting flight.
Chrysaniline: A yellow substance obtained as a by-product in the manufacture of rosaniline. It dyes silk a fine golden-yellow color.
Catelectrotonus: The condition of increased irritability of a nerve in the region of the cathode or negative electrode, on the passage of a current of electricity through it.
Conning tower: The shot-proof pilot house of a war vessel.
Cosmic: Pertaining to the universe, and having special reference to universal law or order, or to the one grand harmonious system of things; hence; harmonious; orderly.
Codicillary: Of the nature of a codicil.
cock-a-doodle-doo: the crowing sound made by a rooster.
Catastaltic: Checking evacuations through astringent or styptic qualities.
Chamaecytisus: a genus of small late-flowering trees or subshrubs having yellow to red flowers and leathery or woody pods; -- often used especially for those formerly included in genus Cytisus.
Cringle: A withe for fastening a gate.
Cantred: A district comprising a hundred villages, as in Wales.
codlins-and-cream: a plant of Europe and Asia (Epilobium hirsutum) having purplish-red flowers and hairy stems and leaves; it was introduced into North America.
Centrosphere: The nucleus or central part of the earth, forming most of its mass; -- disting. from lithosphere, hydrosphere, etc.
Cerused: Washed with a preparation of white lead; as, cerused face.
Cowardly: In the manner of a coward.
Coetaneous: Of the same age; beginning to exist at the same time; contemporaneous.
Conventicler: One who supports or frequents conventicles.
collage: any picture made by sticking together pieces of paper or photographs, especially in unusual or surprising ways.
Congo group: A group of artificial dyes with an affinity for vegetable fibers, so that no mordant is required. Most of them are azo compounds derived from benzidine or tolidine. Called also benzidine dyes.
caranda: a South American palm (Copernicia australis or Copernicia alba) yielding a wax similar to carnauba wax.
catatonia: an abnormal behavioral syndrome characterized by stupor, negativism, and muscular rigidity, sometimes alternating with purposeless excitement, and seen most frequently in schizophrenia; called also catatonic schizophrenia.
Champlev\u00e9: Having the ground engraved or cut out in the parts to be enameled; inlaid in depressions made in the ground; -- said of a kind of enamel work in which depressions made in the surface are filled with enamel pastes, which are afterward fired; also, designating the process  of making such enamel work.
Centonism: The composition of a cento; the act or practice of composing a cento or centos.
Cachucha: An Andalusian dance in three-four time, resembling the bolero.
Conformator: An apparatus for taking the conformation of anything, as of the head for fitting a hat, or, in craniometry, finding the largest horizontal area of the head.
Capsulitis: Inflammation of a capsule, as that of the crystalline lens.
cyclosporin: a chemical substance produced by some soil fungi, which suppresses the cellular immune response by inhibiting T cell activation, and has been used in medicine to reduce foreign tissue rejection, especially subsequent to organ transplant surgery.
Crux: Anything that is very puzzling or difficult to explain.
Coxcombical: Befitting or indicating a coxcomb; like a coxcomb; foppish; conceited.
Crucifier: One who crucifies; one who subjects himself or another to a painful trial.
Crut: The rough, shaggy part of oak bark.
Cogue: A small wooden vessel; a pail.
cotyloid: Shaped like a cup; cup-shaped; as, the cotyloid cavity, the cup-shaped socket which receives the head of the thigh bone.
Confidently: With confidence; with strong assurance; positively.
Cartway: A way or road for carts.
Cherubic: Of or pertaining to cherubs; angelic.
Cherubim: The Hebrew plural of Cherub.. Cf. Seraphim.
crepe paper: Paper with a finely crinkle texture, usually sold in rolls of 2-3 inches width; crepe paper; -- it is usually colored brightly and used for decoration.  Same as crepe{4}.
Concionatory: Of or pertaining to preaching or public addresses.
canid: any doglike animal of the family canidae.
Cacography: Incorrect or bad writing or spelling.
Cariama: the type genus of the Cariamidae, consisting only of the Cariama cristata, also called the seriema.
Cashmerette: A kind of dress goods, made with a soft and glossy surface like cashmere.
\u00c7a ira: The refrain of a famous song of the French Revolution.
Cuproid: A solid related to a tetrahedron, and contained under twelve equal triangles.
Crouch: To sign with the cross; to bless.
Costumer: One who makes or deals in costumes, as for theaters, fancy balls, etc.
Crocin: The coloring matter of Chinese yellow pods, the fruit of Gardenia grandiflora.
Confessorship: The act or state of suffering persecution for religious faith.
Counterbalance: A weight, power, or agency, acting against or balancing another
Caulome: A stem structure or stem axis of a plant, viewed as a whole.
Cuminil: A substance, analogous to benzil, obtained from oil of caraway.
Crotonic: Of or pertaining to, or derived from, a plant of the genus Croton, or from croton oil.
Crucify: To fasten to a cross; to put to death by nailing the hands and feet to a cross or gibbet.
crateful: the quantity contained in a crate.
Cabling: The decoration of a fluted shaft of a column or of a pilaster with reeds, or rounded moldings, which seem to be laid in the hollows of the fluting.  These are limited in length to about one third of the height of the shaft.
carbomycin: a colorless basic macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the growth of Gram-positive organisms.
Certhiidae: a natural family of birds cosisting of several species of creepers, such as Certhia americana, the tree creeper.
cooked-over: heated again after having cooled down; -- often used of food remaining from a previous day.
cutaneous: Of or pertaining to the skin; existing on, or affecting, the skin; as, a cutaneous disease; cutaneous absorption; cutaneous respiration; cutaneous nerves; a cutaneous infection.
Cantillation: A chanting; recitation or reading with musical modulations.
Cephalism: Form or development of the skull; as, the races of man differ greatly in cephalism.
Comparative: The comparative degree of adjectives and adverbs; also, the form by which the comparative degree is expressed; as, stronger, wiser, weaker, more stormy, less windy, are all comparatives.
Cordon bleu: a first-rate cook, or one worthy to be the cook of the cordons bleus, or Knights of the Holy Ghost, a distinguished order of French knights, famous for their good dinners.
Crown office: The criminal branch of the Court of King's or Queen's Bench, commonly called the crown side of the court, which takes cognizance of all criminal cases.
Cogwheel: A wheel with cogs or teeth; a gear wheel. See Illust. of Gearing.
Cynoglossidae: a natural family of fish including the tonguefishes.
Contestant: One who contests; an opponent; a litigant; a disputant; one who claims that which has been awarded to another.
Colly: A kind of dog. See Collie.
Conducive: Loading or tending; helpful; contributive; tending to promote.
Caracul: Var. of Karakul, a kind of fur.
Calcareo-bituminous: Consisting of, or containing, lime and bitumen.
cecal: of, pertaining to, or like a cecum.
cross-refer: to refer from one entry to another, as in catalogues, books, and lists.
Crenelation: The act of crenelating, or the state of being crenelated; an indentation or an embrasure.
Cebuan: An inhabitant of the island of Cebu; a member of the Visayan (or Bisayan) people of the Philippines.
Centrode: In two figures having relative motion, one of the two curves which are the loci of the instantaneous center.
Cnicus: a genus of plants having only one species, the blessed thistle.
Cubation: The act of lying down; a reclining.
Chromophotograph: A picture made by any of the processes for reproducing photographs in colors; a color photograph.
Cembalo: An old name for the harpsichord.
Cirrhotic: Pertaining to, caused by, or affected with, cirrhosis; as, cirrhotic degeneration; a cirrhotic liver.
Coagulability: The quality of being coagulable; capacity of being coagulated.
Catching: The act of seizing or taking hold of.
Ca\u00f1ada: A small cañon; a narrow valley or glen; also, but less frequently, an open valley.
colonic: of or pertaining to the colon.
Coffle: A gang of negro slaves being driven to market.
Concreate: To create at the same time.
Chelone: A genus of hardy perennial flowering plants, of the order Scrophulariaceæ, natives of North America; -- called also snakehead, turtlehead, shellflower, etc.
counterclockwise: in the opposite direction to that in which the hands of a clock rotate, as viewed from in front of the clock face; -- of rotatory motion or spiral direction.  Opposite of clockwise, or right-handed
Concavo-convex: Concave on one side and convex on the other, as an eggshell or a crescent.
Cartographer: One who makes charts or maps.
Cahoot: Partnership; league; as, to go in cahoot (or in cahoots) with a person.  Usually used in the plural, and in modern usage often used to imply that the joint effort is unethical, shady, questionable, or illegal; as, a shill in cahoots with a pickpocket, to serve as a distraction.
Cypress: A coniferous tree of the genus Cupressus. The species are mostly evergreen, and have wood remarkable for its durability.
Consentaneous: Consistent; agreeable; suitable; accordant to; harmonious; concurrent.
Cyclas: A long gown or surcoat (cut off in front), worn in the Middle Ages. It was sometimes embroidered or interwoven with gold. Also, a rich stuff from which the gown was made.
Cacostomia: Diseased or gangrenous condition of the mouth.
chemosorption: adsorption (especially when irreversible) by means of chemical instead of physical forces; as, chemosorption of gaseous nitrogen on iron catalysts.
Convexity: The state of being convex; the exterior surface of a convex body; roundness.
Cothurn: A buskin anciently used by tragic actors on the stage; hence, tragedy in general.
Conventionality: The state of being conventional; adherence to social formalities or usages; that which is established by conventional use; one of the customary usages of social life.
Chamaeleo: the type genus of the Chamaeleontidae.
Crevet: A crucible or melting pot; a cruset.
Cypriniformes: an order of fishes including almost entirely freshwater fishes: characins; loaches; carp; suckers; sometimes classified as Cyprinoidea, a suborder of Ostariophysi.
chromatid: one of two identical strands into which a chromosome splits during mitosis.
Conjugal: Belonging to marriage; suitable or appropriate to the marriage state or to married persons; matrimonial; connubial.
Cross-bun: A bun or cake marked with a cross  of icing, and intended to be eaten on Good Friday; also, called hot cross bun, even when not hot.
Cycadofilicales: an order of fossil gymnospermous trees or climbing plants from the Devonian: seed ferns.
Codification: The act or process of codifying or reducing laws to a code.
Cancan: A rollicking French dance, accompanied by indecorous or extravagant postures and gestures.
cigarillo: a small cigar or cigarette wrapped in tobacco instead of paper.
Counterfeit: To carry on a deception; to dissemble; to feign; to pretend.
Cruciform: Cross-shaped; (Bot.) having four parts arranged in the form of a cross.
clintonia: any temperate liliaceous plant of the genus Clintonia having broad basal leaves and white or yellowish or purplish flowers followed by blue or black berries.
Chloropeptic: Of or pertaining to an acid more generally called pepsin-hydrochloric acid.
Conyrine: A blue, fluorescent, oily base (regarded as a derivative of pyridine), obtained from conine.
Co\u00f6perate: To act or operate jointly with another or others; to concur in action, effort, or effect.
Caligo: Dimness or obscurity of sight, dependent upon a speck on the cornea; also, the speck itself.
candyfloss: a candy made by spinning sugar that has been boiled to a high temperature; -- called commonly cotton candy.
Capitulation: A reducing to heads or articles; a formal agreement.
Cathartic: A medicine that promotes alvine discharges; a purge; a purgative of moderate activity.
Carbonatation: The saturation of defecated beet juice with carbonic acid gas.
Cacology: Bad speaking; bad choice or use of words.
coyol: a tropical American palm (Acrocomia vinifera) having edible nuts and yielding a useful fiber.
Correlation: Reciprocal relation; corresponding similarity or parallelism of relation or law; capacity of being converted into, or of giving place to, one another, under certain conditions; as, the correlation of forces, or of zymotic diseases.
Counterpart: A part corresponding to another part; anything which answers, or corresponds, to another; a copy; a duplicate; a facsimile.
confidentiality: the state or attribute of being secret; privacy; as, you must respect the confidentiality of your client's communications.
Concealment: The act of concealing; the state of being concealed.
camshaft: a shaft that has cams attached to it, forming part of a mechanical device.
cubebic: Pertaining to, or derived from, cubebs; as, cubebic acid (a soft olive-green resin extracted from cubebs).
Canker fly: A fly that preys on fruit.
Cascarilla: A euphorbiaceous West Indian shrub (Croton Eleutheria); also, its aromatic bark.
Catechumenate: The state or condition of a catechumen or the time during which one is a catechumen.
Canticoy: A social gathering; usually, one for dancing.
Capitular: Of or pertaining to a chapter; capitulary.
Camelopard: An African ruminant; the giraffe. See Giraffe.
Cannula: A small tube of metal, wood, or India rubber, used for various purposes, esp. for injecting or withdrawing fluids. It is usually associated with a trocar.
Creature: Anything created; anything not self-existent; especially, any being created with life; an animal; a man.
Corollaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, a corolla; having the form or texture of a corolla.
Conusable: Cognizable; liable to be tried or judged.
Chanter: One who chants; a singer or songster.
Cataphractic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cataphract.
Circumincession: The reciprocal existence in each other of the three persons of the Trinity.
Conviciate: To utter reproaches; to raise a clamor; to rail.
Corrode: To have corrosive action; to be subject to corrosion.
Constructionist: One who puts a certain construction upon some writing or instrument, as the Constitutions of the United States; as, a strict constructionist; a broad constructionist.
Contemporaneously: At the same time with some other event.
Coregonidae: a natural family of soft-finned fishes comprising the freshwater whitefishes; formerly included in the family Salmonidae.
Coachdog: One of a breed of dogs trained to accompany carriages; the Dalmatian dog.
Compromit: To pledge by some act or declaration; to promise.
Caryopsis: A one-celled, dry, indehiscent fruit, with a thin membranous pericarp, adhering closely to the seed, so that fruit and seed are incorporated in one body, forming a single grain, as of wheat, barley, etc.
Comitial: Relating to the comitia, or popular assemblies of the Romans for electing officers and passing laws.
Cushite: A descendant of Cush, the son of Ham and grandson of Noah.
Celotomy: The act or operation of cutting, to relieve the structure in strangulated hernia.
Convallariaceae: One of many subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Liliaceae but not widely accepted.
Cowquake: A genus of plants (Briza); quaking grass.
Convective: Caused or accomplished by convection; as, a convective discharge of electricity.
Change key: A key adapted to open only one of a set of locks; -- distinguished from a master key.
Cymograph: To trace or copy with a cymograph.
Calculary: A congeries of little stony knots found in the pulp of the pear and other fruits.
Confiscate: To seize as forfeited to the public treasury; to appropriate to the public use.
Circean: Having the characteristics of Circe, daughter of Sol and Perseis, a mythological enchantress, who first charmed her victims and then changed them to the forms of beasts; pleasing, but noxious; as, a Circean draught.
Camerlingo: The papal chamberlain; the cardinal who presides over the pope's household. He has at times possessed great power.
Chatelaine: An ornamental hook, or brooch worn by a lady at her waist, and having a short chain or chains attached for a watch, keys, trinkets, etc. Also used adjectively; as, a chatelaine chain.
Congregation: The act of congregating, or bringing together, or of collecting into one aggregate or mass.
Cinematographer: One who takes motion pictures with a movie camera, especially one expert in the art.
Chilognath: A myriapod of the order Chilognatha.
cookstove: a stove for cooking, especially a wood- or coal-burning kitchen stove.
Chestnut: Of or pertaining of a chestnut; of a reddish brown color; as, chestnut curls.
Calipers: An instrument, usually resembling a pair of dividers or compasses with curved legs, for measuring the diameter or thickness of bodies, as of work shaped in a lathe or planer, timber, masts, shot, etc.; or the bore of firearms, tubes, etc.; -- called also caliper compasses, or caliber compasses.
chick flick: A sentimental motion picture that appeals particularly to women.   See flick, n., movie.
Clivity: Inclination; ascent or descent; a gradient.
Caption: A caviling; a sophism.
Corallin: A yellow coal-tar dyestuff which probably consists chiefly of rosolic acid. See Aurin, and Rosolic acid under Rosolic.
Crusted: Incrusted; covered with, or containing, crust; as, old, crusted port wine.
Center punch: A punch for making indentations or dots in a piece of work, as for suspension between lathe centers, etc.
Cynic: One of a sect or school of philosophers founded by Antisthenes, and of whom Diogenes was a disciple. The first Cynics were noted for austere lives and their scorn for social customs and current philosophical opinions. Hence the term Cynic symbolized, in the popular judgment, moroseness, and contempt for the views of others.
carboxyl group: a monovalent organic radical (written -COOH, -CO2H or -CO.OH) whose presence confers acidic properties on the compound containing it; -- called also carboxylic group.  Monocarboxylic acids (such as acetic acid or butyric acid) have one carboxyl group, dicarboxylic acids (such as oxalic acid or malonic acid) have two, tricarboxylic acids (such as citric acid) have three.  It is weakly acidic, the pKa of acetic acid being 4.75.
crazyweed: any of several leguminous plants of Western North America causing locoism in livestock.
Corporealist: One who denies the reality of spiritual existences; a materialist.
cushioned: furnished with a cushion or other device to reduce hardness.
Chen: a wild goose having white adult plumage.
Crassament: A semisolid mass or clot, especially that formed in coagulation of the blood.
Crandall: A kind of hammer having a head formed of a group of pointed steel bars, used for dressing ashlar, etc.
Carcel lamp: A French mechanical lamp, for lighthouses, in which a superabundance of oil is pumped to the wick tube by clockwork.
cenogenetic: of or pertaining to cenogenesis.  Opposite of palingenetic.
Coarsely: In a coarse manner; roughly; rudely; inelegantly; uncivilly; meanly.
Cutin: A waxy substance containing fatty acids, soaps, and resinous material which, combined with cellulose, forms a substance nearly impervious to water and constituting the cuticle in plants.
cortina: a cobwebby remnant of the partial veil which in some mature mushrooms hang from the edges of the cap.
Corvee: An obligation to perform certain services, as the repair of roads, for the lord or sovereign.
Cockloft: An upper loft; a garret; the highest room in a building.
Chalk: To rub or mark with chalk.
Cottager: One who lives in a cottage.
Couveuse: An incubator for sickly infants, esp. those prematurely born.
coaxing: p. pr. of coax; as, the boys' coaxing voices.
Cinch: In the game of cinch, to protect (a trick) by playing a higher trump than the five.
Collotype: A photomechanical print made directly from a hardened film of gelatin or other colloid; also, the process of making such prints. According to one method, the film is sensitized with potassium dichromate and exposed to light under a reversed negative. After the dichromate has been washed out, the film is soaked in glycerin and water. As this treatment causes swelling in those parts of the film which have been acted on by light, a plate results from which impressions can be taken with prepared ink. The albertype, phototype, and heliotype are collotypes.
Calcified: Consisting of, or containing, calcareous matter or lime salts; calcareous.
centrifuge out: to separate (particles in a suspension) from a liquid by centrifugation.
Colloid: A substance (as albumin, gum, gelatin, etc.) which is of a gelatinous rather than a crystalline nature, and which diffuses itself through animal membranes or vegetable parchment more slowly than crystalloids do; -- opposed to crystalloid.
Coistril: An inferior groom or lad employed by an esquire to carry the knight's arms and other necessaries.
Cicatrisive: Tending to promote the formation of a cicatrix; good for healing of a wound.
Coronilla: A genus of plants related to the clover, having their flowers arranged in little heads or tufts resembling coronets.
Casern: A lodging for soldiers in garrison towns, usually near the rampart; barracks.
Candytuft: An annual plant of the genus Iberis, cultivated in gardens.  The name was originally given to the Iberis umbellata, first, discovered in the island of Candia (The Italian name for Crete).  It is grown as an ornamental plant, having tufted red,violet, purple, or pink flowers.
Carbureted: Combined with carbon in the manner of a carburet or carbide.
Cancerite: Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer; affected with cancer.
Convallamarin: A white, crystalline, poisonous substance, regarded as a glucoside, extracted from the lily of the valley (Convallaria Majalis). Its taste is first bitter, then sweet.
Croftland: Land of superior quality, on which successive crops are raised.
Chyluria: A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fatty matter, giving it a milky appearance.
Cymling: A scalloped or “pattypan” variety of summer squash.
cine-film: photographic film several hundred feet long and wound on a spool, used in a movie camera.
Coetanean: A person coetaneous with another; a contemporary.
Caryatic: Of or pertaining to a caryatid.
Concent: Concert of voices; concord of sounds; harmony; as, a concent of notes.
Cannel coal: A kind of mineral coal of a black color, sufficiently hard and solid to be cut and polished.  It burns readily, with a clear, yellow flame, and on this account has been used as a substitute for candles.
Creeper: One who, or that which, creeps; any creeping thing.
Collude: To have secretly a joint part or share in an action; to play into each other's hands; to conspire; to act in concert.
Catharist: One aiming at or pretending to a greater purity of like than others about him; -- applied to persons of various sects. See Albigenses.
Canonicity: The state or quality of being canonical; agreement with the canon.
cheesecloth: A thin, loosely-woven cotton cloth of a gauze texture, such as is used in pressing cheese curds.
Campestral: Relating to an open field; growing in a field, or open ground.
chitlings: small intestines of hogs prepared as food.
Compilation: The act or process of compiling or gathering together from various sources.
curium: a radioactive transuranic element of atomic number 96, having an atomic weight of 247 for its most stable isotope (half-life 1.6 x 107 years).  The chemical symbol is Cm.
Counterscale: Counterbalance; balance, as of one scale against another.
Canonicalness: The quality of being canonical; canonicity.
Consectaneous: Following as a matter of course.
Centurial: Of or pertaining to a century; as, a centurial sermon.
Crystalloid: A body which, in solution, diffuses readily through animal membranes, and generally is capable of being crystallized; -- opposed to colloid.
Cytoblast: The nucleus of a cell; the germinal or active spot of a cellule, through or in which cell development takes place.
Constancy: The state or quality of being constant or steadfast; freedom from change; stability; fixedness; immutability; as, the constancy of God in his nature and attributes.
Ceylonese: Of or pertaining to Ceylon; -- since the change of name, replaced by Sri Lankan.
Cirrigerous: Having curled locks of hair; supporting cirri, or hairlike appendages.
Club-shaped: Enlarged gradually at the end, as the antennæ of certain insects.
Coccoidea: a superfamily of scale insects and mealybugs.
Conjuration: The act of calling or summoning by a sacred name, or in solemn manner; the act of binding by an oath; an earnest entreaty; adjuration.
Catchweight: Without any additional weight; without being handicapped; as, to ride catchweight.
concentrated: Having a high density of (the indicated substance); as, a narrow thread of concentrated ore.
Carduelinae: a subfamily of birds consisting of the old world finches, many of which have taken up residence in the Americas; -- it is a subgroup of finches used in some classifications, in which the Fringillidae are divided into two subfamilies, the Carduelinae (including the goldfinches, siskins, redpolls, crossbills, and linnets) and Fringillinae (the brambling and the chaffinches).  The siskins and goldfinches have migrated as far south as the southern end of South America.
Catechu: A dry, brown, astringent extract, obtained by decoction and evaporation from the Acacia catechu, and several other plants growing in India. It contains a large portion of tannin or tannic acid, and is used in medicine and in the arts. It is also known by the names terra japonica, cutch, gambier, etc.
Citation: An official summons or notice given to a person to appear; the paper containing such summons or notice.
Censor: One of two magistrates of Rome who took a register of the number and property of citizens, and who also exercised the office of inspector of morals and conduct.
Camis: A light, loose dress or robe.
Convivial: Of or relating to a feast or entertainment, or to eating and drinking, with accompanying festivity; festive; social; gay; jovial.
Cerebration: Action of the brain, whether conscious or unconscious.
Cureall: A remedy for all diseases, or for all ills; a panacea.
Cyclone cellar: A cellar or excavation used for refuge from a cyclone, or tornado.
Cacaj\u00e3o: A South American short-tailed monkey (Pithecia melanocephala syn. Brachyurus melanocephala).
Chancroid: A venereal sore, resembling a chancre in its seat and some external characters, but differing from it in being the starting point of a purely local process and never of a systemic disease; -- called also soft chancre.
collider: a particle accelerator in which two separate beams of particles (usually of opposite charge) are circulated in opposite directions and directed so as to collide head on.  This technique allows the production of collisions of higher energy than would be possible with a single beam produced by the same device.
Cataclysmal: Of or pertaining to a cataclysm.
Cajanus: a genus of erect densely branched shrubby perennials of Old World tropics; naturalized in other warm regions.
