Campanulaceous: Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants (Campanulaceæ) of which Campanula is the type, and which includes the Canterbury bell, the harebell, and the Venus's looking-glass.
Conformation: The act of conforming; the act of producing conformity.
Confutation: The act or process of confuting; refutation.
cross-match: to match items from two or more lists.
Chenille: Tufted cord, of silk or worsted, for the trimming of ladies' dresses, for embroidery and fringes, and for the weft of Chenille rugs.
clifflike: characterized by cliffs; -- of a shore or shoreline; -- contrasted with beachy.
Convellent: Tending to tear or pull up.
coonskin: a cap made from the skin of a raccoon, with the tail hanging down the back; -- called also coonskin cap.
Convince: To overpower; to overcome; to subdue or master.
Confocal: Having the same foci; as, confocal quadrics.
Commendatary: One who holds a living in commendam.
Crosshead: A beam or bar across the head or end of a rod, etc., or a block attached to it and carrying a knuckle pin; as the solid crosspiece running between parallel slides, which receives motion from the piston of a steam engine and imparts it to the connecting rod, which is hinged to the crosshead.
Catanadromous: Ascending and descending fresh streams from and to the sea, as the salmon; anadromous.
Copepod: Of or pertaining to the Copepoda.
Cancellation: The act, process, or result of canceling; as, the cansellation of certain words in a contract, or of the contract itself.
Colure: One of two great circles intersecting at right angles in the poles of the equator. One of them passes through the equinoctial points, and hence is denominated the equinoctial colure; the other intersects the equator at the distance of 90° from the former, and is called the solstitial colure.
Chondrology: The science which treats of cartilages.
Crescendo: A gradual increase in the strength and fullness of tone with which a passage is performed.
Concerted: Mutually contrived or planned; agreed on; as, concerted schemes, signals.
Cribber: A horse that has the habit of cribbing.
Commander: A chief; one who has supreme authority; a leader; the chief officer of an army, or of any division of it.
Callitris: a genus of evergreen monoecious coniferous trees or shrubs; the cypress pines.
crossbencher: a member of the House of Commons of Great Britain who does not vote regularly with either the Government or the Opposition.
Coupler: One who couples; that which couples, as a link, ring, or shackle, to connect cars.
Chidingly: In a chiding or reproving manner.
Coadunation: Union, as in one body or mass; unity.
Catafalque: A temporary structure sometimes used in the funeral solemnities of eminent persons, for the public exhibition of the remains, or their conveyance to the place of burial.
Capoc: A sort of cotton so short and fine that it can not be spun, used in the East Indies to line palanquins, to make mattresses, etc.
Conventical: Of or from, or pertaining to, a convent.
canoe: To manage a canoe, or voyage in a canoe.
Capon: To castrate; to make a capon of.
Capot: To win all the tricks from, in playing at piquet.
Cicatrize: To heal; to have a new skin.
Chloridic: Of or pertaining to a chloride; containing a chloride.
Cicisbeism: The state or conduct of a cicisbeo.
Circumgyratory: Moving in a circle; turning round.
Curtation: The interval by which the curtate distance of a planet is less than the true distance.
Cousin-german: A first cousin. See Note under Cousin, 1.
Clypeate: Shaped like a round buckler or shield; scutate.
Capnomancy: Divination by means of the ascent or motion of smoke.
Cryolite: A fluoride of sodium and aluminum, found in Greenland, in white cleavable masses; -- used as a source of soda and alumina.
cryopathy: destruction of tissue by freezing and characterized by tingling, blistering and possibly gangrene.
Ceroplastic: Relating to the art of modeling in wax.
Clear: To become free from clouds or fog; to become fair; -- of the weather; -- often followed by up, off, or away.
Colocasia: a small genus of perennial tuberous herbs of the arum family, of tropical Asia and the Pacific islands, including the taro (Colocasia esculente).
Catapasm: A compound medicinal powder, used by the ancients to sprinkle on ulcers, to absorb perspiration, etc.
Caudal: Of the nature of, or pertaining to, a tail; having a tail-like appendage.
Carneous: Consisting of, or like, flesh; carnous; fleshy.
Clean: To render clean; to free from whatever is foul, offensive, or extraneous; to purify; to cleanse.
Chelidonic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the celandine.
Cursoriness: The quality of being cursory; superficial performance; as, cursoriness of view.
Caudad: Backwards; toward the tail or posterior part.
Caffetannic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the tannin of coffee.
clobber: personal possessions; -- an informal term; as, did you take all your clobber?.
Cagmag: A tough old goose; hence, coarse, bad food of any kind.
Cyclopedia: The circle or compass of the arts and sciences (originally, of the seven so-called liberal arts and sciences); circle of human knowledge. Hence, a work containing, in alphabetical order, information in all departments of knowledge, or on a particular department or branch; as, a cyclopedia of the physical sciences, or of mechanics. See Encyclopedia.
Cachexia: A condition of ill health and impairment of nutrition due to impoverishment of the blood, esp. when caused by a specific morbid process (as cancer or tubercle).
Cardiospermum: A genus of tendril-climbing herbs or shrubs whose seeds have a white heart-shaped spot.
Conserve: Anything which is conserved; especially, a sweetmeat prepared with sugar; a confection.
Churchwarden: One of the officers (usually two) in an Episcopal church, whose duties vary in different dioceses, but always include the provision of what is necessary for the communion service.
cryptanalysis: the science which studies methods to discovering the secret meaning of encrypted messages for which one does not possess the secret decoding information (called the key).
Continental drift: the movements of continents relative to each other across the Earth's surface; see plate tectonics.
Cow-pilot: A handsomely banded, coral-reef fish, of Florida and the West Indies (Pomacentrus saxatilis); -- called also mojarra.
Crawfish: Any decapod crustacean of the family Astacidæ (genera Cambarus and Cambarus), resembling the lobster, but smaller, and found in fresh waters. Crawfishes are esteemed very delicate food both in Europe and America. The North American species are numerous and mostly belong to the genus Cambarus. The blind crawfish of the Mammoth Cave is Cambarus pellucidus. The common European species is Astacus fluviatilis.
Canap\u00e9 confident: A sofa having a seat at each end at right angles to the main seats.
Conservative: One who, or that which, preserves from ruin, injury, innovation, or radical change; a preserver; a conserver.
Centripetal: Tending, or causing, to approach the center.
Copper-bottomed: Having a bottom made of copper, as a tin boiler or other vessel, or sheathed with copper, as a ship.
Campylospermous: Having seeds grooved lengthwise on the inner face, as in sweet cicely.
Conceivable: Capable of being conceived, imagined, or understood.
Cupric: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper; -- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is present in its lowest proportion.
catbrier: a very prickly woody vine of eastern U.S. (Smilax rotundifolia) growing in tangled masses, having tough round stems with shiny leathery leaves and small greenish flowers followed by clusters of inedible shiny black berries.
cilantro: an Old World herb (Coriandrum sativum) with aromatic parsleylike leaves and seed.
Christian Socialism: Any theory or system that aims to combine the teachings of Christ with the teachings of socialism in their applications to life; Christianized socialism; esp., the principles of this nature advocated by F. D. Maurice, Charles Kingsley, and others in England about 1850.
Commutation ticket: A ticket for transportation at a reduced rate in consideration of some special circumstance, as increase of travel; specif., a ticket for a certain number of, or for daily, trips between neighboring places at a reduced rate, such as are commonly used by those doing business in a city and living in a suburb. Commutation tickets are excepted from the prohibition against special rates contained in the Interstate Commerce Act of Feb. 4, 1887 (24 Stat. 379), and in 145 U. S. 263 it was held that party tickets were also excepted as being “obviously within the commuting principle.”
Colonization: The act of colonizing, or the state of being colonized; the formation of a colony or colonies.
Commutator: A piece of apparatus used for reversing the direction of an electrical current; an attachment to certain electrical machines, by means of which alternating currents are made to be continuous or to have the same direction.  It may be attached to the end of the spindle of an electric motor, where a brush is in contact sequentially with the parts of the spindle that conduct current to the different windings of the motor.
Crank: To run with a winding course; to double; to crook; to wind and turn.
Crane: To cause to rise; to raise or lift, as by a crane; -- with up.
Cankerworm: The larva of two species of geometrid moths which are very injurious to fruit and shade trees by eating, and often entirely destroying, the foliage. Other similar larvæ are also called cankerworms.
Calash: A light carriage with low wheels, having a top or hood that can be raised or lowered, seats for inside, a separate seat for the driver, and often a movable front, so that it can be used as either an open or a closed carriage.
Colotomy: An operation for opening the colon
Cauliculus: In the Corinthian capital, one of the eight stalks rising out of the lower leafage and terminating in leaves which seem to support the volutes. See Illust. of Corinthian order, under Corinthian.
Conciliatory: Tending to conciliate; pacific; mollifying; propitiating.
Campyloneurum: a genus of epiphytic ferns of tropical America.
countrywide: extending throughout a country or nation as a whole; as, a countrywide fund-raising campaign.
Cantoris: Of or pertaining to a cantor; as, the cantoris side of a choir; a cantoris stall.
Catacrotic: Designating, pertaining to, or characterized by, that form of pulse tracing, or sphygmogram, in which the descending portion of the curve is marked by secondary elevations due to two or more expansions of the artery in the same beat.
Catapetalous: Having the petals held together by stamens, which grow to their bases, as in the mallow.
Counterwait: To wait or watch for; to be on guard against.
circular-knit: knit on a circular form so as to have no seams; -- said of stockings.
Chlorophyll: Literally, leaf green; a green granular matter formed in the cells of the leaves (and other parts exposed to light) of plants, to which they owe their green color, and through which all ordinary assimilation of plant food takes place. Similar chlorophyll granules have been found in the tissues of the lower animals.
Contentious: Fond of contention; given to angry debate; provoking dispute or contention; quarrelsome.
Chthonic: Pertaining to the earth; earthy; as, chthonic religions.
Contemporary: One who lives at the same time with another; as, Petrarch and Chaucer were contemporaries.
can-do: having an eager willingness to accept and overcome challenges; as, a can-do kind of person; the city's indomitable optimism and can-do spirit.
Clausure: The act of shutting up or confining; confinement.
Crocodility: A caption or sophistical mode of arguing.
Cobra de capello: The hooded snake (Naia tripudians), a highly venomous serpent inhabiting India.
Copious: Large in quantity or amount; plentiful; abundant; fruitful.
Cephalology: The science which treats of the head.
Cumshaw: To give or make a present to.
Contorniate: A species of medal or medallion of bronze, having a deep furrow on the contour or edge; -- supposed to have been struck in the days of Constantine and his successors.
Cedrene: A rich aromatic oil, C15H24, extracted from oil of red cedar, and regarded as a polymeric terpene; also any one of a class of similar substances, as the essential oils of cloves, cubebs, juniper, etc., of which cedrene proper is the type.
Charina: a genus of boas of western North America.
coatdress: a dress that is tailored like a coat and buttons up the front.
Cerasin: A white amorphous substance, the insoluble part of cherry gum; -- called also meta-arabinic acid.
Cumu-cirro-stratus: Nimbus, or rain cloud. See Nimbus, and Cloud.
Chamfron: The frontlet, or head armor, of a horse.
Costate: Having ribs, or the appearance of ribs; (Bot.) having one or more longitudinal ribs.
Coronary thrombosis: the blockage of the coronary artery of the heart by a thrombus.
Ciclatoun: A costly cloth, of uncertain material, used in the Middle Ages.
Colluctancy: A struggling to resist; a striving against; resistance; opposition of nature.
Carcharodon: A genus of sharks including man-eating sharks, such as the great white shark, Carcharodon carcharias.
Chivalrous: Pertaining to chivalry or knight-errantry; warlike; heroic; gallant; high-spirited; high-minded; magnanimous.
Chronogrammatic: Belonging to a chronogram, or containing one.
Conspicuity: The state or quality of being clear or bright; brightness; conspicuousness.
Cation: a positively charged atom, radical, or molecule, which in electrolysis migrates to the cathode; a positive ion; -- opposed to anion.
Chemiloon: A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers united in one.
Churchism: Strict adherence to the forms or principles of some church organization; sectarianism.
Cital: Summons to appear, as before a judge.
Confalon: One of a fraternity of seculars, also called Penitents.
Coppersmith: One whose occupation is to manufacture copper utensils; a worker in copper.
Cerebro-spinal: Of or pertaining to the central nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord.
calciferol: one of the forms of vitamin D, a fat-soluble vitamin that prevents rickets.  It is an unsaturated alcohol, C28H43OH found in foods such as milk and fish liver oils.  It is used as a dietary supplement in milk.
Calamint: A genus of perennial plants (Calamintha) of the Mint family, esp. the Calamintha Nepeta and Calamintha Acinos, which are called also basil thyme.
Calamine: A mineral, the hydrous silicate of zinc.
Callirhoe: small genus of North American herbs having usually red or purple flowers.
Cowherd: One whose occupation is to tend cows.
Concoctive: Having the power of digesting or ripening; digestive.
Collection: The act or process of collecting or of gathering; as, the collection of specimens.
Chelicera: One of the anterior pair of mouth organs, terminated by a pincherlike claw, in scorpions and allied Arachnida. They are homologous with the falcers of spiders, and probably with the mandibles of insects.
Countrified: Having the appearance and manners of a rustic; rude; as, countrified clothes.
Cataleptic: Pertaining to, or resembling, catalepsy; affected with catalepsy; as, a cataleptic fit.
Cufic: Of or pertaining to the older characters of the Arabic language.
Constitutionalism: The theory, principles, or authority of constitutional government; attachment or adherence to a constitution or constitutional government.
Choanoid: Funnel-shaped; -- applied particularly to a hollow muscle attached to the ball of the eye in many reptiles and mammals.
Coquette: A vain, trifling woman, who endeavors to attract admiration from a desire to gratify vanity; a flirt; -- formerly sometimes applied also to men.
Conico-: A combining form, meaning somewhat resembling a cone; as, conico-cylindrical, resembling a cone and a cylinder; conico-hemispherical; conico-subulate.
Cola nut: The bitter fruit of Cola acuminata, which is nearly as large as a chestnut, and furnishes a stimulant, which is used in medicine.
Charwoman: A woman hired for odd work or for single days.
Cataract: A great fall of water over a precipice; a large waterfall.
containerful: the quantity that a container will hold.
Catchment: A surface of ground on which water may be caught and collected into a reservoir.
Caution: To give notice of danger to; to warn; to exhort [one] to take heed.
Confluxibility: The  tendency of fluids to run together.
Cookery: The art or process of preparing food for the table, by dressing, compounding, and the application of heat; cooking.
Culinarily: In the manner of a kitchen; in connection with a kitchen or cooking.
centrifugate: to drive out; to subject to the action of a centrifuge.
Criterion: A standard of judging; any approved or established rule or test, by which facts, principles opinions, and conduct are tried in forming a correct judgment respecting them.
carved: formed by carving or having a design carved into the surface.
Cryptogramma: a genus sometimes placed in the family Polypodiaceae or Cryptogrammataceae.
Crotonine: A supposed alkaloid obtained from croton oil by boiling it with water and magnesia, since found to be merely a magnesia soap of the oil.
Cercopidae: a natural family comprising the froghoppers or spittlebugs.
Cosmopolitical: Having the character of a cosmopolite.
Crossly: Athwart; adversely; unfortunately; peevishly; fretfully; with ill humor.
Charte: The constitution, or fundamental law, of the French monarchy, as established on the restoration of Louis XVIII., in 1814.
configurationism: an approach to psychology that emphasizes the importance of configurational properties.
Cotenant: A tenant in common, or a joint tenant.
Charta: Material on which instruments, books, etc., are written; parchment or paper.
curlicue: Some thing curled or spiral, as a flourish made with a pen on paper, or with skates on the ice; a trick; a frolicsome caper.
Cochlear: Of or pertaining to the cochlea.
Coulomb: The standard unit of quantity in electrical measurements. It is the quantity of electricity conveyed in one second by the current produced by an electro-motive force of one volt acting in a circuit having a resistance of one ohm, or the quantity transferred by one ampère in one second. Formerly called weber.
Cyclic: Of or pertaining to a cycle or circle; moving in cycles; as, cyclical time.
Crossgrained: Having the grain or fibers run diagonally, or more or less transversely and irregularly, so as to interfere with splitting or planing.
Cammock: A plant having long hard, crooked roots, the Ononis spinosa; -- called also rest-harrow. The Scandix Pecten-Veneris is also called cammock.
Craze-mill: A mill for grinding tin ore.
Contraption: A contrivance; a new-fangled device; -- used scornfully.
Cenogamy: The state of a community which permits promiscuous sexual intercourse among its members, as in certain societies practicing communism.
Cheiroptera: An earlier spelling for Chiroptera, an order of Mammalia, including the bats, having four toes of each of the anterior limbs elongated and connected by a web, so that they can be used like wings in flying.  See Chiroptera and Bat.
clowning: acting like a clown or buffoon.
Camptosorus: a classification used in some esp. former systems for plants usually placed in the genus Asplenium.
Casemated: Furnished with, protected by, or built like, a casemate.
Cerebrum: The anterior, and in man the larger, division of the brain; the seat of the reasoning faculties and the will. See Brain.
Contemporaneous: Living, existing, or occurring at the same time; contemporary.
Chlorosis: The green sickness; an anæmic disease of young women, characterized by a greenish or grayish yellow hue of the skin, weakness, palpitation, etc.
Canada: A country in North America, bordering the United States on the north.  It is a federation which includes English-speaking provinces and the French-speaking Province of Quebec.
Colloquialize: To make colloquial and familiar; as, to colloquialize one's style of writing.
Cadmean: Of or pertaining to Cadmus, a fabulous prince of Thebes, who was said to have introduced into Greece the sixteen simple letters of the alphabet -- α, β, γ, δ, ε, ι, κ, λ, μ, ν, ο, π, ρ, σ, τ, υ. These are called Cadmean letters.
Currier: One who curries and dresses leather, after it is tanned.
Credulous: Apt to believe on slight evidence; easily imposed upon; unsuspecting.
Collodiotype: A picture obtained by the collodion process; a melanotype or ambrotype.
Capreolus: a genus of deer including the roe deer (Capreolus capreolus).
Conceitedness: The state of being conceited; conceit; vanity.
Chirrup: The act of chirping; a chirp.
chewing: biting your food in your mouth so it becomes soft enough to swallow.
CPA: a certified public accountant; an accountant certified by the state.
Coronis: In Greek grammar, a sign ['] sometimes placed over a contracted syllable.
centromere: a specialized condensed region of a chromosomes that appears during mitosis where the chromatids are held together to form an X shape.
Countercurrent: A current running in an opposite direction to the main current.
Capricorn: The tenth sign of zodiac, into which the sun enters at the winter solstice, about December 21. See Tropic.
Corpuscle: A minute particle; an atom; a molecule.
Confabulatory: Of the nature of familiar talk; in the form of a dialogue.
Carmot: The matter of which the philosopher's stone was believed to be composed.
Closehauled: Under way and moving as nearly as possible toward the direction from which the wind blows; having the sails trimmed for sailing as close to the wind as possible; -- said of a sailing vessel.
Chupatty: A kind of griddlecake of unleavened bread, used among the natives of India.
Chalybite: Native iron carbonate; -- usually called siderite.
Crookedness: The condition or quality of being crooked; hence, deformity of body or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.
Copper: To cover or coat with copper; to sheathe with sheets of copper; as, to copper a ship.
Climactic: Of or pertaining to a climax; forming, or of the nature of, a climax, or ascending series.
chamaeleon: a lizard of Africa and Madagascar able to change skin color and having a projectile tongue.
Cat-eyed: Having eyes like a cat; hence, able to see in the dark.
Core: To take out the core or inward parts of; as, to core an apple.
compartmental: divided up into compartments or categories.
Canzone: A song or air for one or more voices, of Provençal origin, resembling, though not strictly, the madrigal.
Copped: Rising to a point or head; conical; pointed; crested.
conceptualize: to to form a concept of; as, He could not conceptualize a robot that would help paralyzed patients.
Childbed: The state of a woman bringing forth a child, or being in labor; parturition.
Corrasion: The erosion of the bed of a stream by running water, principally by attrition of the detritus carried along by the stream, but also by the solvent action of the water.
Congestive: Pertaining to, indicating, or attended with, congestion in some part of the body; as, a congestive fever.
Cephalomere: One of the somites (arthromeres) which make up the head of arthropods.
Cedule: A scroll; a writing; a schedule.
Cross-stitch: A form of stitch, where the stitches are diagonal and in pairs, the thread of one stitch crossing that of the other.
Colaborer: One who labors with another; an associate in labor.
Cofferdam: A water-tight inclosure, as of piles packed with clay, from which the water is pumped to expose the bottom (of a river, etc.) and permit the laying of foundations, building of piers, etc.
Casuarinales: an order of chiefly Australian trees and shrubs comprising the casuarinas, having only one family, Casuarinaceae.
Cuckoo: A bird belonging to Cuculus, Coccyzus, and several allied genera, of many species.
Confer: To have discourse; to consult; to compare views; to deliberate.
Convincement: Act of convincing, or state of being convinced; conviction.
Cardioinhibitory: Checking or arresting the heart's action.
Conflagration: A fire extending to many objects, or over a large space; a general burning.
Clupeidae: a natural family of teleostean marine fishes which includes the herrings, shad, sardines, menhaden, and others.
Con-: A prefix, fr. L. cum, signifying with, together, etc. See Com-.
Circumference: To include in a circular space; to bound.
Critically: In a critical manner; with nice discernment; accurately; exactly.
Charlie: A familiar nickname or substitute for Charles.
Callithricidae: a natural family comprising the marmosets.
contused: injured without breaking the skin; as, a cut arm and contused cheek.
Calvary: The place where Christ was crucified, on a small hill outside of Jerusalem.
chordophone: a stringed instrument of the group including harps, lutes, lyres, and zithers.
Cursor: Any part of a mathematical instrument that moves or slides backward and forward upon another part.
Collimator: A telescope arranged and used to determine errors of collimation, both vertical and horizontal.
coelostat: an optical instrument used to follow the path of a celestial body and reflect its light into a telescope; it has a movable and a fixed mirror.
Confessional: Pertaining to a confession of faith.
Cony: A rabbit, esp., the European rabbit (Lepus cuniculus)
Contiguous: In actual contact; touching; also, adjacent; near; neighboring; adjoining.
Chaffing: The use of light, frivolous language by way of fun or ridicule; raillery; banter.
Cone: To render cone-shaped; to bevfl like whe circwlar segoent of a cone; as, to cone the tires of car wheels.
Concert of the powers: An agreement or understanding between the chief European powers, the United States, and Japan in 1900 to take only joint action in the Chinese aspect of the Eastern Question.
Curcumin: The coloring principle of turmeric, or curcuma root, extracted as an orange yellow crystalline substance, C14H14O4, with a green fluorescence.
Cerebroscopy: Examination of the brain for the diagnosis of disease; esp., the act or process of diagnosticating the condition of the brain by examination of the interior of the eye (as with an ophthalmoscope).
Carbimide: The technical name for isocyanic acid. See under Isocyanic.
Cyclostylar: Relating to a structure composed of a circular range of columns, without a core or building within.
Chibouque: A Turkish pipe, usually with a mouthpiece of amber, a stem, four or five feet long and not pliant, of some valuable wood, and a bowl of baked clay.
Conclavist: One of the two ecclesiastics allowed to attend a cardinal in the conclave.
Canton: To divide into small parts or districts; to mark off or separate, as a distinct portion or division.
conspiratorial: relating to or characteristic of conspiracy or conspirators; as, a conspiratorial whisper.
Cranioscopist: One skilled in, or who practices, cranioscopy.
Cantor: A singer; esp. the leader of a church choir; a precentor.
Cardinal: One of the ecclesiastical princes who constitute the pope's council, or the sacred college.
Cajole: To deceive with flattery or fair words; to wheedle.
closed-chain: having atoms linked by bonds which form a ring.
Cisleithan: On the Austrian side of the river Leitha; Austrian.
Casuarina: A genus of leafless trees or shrubs, with drooping branchlets of a rushlike appearance, mostly natives of Australia. Some of them are large, producing hard and heavy timber of excellent quality, called beefwood from its color.
Carvelbuilt: Having the planks meet flush at the seams, instead of lapping as in a clinker-built vessel.
Catena: A chain or series of things connected with each other.
Crosscut: A short cut across; a path shorter than by the high road.
Crash: Coarse, heavy, narrow linen cloth, used esp. for towels.
Chorist: A singer in a choir; a chorister.
Chinese-red: of a vivid red to reddish-orange color.
Clacker: One who clacks; that which clacks; especially, the clapper of a mill.
Chloroform: To treat with chloroform, or to place under its influence.
Cymogene: A highly volatile liquid, condensed by cold and pressure from the first products of the distillation of petroleum; -- used for producing low temperatures.
Cushion: To seat or place on, or as on a cushion.
Chutney: A warm or spicy condiment or pickle made in India, compounded of various vegetable substances, such as chopped fruits or green tomatoes, etc., often cooked with sweets and acids such as sugar and vinegar, with ginger and spices.
Crass: Gross; thick; dense; coarse; not elaborated or refined.
Corporately: In a corporate capacity; acting as a corporate body.
Chalcis: the type genus of the Chalcididae.
casino-hotel: a business establishment that combines a casino and a hotel.
Cineritious: Like ashes; having the color of ashes, -- as the cortical substance of the brain.
Croupade: A leap in which the horse pulls up his hind legs toward his belly.
Cheese: The curd of milk, coagulated usually with rennet, separated from the whey, and pressed into a solid mass in a hoop or mold.
Clavate: Club-shaped; having the form of a club; growing gradually thicker toward the top. [See Illust. of Antennae.]
Contraversion: A turning to the opposite side; antistrophe.
Chervil: A plant (Anthriscus cerefolium) with pinnately divided aromatic leaves, of which several curled varieties are used in soups and salads.
cuddlesome: inviting cuddling or hugging; as, a cuddlesome baby.
caliche-topped: covered with caliche{2}, a hard calcium-carbonate encrusted soil.
Complicant: Overlapping, as the elytra of certain beetles.
Captor: One who captures any person or thing, as a prisoner or a prize.
Cathedral: The principal church in a diocese, so called because in it the bishop has his official chair (Cathedra) or throne.
Corselet: Armor for the body, as, the body breastplate and backpiece taken together; -- also, used for the entire suit of the day, including breastplate and backpiece, tasset and headpiece.
changeover: an event that results in a transformation.
Cheesy: Having the nature, qualities, taste, form, consistency, or appearance of cheese.
Cerris: A species of oak (Quercus cerris) native in the Orient and southern Europe; -- called also bitter oak and Turkey oak.
Conference: The act of comparing two or more things together; comparison.
Chrysophyta: a division of mostly freshwater eukaryotic algae having the chlorophyll masked by brown or yellow pigment; yellow-green and golden-brown algae and diatoms, including the Xanthophyceae, Chrysophyceae, Bacillariophyceae; some some classification systems superseded or subsumed by Heterokontophyta.
Castellan: A governor or warden of a castle.
Congo red: An artificial red dye from which the Congo group received its name. It is also widely used either in aqueous solution or as test paper (Congo paper) for the detection of free acid, which turns it blue.
Co\u00f6rdinateness: The state of being coördinate; equality of rank or authority.
Cabinetmaking: The art or occupation of making the finer articles of household furniture.
Combative: Disposed to engage in combat; pugnacious.
Chandler: A maker or seller of candles.
contractable: capable of being transmitted by infection; same as communicable, 1; -- of disease.
Centrosome: A peculiar rounded body lying near the nucleus of a cell. It is regarded as the dynamic element by means of which the machinery of cell division is organized.
Chaw: As much as is put in the mouth at once; a chew; a quid.
Chrysocolla: A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring massive, of a blue or greenish blue color.
Cinchonidine: One of the quinine group of alkaloids, found especially in red cinchona bark. It is a white crystalline substance, C19H22N2O, with a bitter taste and qualities similar to, but weaker than, quinine; -- sometimes called also cinchonidia.
Computation: The act or process of computing; calculation; reckoning.
Catechetically: In a catechetical manner; by question and answer.
Corticose: Abounding in bark; resembling bark; barky.
Crutch: To support on crutches; to prop up.
conveniences: things that make one comfortable and at ease.
Candy: A weight, at Madras 500 pounds, at Bombay 560 pounds.
Concessionaire: The beneficiary of a concession or grant.
Cocklebur: A coarse, composite weed, having a rough or prickly fruit; one of several species of the genus Xanthium; -- called also clotbur.
Covenanting: Belonging to a covenant. Specifically, belonging to the Scotch Covenanters.
Cross-springer: One of the ribs in a groined arch, springing from the corners in a diagonal direction. [See Illustr. of Groined vault.]
Carbonade: Flesh, fowl, etc., cut across, seasoned, and broiled on coals; a chop.
caballero: A knight or cavalier; hence, a gentleman.
Cotillon: A brisk dance, performed by eight persons; a quadrille.
Chiropody: The art of treating diseases of the hands and feet.
Chlamydomonadaceae: a natural family of green algae some of which are colored red by hematochrome.
Centesimo: A copper coin of Italy and Spain equivalent to a centime.
Contrastimulant: Counteracting the effects of stimulants; relating to a course of medical treatment based on a theory of contrastimulants.
Cephalocercal: Relating to the long axis of the body.
Cerebrate: To exhibit mental activity; to have the brain in action.
Crapnel: A hook or drag; a grapnel.
Courter: One who courts; one who plays the lover, or who solicits in marriage; one who flatters and cajoles.
Chark: To burn to a coal; to char.
Carryall: A light covered carriage, having four wheels and seats for four or more persons, usually drawn by one horse.
Calendrer: A person who calenders cloth; a calender.
Caprimulgidae: a widely distributed natural family of nocturnally active birds including the whip-poor-will (Caprimulgus vociferus), the chuck-will's-widow (Caprimulgus carolinensis), and the common nighthawk (Chordeiles minor); -- called popularly the goatsuckers or nightjars.  The nighthawks are sometimes active during the day.
Cynarrhodium: A fruit like that of the rose, consisting of a cup formed of the calyx tube and receptacle, and containing achenes.
Corrodiate: To eat away by degrees; to corrode.
Charm: To use magic arts or occult power; to make use of charms.
Cryptogam: A plant belonging to the Cryptogamia.
Crupper: To fit with a crupper; to place a crupper upon; as, to crupper a horse.
Clansman: One belonging to the same clan with another.
Consist: To stand firm; to be in a fixed or permanent state, as a body composed of parts in union or connection; to hold together; to be; to exist; to subsist; to be supported and maintained.
Cerastes: A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale over each eye; the horned viper.
Coprophagan: A kind of beetle which feeds upon dung.
Counterbuff: A blow in an opposite direction; a stroke that stops motion or cause a recoil.
Curler: One who, or that which, curls.
Curlew: A wading bird of the genus Numenius, remarkable for its long, slender, curved bill.
Curship: The state of being a cur; one who is currish.
Cydonia: a genus of plants including the quince.
Crants: A garland carried before the bier of a maiden.
Cistus: a genus of small to medium-sized evergreen shrubs of southern Europe and northern Africa.
Cebidae: A natural family including all the New World monkeys except marmosets and tamarins.
Chloride: A binary compound of chlorine with another element or radical; as, chloride of sodium (common salt).
Copalm: The yellowish, fragrant balsam yielded by the sweet gum; also, the tree itself.
Chalet: A herdsman's hut in the mountains of Switzerland.
Clash: A loud noise resulting from collision; a noisy collision of bodies; a collision.
Classman: A member of a class; a classmate.
curriculum vitae: A brief biographical summary of the main points of a person's life, especially one's education and training, the jobs one has held, and other notable activities one has participated in, as well as other notable points such as honors one has received.  It is prepared and used commonly by a person who is submitting an application for a job or position of responsibility.  It is also called a vita or vitae, and is abbreviated CV.
Corkwood: The wood of the cork oak.
Class: exhibiting refinement and high character; as, a class act.  Opposite of low-class
Cervelat: An ancient wind instrument, resembling the bassoon in tone.
Can hook: A device consisting of a short rope with flat hooks at each end, for hoisting casks or barrels by the ends of the staves.
Changeless: That can not be changed; constant; as, a changeless purpose.
Crapaudine: An ulcer on the coronet of a horse.
chucker-out: a person whose duty is to throw troublemakers out of a bar or public meeting; a bouncer{5}.
Chank: The East Indian name for the large spiral shell of several species of sea conch much used in making bangles, esp. Turbinella pyrum. Called also chank shell.
Chrysography: The art of writing in letters of gold.
Cathay: China; -- an old name for the Celestial Empire, said have been introduced by Marco Polo and to be a corruption of the Tartar name for North China (Khitai, the country of the Khitans.)
corrugated: shaped into parallel folds alternately grooved and ridged; as, the surface of the ocean was rippled and corrugated.
Camelidae: a natural family comprising the camels and llamas and vicunas.
Calycle: A row of small bracts, at the base of the calyx, on the outside.
Cytoid: Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle, etc.
Conglobulate: To gather into a small round mass.
Carinaria: A genus of oceanic heteropod Mollusca, having a thin, glassy, bonnet-shaped shell, which covers only the nucleus and gills.
Calefactor: A heater; one who, or that which, makes hot, as a stove, etc.
Corporator: A member of a corporation, esp. one of the original members.
Courier: A messenger sent with haste to convey letters or dispatches, usually on public business.
Charily: In a chary manner; carefully; cautiously; frugally.
Clione: A genus of naked pteropods. One species (Clione papilonacea), abundant in the Arctic Ocean, constitutes a part of the food of the Greenland whale. It is sometimes incorrectly called Clio.
checkpoint: a place (as at a frontier) where travellers are stopped for inspection and clearance.
Convoke: To call together; to summon to meet; to assemble by summons.
Cinnamone: A yellow crystalline substance, (C6H5.C2H2)2CO, the ketone of cinnamic acid.
Cauliform: Having the form of a caulis.
Chapless: Having no lower jaw; hence, fleshless.
Couchee: A reception held at the time of going to bed, as by a sovereign or great prince.
Carapato: A south American tick of the genus Amblyomma. There are several species, very troublesome to man and beast.
Compacture: Close union or connection of parts; manner of joining; construction.
Cancer: A genus of decapod Crustacea, including some of the most common shore crabs of Europe and North America, as the rock crab, Jonah crab, etc. See Crab.
Cuboid: Cube-shaped, or nearly so; as, the cuboid bone of the foot.
Caustic: Any substance or means which, applied to animal or other organic tissue, burns, corrodes, or destroys it by chemical action; an escharotic.
Cancel: To inclose or surround, as with a railing, or with latticework.
Click: A detent, pawl, or ratchet, as that which catches the cogs of a ratchet wheel to prevent backward motion. See Illust. of Ratched wheel.
Complicate: To fold or twist together; to combine intricately; to make complex; to combine or associate so as to make intricate or difficult.
Chambertin: A red wine from Chambertin near Dijon, in Burgundy.
coondog: any dog trained to hunt raccoons.
Corticate: Having a special outer covering of a nature unlike the interior part.
Coleoptera: An order of insects having the anterior pair of wings (elytra) hard and horny, and serving as coverings for the posterior pair, which are membranous, and folded transversely under the others when not in use. The mouth parts form two pairs of jaws (mandibles and maxillæ) adapted for chewing. Most of the Coleoptera are known as beetles and weevils.
Curability: The state of being curable; curableness.
Cere: To wax; to cover or close with wax.
Chemitype: One of a number of processes by which an impression from an engraved plate is obtained in relief, to be used for printing on an ordinary printing press.
Chartomancy: Divination by written paper or by cards.
Crude: In its natural state; not cooked or prepared by fire or heat; undressed; not altered, refined, or prepared for use by any artificial process; raw; as, crude flesh.
Conquian: A game for two, played with 40 cards, in which each player tries to form three or four of a kind or sequences.
Chattering: The act or habit of talking idly or rapidly, or of making inarticulate sounds; the sounds so made; noise made by the collision of the teeth; chatter.
Club: To form a club; to combine for the promotion of some common object; to unite.
Chrysology: That branch of political economy which relates to the production of wealth.
Clue: A ball of thread; a thread or other means of guidance. Same as Clew.
Connascent: Born together; produced at the same time.
Conversableness: The quality of being conversable; disposition to converse; sociability.
Campaigner: One who has served in an army in several campaigns; an old soldier; a veteran.
Calico: Made of, or having the appearance of, calico; -- often applied to an animal, as a horse or cat, on whose body are large patches of a color strikingly different from its main color.
Capivi: A balsam of the Spanish West Indies.  See Copaiba.
Crat\u00e6gus: A genus of small, hardy trees, including the hawthorn, much used for ornamental purposes.
Casein: A proteid substance present in both the animal and the vegetable kingdom. In the animal kingdom it is chiefly found in milk, and constitutes the main part of the curd separated by rennet; in the vegetable kingdom it is found more or less abundantly in the seeds of leguminous plants. Its reactions resemble those of alkali albumin.
Consociational: Of or pertaining to a consociation.
Caseic: Of or pertaining to cheese; as, caseic acid.
Culminate: Growing upward, as distinguished from a lateral growth; -- applied to the growth of corals.
Chorography: the mapping or description of a region or district.
Cartilaginification: The act or process of forming cartilage.
Cicuta: a genus of poisonous umbelliferous plants, of which the water hemlock or cowbane is best known.
Clout: To cover with cloth, leather, or other material; to bandage; patch, or mend, with a clout.
Circumnutate: To pass through the stages of circumnutation.
Campbellite: A member of the denomination called Christians or Disciples of Christ.  They themselves repudiate the term Campbellite as a nickname.  See Christian, 3.
Catamenia: The monthly courses of women; menstrual discharges; menses.
Cloud: To grow cloudy; to become obscure with clouds; -- often used with up.
cut-in: a still inserted and interrupting the action.
Consumption: The act or process of consuming by use, waste, etc.; decay; destruction.
Camembert: A kind of rich, soft, unpressed cream cheese made in the vicinity of Camembert, near Argentan, France; also, any cheese of the same type, wherever made.
Camel-backed: Having a back like a camel; humpbacked.
Condemned: Pronounced to be wrong, guilty, worthless, or forfeited; adjudged or sentenced to punishment, destruction, or confiscation.
Crossbill: A bird of the genus Loxia, allied to the finches. Their mandibles are strongly curved and cross each other; the crossbeak.
Coadjutor: One who aids another; an assistant; a coworker.
C\u00e6sious: Of the color of lavender; pale blue with a slight mixture of gray.
Cosignitary: One who signs a treaty or public document along with others or another; as, the cosignitaries of the treaty of Berlin.
Clean-limbed: With well-proportioned, unblemished limbs; as, a clean-limbed young fellow.
Chabouk: A long whip, such as is used in the East in the infliction of punishment.
Conformably: With conformity or in conformity; suitably; agreeably.
Cellar: A room or rooms under a building, and usually below the surface of the ground, where provisions and other stores are kept.
Connubiality: The quality of being connubial; something characteristics of the conjugal state; an expression of connubial tenderness.
Confederate: To unite in a league; to join in a mutual contract or covenant; to band together.
Corydalus: The type genus of the Corydalidae.  It includes the dobsonfly (Corydalus cornutus), whose aquatic larva, the hellgrammite, is used as bait in fishing.
Celebrate: To extol or honor in a solemn manner; as, to celebrate the name of the Most High.
cost-plus: determining payment based on the actual cost of production plus an agreed-upon fee or rate of profit; as, a cost-plus government contract.
cliffbrake: any of several small lithophytic ferns of tropical and warm temperate regions.
Cowbird: The cow blackbird (Molothrus ater), an American starling. Like the European cuckoo, it builds no nest, but lays its eggs in the nests of other birds; -- so called because frequently associated with cattle.
Curvirostral: Having a crooked beak, as the crossbill.
Colocolo: A South American wild cat (Felis colocolo), of the size of the ocelot.
Code: A body of law, sanctioned by legislation, in which the rules of law to be specifically applied by the courts are set forth in systematic form; a compilation of laws by public authority; a digest.
Collimate: To render parallel to a certain line or direction; to bring into the same line, as the axes of telescopes, etc.; to render parallel, as rays of light.
calypter: a scalelike structure between the base of the wing and the halter of a two-winged fly.
Crewel: Worsted yarn,, slackly twisted, used for embroidery.
Consumptiveness: A state of being consumptive, or a tendency to a consumption.
Cyprinidae: a natural family of fishes including the carp; tench; roach; rudd; and dace.
Creephole: A hole or retreat into which an animal may creep, to escape notice or danger.
Chain wheel: A chain pulley, or sprocket wheel.
Camonflet: A small mine, sometimes formed in the wall or side of an enemy's gallery, to blow in the earth and cut off the retreat of the miners.
Catarrhine: One of the Catarrhina, a division of Quadrumana, including the Old World monkeys and apes which have the nostrils close together and turned downward. See Monkey.
corticosteroid: a steroid compound produced by the adrenal cortex, or a synthetic analog of such a compound.
Carnose: Of or pertaining to flesh; fleshy.
Consopiation: The act of sleeping, or of lulling, to sleep.
Complexional: Of or pertaining to constitutional complexion.
Calorific: Possessing the quality of producing heat; heating.
Conformable: Corresponding in form, character, opinions, etc.; similar; like; consistent; proper or suitable; -- usually followed by to.
cross-dresser: someone who adopts the dress or manner or sexual role of the opposite sex.
Centiliter: The hundredth part of a liter; a measure of volume or capacity equal to a little more than six tenths (0.6102) of a cubic inch, or one third (0.338) of a fluid ounce.
Cull: A cully; a dupe; a gull. See Cully.
Cresting: An ornamental finish on the top of a wall or ridge of a roof.
Cotyledonal: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cotyledon.
Carman: A man whose employment is to drive, or to convey goods in, a car or car.
Chapbook: Any small book carried about for sale by chapmen or hawkers.  Hence, any small book; a toy book.
Cloud-built: Built of, or in, the clouds; airy; unsubstantial; imaginary.
Conversable: Qualified for conversation; disposed to converse; sociable; free in discourse.
Cadie: A Scotch errand boy, porter, or messenger.
Campagna: An open level tract of country; especially “Campagna di Roma.” The extensive undulating plain which surrounds Rome.
Contractility: The quality or property by which bodies shrink or contract.
Curare: A black resinoid extract prepared by the South American Indians from the bark of several species of Strychnos (Strychnos toxifera, etc.). It sometimes has little effect when taken internally, but is quickly fatal when introduced into the blood, and used by the Indians as an arrow poison.
Consignor: One who consigns something to another; -- opposed to consignee.
Clusiaceae: a widely distributed family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs and vines that produce oils and resins and some usable timber.
Chip: A piece of wood, stone, or other substance, separated by an ax, chisel, or cutting instrument.
Confounded: Confused; perplexed; unclear in mind or intent; bewildered.
Chin: The lower extremity of the face below the mouth; the point of the under jaw.
Chic: Original and in good taste or form; stylish; in current fashion, fashionable.
Cascara sagrada: Holy bark; the bark of the California buckthorn (Rhamnus Purshianus), used as a mild cathartic or laxative; -- called also cascara.
Collyrium: An application to the eye, usually an eyewater.
Commandress: A woman invested with authority to command.
celesta: a musical instrument consisting of graduated steel plates that are struck by hammers activated by a keyboard.
Complaisant: Desirous to please; courteous; obliging; compliant; as, a complaisant gentleman.
cenogenesis: The introduction during embryonic development of characters or structure not present in the earlier evolutionary history of the strain or species (as addition of the placenta in mammalian evolution); a modified evolution, in which nonprimitive characters make their appearance in consequence of a secondary adaptation of the embryo to the peculiar conditions of its environment; -- distinguished from palingenesis.
Colportage: The distribution of religious books, tracts, etc., by colporteurs.
Cryptogamia: The series or division of flowerless plants, or those never having true stamens and pistils, but propagated by spores of various kinds.
Cracovian: Of or pertaining to Cracow in Poland.
Calculus: Any solid concretion, formed in any part of the body, but most frequent in the organs that act as reservoirs, and in the passages connected with them; as, biliary calculi; urinary calculi, etc.
Curtana: The pointless sword carried before English monarchs at their coronation, and emblematically considered as the sword of mercy; -- also called the sword of Edward the Confessor.
Crockery: Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay, especially the coarser kinds.
Carp: A fresh-water herbivorous fish (Cyprinus carpio.). Several other species of Cyprinus, Catla, and Carassius are called carp. See Cruclan carp.
Cr\u00e9dit foncier: A company licensed for the purpose of carrying out improvements, by means of loans and advances upon real securities.
Cart: To carry burdens in a cart; to follow the business of a carter.
Complacent: Self-satisfied; contented; kindly; as, a complacent temper; a complacent smile.
Cark: To vex; to worry; to make by anxious care or worry.
certified check: a check drawn on a bank and bearing marks from that bank guaranteeing that funds have been reserved for payment.
Col-: A prefix signifying with, together. See Com-.
Cosmographically: In a cosmographic manner; in accordance with cosmography.
Card: To comb with a card; to cleanse or disentangle by carding; as, to card wool; to card a horse.
Care: To be anxious or solicitous; to be concerned; to have regard or interest; -- sometimes followed by an objective of measure.
Commonwealth: A state; a body politic consisting of a certain number of men, united, by compact or tacit agreement, under one form of government and system of laws.
Chih tai: A Chinese governor general; a tsung tu (which see).
Caprifoliaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Honeysuckle family of plants (Caprifoliacæ.
Chordospartium: a genus containing two species of small New Zealand trees: weeping tree broom; endangered.
Convexo-plane: Convex on one side, and flat on the other; plano-convex.
Carroty: Like a carrot in color or in taste; -- an epithet given to reddish yellow hair, etc.
Counterseal: To seal or ratify with another or others.
Concert: Agreement in a design or plan; union formed by mutual communication of opinions and views; accordance in a scheme; harmony; simultaneous action.
Coupon: A certificate of interest due, printed at the bottom of transferable bonds (state, railroad, etc.), given for a term of years, designed to be cut off and presented for payment when the interest is due; an interest warrant.
Colt: To horse; to get with young.
Cataplasm: A soft and moist substance applied externally to some part of the body; a poultice.
Consecrate: To make, or declare to be, sacred; to appropriate to sacred uses; to set apart, dedicate, or devote, to the service or worship of God; as, to consecrate a church; to give (one's self) unreservedly, as to the service of God.
Cong\u00e9: The act of taking leave; parting ceremony; farewell; also, dismissal.
caliche: a deposit of sand or clay on the surface containing crystallized salts such as sodium chloride or sodium nitrate; -- used especially of the sodium nitrate deposits of Chile and Peru.
Church: To bless according to a prescribed form, or to unite with in publicly returning thanks in church, as after deliverance from the dangers of childbirth; as, the churching of women.
Cole: A plant of the Brassica or Cabbage genus; esp. that form of Brassica oleracea called rape and coleseed.
Cerebralism: The doctrine or theory that psychical phenomena are functions or products of the brain only.
Cola: A genus of sterculiaceous trees, natives of tropical Africa, esp. Guinea, but now naturalized in tropical America, esp. in the West Indies and Brazil.
Contravallation: A trench guarded with a parapet, constructed by besiegers, to secure themselves and check sallies of the besieged.
C\u0153nurus: The larval stage of a tapeworm (Tænia cœnurus) which forms bladderlike sacs in the brain of sheep, causing the fatal disease known as water brain, vertigo, staggers or gid.
caramelize: to to convert [usu. sugar] into caramel, by the action of heat.
core dump: An complete and exact copy of the contents of a computer core{9}, usually produced as a file when some serious error occurs in the execution of a computer program, and used for debugging the program which produced the error.
Cornerwise: With the corner in front; diagonally; not square.
Conjugally: In a conjugal manner; matrimonially; connubially.
Copper works: A place where copper is wrought or manufactured.
Contrariness: state or quality of being contrary; opposition; inconsistency; contrariety; perverseness; obstinacy.
Comptroler: A controller; a public officer whose duty it is to examine certify accounts.
co-star: to be the co-star in a performance; as, Robin Williams co-starred in the film.
Charger: One who, or that which charges.
Chickaree: The American red squirrel (Tamiasciurus Hudsonius, formerly Sciurus Hudsonius); -- so called from its cry.
Coptic Church: The native church of Egypt or church of Alexandria, which in general organization and doctrines resembles the Roman Catholic Church, except that it holds to the Monophysitic doctrine which was condemned (a. d. 451) by the council of Chalcedon, and allows its priests to marry. The “pope and patriarch” has jurisdiction over the Abyssinian Church. Since the 7th century the Coptic Church has been so isolated from modifying influences that in many respects it is the most ancient monument of primitive Christian rites and ceremonies. But centuries of subjection to Moslem rule have weakened and degraded it.
cunningman: A fortune teller; one who pretends to reveal mysteries.
Chorus: To sing in chorus; to exclaim simultaneously.
Cynodontia: a division of Triassic Therapsida comprising small carnivorous reptiles often with mammallike teeth.
Counterturn: The critical moment in a play, when, contrary to expectation, the action is embroiled in new difficulties.
Crore: Ten millions; as, a crore of rupees (which is nearly $5,000,000).
canned: Recorded; in contrast with live; -- used of sound or video broadcasts.
Cratch: A manger or open frame for hay; a crib; a rack.
Cameo: A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewel for personal adornment, or like.
Cetology: The description or natural history of cetaceous animals.
Cabled: Fastened with, or attached to, a cable or rope.
Chrysosplenium: a genus of widely distributed semiaquatic herbs with minute greenish-yellow apetalous flowers.
Cicatricle: The germinating point in the embryo of a seed; the point in the yolk of an egg at which development begins.
California condor: a large vulture (Gymnogyps californianus), also called California vulture.
Chylaqueous: Consisting of chyle much diluted with water; -- said of a liquid which forms the circulating fluid of some inferior animals.
Conge: To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow ceremoniously, or courtesy.
Catheterize: To operate on with a catheter.
Catenation: Connection of links or union of parts, as in a chain; a regular or connected series. See Concatenation.
croodle: To cower or cuddle together, as from fear or cold; to lie close and snug together, as pigs in straw.
Costliness: The quality of being costy; expensiveness; sumptuousness.
Chyle: A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in a state of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme by the action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals, and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.
Colloquy: Mutual discourse of two or more persons; conference; conversation.
Cockspur: A variety of Cratægus, or hawthorn (Cratægus Crus-galli), having long, straight thorns; -- called also Cockspur thorn.
Collards: Young cabbage, used as “greens”; esp. the leaves of a kind cultivated for that purpose, the collard or colewort.
Cogon: A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the Philippine Islands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
Circumstance: To place in a particular situation; to supply relative incidents.
Comate: Encompassed with a coma, or bushy appearance, like hair; hairy.
Carbon transmitter: A telephone transmitter in which a carbon contact is used.
Carpetmonger: One who deals in carpets; a buyer and seller of carpets.
Chorology: The science which treats of the laws of distribution of living organisms over the earth's surface as to latitude, altitude, locality, etc.
Chebec: A small American bird (Empidonax minimus); the least flycatcher.
Ca\u00f1on: A deep gorge, ravine, or gulch, between high and steep banks, worn by water courses.
Catelectrode: The negative electrode or pole of a voltaic battery.
Cerebrifugal: Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the brain to the spinal cord, and so transfer cerebral impulses (centrifugal impressions) outwards.
Cydippida: an order of ctenophores having two long pinnate tentacles.
Collectivism: The doctrine that land and capital should be owned by society collectively or as a whole; communism.
Conclude: To come to a termination; to make an end; to close; to end; to terminate.
Cyathiform: In the form of a cup, a little widened at the top.
crossing guard: a person who stands at a street crossing to assist children to cross the street safely; -- usually used near schools during the times that children are entering or leaving the school.
Compend: A compendium; an epitome; a summary.
Capoch: To cover with, or as with, a hood; hence, to hoodwink or blind.
Collectivist: Relating to, characteristic of, or advocating, collectivism.
cedar waxwing: a species of chatterer (Bombycilla cedrorum, formerly Ampelis cedrorum) widely distributed over temperate North America, so named from its frequenting cedar trees; -- called also cedar bird, cherry bird, Canada robin, and American waxwing.  It is a brownish bird about 7 inches long, between the size of a robin and a sparrow, has a crest on the head, a black face mask, and a yellow-tipped tail.  The name comes from the black color of the tips of the wings, like that of a black sealing wax.  They sometimes are seen in flocks.
Cinquefoil: The name of several different species of the genus Potentilla; -- also called five-finger, because of the resemblance of its leaves to the fingers of the hand.
Club-rush: A rushlike plant, the reed mace or cat-tail, or some species of the genus Scirpus. See Bulrush.
Childcrowing: The crowing noise made by children affected with spasm of the laryngeal muscles; false croup.
chiggerflower: an erect perennial of eastern and southern U. S. (Asclepias tuberosa) having showy orange flowers.
carbonous: relating to, containing, or rich in carbon.
Chrismation: The act of applying the chrism, or consecrated oil.
Chouse: One who is easily cheated; a tool; a simpleton; a gull.
Comparator: An instrument or machine for comparing anything to be measured with a standard measure; -- applied especially to a machine for comparing standards of length.
Cereus: A genus of plants of the Cactus family. They are natives of America, from California to Chili.
caulked: having cracks and crevices stopped up with a filler such as caulk.  Contrasted with uncaulked.
Cardiographic: Of or pertaining to, or produced by, a cardiograph.
cestoid: Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.
Compaction: The act of making compact, or the state of being compact.
Ceryl: A radical, C27H55 supposed to exist in several compounds obtained from Chinese wax, beeswax, etc.
Caudex: The stem of a tree., esp. a stem without a branch, as of a palm or a tree fern; also, the perennial rootstock of an herbaceous plant.
coffee-pot: A covered pot in which coffee is prepared, or is brought upon the table for drinking.
Cheiropterygium: The typical pentadactyloid limb of the higher vertebrates.
Colossus: A statue of gigantic size. The name was especially applied to certain famous statues in antiquity, as the Colossus of Nero in Rome, the Colossus of Apollo at Rhodes.
Cultirostres: A tribe of wading birds including the stork, heron, crane, etc.
Chlorhydrin: One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasic alcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorine for one or more hydroxyl groups.
Chilostomatous: Of or pertaining to the Chilostoma.
Clinch: The act or process of holding fast; that which serves to hold fast; a grip; a grasp; a clamp; a holdfast; as, to get a good clinch of an antagonist, or of a weapon; to secure anything by a clinch.
Cimolite: A soft, earthy, clayey mineral, of whitish or grayish color.
Countryman: An inhabitant or native of a region.
Cleanness: The state or quality of being clean.
Cankery: Like a canker; full of canker.
Cripple: To deprive of the use of a limb, particularly of a leg or foot; to lame.
Cephalopodic: Belonging to, or resembling, the cephalopods.
Crimper: One who, or that which, crimps
Counter tenor: One of the middle parts in music, between the tenor and the treble; high tenor.
Creole: Of or pertaining to a Creole or the Creoles.
Congregational: Of or pertaining to a congregation; conducted, or participated in, by a congregation; as, congregational singing.
Cycas: A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palms and the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes a valuable kind of sago.
Cholic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the bile.
C\u00e6latura: Art of producing metal decorative work other than statuary, as reliefs, intaglios, engraving, chasing, etc.
chapati: a flat pancakelike bread cooked on a griddle, originating in India.
Colitis: An inflammation of the large intestine, esp. of its mucous membrane; colonitis.
Collaret: A small collar; specif., a woman's collar of lace, fur, or other fancy material.
Cork fossil: A variety of amianthus which is very light, like cork.
Crease: To make a crease or mark in, as by folding or doubling.
Civilizer: One who, or that which, civilizes or tends to civilize.
Consanguineous: Of the same blood; related by birth; descended from the same parent or ancestor.
Cataplexy: A morbid condition caused by an overwhelming shock or extreme fear and marked by rigidity of the muscles.
Chevrette: A machine for raising guns or mortar into their carriages.
Connate-perfoliate: Connate or coalescent at the base so as to produce a broad foliaceous body through the center of which the stem passes; -- applied to leaves, as the leaves of the boneset.
Cyamellone: A complex derivative of cyanogen, regarded as an acid, and known chiefly in its salts; -- called also hydromellonic acid.
Consolidated: Made solid, hard, or compact; united; joined; solidified.
Campanularian: A hydroid of the family Campanularidæ, characterized by having the polyps or zooids inclosed in bell-shaped calicles or hydrothecæ.
Choke-strap: A strap leading from the bellyband to the lower part of the collar, to keep the collar in place.
Choking: That chokes; producing the feeling of strangulation.
Cataphonic: Of or relating to cataphonics; catacoustic.
Conductance: Conducting power; -- the reciprocal of resistance. A suggested unit is the mho, the reciprocal of the ohm.
catamountain: the bushy-tailed European wildcat (Felis silvestris) resembling the domestic tabby and regarded as the ancestor of the domestic cat.
Crow: To make the shrill sound characteristic of a cock, either in joy, gayety, or defiance.
Chryso\u00efdine: An artificial, yellow, crystalline dye, C6H5N2.C6H3(NH2)2. Also, one of a group of dyestuffs resembling chrysoïdine proper.
Checkmate: To check (an adversary's king) in such a manner that escape in impossible; to defeat (an adversary) by putting his king in check from which there is no escape.
Catalogue: To make a list or catalogue; to insert in a catalogue.
Countersway: A swaying in a contrary direction; an opposing influence.
Conduplicate: Folded lengthwise along the midrib, the upper face being within; -- said of leaves or petals in vernation or æstivation.
Confluxible: Inclined to flow or run together.
Cadmia: An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces where zinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.
Cadmic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cadmium; as, cadmic sulphide.
Calkin: A calk on a shoe. See Calk, n., 1.
Cicadellidae: a natural family comprising the leafhoppers.
Ceremonious: Consisting of outward forms and rites; ceremonial. [In this sense ceremonial is now preferred.]
Criminality: The quality or state of being criminal; that which constitutes a crime; guiltiness; guilt.
Circumstantial: Something incidental to the main subject, but of less importance; opposed to an essential; -- generally in the plural; as, the circumstantials of religion.
Contagious: Communicable by contact, by a virus, or by a bodily exhalation; catching; as, a contagious disease.
clear-thinking: able to think clearly and accurately.
Centigrade: Consisting of a hundred degrees; graduated into a hundred divisions or equal parts.
cheiropter: One of the Chiroptera; -- an older spelling of chiropter.
Candidating: The taking of the position of a candidate; specifically, the preaching of a clergyman with a view to settlement.
Cochlea: An appendage of the labyrinth of the internal ear, which is elongated and coiled into a spiral in mammals. See Ear.
Coving: A cove or series of coves, as the concaved surface under the overhang of a projecting upper story.
Connection: The act of connecting, or the state of being connected; the act or process of bringing two things into contact; junction; union; as, the connection between church and state is inescapable; the connection of pipes of different diameters requires an adapter.
Cobia: An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater; -- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
cookware: cooking utensils, such as pots, pans, or baking dishes made of heat-resistant material.
Cameralistic: Of or pertaining to finance and public revenue.
Cliental: Of or pertaining to a client.
Contractibility: Capability of being contracted; quality of being contractible; as, the contractibility and dilatability of air.
CPI: the consumer price index, an index of the cost of all goods and services to a typical consumer.  The increase of this value each year is one measure of monetary inflation.
Clarification: The act or process of making clear or transparent, by freeing visible impurities; as, the clarification of wine.
Chlorite: Any salt of chlorous acid; as, chlorite of sodium.
Caco\u00ebthes: A bad custom or habit; an insatiable desire; as, cacoëthes scribendi, “The itch for writing”.
Cierge: A wax candle used in religous rites.
Caperberry: The small olive-shaped berry of the European and Oriental caper, said to be used in pickles and as a condiment.
CPU: The central processing unit, that part of the electronic circuitry of a computer in which the arithmetic and logical operations are performed on input data, which are thereby converted to output data; it is usually located on the mainboard, or motherboard, of a computer.  The CPU and the memory form the central part of a computer to which the peripherals are attached.  Most personal computers as of 1998 had only one CPU, but some computers may have more than one CPU.
Catadromous: Having the lowest inferior segment of a pinna nearer the rachis than the lowest superior one; -- said of a mode of branching in ferns, and opposed to anadromous.
Curly: Curling or tending to curl; having curls; full of ripples; crinkled.
Cisalpine: On the hither side of the Alps with reference to Rome, that is, on the south side of the Alps; -- opposed to transalpine.
Clairaudience: Act of hearing, or the ability to hear, sounds not normally audible; -- usually claimed as a special faculty of spiritualistic mediums, or the like.
Catechumen: One who is receiving rudimentary instruction in the doctrines of Christianity; a neophyte; in the primitive church, one officially recognized as a Christian, and admitted to instruction preliminary to admission to full membership in the church.
Copse: To trim or cut; -- said of small trees, brushwood, tufts of grass, etc.
Courageousness: The quality of being courageous; courage.
Chiliast: One who believes in the second coming of Christ to reign on earth a thousand years; a millenarian.
Cantonal: Of or pertaining to a canton or cantons; of the nature of a canton.
Cupping: The operation of drawing blood to or from the surface of the person by forming a partial vacuum over the spot. Also, sometimes, a similar operation for drawing pus from an abscess.
Cross-days: The three days preceding the Feast of the Ascension.
Clown: To act as a clown; -- with it.
Crematorium: A furnace for cremating corpses; a building containing such a furnace.
Cubature: The process of determining the solid or cubic contents of a body.
Coffeehouse: A house of entertainment, where guests are supplied with coffee and other refreshments, and where men meet for conversation.
Congreve: Short for Cogreve rocket, a powerful form of rocket formerly used in war, either in the field or for bombardment. In the former case it was armed with shell, shrapnel, or other missiles; in the latter, with an inextinguishable explosive material, inclosed in a metallic case. It was guided by a long wooden stick.
Catopter: A reflecting optical glass or instrument; a mirror.
crossheading: a heading of a subsection printed within the body of the text.
Capsicine: A volatile alkaloid extracted from Capsicum annuum or from capsicin.
Correlatable: Such as can be correlated; as, correlatable phenomena.
Currently: In a current manner; generally; commonly; as, it is currently believed.
crook: A bend, turn, or curve; curvature; flexure.
Clinopinacoid: The plane in crystals of the monoclinic system which is parallel to the vertical and the inclined lateral (clinidiagonal) axes.
Cataphonics: That branch of acoustics which treats of reflected sounds; catacoustics.
Condolence: Expression of sympathy with another in sorrow or grief.
Chatteration: The act or habit of chattering.
Chapellany: A chapel within the jurisdiction of a church; a subordinate ecclesiastical foundation.
Cystoplast: A nucleated cell having an envelope or cell wall, as a red blood corpuscle or an epithelial cell; a cell concerned in growth.
Chump: A short, thick, heavy piece of wood.
Calcification: The process of change into a stony or calcareous substance by the deposition of lime salt; -- normally, as in the formation of bone and of teeth; abnormally, as in calcareous degeneration of tissue.
Conirostres: A tribe of perching birds, including those which have a strong conical bill, as the finches.
Carangoid: Belonging to the Carangidæ, a family of fishes allied to the mackerels, and including the caranx, American bluefish, and the pilot fish.
Crustacean: Of or pertaining to the Crustacea; crustaceous.
Chairmanship: The office of a chairman of a meeting or organized body.
Cachet: A seal, as of a letter.
Chlorotic: Pertaining to, or affected by, chlorosis.
Contiguity: The state of being contiguous; intimate association; nearness; proximity.
Changeling: Taken or left in place of another; changed.
Cavern: A large, deep, hollow place in the earth; a large cave.
Confervous: Pertaining to confervae; consisting of, or resembling, the confervae.
Convection: The act or process of conveying or transmitting.
Contribution plan: A plan of distributing surplus by giving to each policy the excess of premiums and interest earned thereon over the expenses of management, cost of insurance, and the policy value at the date of computation. This excess is called the contribution of the policy.
Cyprinus: the type genus of the family Cyprinidae; carp.
Category: One of the highest classes to which the objects of knowledge or thought can be reduced, and by which they can be arranged in a system; an ultimate or undecomposable conception; a predicament.
civil-libertarian: a person having or showing active concern for protection of civil liberties protected by law.
Circumscriptive: Circumscribing or tending to circumscribe; marcing the limits or form of.
Conium: A genus of biennial, poisonous, white-flowered, umbelliferous plants, bearing ribbed fruit (“seeds”) and decompound leaves.
Condor: A very large bird of the Vulture family (Sarcorhamphus gryphus), found in the most elevated parts of the Andes.
Curiality: The privileges, prerogatives, or retinue of a court.
Consonant: An articulate sound which in utterance is usually combined and sounded with an open sound called a vowel; a member of the spoken alphabet other than a vowel; also, a letter or character representing such a sound.
Cabinetwork: The art or occupation of working upon wooden furniture requiring nice workmanship; also, such furniture.
Counter-: A prefix meaning contrary, opposite, in opposition; as, counteract, counterbalance, countercheck. See Counter, adv. & a.
Clearcole: To coat or paint with clearcole.
Cyclosorus: a small genus of terrestrial ferns of tropical and subtropical southern hemisphere.
Calicle: One of the small cuplike cavities, often with elevated borders, covering the surface of most corals. Each is formed by a polyp. (b) One of the cuplike structures inclosing the zooids of certain hydroids. See Campanularian.
Chop: A jaw of an animal; -- commonly in the pl. See Chops.
Consummate: To bring to completion; to raise to the highest point or degree; to complete; to finish; to perfect; to achieve.
Chow: A prefecture or district of the second rank in China, or the chief city of such a district; -- often part of the name of a city, as in Foochow.
Consentingly: With consent; in a compliant manner.
Connaturally: By the act of nature; originally; from birth.
Curate: One who has the cure of souls; originally, any clergyman, but now usually limited to one who assists a rector or vicar.
Cricothyroid: Of or pertaining both to the cricoid and the thyroid cartilages.
cuckoopint: a common European arum (Arum maculatum) with lanceolate spathe and short purple spadix; it emerges in early spring, and is the source of a sagolike starch called arum.
Chlamyphore: A small South American edentate (Chlamyphorus truncatus, and Chlamyphorus retusus) allied to the armadillo. It is covered with a leathery shell or coat of mail, like a cloak, attached along the spine.
Couleur: Color; -- chiefly used in a few French phrases, as couler de rose, color of rose; and hence, adjectively, rose-colored; roseate.
compartmented: divided up into compartments; as, a compartmented box.
choirboy: a boy who sings in a choir.
Curculio: One of a large group of beetles (Rhynchophora) of many genera; -- called also weevils, snout beetles, billbeetles, and billbugs. Many of the species are very destructive, as the plum curculio, the corn, grain, and rice weevils, etc.
Cata: The Latin and English form of a Greek preposition, used as a prefix to signify down, downward, under, against, contrary or opposed to, wholly, completely; as in cataclysm, catarrh. It sometimes drops the final vowel, as in catoptric; and is sometimes changed to cath, as in cathartic, catholic.
calyceal: of or pertaining to a calyx.
Copier: One who copies; one who writes or transcribes from an original; a transcriber.
coenzyme: a molecule that is essential for the activity of some enzymes; it may exist free in solution within a living organism, but functions by binding to an enzyme to assist in catalyzing a reaction.  The molecule itself may be temporarily changed during the reaction, but is ultimately restored to its original form.  Many vitamins function as coenzymes.
Crumb: To break into crumbs or small pieces with the fingers; as, to crumb bread.
Christmas: An annual church festival (December 25) and in some States a legal holiday, in memory of the birth of Christ, often celebrated by a particular church service, and also by special gifts, greetings, and hospitality.
Castillan: Of or pertaining to Castile, in Spain.
colorful: having striking color.  Opposite of colorless.
Celibate: Unmarried; single; as, a celibate state.
cross-eyed: having convergent strabismus.  Contrasted with walleyed.
Composition: The act or art of composing, or forming a whole or integral, by placing together and uniting different things, parts, or ingredients.
Catcall: A sound like the cry of a cat, such as is made in playhouses to express dissatisfaction with a play; also, a small shrill instrument for making such a noise.
clapperboard: a device which synchronizes sound and picture while making a motion picture, consisting of boards held in front of a movie camera, which are are banged together.
Carburetor: An apparatus in which coal gas, hydrogen, or air is passed through or over a volatile hydrocarbon, in order to confer or increase illuminating power.
Chucklehead: A person with a large head; a numskull; a dunce.
Chevron: One of the nine honorable ordinaries, consisting of two broad bands of the width of the bar, issuing, respectively from the dexter and sinister bases of the field and conjoined at its center.
Corroval: A dark brown substance of vegetable origin, allied to curare, and used by the natives of New Granada as an arrow poison.
clostridium: spindle-shaped bacterial cell esp. one swollen at the center by an endospore.
Chisel: To cut, pare, gouge, or engrave with a chisel; as, to chisel a block of marble into a statue.
Confectioners sugar: A highly refined sugar in impalpable powder, esp. suited to confectioners' uses.
cornbind: A weed that binds stalks of corn, as Convolvulus arvensis, Polygonum Convolvulus.
Community: Common possession or enjoyment; participation; as, a community of goods.
characid: any freshwater fish of the family Characinidae; -- also called characin.
classy: having elegance or taste or refinement in manners or dress.  Opposite of styleless.
characin: any freshwater fish of the family Characinidae; -- also called characid.
