crape fern: a fern of New Zealand (Leptopteris superba) with pinnate fronds and a densely woolly stalks; sometimes included in genus Todea.
Catholic: A person who accepts the creeds which are received in common by all parts of the orthodox Christian church.
cleistocarp: the closed spore-bearing structure of some fungi (especially  Aspergillaceae and Eurysiphaceae) from which spores are released only by decay or disintegration; -- called also cleistothecium.
Coromandel: The west coast, or a portion of the west coast, of the Bay of Bengal.
Calabar: A district on the west coast of Africa.
Cotswold: An open country abounding in sheepcotes, as in the Cotswold hills, in Gloucestershire, England.
Corporature: The state of being embodied; bodily existence.
Cottoid: Like a fish of the genus Cottus.
Cotland: Land appendant to a cot or cottage, or held by a cottager or cotter.
Corpuscularian: An adherent of the corpuscular philosophy.
Cledgy: Stiff, stubborn, clayey, or tenacious; as, a cledgy soil.
Causally: The lighter, earthy parts of ore, carried off washing.
cut-rate: a price below the standard price.
Canvasback: A Species of duck (Aythya vallisneria), esteemed for the delicacy of its flesh. It visits the United States in autumn; particularly Chesapeake Bay and adjoining waters; -- so named from the markings of the plumage on its back.
Catery: The place where provisions are deposited.
Crenate: Having the margin cut into rounded teeth notches, or scallops.
Chowter: To grumble or mutter like a froward child.
Cajolery: A wheedling to delude; words used in cajoling; flattery.
Cledge: The upper stratum of fuller's earth.
Crawl: A pen or inclosure of stakes and hurdles on the seacoast, for holding fish.
Constableship: The office or functions of a constable.
Conflation: A blowing together, as of many instruments in a concert, or of many fires in a foundry.
Conviction: The act of convicting; the act of proving, finding, or adjudging, guilty of an offense.
Complaisance: Disposition to please or oblige; obliging compliance with the wishes of others; a deportment indicative of a desire to please; courtesy; civility.
Concupiscent: Having sexual lust; libidinous; lustful; lecherous; salacious.
Catch-basin: A cistern or vault at the point where a street gutter discharges into a sewer, to catch bulky matters which would not pass readily through the sewer.
Contemporariness: Existence at the same time; contemporaneousness.
clip-on: having a clip as the means of attachment; as, clip-on earrings; a clip-on bow tie.
Cephalotripsy: The act or operation of crushing the head of a fetus in the womb in order to effect delivery.
Caprid: Of or pertaining to the tribe of ruminants of which the goat, or genus Capra, is the type.
Cystidea: An order of Crinoidea, mostly fossils of the Paleozoic rocks. They were usually roundish or egg-shaped, and often unsymmetrical; some were sessile, others had short stems.
Chromophane: A general name for the several coloring matters, red, green, yellow, etc., present in the inner segments in the cones of the retina, held in solution by fats, and slowly decolorized by light; distinct from the photochemical pigments of the rods of the retina.
Cylindroid: A solid body resembling a right cylinder, but having the bases or ends elliptical.
Couchancy: State of lying down for repose.
Citrine: A yellow, pellucid variety of quartz.
Commissive: Relating to commission; of the nature of, or involving, commission.
Cheng: A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
Catchdrain: A ditch or drain along the side of a hill to catch the surface water; also, a ditch at the side of a canal to catch the surplus water.
Conjecture: To make conjectures; to surmise; to guess; to infer; to form an opinion; to imagine.
Chopfallen: Having the lower chop or jaw depressed; hence, crestfallen; dejected; dispirited; downcast. See Chapfallen.
czar: A king; a chief; the title of the emperor of Russia.
Conservatrix: A woman who preserves from loss, injury, etc.
culottes: a type of women's trousers with wide legs cut loose and full so as to resemble a skirt.
Consanguinity: The relation of persons by blood, in distinction from affinity or relation by marriage; blood relationship; as, lineal consanguinity; collateral consanguinity.
Coffeeroom: A public room where coffee and other refreshments may be obtained.
Colloped: Having ridges or bunches of flesh, like collops.
Christianization: The act or process of converting or being converted to a true Christianity.
Cathodic: A term applied to the centrifugal, or efferent, course of the nervous influence.
Cryptopine: A colorless crystalline alkaloid obtained in small quantities from opium.
Charpie: Straight threads obtained by unraveling old linen cloth; -- used for surgical dressings.
Centimeter: The hundredth part of a meter; a measure of length equal to rather more than thirty-nine hundredths (0.3937) of an inch. See Meter.
Convulsional: Pertaining to, or having, convulsions; convulsionary.
centrarchid: any of a group of small carnivorous freshwater percoid fishes of North America usually having a laterally compressed body and metallic luster: crappies; black bass; bluegills; pumpkinseed.
Caper: The pungent grayish green flower bud of the European and Oriental caper (Capparis spinosa), much used for pickles.
Conculcate: To tread or trample under foot.
Cacochymia: A vitiated state of the humors, or fluids, of the body, esp. of the blood.
Cacochymic: Having the fluids of the body vitiated, especially the blood.
Contentment: The state of being contented or satisfied; content.
Capel: A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornblende) in the walls of tin and copper lodes.
Cretinism: A condition of endemic or inherited idiocy, accompanied by physical degeneracy and deformity (usually with goiter), frequent in certain mountain valleys, esp. of the Alps.
Coagulum: The thick, curdy precipitate formed by the coagulation of albuminous matter; any mass of coagulated matter, as a clot of blood.
Combustible: A substance that may be set on fire, or which is liable to take fire and burn.
Cangue: A very broad and heavy wooden collar which certain offenders in China are compelled to wear as a punishment.
clitoral: Of or pertaining to the clitoris.
Conclamation: An outcry or shout of many together.
Cabrilla: A name applied to various species of edible fishes of the genus Serranus, and related genera, inhabiting the Meditarranean, the coast of California, etc.  In California, some of them are also called rock bass and kelp salmon.
co-op: a commercial enterprise run for the benefit of its owners.
Carelessness: The quality or state of being careless; heedlessness; negligence; inattention.
Cuirassier: A soldier armed with a cuirass; especially, a soldier of the heaviest cavalry, wearing a cuirass only when in full dress.
cronstedtite: A mineral consisting principally of silicate of iron, and crystallizing in hexagonal prisms with perfect basal cleavage; -- so named from the Swedish mineralogist Cronstedt.
Calcium: An elementary substance; a metal which combined with oxygen forms lime. It is of a pale yellow color, tenacious, and malleable. It is a member of the alkaline earth group of elements. Atomic weight 40. Symbol Ca.
Checkerboard: A board with sixty-four squares of alternate color, used for playing checkers, chess, or draughts.
Cortex: Bark, as of a tree; hence, an outer covering.
Coruscate: To glitter in flashes; to flash.
Curvate: Bent in a regular form; curved.
Chilostoma: An extensive suborder of marine Bryozoa, mostly with calcareous shells. They have a movable lip and a lid to close the aperture of the cells.
Couranto: A sprightly dance; a coranto; a courant.
Curing: p. a. & vb. n. of Cure.
Corny: Producing corn or grain; furnished with grains of corn.
Cassican: An American bird of the genus Cassicus, allied to the starlings and orioles, remarkable for its skillfully constructed and suspended nest; the crested oriole. The name is also sometimes given to the piping crow, an Australian bird.
Charqui: Jerked beef; beef cut into long strips and dried in the wind and sun.
Cornu: A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
Casings: Dried dung of cattle used as fuel.
Confectory: Pertaining to the art of making sweetmeats.
Coprophagous: Feeding upon dung, as certain insects.
Cresol: Any one of three metameric substances, CH3.C6H4.OH, homologous with and resembling phenol. They are obtained from coal tar and wood tar, and are colorless, oily liquids or solids. [Called also cresylic acid.]
Comfortment: Act or process of administering comfort.
Canker blossom: That which blasts a blossom as a canker does.
Cubby: A snug or confined or secluded place; a small room or a snug space within a room.
Chode: the old imp. of chide. See Chide.
Curvature: The act of curving, or the state of being bent or curved; a curving or bending, normal or abnormal, as of a line or surface from a rectilinear direction; a bend; a curve.
Co-respondent: One who is called upon to answer a summons or other proceeding jointly with another.
Copartnery: the state of being copartners in any undertaking.
Charon: The son of Erebus and Nox, whose office it was to ferry the souls of the dead over the Styx, a river of the infernal regions.
Corkage: The charge made by innkeepers for drawing the cork and taking care of bottles of wine bought elsewhere by a guest.
Champ: The field or ground on which carving appears in relief.
Compiler: One who compiles; esp., one who makes books by compilation.
Colliquative: Causing rapid waste or exhaustion; melting; as, colliquative sweats.
Cultus cod: See Cod, and Buffalo cod, under Buffalo.
Cashmere: A rich stuff for shawls, scarfs, etc., originally made in Cashmere from the soft wool found beneath the hair of the goats of Cashmere, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Some cashmere, of fine quality, is richly embroidered for sale to Europeans.
Columbian: Of or pertaining to the United States, or to America.
Calamus: The indian cane, a plant of the Palm family. It furnishes the common rattan. See Rattan, and Dragon's blood.
Columbiad: A form of seacoast cannon; a long, chambered gun designed for throwing shot or shells with heavy charges of powder, at high angles of elevation.
Copperplate: A plate of polished copper on which a design or writing is engraved.
Coequality: The state of being on an equality, as in rank or power.
Cremocarp: The peculiar fruit of fennel, carrot, parsnip, and the like, consisting of a pair of carpels pendent from a supporting axis.
Companionship: Fellowship; association; the act or fact of keeping company with any one.
Coast and Geodetic Survey: A bureau of the United States government charged with the topographic and hydrographic survey of the coast and the execution of belts of primary triangulation and lines of precise leveling in the interior. It now belongs to the Department of Commerce and Labor.
centralized: drawn toward a center or brought under the control of a central authority; as, centralized control of emergency relief efforts; centralized government.  Opposite of decentralized.
Checker: A piece in the game of draughts or checkers.
Collembola: The division of Thysanura which includes Podura, and allied forms.
Creditably: In a creditable manner; reputably; with credit.
Cemeterial: Of or pertaining to a cemetery.
camachile: a common thorny tropical American tree (Pithecellobium dulce) having terminal racemes of yellow flowers followed by sickle-shaped or circinate edible pods and yielding good timber and a yellow dye and mucilaginous gum.
Changeful: Full of change; mutable; inconstant; fickle; uncertain.
Cement steel: Steel produced by cementation; blister steel.
Candleberry tree: A shrub (the Myrica cerifera, or wax-bearing myrtle), common in North America, the little nuts of which are covered with a greenish white wax, which was formerly, used for hardening candles; -- also called bayberry tree, bayberry, or candleberry.
Corybant: One of the priests of Cybele in Phrygia. The rites of the Corybants were accompanied by wild music, dancing, etc.
Compulsory: Having the power of compulsion; constraining.
Cartilaginous: Of or pertaining to cartilage; gristly; firm and tough like cartilage.
Campion: A plant of the Pink family (Cucubalus bacciferus), bearing berries regarded as poisonous.
Crispness: The state or quality of being crisp.
Cucumber: A creeping plant, and its fruit, of several species of the genus Cucumis, esp. Cucumis sativus, the unripe fruit of which is eaten either fresh or picked. Also, similar plants or fruits of several other genera. See below.
Cissoid: A curve invented by Diocles, for the purpose of solving two celebrated problems of the higher geometry; viz., to trisect a plane angle, and to construct two geometrical means between two given straight lines.
Cerate: An unctuous preparation for external application, of a consistence intermediate between that of an ointment and a plaster, so that it can be spread upon cloth without the use of heat, but does not melt when applied to the skin.
Cimbrian: Of or pertaining to the Cimbri.
Costard: An apple, large and round like the head.
Copyist: A copier; a transcriber; an imitator; a plagiarist.
Chronologist: A person who investigates dates of events and transactions; one skilled in chronology.
cocozelle: a squash plant having a dark green fruit with skin mottled with light green or yellow.
Consumable: Capable of being consumed; that may be destroyed, dissipated, wasted, or spent.
Chouicha: The salmon of the Columbia River or California. See Quinnat.
Claimant: One who claims; one who asserts a right or title; a claimer.
Carbinol: Methyl alcohol, CH3OH; -- also, by extension, any one in the homologous series of paraffine alcohols of which methyl alcohol is the type.
Consolato del mare: A collection of maritime laws of disputed origin, supposed to have been first published at Barcelona early in the 14th century. It has formed the basis of most of the subsequent collections of maritime laws.
Cyanometer: An instrument for measuring degress of blueness.
Catasterism: A placing among the stars; a catalogue of stars.
Crawler: One who, or that which, crawls; a creeper; a reptile.
Coeval: One of the same age; a contemporary.
Cretaceous: Having the qualities of chalk; abounding with chalk; chalky; as, cretaceous rocks and formations. See Chalk.
Caen stone: A cream-colored limestone for building, found near Caen, France.
Compensate: To make amends; to supply an equivalent; -- followed by for; as, nothing can compensate for the loss of reputation.
Columbus Day: The 12th day of October, on which day in 1492 Christopher Columbus discovered America, landing on one of the Bahama Islands (probably the one now commonly called Watling Island), and naming it “San Salvador”; -- called also Discovery Day. This day is made a legal holiday in many States of The United States.
Candify: To make or become white, or candied.
CRO: acronym for cathode-ray oscilloscope, an electronic device which provides visual images of varying electrical quantities.  See oscilloscope.
Cargoose: A species of grebe (Podiceps crisratus); the crested grebe.
Conflate: To blow together; to bring together; to collect;  to fuse together; to join or weld; to consolidate.
Coronary bone: The small pastern bone of the horse and allied animals.
Conjoin: To unite; to join; to league.
Cliff limestone: A series of limestone strata found in Ohio and farther west, presenting bluffs along the rivers and valleys, formerly supposed to be of one formation, but now known to be partly Silurian and partly Devonian.
Creole State: Louisiana; -- a nickname. See Creole, n. & a.
cloveroot: a hairy Eurasian plant (Geum urbanum) with small yellow flowers and an astringent root formerly used medicinally.
Combustion chamber: A space over, or in front of, a boiler furnace where the gases from the fire become more thoroughly mixed and burnt.
crotal: any of several lichens of the genus Parmelia from which reddish brown or purple dyes are made.
Coquetry: Attempts to attract admiration, notice, or love, for the mere gratification of vanity; trifling in love.
Contriteness: Deep sorrow and penitence for sin; contrition.
Consulship: The office of a consul; consulate.
Clairaudient: One alleged to have the power of clairaudience.
Chaplainship: The office or business of a chaplain.
carangid: any fish of the family Carangidae, including the cavallas, jacks, pompanos and scads.
Centrarchidae: a natural family of fish comprising the sunfishes.  See sunfish.
Chalazogamy: A process of fecundation in which the pollen tube penetrates to the embryosac through the tissue of the chalaza, instead of entering through the micropyle. It was originally discovered by Treub in Casuarina, and has since been found to occur regularly in the families Betulaceæ and Juglandaceæ. Partial chalazogamy is found in Ulmus, the tube here penetrating the nucleus midway between the chalaza and micropyle.
Colutea: small genus of Eurasian shrubs with yellow flowers and bladdery pods.
contemporaries: all the people living at the same time or of approximately the same age.
Cowl: A vessel carried on a pole between two persons, for conveyance of water.
Coccosphere: A small, rounded, marine organism, capable of braking up into coccoliths.
Calycozoa: A group of acalephs of which Lucernaria is the type. The body is cup-shaped with eight marginal lobes bearing clavate tentacles. An aboral sucker serves for attachment. The interior is divided into four large compartments. See Lucernarida.
Cicada: Any species of the genus Cicada or of the family Cicadidae. They are large hemipterous insects, with nearly transparent wings. The male makes a shrill sound by peculiar organs in the under side of the abdomen, consisting of a pair of stretched membranes, acted upon by powerful muscles. A noted American species (Cicada septendecim) is called the seventeen year locust. Another common species is the dogday cicada.
Centennial: The celebration of the hundredth anniversary of any event; a centenary.
Cicerone: One who shows strangers the curiosities of a place; a guide.
Candle: A slender, cylindrical body of tallow, containing a wick composed of loosely twisted linen of cotton threads, and used to furnish light.
Czarinian: Of or pertaining to the czar or the czarina; czarish.
Campus: The principal grounds of a college or school, between the buildings or within the main inclosure; as, the college campus.
Counteractive: One who, or that which, counteracts.
Christ: The Anointed; an appellation given to Jesus, the Savior.  It is synonymous with the Hebrew Messiah.
Celosia: a genus of annual or perennial herbs or vines of tropical and subtropical America and Asia and Africa.
Circumvallation: The act of surrounding with a wall or rampart.
Conglutin: A variety of vegetable casein, resembling legumin, and found in almonds, rye, wheat, etc.
Competently: In a competent manner; adequately; suitably.
Chilopod: A myriapod of the order Chilopoda.
Contrition: The act of grinding or ribbing to powder; attrition; friction; rubbing.
Cerulific: Producing a blue or sky color.
Crouched: Marked with the sign of the cross.
Coctile: Made by baking, or exposing to heat, as a brick.
chalkboard: a dark sheet of slate used as a surface for writing on, with chalk.
Chrysothamnus: a genus of low branching shrubs of West North America.
chastised: having bad behavior criticised and punished; as, the chastised child sat humbly in the corner.
Campanulales: an order of plants which includes the Campanulaceae; Lobeliaceae; Cucurbitaceae; Goodeniaceae; Stylidiaceae; Calyceraceae; and Compositae.
chlamydia: a coccoid rickettsia which may infect birds and mammals; it causes infections of eyes and lungs and the genitourinary tract.
Compile: To put together; to construct; to build.
cacogenics: the study of the operation of factors causing degeneration in the type of offspring produced.
Chowry: A whisk to keep off files, used in the East Indies.
Conchologist: One who studies, or is versed in, conchology.
choirmaster: the musical director of a choir.
Catchup: A pureed table sauce made predominantly from tomatoes, flavored with onions, sugar, salt and spices; called also tomato ketchup. The term is also applied to pureed sauces containing mushrooms, walnuts, etc., being called in such cases mushroom ketchup, walnut ketchup, etc.
Cnida: One of the peculiar stinging cells found in Cœlenterata; a nematocyst; a lasso cell.
Covert: A place that covers and protects; a shelter; a defense.
Clidastes: A genus of extinct marine reptiles, allied to the Mosasaurus. See Illust. in Appendix.
Coadjutorship: The state or office of a coadjutor; joint assistance.
Chess: A species of brome grass (Bromus secalinus) which is a troublesome weed in wheat fields, and is often erroneously regarded as degenerate or changed wheat; it bears a very slight resemblance to oats, and if reaped and ground up with wheat, so as to be used for food, is said to produce narcotic effects; -- called also cheat and Willard's bromus.
Colt revolver: A revolver made according to a system using a patented revolving cylinder, holding six cartridges, patented by Samuel Colt, an American inventor, in 1835. With various modifications, it was for many years been the standard for the United States army.
Cabalistic: Of or pertaining to the cabala; containing or conveying an occult meaning; mystic.
Circuitous: Going round in a circuit; roundabout; indirect; as, a circuitous road; a circuitous manner of accomplishing an end.
Chylifaction: The act or process by which chyle is formed from food in animal bodies; chylification, -- a digestive process.
Coccolite: A granular variety of pyroxene, green or white in color.
Cowled: Wearing a cowl; hooded; as, a cowled monk.
Catlinite: A red clay from the Upper Missouri region, used by the Indians for their pipes.
Consubstantial: Of the same kind or nature; having the same substance or essence; coessential.
Coccolith: One of a kind of minute, calcareous bodies, probably vegetable, often abundant in deep-sea mud.
carsick: feeling nauseous due to the movement of a car or other land vehicle; -- similar to airsick and seasick.
Clavicular: Of or pertaining to the clavicle.
Crossopterygii: An order of ganoid fishes including among living species the bichir (Polypterus). See Brachioganoidei.
Capability: The quality of being capable; capacity; capableness; esp. intellectual power or ability.
Casualism: The doctrine that all things exist or are controlled by chance.
Colugo: A peculiar East Indian mammal (Galleopithecus volans), having along the sides, connecting the fore and hind limbs, a parachutelike membrane, by means of which it is able to make long leaps, like the flying squirrel; -- called also flying lemur.
Catchwater: A ditch or drain for catching water. See Catchdrain.
cultivar: a variety of a plant developed from a natural species and maintained under cultivation.
Chylification: The formation of chyle. See Chylifaction.
Creatic: Relating to, or produced by, flesh or animal food; as, creatic nausea.
Consuetudinary: A manual or ritual of customary devotional exercises.
Creatin: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance found abundantly in muscle tissue.
Constabulary: The collective body of constables in any town, district, or country.
Condignity: Merit, acquired by works, which can claim reward on the score of general benevolence.
clintonomics: the economic policies of president Bill Clinton.
Countermure: To fortify with a wall behind another wall.
Chiromancy: The art or practice of foretelling events, or of telling the fortunes or the disposition of persons by inspecting the hand; palmistry.
Cavy: A rodent of the genera Cavia and Dolichotis, as the guinea pig (Cavia cobaya). Cavies are natives of South America.
candlepower: luminous intensity; illuminating power, as of a lamp, or gas flame, measured in candelas, referring to the light of a standard candle.
crapette: a game in which two play solitaire with separate packs.
Closet: To shut up in, or as in, a closet; to conceal.
Chattiness: The quality of being chatty, or of talking easily and pleasantly.
clipped: trimmed with clippers; as, a clipped hedge.
coattails: the influence of another person; the effect of association with another person; as, he was elected to office on the president's coattails.
Cestoidea: A class of parasitic worms of the phylum Platyhelminthes (formerly Platelminthes) of which the tapeworms are the most common examples.  The body is flattened, and usually but not always long, and composed of numerous joints or segments, each of which may contain a complete set of male and female reproductive organs. They have neither mouth nor intestine. See Tapeworm.
Connaturalize: To bring to the same nature as something else; to adapt.
Comicry: The power of exciting mirth; comicalness.
cedar: The name of several evergreen trees.  The wood is remarkable for its durability and fragrant odor.
Cr\u00e9dit mobilier: A joint stock company, formed for general banking business, or for the construction of public works, by means of loans on personal estate, after the manner of the crédit foncier on real estate. In practice, however, this distinction has not been strictly observed.
Chiton: An under garment among the ancient Greeks, nearly representing the modern shirt.
Cr\u00e9maill\u00e8re: An indented or zigzaged line of intrenchment.
Creek: A small inlet or bay, narrower and extending further into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea, or of a river.
Crees: An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part of British America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson's Bay.
Creep: The act or process of creeping.
Cebu: one of the Visayan islands of the central Philippines, important for its fine harbor.
Confabulation: Familiar talk; easy, unrestrained, unceremonious conversation.
Chalcidian: One of a tropical family of snakelike lizards (Chalcidæ), having four small or rudimentary legs.
Coleridgian: Pertaining to Samuel Taylor Coleridge, or to his poetry or metaphysics.
Centropomidae: a natural family of fishes comprising the robalos (also called snooks).
Conversive: Capable of being converted or changed.
CNS: acronym for central nervous system the portion of the vertebrate nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord.
Commerce destroyer: A very fast, unarmored, lightly armed vessel designed to capture or destroy merchant vessels of an enemy. Not being intended to fight, they may be improvised from fast passenger steamers.
collaborative: accomplished by collaboration; cooperative; as, collaborative effort of industry and the universities.  Opposed to competitive.
Crudeness: A crude, undigested, or unprepared state; rawness; unripeness; immatureness; unfitness for a destined use or purpose; as, the crudeness of iron ore; crudeness of theories or plans.
Causerie: Informal talk or discussion, as about literary matters; light conversation; chat.
Cynoidea: A division of Carnivora, including the dogs, wolves, and foxes.
Cannabidaceae: a grouping of plants containing two genera of erect or twining wind-pollinated herbs, the genera Cannabis and Humulus; this term is not used in all classifications; in some the genus Cannabis is placed in the family Moraceae and the genus Humulus in the family Urticaceae.
Centime: The hundredth part of a franc; a small French copper coin and money of account.
Courap: A skin disease, common in India, in which there is perpetual itching and eruption, esp. of the groin, breast, armpits, and face.
Cremator: One who, or that which, cremates or consumes to ashes.
Conch: A name applied to various marine univalve shells; esp. to those of the genus Strombus, which are of large size. Strombus gigas is the large pink West Indian conch.  The large king, queen, and cameo conchs are of the genus Cassis. See Cameo and cameo conch.
cube-shaped: Shaped like or approximately like a cube.
Cantonment: A town or village, or part of a town or village, assigned to a body of troops for quarters; temporary shelter or place of rest for an army; quarters.
Castile soap: A kind of fine, hard, white or mottled soap, made with olive oil and soda; also, a soap made in imitation of the above-described soap.
Caviling: Disposed to cavil; finding fault without good reason. See Captious.
Coccyx: The end of the vertebral column beyond the sacrum in man and tailless monkeys. It is composed of several vertebræ more or less consolidated.
Commixture: The act or process of mixing; the state of being mingled; the blending of ingredients in one mass or compound.
Collenchyma: A tissue of vegetable cells which are thickend at the angles and (usually) elongated.
Cagot: One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until 1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They are supposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.
Comminution: The act of reducing to a fine powder or to small particles; pulverization; the state of being comminuted.
Centrostaltic: A term applied to the action of nerve force in the spinal center.
Crinum: A genus of bulbous plants, of the order Amaryllidaceæ, cultivated as greenhouse plants on account of their beauty.
Chebacco: A narrow-sterned boat formerly much used in the Newfoundland fisheries; -- called also pinkstern and chebec.
Craftsman: One skilled in some trade or manual occupation; an artificer; a mechanic.
Chreotechnics: The science of the useful arts, esp. agriculture, manufactures, and commerce.
cortico-hypothalamic: of or relating to the cortex and the hypothalamus.
Clinidae: a natural family of viviparous blennies of temperate and tropical seas.
Covariant: A function involving the coefficients and the variables of a quantic, and such that when the quantic is lineally transformed the same function of the new variables and coefficients shall be equal to the old function multiplied by a factor. An invariant is a like function involving only the coefficients of the quantic.
Creviced: Having a crevice or crevices; as, a creviced structure for storing ears of corn.
Cancrine: Having the qualities of a crab; crablike.
Cuir bouilli: In decorative art, boiled leather, fitted by the process to receive impressed patterns, like those produced by chasing metal, and to retain the impression permanently.
Coarsen: To make coarse or vulgar; as, to coarsen one's character.
Crammer: One who crams; esp., one who prepares a pupil hastily for an examination, or a pupil who is thus prepared.
Colorist: One who colors; an artist who excels in the use of colors; one to whom coloring is of prime importance.
Crookes tube: A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very high degree, with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- so called from W. Crookes who introduced it.
Crossroad: A road that crosses another; an obscure road intersecting or avoiding the main road.
Coarse-grained: Having a coarse grain or texture, as wood; hence, wanting in refinement.
Chela: In India, a dependent person occupying a position between that of a servant or slave and a disciple; hence, a disciple or novice.
Cheval-de-frise: A piece of timber or an iron barrel traversed with iron-pointed spikes or spears, five or six feet long, used to defend a passage, stop a breach, or impede the advance of cavalry, etc.
Cartman: One who drives or uses a cart; a teamster; a carter.
Conciliar: Of or pertaining to, or issued by, a council.
Corniculum: A small hornlike part or process.
Colocynthin: The active medicinal principle of colocynth; a bitter, yellow, crystalline substance, regarded as a glucoside.
Consumptively: In a way tending to or indication consumption.
Coronium: The principal gaseous substance forming the solar corona, characterized by a green line in the coronal spectrum.
Chateau-Thierry: a World War I battle in northwestern France where the Allies defeated the Germans in 1918.
Cooky: A small, flat, sweetened cake of various kinds.
Conclusiveness: The quality of being conclusive; decisiveness.
Chaffer: To buy or sell; to trade in.
chained: bound with chains; as, prisoners chained together to prevent escape.
Citicism: The manners of a cit or citizen.
Clayey: Consisting of clay; abounding with clay; partaking of clay; like clay.
Clement: Mild in temper and disposition; merciful; compassionate.
Caster: One who casts; as, caster of stones, etc. ; a caster of cannon; a caster of accounts.
Cross-spale: One of the temporary wooden braces, placed horizontally across a frame to hold it in position until the deck beams are in; a cross-pawl.
Corbel-table: A horizontal row of corbels, with the panels or filling between them; also, less properly used to include the stringcourse on them.
Commutation: A passing from one state to another; change; alteration; mutation.
Calambour: A species of agalloch, or aloes wood, of a dusky or mottled color, of a light, friable texture, and less fragrant than calambac; -- used by cabinetmakers.
Ch\u00e6tetes: A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurian limestones.
Calamist: One who plays upon a reed or pipe.
Credibleness: The quality or state of being credible; worthiness of belief; credibility.
Couscous: A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa, made of millet flour with flesh, and leaves of the baobab; -- called also lalo.
Clinical: Of or pertaining to a bed, especially, a sick bed.
Croylstone: Crystallized cawk, in which the crystals are small.
Converse: A proposition which arises from interchanging the terms of another, as by putting the predicate for the subject, and the subject for the predicate; as, no virtue is vice, no vice is virtue.
Coprolite: A piece of petrified dung; a fossil excrement.
Cheerfulness: Good spirits; a state of moderate joy or gayety; alacrity.
Cooncan: A game of cards derived from conquian, played by two or more players with one or two full packs of cards.
Coccinella: A genus of small beetles of many species. They and their larvæ feed on aphids or plant lice, and hence are of great benefit to man. Also called ladybirds and ladybugs.
colonized: inhabited by people who were born in or retain strong ties to another country.
Commentatorial: Pertaining to the making of commentaries.
cyclide: A surface of the fourth degree, having certain special relations to spherical surfaces. The tore or anchor ring is one of the cyclides.
Chronometer: An instrument for measuring time; a timekeeper.
Calochortus: large genus of West North American leafy-stemmed bulbous herbs.
Context: To knit or bind together; to unite closely.
Cyanide: A compound formed by the union of cyanogen with an element or radical.
Congressman: A member of the Congress of the United States, esp. of the House of Representatives.
Cultirostral: Having a bill shaped like the colter of a plow, or like a knife, as the heron, stork, etc.
carcinogenic: Causing or tending to cause cancer; as, the carcinogenic action of certain chemicals or of ionizing radiation.
Coindication: One of several signs or symptoms indicating the same fact; as, a coindication of disease.
Canonistic: Of or pertaining to a canonist.
Cathetometer: An instrument for the accurate measurement of small differences of height; esp. of the differences in the height of the upper surfaces of two columns of mercury or other fluid, or of the same column at different times. It consists of a telescopic leveling apparatus (d), which slides up or down a perpendicular metallic standard very finely graduated (bb). The telescope is raised or depressed in order to sight the objects or surfaces, and the differences in vertical height are thus shown on the graduated standard.
California jack: A game at cards, a modification of seven-up, or all fours.
Clysmian: Connected with, or related to, the deluge, or to a cataclysm; as, clysmian changes.
Cockchafer: A beetle of the genus Melolontha (esp. Melolontha vulgaris) and allied genera; -- called also May bug, chafer, or dorbeetle.
Concessive: Implying concession; as, a concessive conjunction.
Critique: To criticise or pass judgment upon.
Corymbiferous: Bearing corymbs of flowers or fruit.
Centrolineal: Converging to a center; -- applied to lines drawn so as to meet in a point or center.
Craniometry: The art or act of measuring skulls.
Cinerescent: Somewhat cinereous; of a color somewhat resembling that of wood ashes.
Compression: The act of compressing, or state of being compressed.
Chambray: A gingham woven in plain colors with linen finish.
Crossette: A return in one of the corners of the architrave of a door or window; -- called also ancon, ear, elbow.
Coppice: To cause to grow in the form of a coppice; to cut back (as young timber) so as to produce shoots from stools or roots.
Cheeseparing: A thin portion of the rind of a cheese.
Cannular: Having the form of a tube; tubular.
Cancelier: The turn of a hawk upon the wing to recover herself, when she misses her aim in the stoop.
Commemorate: To call to remembrance by a special act or observance; to celebrate with honor and solemnity; to honor, as a person or event, by some act of respect or affection, intended to preserve the remembrance of the person or event; as, to commemorate the sufferings and dying love of our Savior by the sacrament of the Lord's Supper; to commemorate the Declaration of Independence by the observance of the Fourth of July.
Consignify: To signify or denote in combination with something else.
Carus: Coma with complete insensibility; deep lethargy.
Chaldrich: A kind of bird; the oyster catcher.
Corneous: Of a texture resembling horn; horny; hard.
Cerinthian: One of an ancient religious sect, so called from Cerinthus, a Jew, who attempted to unite the doctrines of Christ with the opinions of the Jews and Gnostics.
Cirripedia: An order of Crustacea including the barnacles. When adult, they have a calcareous shell composed of several pieces. From the opening of the shell the animal throws out a group of curved legs, looking like a delicate curl, whence the name of the group. See Anatifa.
Criminate: To accuse of, or charge with, a crime.
Cogent: Compelling, in a physical sense; powerful.
closeup: a photograph or other recorded image taken at close range, or using a telephoto lens so as to appear to have been taken at close range; -- used especially of images of faces in which the face fills all or most of the photograph.
Chorepiscopus: A “country” or suffragan bishop, appointed in the ancient church by a diocesan bishop to exercise episcopal jurisdiction in a rural district.
Czechoslovakian: a native or inhabitant of Czechoslovakia.
Captainry: Power, or command, over a certain district; chieftainship.
Cm: the chemical symbol for the element curium.
Catalogize: To insert in a catalogue; to register; to catalogue.
Catastasis: That part of a speech, usually the exordium, in which the orator sets forth the subject matter to be discussed.
Cordelier: A Franciscan; -- so called in France from the girdle of knotted cord worn by all Franciscans.
Cicisbeo: A professed admirer of a married woman; a dangler about women.
campanular: shaped like a bell or campana; campaniform.
counterblast: a vigorous and unrestrained verbal response; as, her tirade provoked a counterblast from her husband.
chew: To bite and grind with the teeth; to masticate.
Croconic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling saffron; having the color of saffron; as, croconic acid.
Cacotechny: A corruption or corrupt state of art.
Coloradan: a resident of the state of Colorado.
Chicory: A branching perennial plant (Cichorium Intybus) with bright blue flowers, growing wild in Europe, Asia, and America; also cultivated for its roots and as a salad plant; succory; wild endive. See Endive.
Chronoscope: An instrument for measuring minute intervals of time; used in determining the velocity of projectiles, the duration of short-lived luminous phenomena, etc.
Ce: the chemical symbol for cerium, the most abundant element of the rare-earth group.
Cavin: A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate their aproach to a place.
Cantoon: A cotton stuff showing a fine cord on one side and a satiny surface on the other.
Coomb: A hollow in a hillside. [Prov. Eng.] See Comb, Combe.
colonialist: a believer in or advocate of colonialism{3}.
callowness: having a lack of experience of life.
candymaker: someone who makes candies and other sweets.
Counterclaim: A claim made by a person as an offset to a claim made on him.
Catgut: A cord of great toughness made from the intestines of animals, esp. of sheep, used for strings of musical instruments, etc.
CSA: acronym for the Confederate States of America.
Carcajou: The wolverene; -- also applied, but erroneously, to the Canada lynx, and sometimes to the American badger. See Wolverene.
Cabe\u00e7a: The finest kind of silk received from India.
Corrugation: The act corrugating; contraction into wrinkles or alternate ridges and grooves.
Countervail: Power or value sufficient to obviate any effect; equal weight, strength, or value; equivalent; compensation; requital.
Cringeling: One who cringes meanly; a fawner.
Constellation: A cluster or group of fixed stars, or division of the heavens, designated in most cases by the name of some animal, or of some mythologial personage, within whose imaginary outline, as traced upon the heavens, the group is included.
Contrive: To make devices; to form designs; to plan; to scheme; to plot.
Catso: A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat.
cross-pollination: fertilization by transfer of pollen from the anthers of one flower to the stigma of another.
Chloroxylon: a genus of deciduous trees of India and Sri Lanka.
Countrify: To give a rural appearance to; to cause to appear rustic.
Castoroides: a genus of extinct beavers of the Pleistocene; of eastern and southern U.S.
Convenance: That which is suitable, agreeable, or convenient.
Configure: To arrange or dispose in a certain form, figure, or shape.
choosey: difficult to please, especially in details.
Cuspid: One of the canine teeth; -- so called from having but one point or cusp on the crown. See Tooth.
Compass: To go about or entirely round; to make the circuit of.
chlorpromazine: a drug derived from phenothiazine and used as a sedative and tranquilizer.
Consort: To unite or join, as in affection, harmony, company, marriage, etc.; to associate.
Chianti: a dry red Italian table wine from the Chianti region of Tuscany.
Culminant: Being vertical, or at the highest point of altitude; hence, predominant.
Caramel: Burnt sugar; a brown or black porous substance obtained by heating sugar. It is soluble in water, and is used for coloring spirits, gravies, etc.
Chronicler: A writer of a chronicle; a recorder of events in the order of time; an historian.
Cantoned: Having a charge in each of the four corners; -- said of a cross on a shield, and also of the shield itself.
Crossflow: To flow across, or in a contrary direction.
Cohosh: A perennial American herb (Caulophyllum thalictroides), whose rootstock is used in medicine; -- also called pappoose root. The name is sometimes also given to the Cimicifuga racemosa, and to two species of Actæa, plants of the Crowfoot family.
Cinquecentist: An Italian of the sixteenth century, esp. a poet or artist.
Conominee: One nominated in conjunction with another; a joint nominee.
Court-craft: The artifices, intrigues, and plottings, at courts.
Centuplicate: To make a hundredfold; to repeat a hundred times.
Chloropal: A massive mineral, greenish in color, and opal-like in appearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.
Cosmetic: Any external application intended to beautify and improve the complexion.
Convertibleness: The state of being convertible; convertibility.
Castigatory: An instrument formerly used to punish and correct arrant scolds; -- called also a ducking stool, or trebucket.
Camphine: Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and as a common solvent in varnishes.
candlewood: any of several resinous trees or shrubs often burned for light.
Convulsion: An unnatural, violent, and unvoluntary contraction of the muscular parts of an animal body.
costusroot: an annual herb (Saussurea costus) of the eastern Himalayas (Kashmir) having purple florets and a fragrant root that yields a volatile oil used in perfumery and for preserving furs.
Capital: Of or pertaining to the head.
Cubilose: A mucilagenous secretion of certain birds found as the characteristic ingredient of edible bird's-nests.
Casuarius: the type and sole genus of the Casuaridae; the cassowaries.
Cervicide: The act of killing deer; deer-slaying.
conditioner: exercise that conditions the body; as, farmwork can be a good conditioner.
Ca\u00efque: A light skiff or rowboat used on the Bosporus; also, a Levantine vessel of larger size.
Corallian: A deposit of coralliferous limestone forming a portion of the middle division of the oölite; -- called also coral-rag.
Cachinnation: Loud or immoderate laughter; -- often a symptom of hysterical or maniacal affections.
Cloche: An apparatus used in controlling certain kinds of aëroplanes, and consisting principally of a steering column mounted with a universal joint at the base, which is bellshaped and has attached to it the cables for controlling the wing-warping devices, elevator planes, and the like.
Cream-slice: A wooden knife with a long thin blade, used in handling cream or ice cream.
Countryside: A particular rural district; a country neighborhood.
Columella: An axis to which a carpel of a compound pistil may be attached, as in the case of the geranium; or which is left when a pod opens.
Candle meter: The illumination given by a standard candle at a distance of one meter; -- used as a unit of illumination, except in Great Britain.
Chatoyant: A hard stone, as the cat's-eye, which presents on a polished surface, and in the interior, an undulating or wary light.
Calculated: Worked out by calculation; as calculated tables for computing interest; ascertained or conjectured as a result of calculation; as, the calculated place of a planet; the calculated velocity of a cannon ball.
Crocetin: A dyestuff, obtained from the Chinese crocin, which produces a brilliant yellow.
Carminative: A substance, esp. an aromatic, which tends to expel wind from the alimentary canal, or to relieve colic, griping, or flatulence.
Covin: A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudice a third.
Carousingly: In the manner of a carouser.
Causewayed: Having a raised way (causeway or causey); paved.
customs: money collected under a tariff; a duty imposed on imported goods.
Confirmation: The act of confirming or strengthening; the act of establishing, ratifying, or sanctioning; as, the confirmation of an appointment.
Commissure: A joint, seam, or closure; the place where two bodies, or parts of a body, meet and unite; an interstice, cleft, or juncture.
Carlot: A churl; a boor; a peasant or countryman.
Contemn: To view or treat with contempt, as mean and despicable; to reject with disdain; to despise; to scorn.
Clientship: Condition of a client; state of being under the protection of a patron.
chromatogram: the paper strip, column, gel, or TLC plate on which subsances have been separated by a process of chromatography{2}.
cosmonaut: an astronaut; -- a term used by the Soviets and Russians.
Catchfly: A plant with the joints of the stem, and sometimes other parts, covered with a viscid secretion to which small insects adhere. The species of Silene are examples of the catchfly.
Colloidality: The state or quality of being colloidal.
Chlorura: one of the genera of birds which comprise the towhees.
Chime: To cause to sound in harmony; to play a tune, as upon a set of bells; to move or strike in harmony.
Chelura: A genus of marine amphipod crustacea, which bore into and sometimes destroy timber.
Capitolian: Of or pertaining to the Capitol in Rome.
Caudicle: A slender, elastic process, to which the masses of pollen in orchidaceous plants are attached.
Colonial: Of or pertaining to a colony; as, colonial rights, traffic, wars.
Camerate: To build in the form of a vault; to arch over.
Catholicly: In a catholic manner; generally; universally.
Cymatium: A capping or crowning molding in classic architecture.
Cupressus: one of the genera of cypress trees, the type genus of the Cupressaceae.
checkout counter: a counter in a supermarket where you pay for your purchases.
Chelidonium: a genu having only one species; the greater celandine.
Callionymidae: a natural family comprising the dragonets.
Consolation game: A game, match, etc., open only to losers in early stages of contests.
Chelidonius: A small stone taken from the gizzard of a young swallow. -- anciently worn as a medicinal charm.
clanger: A conspicuous mistake whose effects seem to reverberate; as, he dropped a clanger.
caesarean section: the operation of taking a child from the womb by cutting through the walls of the abdomen and uterus; -- so called because Julius Cæsar is reported to have been brought into the world by such an operation; -- called also caesarean.
Cautery: A burning or searing, as of morbid flesh, with a hot iron, or by application of a caustic that will burn, corrode, or destroy animal tissue.
Cenobitism: The state of being a cenobite; the belief or practice of a cenobite.
Carcel: A light standard much used in France, being the light from a Carcel lamp of stated size and construction consuming 42 grams of colza oil per hour with a flame 40 millimeters in height. Its illuminating power is variously stated at from 8.9 to 9.6 British standard candles.
Control: To check by a counter register or duplicate account; to prove by counter statements; to confute.
Corneule: One of the corneas of a compound eye in the invertebrates.
Citizenship: The state of being a citizen; the status of a citizen.
classified: arranged into classes or categories; as, unclassified.
Cannoneer: A man who manages, or fires, cannon.
Countercharm: That which has the power of destroying the effect of a charm.
catabolic: Of or pertaining to catabolism; as, catabolic processes, which give rise to substances (katastates) of decreasing complexity and increasing stability.
Camassia: a genus of scapose herbs of North and South America having large edible bulbs.
Cacolet: A chair, litter, or other contrivance fitted to the back or pack saddle of a mule for carrying travelers in mountainous districts, or for the transportation of the sick and wounded of an army.
Cast iron: Highly carbonized iron, the direct product of the blast furnace; -- used for making castings, and for conversion into wrought iron and steel. It can not be welded or forged, is brittle, and sometimes very hard. Besides carbon, it contains sulphur, phosphorus, silica, etc.
Checkwork: Anything made so as to form alternate squares like those of a checkerboard.
Canary: To perform the canary dance; to move nimbly; to caper.
Cyclone: A violent storm, often of vast extent, characterized by high winds rotating about a calm center of low atmospheric pressure. This center moves onward, often with a velocity of twenty or thirty miles an hour.
Cephalosporin: any of a class of chemical substances, some of which have therapeutically useful antibacterial activity, whose structure contains a beta-lactam ring fused to a six-membered ring containing a sulfur and a nitrogen atom.  The first of the series, cephalosporin C, was discovered by G. Brotzu in 1955 in the culture broth of a Cephalosporium species found off the coast of Sardinia.  Other cephalosporins have been found to be produced by species of soil bacteria (actinomycetes).  Many semisynthetic analogs have been tested for antibacterial effect, and several of them have found use as important clinically useful antibacterial agents, some of which may be taken orally for treatment of bacterial infections.  The cephalosporins are the second class of beta-lactam antibiotic to be discovered, the first being the penicillins and more recent classes being the thienamycins and sulfazecins.  The cephamycins are a variant of cephalosporins with a methoxyl group on the beta-lactam ring, rendering them more resistant to penicillinases.  Among the cephalosporins which have been found clinically useful are cephalexin, cephaloridine, and cephalothin.
Cecropiaceae: A natural family of insects, in some classifications included in family Moraceae.
Choicely: With care in choosing; with nice regard to preference.
Cereal: Any grass cultivated for its edible grain, or the grain itself; -- usually in the plural.
Completement: Act of completing or perfecting; completion.
Clasper: One who, or that which, clasps, as a tendril.
Cloisonn\u00e9: Inlaid between partitions: -- said of enamel when the lines which divide the different patches of fields are composed of a kind of metal wire secured to the ground; as distinguished from champlevé enamel, in which the ground is engraved or scooped out to receive the enamel.
coldhearted: Wanting passion or feeling or emotional warmth; indifferent.
Carpolite: A general term for a fossil fruit, nut, or seed.
Catholicity: The state or quality of being catholic; universality.
Contradictoriness: The quality of being contradictory; opposition; inconsistency.
certified: endorsed authoritatively as having met certain requirements; guranteed; as, certified milk; certified mail; a certified check.  Opposite of uncertified.
Connotation: The act of connoting; a making known or designating something additional; implication of something more than is asserted.
Correctional: Tending to, or intended for, correction; used for correction; as, a correctional institution.
Contributory: One who contributes, or is liable to be called upon to contribute, as toward the discharge of a common indebtedness.
Ctenoid: Having a comblike margin, as a ctenoid scale
Cerotype: A printing process of engraving on a surface of wax spread on a steel plate, for electrotyping.
Christcross-row: The alphabet; -- formerly so called, either from the cross usually set before it, or from a superstitious custom, sometimes practiced, of writing it in the form of a cross, by way of a charm.
Cheiropterous: chiropterous; belonging to the Chiroptera, or Bat family.
Cooper: To do the work of a cooper upon; as, to cooper a cask or barrel.
Carbon steel: Steel deriving its qualities from carbon chiefly, without the presence of other alloying elements; -- opposed to alloy steel.
Cornin: A bitter principle obtained from dogwood (Cornus florida), as a white crystalline substance; -- called also cornic acid.
Celt: A weapon or implement of stone or metal, found in the tumuli, or barrows, of the early Celtic nations.
Conjuror: One bound by a common oath with others.
crooning: singing in a soft low tone; as, her crooning soon put the child to sleep.
Cell: To place or inclose in a cell.
Czechic: Of or pertaining to the Czechs.
Cockyolly: A pet name for any small bird.
Cytococcus: The nucleus of the cytula or parent cell.
centrifuge: to drive out; to subject to the action of a centrifuge.
Contravene: To meet in the way of opposition; to come into conflict with; to oppose; to contradict; to obstruct the operation of; to defeat.
Cramponee: Having a cramp or square piece at the end; -- said of a cross so furnished.
Cornetcy: The commission or rank of a cornet.
coccidioidomycosis: a disease of the lungs and skin characterized by excessive sputum and nodules.
Clang: A loud, ringing sound, like that made by metallic substances when clanged or struck together.
Catelectrotonic: Relating to, or characterized by, catelectrotonus.
C\u0153lodont: Having hollow teeth; -- said of a group lizards.
Contagious disease: A disease communicable by contact with a patient suffering from it, or with some secretion of, or object touched by, such a patient. Most such diseases have already been proved to be germ diseases, and their communicability depends on the transmission of the living germs.  Many germ diseases are not contagious, some special method of transmission or inoculation of the germs being required.
Cadenza: A parenthetic flourish or flight of ornament in the course of a piece, commonly just before the final cadence.
Chaperonage: Attendance of a chaperon on a lady in public; protection afforded by a chaperon.
Census: A numbering of the people, and valuation of their estate, for the purpose of imposing taxes, etc.; -- usually made once in five years.
Chamfer: The surface formed by cutting away the arris, or angle, formed by two faces of a piece of timber, stone, etc.
Cornic: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, the dogwood (Cornus florida).
Choking coil: A coil of small resistance and large inductance, used in an alternating-current circuit to impede or throttle the current, or to change its phase; -- called also reactance coil or reactor, these terms being now preferred in engineering usage.
Croupier: One who presides at a gaming table and collects the stakes.
Corncrake: A bird (Crex crex or Crex pratensis) which frequents grain fields; the European crake or land rail; -- called also corn bird.
Coreidae: a natural family containing the squash bugs and leaf-footed bugs.
Cagit: A kind of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in the Philippine Islands.
coldcock: to to knock to the ground with force.
Cookmaid: A female servant or maid who dresses provisions and assists the cook.
Cytogenesis: Development of cells in animal and vegetable organisms. See Gemmation, Budding, Karyokinesis; also Cell development, under Cell.
Circinate: To make a circle around; to encompass.
Contusion: The act or process of beating, bruising, or pounding; the state of being beaten or bruised.
Cornloft: A loft for corn; a granary.
Clinodiagonal: That diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal which makes an oblique angle with the vertical axis. See Crystallization.
Copperhead: A poisonous American serpent (Ancistrodon conotortrix), closely allied to the rattlesnake, but without rattles; -- called also copper-belly, and red viper.
Crax: the type genus of the Cracidae; curassows.
Correct: To make right; to bring to the standard of truth, justice, or propriety; to rectify; as, to correct manners or principles.
Carburet: To combine or to impregnate with carbon, as by passing through or over a liquid hydrocarbon; to carbonize or carburize.
Christian: Pertaining to Christ or his religion; as, Christian people.
Concrete: To form into a mass, as by the cohesion or coalescence of separate particles.
Cantharis: A beetle (Lytta  vesicatoria, syn. Cantharis vesicatoria), having an elongated cylindrical body of a brilliant green color, and a nauseous odor; the blister fly or blister beetle, of the apothecary; -- also called Spanish fly. Many other species of Lytta, used for the same purpose, take the same name. See Blister beetle, under Blister. The plural form in usually applied to the dried insects used in medicine.
Clergical: Of or pertaining to the clergy; clerical; clerkily; learned.
Cranked: Formed with, or having, a bend or crank; as, a cranked axle.
Clevis: A piece of metal bent in the form of an oxbow, with the two ends perforated to receive a pin, used on the end of the tongue of a plow, wagen, etc., to attach it to a draft chain, whiffletree, etc.; -- called also clavel, clevy.
Coexist: To exist at the same time; -- sometimes followed by with.
Chloralamide: A compound of chloral and formic amide used to produce sleep.
Criminous: Criminal; involving great crime or grave charges; very wicked; heinous.
Cocciferous: Bearing or producing berries; bacciferous; as, cocciferous trees or plants.
Cup-gall: A kind of oak-leaf gall. See Gall.
Caimacam: The governor of a sanjak or district in Turkey.
Circumjacence: Condition of being circumjacent, or of bordering on every side.
Chylaceous: Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.
Coleopteran: One of the order of Coleoptera.
Coleopteral: Having wings covered with a case or sheath; belonging to the Coleoptera.
Confuse: To mix or blend so that things can not be distinguished; to jumble together; to confound; to render indistinct or obscure; as, to confuse accounts; to confuse one's vision.
Cancellous: Having a spongy or porous structure; made up of cancelli; cancellated; as, the cancellous texture of parts of many bones.
Chronology: The science which treats of measuring time by regular divisions or periods, and which assigns to events or transactions their proper dates.
Coyotillo: A low rhamnaceous shrub (Karwinskia humboldtiana) of the southwestern United States and Mexico. Its berries are said to be poisonous to the coyote.
Calefaction: The act of warming or heating; the production of heat in a body by the action of fire, or by communication of heat from other bodies.
Cosmosphere: An apparatus for showing the position of the earth, at any given time, with respect to the fixed stars. It consist of a hollow glass globe, on which are depicted the stars and constellations, and within which is a terrestrial globe.
Contractile: tending to contract; having the power or property of contracting, or of shrinking into shorter or smaller dimensions; as, the contractile tissues.
Chieftaincy: The rank, dignity, or office of a chieftain.
Cumbrous: Rendering action or motion difficult or toilsome; serving to obstruct or hinder; burdensome; clogging.
Consociation: Intimate union; fellowship; alliance; companionship; confederation; association; intimacy.
Casse-t\u00eate: A small war club, esp. of savages; -- so called because of its supposed use in crushing the skull.
Casus: An event; an occurrence; an occasion; a combination of circumstances; a case; an act of God. See the Note under Accident.
crape jasmine: a tropical shrub (Tabernaemontana divaricata), native to India, having glossy foliage and fragrant nocturnal flowers with crimped or wavy corollas; Northern India to Thailand.
Countenancer: One who countenances, favors, or supports.
Cheap-jack: A seller of low-priced, shoddy, or second goods; a hawker.
Countermand: A contrary order; revocation of a former order or command.
Castor oil: A mild cathartic oil, expressed or extracted from the seeds of the Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi. When fresh the oil is inodorous and insipid.
Contingent: An event which may or may not happen; that which is unforeseen, undetermined, or dependent on something future; a contingency.
countersignature: a second confirming signature endorsing a document already signed.
Church-bench: A seat in the porch of a church.
Croise: A pilgrim bearing or wearing a cross.
chanar: a thorny shrub or small tree (Geoffroea decorticans) common in central Argentina having small orange or yellow flowers followed by edible berries.
Complexionary: Pertaining to the complexion, or to the care of it.
Cautionary block: A block in which two or more trains are permitted to travel, under restrictions imposed by a caution card or the like.
Centropomus: the type genus of the Centropomidae, comprising the snooks, and including Centropomus undecimalis, a large bony sport fish also esteemed as food.
Coulombs law: The law that the force exerted between two electric or magnetic charges is directly proportional to the product of the charges and inversely to the square of the distance between them.
closed-minded: not ready to receive new ideas.
Capacitate: To render capable; to enable; to qualify.
Cach\u00e6mia: A degenerated or poisoned condition of the blood.
Corsage: The waist or bodice of a lady's dress; as, a low corsage.
Caseation: A degeneration of animal tissue into a cheesy or curdy mass.
Crime: Any violation of law, either divine or human; an omission of a duty commanded, or the commission of an act forbidden by law.
Consciously: In a conscious manner; with knowledge of one's own mental operations or actions.
Candleholder: One who, or that which, holds a candle; also, one who assists another, but is otherwise not of importance.
Carafe: A glass water bottle for the table or toilet; -- called also croft.
Contemperation: The act of tempering or moderating.
Cultriform: Shaped like a pruning knife; cultrate.
Cardiosphygmograph: A combination of cardiograph and sphygmograph.
Cosmically: With the sun at rising or setting; as, a star is said to rise or set cosmically when it rises or sets with the sun.
Caracal: A lynx (Felis caracal syn. Lynx caracal).  It is a native of Africa and Asia.  Its ears are black externally, and tipped with long black hairs.
Contopus: a genus of birds comprised of pewees, and including the wood pewees Contopus sordidulus and Contopus virens.
Cystine: A white crystalline substance, C3H7NSO2, containing sulphur, occuring as a constituent of certain rare urinary calculi, and occasionally found as a sediment in urine.
Clearness: The quality or state of being clear.
centrolinead: An instrument for drawing lines through a point, or lines converging to a center.
Carse: Low, fertile land; a river valley.
Clamatorial: Like or pertaining to the Clamatores.
Comprehensive: Including much; comprising many things; having a wide scope or a full view.
cross-eye: convergent strabismus; a disorder in which one or both eyes turn inward toward the nose rather than directly at the object of vision; crossed eyes.
Coadunate: United at the base, as contiguous lobes of a leaf.
Crossbowman: One who shoots with a crossbow. See Arbalest.
Cleridae: a natural family of beetles that prey on other insects.
Costotome: An instrument (chisel or shears) to cut the ribs and open the thoracic cavity, in post-mortem examinations and dissections.
Claribella: A soft, sweet stop, or set of open wood pipes in an organ.
Cough: A sudden, noisy, and violent expulsion of air from the chest, caused by irritation in the air passages, or by the reflex action of nervous or gastric disorder, etc.
Cecidomyia: A genus of small dipterous files, including several very injurious species, as the Hessian fly. See Hessian fly.
Creamcake: A kind of cake filled with custard made of cream, eggs, etc.
Centare: A measure of area, the hundredth part of an are; one square meter, or about 11/5 square yards.
Civily: In a civil manner; as regards civil rights and privileges; politely; courteously; in a well bred manner.
Cynodon: a genus of creeping perennial grasses of tropical and southern Africa.
Chalazion: A small circumscribed tumor of the eyelid caused by retention of secretion, and by inflammation of the Melbomian glands.
Conversationism: A word or phrase used in conversation; a colloquialism.
corporate raider: a person who purchases or attempts to purchase a controlling interest in a publicly-traded company against the wishes of the current management.
Commination: A threat or threatening; a denunciation of punishment or vengeance.
Color-blind: Affected with color blindness. See Color blindness, under Color, n.
caballine: Of or pertaining to a horse.
Cutworm: A caterpillar which at night eats off young plants of cabbage, corn, etc., usually at the ground. Some kinds ascend fruit trees and eat off the flower buds. During the day, they conceal themselves in the earth. The common cutworms are the larvæ of various species of Agrotis and related genera of noctuid moths.
Conatus: A natural tendency inherent in a body to develop itself; an attempt; an effort.
Convey: To play the thief; to steal.
Corocore: A kind of boat of various forms, used in the Indian Archipelago.
Cokes: A simpleton; a gull; a dupe.
Clerical: Of or pertaining to the clergy; suitable for the clergy.
Crizzel: A kind of roughness on the surface of glass, which clouds its transparency.
chiroptera: an ancient order of mammalia dating to the early Eocene, including the bats. They are nocturnal mouselike mammals having four toes of each of the anterior limbs elongated and connected by a web, so that they form membranous wings that can be used in flying.  They also have anatomical adaptations, including large ears, for echolocation, by which they navigate and in some cases find insects.  The order includes the suborders Megachiroptera (the fruit bats) and Microchiroptera (insectivorous bats). See Bat.  Previously spelled cheiroptera.
condescending: exhibiting an attitude of superiority; patronizing; -- used of behavior or attitude.
Czarowitz: The title of the eldest son of the czar of Russia.
Confessionalist: A priest hearing, or sitting to hear, confession.
Compliment: To pass compliments; to use conventional expressions of respect.
companionway: a stairway or ladder that leads from one deck to another on a ship.
Carbonated: Combined or impregnated with carbonic acid.
Corbel: To furnish with a corbel or corbels; to support by a corbel; to make in the form of a corbel.
Calcography: The art of drawing with chalk.
Callisaurus: a genus of lizards including the the zebra-tailed lizard.
Corant: A sprightly but somewhat stately dance, now out of fashion.
Christianize: To adopt the character or belief of a Christian; to become Christian.
Cognize: To know or perceive; to recognize.
Collusion: A secret agreement and cooperation for a fraudulent or deceitful purpose; a playing into each other's hands; deceit; fraud; cunning.
Crastination: Procrastination; a putting off till to-morrow.
Chloasma: A cutaneous affection characterized by yellow or yellowish brown pigmented spots.
Cursive: A character used in cursive writing.
Chargeless: Free from, or with little, charge.
Cincture: A belt, a girdle, or something worn round the body, -- as by an ecclesiastic for confining the alb.
Clepsydra: A water clock; a contrivance for measuring time by the graduated flow of a liquid, as of water, through a small aperture. See Illust. in Appendix.
Conistra: Originally, a part of the palestra, or gymnasium among the Greeks; either the place where sand was stored for use in sprinkling the wrestlers, or the wrestling ground itself. Hence, a part of the orchestra of the Greek theater.
clean-shaven: having the surface shaved to smoothness.
cloud nine: a state of extreme or perfect happiness; used especially in the phrase on cloud nine.
Congression: A coming or bringing together, as in a public meeting, in a dispute, in the act of comparing, or in sexual intercourse.
Cultivate: To bestow attention, care, and labor upon, with a view to valuable returns; to till; to fertilize; as, to cultivate soil.
Copiousness: The state or quality of being copious; abudance; plenty; also, diffuseness in style.
Clarr\u00e9: Wine with a mixture of honey and species.
Correctly: In a correct manner; exactly; acurately; without fault or error.
Cymoid: Having the form of a cyme.
Cryptobranchiata: A division of the Amphibia; the Derotremata.
Conspirant: Engaging in a plot to commit a crime; conspiring.
conk: to hit on the head; as, to conk someone on the head with a pipe.
Cousinry: A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of persons who stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.
Conhydrine: A vegetable alkaloid found with conine in the poison hemlock (Conium maculatum). It is a white crystalline substance, C8H17NO, easily convertible into conine.
Caddis: A kind of worsted lace or ribbon.
Chim\u00e6roid: Related to, or like, the chimæra.
Constitutionalist: One who advocates a constitutional form of government; a constitutionalist.
Charnel: A charnel house; a grave; a cemetery.
Convener: One who convenes or meets with others.
Convoy pennant: A white pennant with red border, carried: (a) Forward on all vessels on convoy duty. (b) Alone by a senior officer present during evolutions or drills, when it commands “Silence.”  (c) Over a signal number, when it refers to the signal number of an officer in the Annual Navy Register.
Chaja: The crested screamer of Brazil (Palamedea chavaria syn. Chauna chavaria), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called also chauna, and faithful kamichi. It is often domesticated and is useful in guarding other poultry. See Kamichi.
Chargeship: The office of a chargé d'affaires.
Counterscarp: The exterior slope or wall of the ditch; -- sometimes, the whole covered way, beyond the ditch, with its parapet and glacis; as, the enemy have lodged themselves on the counterscarp.
Caliver: An early form of hand gun, a variety of the arquebus; originally a gun having a regular size of bore.
Christian Seneca: Joseph Hall (1574 -- 1656), Bishop of Norwich, a divine eminent as a moralist.
Clementine: Of or pertaining to Clement, esp. to St. Clement of Rome and the spurious homilies attributed to him, or to Pope Clement V. and his compilations of canon law.
C\u0153lacanth: Having hollow spines, as some ganoid fishes.
collared lizard: any of several species of lizards of the genus Crotaphytus and the family Iguanidae, of the central and western U.S. and northern Mexico, having long tails and usually bearing markings on the neck appearing like a collar of two black bands.
Ceruleum: A greenish blue pigment prepared in various ways, consisting essentially of cobalt stannate. Unlike other cobalt blues, it does not change color by gaslight.
Confound: To mingle and blend, so that different elements can not be distinguished; to confuse.
Compendiousness: The state or quality of being compendious.
collectivize: to bring under collective control; to organize for operation by the principles of collectivism; -- especially of farms and industrial enterprises.
Computable: Capable of being computed, numbered, or reckoned.
Conductivity: The quality or power of conducting, or of receiving and transmitting, as heat, electricity, etc.; as, the conductivity of a nerve.
centrex: a contracted form of CENTRal EXchange.
Couple: To come together as male and female; to copulate.
Commix: To mix or mingle together; to blend.
Conversion: The act of turning or changing from one state or condition to another, or the state of being changed; transmutation; change.
Cortes: The legislative assembly, composed of nobility, clergy, and representatives of cities, which in Spain and in Portugal answers, in some measure, to the Parliament of Great Britain.
Certify: To give cetain information to; to assure; to make certain.
camelhair: a soft tan cloth made with the hair of a camel.
Creditor: One who credits, believes, or trusts.
Compsognathus: A genus of carnivorous Dinosauria found in the Jurassic formation with a slender body, and remarkable for having several birdlike features.  It reached a length of 30 inches when adult.
Clownish: Of or resembling a clown, or characteristic of a clown; ungainly; awkward.
Cosmopolitism: The condition or character of a cosmopolite; disregard of national or local peculiarities and prejudices.
Crestfallen: With hanging head; hence, dispirited; dejected; cowed.
Confucian: Of, or relating to, Confucius, the great Chinese philosopher and teacher, or to Confucianism; as, Confucian ethics.
cervid: any member of the family Cervidae, a type of deer distinguished from the Bovidae by the male's having solid deciduous antlers.
Cima: A kind of molding. See Cyma.
Capping plane: A plane used for working the upper surface of staircase rails.
Catallacta: A division of Protozoa, of which Magosphæra is the type. They exist both in a myxopod state, with branched pseudopodia, and in the form of ciliated bodies united in free, spherical colonies.
Compaternity: The relation of a godfather to a person.
Colubridae: a broad family including only nonvenomous snakes, containing about two-thirds of all living species.  It includes the bullsnakes, garter snakes, and water snakes as well as many other species.
Coinhere: To inhere or exist together, as in one substance.
Capitellate: Having a very small knoblike termination, or collected into minute capitula.
Cacholong: An opaque or milk-white chalcedony, a variety of quartz; also, a similar variety of opal.
Chromospheric: Of or pertaining to the chromosphere.
Co\u00f6rdain: To ordain or appoint for some purpose along with another.
Canellaceae: a natural family having one genus: aromatic tropical trees of East Africa and Florida to West Indies.
cooled: made or become cool or made cool as specified; often used as a combining form; as, air-cooled auto engine; the cooled milk was put in the refrigerator.
Cajolement: The act of cajoling; the state of being cajoled; cajolery.
Culprit: One accused of, or arraigned for, a crime, as before a judge.
Corallum: The coral or skeleton of a zoöphyte, whether calcareous of horny, simple or compound. See Coral.
collarbone: The clavicle, a bone linking the scapula and sternum.
Cursores: An order of running birds including the ostrich, emu, and allies; the Ratitaæ.
Commission: To give a commission to; to furnish with a commission; to empower or authorize; as, to commission persons to perform certain acts; to commission an officer.
Crack-loo: A kind of gambling game consisting in pitching coins to or towards the ceiling of a room so that they shall fall as near as possible to a certain crack in the floor.
cheewink: the common rufous-sided towhee of eastern North America, Pipilo erythrophthalmus.
cede: To yield or surrender; to give up; to resign; as, to cede a fortress, a province, or country, to another nation, by treaty.
cruet-stand: a frame for holding cruets; a caster; a stand for cruets together with the cruets containing various condiments.
Cheliferous: Having cheliform claws, like a crab.
Collodionize: To prepare or treat with collodion.
Candent: Heated to whiteness; glowing with heat.
Culex: A genus of mosquitoes of the family Culicidae, to which most of the North American species belong.  Some members of this genus are exceedingly annoying, as Culex sollicitans, which breeds in enormous numbers in the salt marshes of the Atlantic coast, and Culex pipiens, the common house mosquito, breeding very widely in the fresh waters of North America. (For characters distinguishing these from the malaria mosquitoes, see Anopheles, above).  The yellow-fever mosquito is now placed in another genus, Stegomyia.
Construe: To apply the rules of syntax to (a sentence or clause) so as to exhibit the structure, arrangement, or connection of, or to discover the sense; to explain the construction of; to interpret; to translate.
Cashiers check: A check drawn by a bank upon its own funds, signed by the cashier.
Clutch: To reach (at something) as if to grasp; to catch or snatch; -- often followed by at.
Changeableness: The quality of being changeable; fickleness; inconstancy; mutability.
Coincider: One who coincides with another in an opinion.
cowskin: leather from the skin of a cow.
Crucian carp: A kind of European carp (Carasius vulgaris), inferior to the common carp; -- called also German carp.
Coexistent: Existing at the same time with another.
Clayish: Partaking of the nature of clay, or containing particles of it.
C\u00e6sarean: Of or pertaining to Cæsar or the Cæsars; imperial.
Ceramic: Of or pertaining to pottery; relating to the art of making earthenware; as, ceramic products; ceramic ornaments for ceilings.
caravanning: the practice of taking holidays in a caravan.
canonic: Of or pertaining to a canon; established by, or according to, a canon or canons.
Capitulum: A thick head of flowers on a very short axis, as a clover top, or a dandelion; a composite flower. A capitulum may be either globular or flat.
Cut: Gashed or divided, as by a cutting instrument.
Cephalata: A large division of Mollusca, including all except the bivalves; -- so called because the head is distinctly developed. See Illustration in Appendix.
Cup: To supply with cups of wine.
Carnalism: The state of being carnal; carnality; sensualism.
croaky: like the sounds of frogs and crows; as, acres of croaky frogs.
Cerargyrite: Native silver chloride, a mineral of a white to pale yellow or gray color, darkening on exposure to the light. It may be cut by a knife, like lead or horn (hence called horn silver).
Cud: That portion of food which is brought up into the mouth by ruminating animals from their first stomach, to be chewed a second time.
