Chondro-: A combining form meaning a grain, granular, granular cartilage, cartilaginous; as, the chondrocranium, the cartilaginous skull of the lower vertebrates and of embryos.
Christlike: Resembling Christ in character, actions, etc.
Conversant: One who converses with another; a convenser.
Coinhabitant: One who dwells with another, or with others.
Coryph\u00e6noid: Belonging to, or like, the genus Coryphæna. See Dolphin.
Complemental: Supplying, or tending to supply, a deficiency; fully completing.
Chameleon: A lizardlike reptile of the genus Chamæleo, of several species, found in Africa, Asia, and Europe. The skin is covered with fine granulations; it has eyes which can move separately, the tail is prehensile, and the body is much compressed laterally, giving it a high back.  It is remarkable for its ability to change the color of its skin to blend with its surroundings.
Cymidine: A liquid organic base, C10H13.NH2, derived from cymene.
Cappadine: A floss or waste obtained from the cocoon after the silk has been reeled off, used for shag.
Cream-fruit: A plant of Sierra Leone which yields a wholesome, creamy juice.
Cimicifuga: a small genus of perennial herbs of N temperate regions: bugbane.
Coster: One who hawks about fruit, green vegetables, fish, etc.
Cambrasine: A kind of linen cloth made in Egypt, and so named from its resemblance to cambric.
Corruptly: In a corrupt manner; by means of corruption or corrupting influences; wrongfully.
Conspirator: One who engages in a conspiracy; a plotter.
Churrus: A powerfully narcotic and intoxicating gum resin which exudes from the flower heads, seeds, etc., of Indian hemp.
Cadene: A species of inferior carpet imported from the Levant.
catalyst: a substance that initiates or accelerates a chemical reaction without itself being affected; as, thousands of enzymes serve in concert as calaysts to produce the sequence of reactions we call “life“; the industrial production of cheap ammonia depended on finding a good catalyst.
Cacuminal: Pertaining to the top of the palate; cerebral; -- applied to certain consonants; as, cacuminal (or cerebral) letters.
Creat: An usher to a riding master.
Carborundum: A beautiful crystalline compound, silicon carbide (SiC), consisting of carbon and silicon in combination; -- also called carbon silicide. It is made by heating carbon and sand together in an electric furnace. The commercial article is dark-colored and iridescent. It is harder than emery, and is used as an abrasive.
Choledology: A treatise on the bile and bilary organs.
Carpal: Of or pertaining to the carpus, or wrist.
Concavo-concave: Concave or hollow on both sides; double concave.
Crowth: An ancient musical instrument. See 4th Crowd.
Creak: The sound produced by anything that creaks; a creaking.
Coronary cushion: A cushionlike band of vascular tissue at the upper border of the wall of the hoof of the horse and allied animals. It takes an important part in the secretion of the horny walls.
Carthaginian: Of a pertaining to ancient Carthage, a city of northern Africa.
Choregraphy: The art of representing dancing by signs, as music is represented by notes; -- also called choreography.
conserves: fruit preserved by cooking with sugar.
Chemism: The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substance whereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction; affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemical activity or relationship.
clitellus: A thickened glandular portion of the body of the adult earthworm, consisting of several united segments modified for reproductive purposes.
Chromatics: The science of colors; that part of optics which treats of the properties of colors.
Carronade: A kind of short cannon, formerly in use, designed to throw a large projectile with small velocity, used for the purpose of breaking or smashing in, rather than piercing, the object aimed at, as the side of a ship. It has no trunnions, but is supported on its carriage by a bolt passing through a loop on its under side.
Cent: A hundred; as, ten per cent, the proportion of ten parts in a hundred.
Chemise: A shift, or undergarment, worn by women.
chinaberry: an evergreen of tropical America having pulpy fruit containing saponin which was used as soap by native Americans.
Circumrotation: The act of rolling or revolving round, as a wheel; circumvolution; the state of being whirled round.
cacao: A small evergreen tree (Theobroma Cacao) of South America and the West Indies.  Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seeds about the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and broma are prepared.
Columnar: Formed in columns; having the form of a column or columns; like the shaft of a column.
Chemist: A person versed in chemistry or given to chemical investigation; an analyst; a maker or seller of chemicals or drugs.
cross-modality: ability to integrate information from different sense modalities.
Cholesterin: A white, fatty, crystalline substance, tasteless and odorless, found in animal and plant products and tissue, and especially in nerve tissue, in the bile, and in gallstones.
Cholesteric: Pertaining to cholesterin, or obtained from it; as, cholesteric acid.
cliffhanger: a contest whose outcome is uncertain up to the very end.
Cuttle: A cephalopod of the genus Sepia, having an internal shell, large eyes, and ten arms furnished with denticulated suckers, by means of which it secures its prey. The name is sometimes applied to dibranchiate cephalopods generally.
Competent: Answering to all requirements; adequate; sufficient; suitable; capable; legally qualified; fit.
Consideration: The act or process of considering; continuous careful thought; examination; contemplation; deliberation; attention.
Counter-courant: Running in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in a coast of arms.
carpellate: bearing or consisting of carpels.  Opposite of acarpelous.
Cremona: A superior kind of violin, formerly made at Cremona, in Italy.
Consistence: The condition of standing or adhering together, or being fixed in union, as the parts of a body; existence; firmness; coherence; solidity.
Crossbarred: Secured by, or furnished with, crossbars.
Clambake: The backing or steaming of clams on heated stones, between layers of seaweed; hence, a picnic party, gathered on such an occasion.
Cubo-octahedral: Presenting a combination of a cube and an octahedron.
Capsheaf: The top sheaf of a stack of grain: (fig.) the crowning or finishing part of a thing.
chairperson: the officer who presides at the meetings of an organization; -- same as chair{3} or chairman{1}, but used to achieve a sex-neutral register.
Corvet: A war vessel, ranking next below a frigate, and having usually only one tier of guns; -- called in the United States navy a sloop of war.
Concurrence: The act of concurring; a meeting or coming together; union; conjunction; combination.
Cordialize: To grow cordial; to feel or express cordiality.
Crescent: To form into a crescent, or something resembling a crescent.
Calcareo-argillaceous: consisting of, or containing, calcareous and argillaceous earths.
Chicken: A young bird or fowl, esp. a young barnyard fowl.
Chandi: the malevolent aspect of Devi: "the fierce".
Corolline: Of or pertaining to a corolla.
Chromophotography: The art of producing photographs in colors-
Coothay: A striped satin made in India.
Conspissation: A making thick or viscous; thickness; inspissation.
Consequence: That which follows something on which it depends; that which is produced by a cause; a result.
Carbazotic: Containing, or derived from, carbon and nitrogen.
Contignation: The act or process of framing together, or uniting, as beams in a fabric.
Crystallizable: Capable of being crystallized; that may be formed into crystals.
Comparable: Capable of being compared; worthy of comparison.
crewman: any member of a ship's crew.
Cinquecento: The sixteenth century, when applied to Italian art or literature; as, the sculpture of the Cinquecento; Cinquecento style.
Caffeic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, coffee.
Crotaphytus: a genus of lizards of the family Iguanidae, including the collared lizards.
Cottontail: The American wood rabbit (Lepus sylvaticus); -- also called Molly cottontail.
Coinage: The act or process of converting metal into money.
Coriander: An umbelliferous plant, the Coriandrum sativum, the fruit or seeds of which have a strong smell and a spicy taste, and in medicine are considered as stomachic and carminative.
Conterminant: Having the same limits; ending at the same time; conterminous.
Catechism: A form of instruction by means of questions and answers.
chittamwood: a shrubby tree of the U. S. Pacific coast (Rhamnus purshianus or Rhamnus purshiana), whose bark is the cascara sagrada, used as a mild cathartic or laxative.
Criticalness: The state or quality of being critical, or of occurring at a critical time.
Confrontment: The act of confronting; the state of being face to face.
Crucifix: A representation in art of the figure of Christ upon the cross; esp., the sculptured figure affixed to a real cross of wood, ivory, metal, or the like, used by the Roman Catholics in their devotions.
Catechist: One who instructs by question and answer, especially in religions matters.
Counterbore: To form a counterbore in, by boring, turning, or drilling; to enlarge, as a hole, by means of a counterbore.
Catamite: A boy kept for unnatural purposes.
Cubiform: Of the form of a cube.
Cheerful: Having or showing good spirits or joy; cheering; cheery; contented; happy; joyful; lively; animated; willing.
Clumsy: Stiff or benumbed, as with cold.
Canella: A genus of trees of the order Canellaceæ, growing in the West Indies.
Compacted: Compact; pressed close; concentrated; firmly united.
Cryptographic: Relating to cryptography; written in secret characters or in cipher, or with sympathetic ink.
compact disk player: an electronic device containing a laser, used to read or play back the data on a compact disk.  The term is usually used for the type of device used to play music recordings.  That used for data storgage n coputer applications is usually called a CD drive.  Called also CD player and informally, CD.
Compressive: Compressing, or having power or tendency to compress; as, a compressive force.
Cinchona: A genus of trees growing naturally on the Andes in Peru and adjacent countries, but now cultivated in the East Indies, producing a medicinal bark of great value.
Camass: A small prairie in a forest; a small grassy plain among hills.
cosh: to hit (someone) with a cosh or similar bludgeon, usually on the head.
Chisinau: The capital city of Moldova.  Population (2000) = 676,700.
Clinker: A mass composed of several bricks run together by the action of the fire in the kiln.
Carcanet: A jeweled chain, necklace, or collar.
Commonplace: To utter commonplaces; to indulge in platitudes.
Consol: A consolidated annuity (see Consols); -- chiefly in combination or attributively.
co-ed: having both female and male students; -- of a school.
Charming: Pleasing the mind or senses in a high degree; delighting; fascinating; attractive.
Cockpit: A pit, or inclosed area, for cockfights.
Cossette: One of the small chips or slices into which beets are cut in sugar making.
collectivized: brought under collective ownership and operating under collectivist principles; -- used especially of organizations operating under the ownership by the state.
Colliquefaction: A melting together; the reduction of different bodies into one mass by fusion.
Conspicuous: Open to the view; obvious to the eye; easy to be seen; plainly visible; manifest; attracting the eye.
Counterbrace: To brace in opposite directions; as, to counterbrace the yards, i. e., to brace the head yards one way and the after yards another.
Coachwhip snake: A large, slender, harmless snake of the southern United States (Masticophis flagelliformis).
Caprimulgus: the type genus of the Caprimulgidae, including the whip-poor-will (Caprimulgus vociferus) and the chuck-will's-widow (Caprimulgus carolinensis).
Calle: A kind of head covering; a caul.
Caponiere: A work made across or in the ditch, to protect it from the enemy, or to serve as a covered passageway.
Cumulatist: One who accumulates; one who collects.
Cynorexia: A voracious appetite, like that of a starved dog.
Curule: Of or pertaining to a chariot.
Causation: The act of causing; also the act or agency by which an effect is produced.
Cynthia: the virgin goddess of the hunt and the moon; daughter of Leto and twin sister of Apollo; identified with Roman Diana.
Ceruminous: Pertaining to, or secreting, cerumen; as, the ceruminous glands.
Carious: Affected with caries; decaying; as, a carious tooth.
convertor: a device for changing one substance or form or state into another.
Carpodacus: a genus of birds including the house finch (Carpodacus mexicanus) and purple finch (Carpodacus purpurea).
Cuspidor: Any ornamental vessel used as a spittoon; hence, to avoid the common term, a spittoon of any sort.
Capstone: A fossil echinus of the genus Cannulus; -- so called from its supposed resemblance to a cap.
chicot: a handsome tree of central and eastern North America (Gymnocladus dioica) having large bipinnate leaves and green-white flowers followed by large woody brown pods whose seeds are used as a coffee substitute.
Cortical: Belonging to, or consisting of, bark or rind; resembling bark or rind; external; outer; superficial; as, the cortical substance of the kidney.
Caucus: To hold, or meet in, a caucus or caucuses.
Complaint: Expression of grief, regret, pain, censure, or resentment; lamentation; murmuring; accusation; fault-finding.
Calumba: The root of a plant (Jateorrhiza Calumba, and probably Cocculus palmatus), indigenous in Mozambique. It has an unpleasantly bitter taste, and is used as a tonic and antiseptic.
Citied: Belonging to, or resembling, a city.
Chrysosperm: The seed of gold; a means of creating gold.
Chati: A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).
Conjunction: The act of conjoining, or the state of being conjoined, united, or associated; union; association; league.
countywide: including or occurring in all parts of a county; as, a countywide war on drugs; countywide elections.
Chinned: Having a chin; -- used chiefly in compounds; as, short-chinned.
Craniota: A comprehensive division of the Vertebrata, including all those that have a skull.
Capriform: Having the form of a goat.
Courtliness: The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.
Clientele: The condition or position of a client; clientship
Cupreous: Consisting of copper or resembling copper; coppery.
commissioned: holding by virtue of a commission a rank of second lieutenant or ensign or above; -- of military officers.  Contrasts with noncommissioned.
carissa: a shrub of the genus Carissa having fragrant white flowers and plumlike red to purple-black fruits.
Clavicornes: A group of beetles having club-shaped antennæ.
Chromic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, chromium; -- said of the compounds of chromium in which it has its higher valence.
Communalism: A French theory of government which holds that commune should be a kind of independent state, and the national government a confederation of such states, having only limited powers. It is advocated by advanced French republicans; but it should not be confounded with communism.
Chromid: One of the Chromidæ, a family of fresh-water fishes abundant in the tropical parts of America and Africa. Some are valuable food fishes, as the bulti of the Nile.
Cascade method: A method of attaining successively lower temperatures by utilizing the cooling effect of the expansion of one gas in condensing another less easily liquefiable, and so on.
Cross-fertilize: To fertilize, as the stigmas of a flower or plant, with the pollen from another individual of the same species.
Campagnol: A mouse (Arvicala agrestis), called also meadow mouse, which often does great damage in fields and gardens, by feeding on roots and seeds.
call-board: a bulletin board backstage in a theater.
cat: Any animal belonging to the natural family Felidae, and in particular to the various species of the genera Felis, Panthera, and Lynx.  The domestic cat is Felis domestica.  The European wild cat (Felis catus) is much larger than the domestic cat.  In the United States the name wild cat is commonly applied to the bay lynx (Lynx rufus).  The larger felines, such as the lion, tiger, leopard, and cougar, are often referred to as cats, and sometimes as big cats.  See Wild cat, and Tiger cat.
Charadriiformes: large diverse order of aquatic birds found along seacoasts and inland waters; shorebirds and coastal diving birds; most feed on animal life.
Castigate: To punish by stripes; to chastise by blows; to chasten; also, to chastise verbally; to reprove; to criticise severely.
Cherokees: An Appalachian tribe of Indians, formerly inhabiting the region about the head waters of the Tennessee River. They are now mostly settled in the Indian Territory, and have become one of the most civilized of the Indian Tribes.
Civilize: To reclaim from a savage state; to instruct in the rules and customs of civilization; to educate; to refine.
Chymification: The conversion of food into chyme by the digestive action of gastric juice.
Chenomorph\u00e6: An order of birds, including the swans, ducks, geese, flamingoes and screamers.
Calluna: a genus having only one species.
Clough: An allowance in weighing. See Cloff.
Conjecturally: In a conjectural manner; by way of conjecture.
Clarty: Sticky and foul; muddy; filthy; dirty.
Cardiometry: Measurement of the heart, as by percussion or auscultation.
Caliphate: The office, dignity, or government of a caliph or of the caliphs.
Congenial: Partaking of the same nature; allied by natural characteristics; kindred; sympathetic.
corundom: a very hard mineral used as an abrasive; same as corundun.
Cetylic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, spermaceti.
Considerably: In a manner or to a degree not trifling or unimportant; greatly; much.
Compressible: Capable of being pressed together or forced into a narrower compass, as an elastic or spongy substance.
Chargeableness: The quality of being chargeable or expensive.
caulking: the process of sealing cracks and crevices with a filler such as caulk{2}.
Caseworm: A worm or grub that makes for itself a case. See Caddice.
Corallite: A mineral substance or petrifaction, in the form of coral.
Countersink: An enlargement of the upper part of a hole, forming a cavity or depression for receiving the head of a screw or bolt.
cranberry tree: a deciduous thicket-forming Old World shrub (Viburnum opulus) with clusters of white flowers and small bright red berries.  It is sometimes called high cranberry to distinguish it from the marsh cranberry or low cranberry.
Clannish: Of or pertaining to a clan; closely united, like a clan; disposed to associate only with one's clan or clique; actuated by the traditions, prejudices, habits, etc., of a clan.
Considerable: Worthy of consideration; requiring to be observed, borne in mind, or attended to.
Cryptogrammataceae: one of a number of families into which the family Polypodiaceae has been subdivided in some classification systems.
Campylotropous: Having the ovules and seeds so curved, or bent down upon themselves, that the ends of the embryo are brought close together.
Carucate: A plowland; as much land as one team can plow in a year and a day; -- by some said to be about 100 acres.
Carding: The act or process of preparing staple for spinning, etc., by carding it. See the Note under Card, v. t.
Cavalier: offhand; unceremonious; gay; easy; frank.  Opposed to serious.
Collectorship: The office of a collector of customs or of taxes.
Colophon: An inscription, monogram, or cipher, containing the place and date of publication, printer's name, etc., formerly placed on the last page of a book.
chiropractic: a method of medical treatment that manipulates body structures, especially the spine, in the belief that it restores proper nerve functioning.
Carburetant: Any volatile liquid used in charging illuminating gases.
Causticness: The quality of being caustic; causticity.
Chronography: A description or record of past time; history.
Casuarinaceae: a natural family of plants having only one genus, Casuarina.
Cha: Tea; -- the Chinese (Mandarin) name, used generally in early works of travel, and now for a kind of rolled tea used in Central Asia.
Circumspection: Attention to all the facts and circumstances of a case; caution; watchfulness.
Coagulative: Having the power to cause coagulation; as, a coagulative agent.
Cloud-compeller: Cloud-gatherer; -- an epithet applied to Zeus.
Contemplative: A religious or either sex devoted to prayer and meditation, rather than to active works of charity.
Croquette: A ball of minced meat, fowl, rice, vegetables, or other ingredients, often in a thick white sauce, highly seasoned, breaded, and fried; as, a dish of crab croquettes.
Coincide: To occupy the same place in space, as two equal triangles, when placed one on the other.
Cuprite: The red oxide of copper; red copper; an important ore of copper, occurring massive and in isometric crystals.
Capillaire: A sirup prepared from the maiden-hair, formerly supposed to have medicinal properties.
Compress: A folded piece of cloth, pledget of lint, etc., used to cover the dressing of wounds, and so placed as, by the aid of a bandage, to make due pressure on any part.
Crow-silk: A filamentous fresh-water alga (Conferva rivularis of Linnaeus, Rhizoclonium rivulare of Kutzing).
Chassis: A traversing base frame, or movable railway, along which the carriage of a barbette or casemate gun moves backward and forward. [See Gun carriage.]
cross-index: to provide cross-references in (a book or other document).
Cenobite: One of a religious order, dwelling in a convent, or a community, in opposition to an anchoret, or hermit, who lives in solitude.
Coniferin: A glucoside extracted from the cambium layer of coniferous trees as a white crystalline substance.
Compliance: The act of complying; a yielding; as to a desire, demand, or proposal; concession; submission.
Counterguard: A low outwork before a bastion or ravelin, consisting of two lines of rampart parallel to the faces of the bastion, and protecting them from a breaching fire.
Compatible: Capable of existing in harmony; congruous; suitable; not repugnant; -- usually followed by with.
Carbineer: A soldier armed with a carbine.
Compliancy: Compliance; disposition to yield to others.
Cohabit: To inhabit or reside in company, or in the same place or country.
Chyliferous: Transmitting or conveying chyle; as, chyliferous vessels.
Chirology: The art or practice of using the manual alphabet or of communicating thoughts by sings made by the hands and fingers; a substitute for spoken or written language in intercourse with the deaf and dumb. See Dactylalogy.
Collegian: A member of a college, particularly of a literary institution so called; a student in a college.
Chanterelle: A name for several species of mushroom, of which one (Cantharellus cibrius) is edible, the others reputed poisonous.
Chylous: Consisting of, or similar to, chyle.
Colchicine: A powerful vegetable alkaloid, C17H19NO5, extracted from the Colchicum autumnale, or meadow saffron, as a white or yellowish amorphous powder, with a harsh, bitter taste; -- called also colchicia.
challenged: having doubts expressed about its truth.
Caroling: A song of joy or devotion; a singing, as of carols.
Cream-faced: White or pale, as the effect of fear, or as the natural complexion.
Caracore: A light vessel or proa used by the people of Borneo, etc., and by the Dutch in the East Indies.
Cassimere: A thin, twilled, woolen cloth, used for men's garments.
Carnification: The act or process of turning to flesh, or to a substance resembling flesh.
Chrysaurin: An orange-colored dyestuff, of artificial production.
Conte: A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising or marvelous events.
Calcinable: That may be calcined; as, a calcinable fossil.
cross-cultural: dealing with or comparing two or more cultures; as, a cross-cultural survey.
Cover: To spread a table for a meal; to prepare a banquet.
Cockle: A plant or weed that grows among grain; the corn rose (Luchnis Githage).
Ceratobranchial: Pertaining to the bone, or cartilage, below the epibranchial in a branchial arch.
Chronogram:
An inscription in which certain numeral letters, made to appear specially conspicuous, on being added together, express a particular date or epoch, as in the motto of a medal struck by Gustavus Adolphus in 1632:
            ChrIstVs DVX; ergo trIVMphVs.
- the capitals of which give, when added as numerals, the sum 1632.
curettage: surgery to remove tissue or growths from a bodily cavity (as the uterus) by scraping with a curette; the act of scraping with a curette.
Conodonta: an extinct order of primitive vertebrates; the precise taxonomy is not clear; in some classifications it is considered a separate phylum.
Copperish: Containing, or partaking of the nature of, copper; like copper; as, a copperish taste.
Commensurately: In a commensurate manner; so as to be equal or proportionate; adequately.
crocheting: something created by interlocking looped stitches with a hooked needle.
Congou: Black tea, of higher grade (finer leaf and less dusty) than the present bohea. Also called English breakfast tea. See Tea.
Combine: To form a union; to agree; to coalesce; to confederate.
Combing: The act or process of using a comb or a number of combs; as, the combing of one's hair; the combing of wool.
Cobelligerent: A nation or state that carries on war in connection with another.
Cowlick: A tuft of hair turned up or awry (usually over the forehead), as if licked by a cow.
checked: Held back from some action especially by force.
Camisole: A short dressing jacket for women.
Ceremonial: A system of rules and ceremonies, enjoined by law, or established by custom, in religious worship, social intercourse, or the courts of princes; outward form.
Cyanosis: A condition in which, from insufficient aëration of the blood, the surface of the body becomes blue. See Cyanopathy.
Cosecant: The secant of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.
Calmer: One who, or that which, makes calm.
Cross-week: Rogation week, when the cross was borne in processions.
Columniation: The employment or arrangement of columns in a structure.
Chorographer: One who describes or makes a map of a district or region.
Cauline: Growing immediately on a caulis; of or pertaining to a caulis.
Cordaites: a genus of tall Paleozoic trees superficially resembling modern screw pines; they were structurally intermediate in some ways between cycads and conifers.
Cretism: A Cretan practice; lying; a falsehood.
chaetognathan: of or pertaining to the Chaetognatha.
Choiceness: The quality of being of particular value or worth; nicely; excellence.
Catchpenny: Made or contrived for getting small sums of money from the ignorant or unwary; as, a catchpenny book; a catchpenny show.
Childbirth: The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor.
Chiffon: Any merely ornamental adjunct of a woman's dress, as a bunch of ribbon, lace, etc.
Creator: One who creates, produces, or constitutes. Specifically, the Supreme Being.
Craniofacial: Of or pertaining to the cranium and face; as, the craniofacial angle.
Conditioned: Surrounded; circumstanced; in a certain state or condition, as of property or health; as, a well conditioned man.
Centriscoid: Allied to, or resembling, the genus Centriscus, of which the bellows fish is an example.
Commissary: One to whom is committed some charge, duty, or office, by a superior power; a commissioner.
cartonful: the quantity contained in a carton.
Cafila: A caravan of travelers; a military supply train or government caravan; a string of pack horses.
Combiner: One who, or that which, combines.
cellulosid: of or containing or made from cellulose.
Claviger: One who carries a club; a club bearer.
Cherry: Like a red cherry in color; ruddy; blooming; as, a cherry lip; cherry cheeks.
Chromatoscope: A reflecting telescope, part of which is made to rotate eccentrically, so as to produce a ringlike image of a star, instead of a point; -- used in studying the scintillation of the stars.
crossover: the interchange of sections between pairing homologous chromosomes during the prophase of meiosis.
Cali: The tenth avatar or incarnation of the god Vishnu.
Calk: To furnish with calks, to prevent slipping on ice; as, to calk the shoes of a horse or an ox.
Carbonaro: A member of a secret political association in Italy, organized in the early part of the nineteenth centry for the purpose of changing the government into a republic.
Calm: Not stormy; without motion, as of winds or waves; still; quiet; serene; undisturbed.
Cynomys: a genus of mammals comprising the prairie dogs.
Carnegiea: a genus of plants consisting of one species, the saguaro.
Crawford: A Crawford peach; a well-known freestone peach, with yellow flesh, first raised by Mr. William Crawford, of New Jersey.
Calf: The young of the cow, or of the Bovine family of quadrupeds. Also, the young of some other mammals, as of the elephant, rhinoceros, hippopotamus, and whale.
Conventionist: One who enters into a convention, covenant, or contract.
Chitin: A white amorphous horny substance forming the harder part of the outer integument of insects, crustacea, and various other invertebrates; entomolin.
Cosmothetic: Assuming or positing the actual existence or reality of the physical or external world.
Comma: A character or point [,] marking the smallest divisions of a sentence, written or printed.
Connatural: Connected by nature; united in nature; inborn; inherent; natural.
Canthus: The corner where the upper and under eyelids meet on each side of the eye.
Condensable: Capable of being condensed; as, vapor is condensable.
carpenteria: a California evergreen shrub (Carpenteria californica) having glossy opposite leaves and terminal clusters of a few fragrant white flowers.
Campanile: A bell tower, esp. one built separate from a church.
Crossbreed: A breed or an animal produced from parents of different breeds; a new variety, as of plants, combining the qualities of two parent varieties or stocks.
Convulsionist: One who has convulsions; esp., one of a body of fanatics in France, early in the eighteenth century, who went into convulsions under the influence of religious emotion; as, the Convulsionists of St. Médard.
Chondrin: A colorless, amorphous, nitrogenous substance, tasteless and odorless, formed from cartilaginous tissue by long-continued action of boiling water. It is similar to gelatin, and is a large ingredient of commercial gelatin.
Cogitability: The quality of being cogitable; conceivableness.
Clincher: One who, or that which, clinches; that which holds fast.
Childhood: The state of being a child; the time in which persons are children; the condition or time from infancy to puberty.
Crecy: the first decisive battle of the Hundred Years' War; in 1346 the English under Edward III defeated the French under King Philip of Valois.
Commiseration: The act of commiserating; sorrow for the wants, afflictions, or distresses of another; pity; compassion.
Correctioner: One who is, or who has been, in the house of correction.
Chapelry: The territorial district legally assigned to a chapel.
Chlorpicrin: A heavy, colorless liquid, CCl3.NO2, of a strong pungent odor, obtained by subjecting picric acid to the action of chlorine.
Coupee: A motion in dancing, when one leg is a little bent, and raised from the floor, and with the other a forward motion is made.
Chromosome: One of the minute bodies into which the chromatin of the nucleus is resolved during mitotic cell division; the idant of Weismann.
Caravaneer: The leader or driver of the camels in caravan.
Crustific: Producing or forming a crust or skin.
Contemplatively: With contemplation; in a contemplative manner.
Candidate: One who offers himself, or is put forward by others, as a suitable person or an aspirant or contestant for an office, privilege, or honor; as, a candidate for the office of governor; a candidate for holy orders; a candidate for scholastic honors.
Compel: To make one yield or submit.
Clash gear: A change-speed gear in which the gears are changed by sliding endwise.
Canonically: In a canonical manner; according to the canons.
Cripply: Lame; disabled; in a crippled condition.
Centurion: A military officer who commanded a minor division of the Roman army; a captain of a century.
Competence: The state of being competent; fitness; ability; adequacy; power.
Chautauqua: a meeting, usually held in the summer outdoors or under a temporary tent, providing public lectures combined with entertainment such as concerts and plays.  It originated in the village of Chautauqua, N. Y., in 1874, and was popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.  Also, a meeting similar to this.
Crowkeeper: A person employed to scare off crows; hence, a scarecrow.
Cascarillin: A white, crystallizable, bitter substance extracted from oil of cascarilla.
Clypeastroid: Like or related to the genus Clupeaster; -- applied to a group of flattened sea urchins, with a rosette of pores on the upper side.
Camomile: A genus of herbs (Anthemis) of the Composite family.  The common camomile, Anthemis nobilis, is used as a popular remedy.  Its flowers have a strong and fragrant and a bitter, aromatic taste.  They are tonic, febrifugal, and in large doses emetic, and the volatile oil is carminative.
Candlefish: A marine fish (Thaleichthys Pacificus), allied to the smelt, found on the north Pacific coast; -- called also eulachon. It is so oily that, when dried, it may be used as a candle, by drawing a wick through it
Cuminic: Pertaining to, or derived from, cumin, or from oil of caraway; as, cuminic acid.
Cathedrated: Relating to the chair or office of a teacher.
Cavalero: A cavalier; a gallant; a libertine.
Carnage: Flesh of slain animals or men.
Caged: Confined in, or as in, a cage; like a cage or prison.
Caryophyllin: A tasteless and odorless crystalline substance, extracted from cloves, polymeric with common camphor.
Chisley: Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said of a soil.
Cornaceae: a natural family of trees including the genera Aucuba; Cornus; Corokia; Curtisia; Griselinia; and Helwingia.
Cucurbitaceae: a natural family of plants including the cucumber; melon; squash; and pumpkin.
Chislev: The third month of the Jewish civil year; the ninth month of the ecclesiastical year in the Jewish calendar, occupying a part of November and a part of December; -- same as Kislev.
Cartography: The art or business of forming charts or maps.
Ctenostomata: A suborder of Bryozoa, usually having a circle of bristles below the tentacles.
Claver: Frivolous or nonsensical talk; prattle; chattering.
Clarinet: A wind instrument, blown by a single reed, of richer and fuller tone than the oboe, which has a double reed. It is the leading instrument in a military band.
Codical: Relating to a codex, or a code.
Concerto: A composition (usually in symphonic form with three movements) in which one instrument (or two or three) stands out in bold relief against the orchestra, or accompaniment, so as to display its qualities or the performer's skill.
Carbonization: The act or process of carbonizing.
Capercailzie: A species of black Old World grouse (Tetrao uragallus) of large size and fine flavor, found in northern Europe and formerly in Scotland; -- called also cock of the woods and horse of the wood.
Counterfeiter: One who counterfeits; one who copies or imitates; especially, one who copies or forges bank notes or coin; a forger.
Camphoraceous: Of the nature of camphor; containing camphor.
Catacala: a genus of moths whose larvae are cutworms: underwings.
County: An earldom; the domain of a count or earl.
Cross-tining: A mode of harrowing crosswise, or transversely to the ridges.
crawfish: to back out in a humilating manner; as, We'll have to crawfish out from meeting with him.
Cellulose: The substance which constitutes the essential part of the solid framework of plants, of ordinary wood, cotton, linen, paper, etc. It is also found to a slight extent in certain animals, as the tunicates. It is a carbohydrate, (C6H10O5)n, isomeric with starch, and is convertible into starches and sugars by the action of heat and acids. When pure, it is a white amorphous mass. See Starch, Granulose, Lignin.
Capillature: A bush of hair; frizzing of the hair.
Catallactics: The science of exchanges, a branch of political economy.
Carromata: In the Philippines, a light, two-wheeled, boxlike vehicle usually drawn by a single native pony and used to convey passengers within city limits or for traveling. It is the common public carriage.
Cruset: A goldsmith's crucible or melting pot.
Commatic: Having short clauses or sentences; brief; concise.
Cowlstaff: A staff or pole on which a vessel is supported between two persons.
Contubernal: Living or messing together; familiar; in companionship.
Compete: To contend emulously; to seek or strive for the same thing, position, or reward for which another is striving; to contend in rivalry, as for a prize or in business; as, tradesmen compete with one another.
Corkscrew: To press forward in a winding way; as, to corkscrew one's way through a crowd.
Chandoo: An extract or preparation of opium, used in China and India for smoking.
Cavicornia: A group of ruminants whose horns are hollow, and planted on a bony process of the front, as the ox.
Cobaltine: A mineral of a nearly silver-white color, composed of arsenic, sulphur, and cobalt.
Cymometer: An instrument for exhibiting and measuring wave motion
Citharistic: Pertaining, or adapted, to the cithara.
Cementer: A person or thing that cements.
Calycular: Pertaining to, or resembling, the bracts of a calycle.
Clydesdale: One of a breed of heavy draft horses originally from Clydesdale, Scotland. They are about sixteen hands high and usually brown or bay.
Crambo: A game in which one person gives a word, to which another finds a rhyme.
Conglomerate: To gather into a ball or round body; to collect into a mass.
Cup shake: A shake or fissure between the annual rings of a tree, found oftenest near the roots.
Crystallization: The act or process by which a substance in solidifying assumes the form and structure of a crystal, or becomes crystallized; the formation of crystals.
Contracted: Drawn together; shrunken; wrinkled; narrow; as, a contracted brow; a contracted noun.
Chevalier: A horseman; a knight; a gallant young man.
Conventicling: Belonging or going to, or resembling, a conventicle.
Calotype: A method of taking photographic pictures, on paper sensitized with iodide of silver; -- also called Talbotype, from the inventor, Mr. Fox. Talbot.
Commonplaceness: The quality of being commonplace; commonness.
Confinable: Capable of being confined, restricted, or limited.
Compartment: One of the parts into which an inclosed portion of space is divided, as by partitions, or lines; as, the compartments of a cabinet, a house, or a garden.
chemisorptive: have the capacity to adsorb by chemical as contrasted with physical forces.
Conchological: Pertaining to, or connected with, conchology.
Coddymoddy: A gull in the plumage of its first year.
Cyanuric: Pertaining to, or derived from, cyanic and uric acids.
Chaldaism: An idiom or peculiarity in the Chaldee dialect.
Congener: A thing of the same genus, species, or kind; a thing allied in nature, character, or action.
Cold-shut: Closed while too cold to become thoroughly welded; -- said of a forging or casting.
Cotyliform: Shaped like a cotyle or a cup.
coccidiosis: any of a group of infectious diseases caused by protozoan parasites (coccidia) of the order Coccidia, which infect the intestines of birds, dogs, and other vertebrates.
Coticular: Pertaining to whetstones; like or suitable for whetstones.
Cowardice: Want of courage to face danger; extreme timidity; pusillanimity; base fear of danger or hurt; lack of spirit.
Cordial: Anything that comforts, gladdens, and exhilarates.
CO2: the chemical formula for carbon dioxide, a heavy odorless gas (CO2) formed during respiration and by the combustion or decomposition of organic substances; it is absorbed from the air by plants in photosynthesis.  The formula itself, pronounced out, is often used instead of the full name, especially with reference to fire extinguishers using this gas for fire suppression; as, a CO2 extinguisher.
Continuation: That act or state of continuing; the state of being continued; uninterrupted extension or succession; prolongation; propagation.
Cardialgla: A burning or gnawing pain, or feeling of distress, referred to the region of the heart, accompanied with cardiac palpitation; heartburn. It is usually a symptom of indigestion.
Congregate: To come together; to assemble; to meet.
Cyrenaic: Pertaining to Cyrenaica, an ancient country of northern Africa, and to Cyrene, its principal city; also, to a school of philosophy founded by Aristippus, a native of Cyrene.
Contraindicate: To indicate, as by a symptom, some method of treatment contrary to that which the general tenor of the case would seem to require; especially, to indicate that a particular method of treatment should not be used; as, penicilin is contraindicated in patients who have shown hypersensitivity.
Crebricostate: Marked with closely set ribs or ridges.
Courtesan: A woman who prostitutes herself for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.
cum: same as semen{2}; -- also spelled come.
Cirrigrade: Moving or moved by cirri, or hairlike appendages.
Cumberland: a tributary of the Ohio River.
Coroniform: Having the form of a crown or coronet; resembling a crown.
Country club: A club usually located in the suburbs or vicinity of a city or town and devoted mainly to outdoor sports, and usually having an attached golf course.
Couch: A bed or place for repose or sleep; particularly, in the United States, a lounge.
Cervine: Of or pertaining to the deer, or to the family Cervidæ.
Charge: A load or burder laid upon a person or thing.
Chalcography: The act or art of engraving on copper or brass, especially of engraving for printing.
Cenatory: Of or pertaining to dinner or supper.
Chary: Careful; wary; cautious; not rash, or reckless; as, the latest internet IPO's were shunned by investors made chary by the poor performance of the first wave of companies that went public.
Covelline: A native sulphide of copper, occuring in masses of a dark blue color; -- hence called indigo copper.
Complete: To bring to a state in which there is no deficiency; to perfect; to consummate; to accomplish; to fulfill; to finish; as, to complete a task, or a poem; to complete a course of education.
Casually: Without design; accidentally; fortuitously; by chance; occasionally.
capaciate: to become active so as to be able to penetrate an ovum; -- of sperm, in the female reproduction system.
Chart: To lay down in a chart; to map; to delineate; as, to chart a coast.
Censual: Relating to, or containing, a census.
Coal-meter: A licensed or official coal measurer in London. See Meter.
Calyx: The covering of a flower. See Flower.
Cyatholith: A kind of coccolith, which in shape resembles a minute cup widened at the top, and varies in size from 1/6000 to 1/8000 of an inch.
Carob: An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in the countries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; -- called also carob tree.
Connubial: Of or pertaining to marriage, or the marriage state; conjugal; nuptial.
Chara: A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems and whorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
Carol: A small closet or inclosure built against a window on the inner side, to sit in for study. The word was used as late as the 16th century.  The term carrel, of the same has largely superseded its use.
Chare: A chore; to chore; to do. See Char.
Chard: The tender leaves or leafstalks of the artichoke, white beet, etc., blanched for table use.
Cerebellum: The large lobe of the hind brain in front of and above the medulla; the little brain. It controls combined muscular action. See Brain.
Cerealia: Public festivals in honor of Ceres.
Cottise: A diminutive of the bendlet, containing one half its area or one quarter the area of the bend. When a single cottise is used alone it is often called a cost. See also Couple-close.
Cracker: One who, or that which, cracks.
Cerealin: A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtained from bran, and possessing the power of converting starch into dextrin, sugar, and lactic acid.
CD-WO: A recordable compact disk; a compact disc on which you can write only once and thereafter is read-only.
Chokeberry: The small apple-shaped or pear-shaped fruit of an American shrub (Pyrus arbutifolia) growing in damp thickets; also, the shrub.
Casehardening: The act or process of converting the surface of iron into steel.
Crampoons: A clutch formed of hooked pieces of iron, like double calipers, for raising stones, lumber, blocks of ice, etc.
Capitally: In a way involving the forfeiture of the head or life; as, to punish capitally.
Consignation: The act of consigning; the act of delivering or committing to another person, place, or state.
Cerolite: A hydrous silicate of magnesium, allied to serpentine, occurring in waxlike masses of a yellow or greenish color.
Committal: The act of committing, or the state of being committed; commitment.
Complexity: The state of being complex; intricacy; entanglement.
Contesseration: An assemblage; a collection; harmonious union.
Convolvulus: A large genus of plants having monopetalous flowers, including the common bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), and formerly the morning-glory, but this is now transferred to the genus Ipomæa.
Caducary: Relating to escheat, forfeiture, or confiscation.
Cuticular: Pertaining to the cuticle, or external coat of the skin; epidermal.
Chooser: One who chooses; one who has the power or right of choosing; an elector.
Chylopoetic: Concerned in the formation of chyle; as, the chylopoetic organs.
Capuched: Cover with, or as with, a hood.
Cephalothorax: The anterior portion of any one of the Arachnida and higher Crustacea, consisting of the united head and thorax.
Crystallographer: One who describes crystals, or the manner of their formation; one versed in crystallography.
Cormophytes: A term proposed by Endlicher to include all plants with an axis containing vascular tissue and with foliage.
Centenary: The aggregate of a hundred single things; specifically, a century.
Costal-nerved: Having the nerves spring from the midrib.
Cross-examine: To examine or question, as a witness who has been called and examined by the opposite party.
Classicism: A classic idiom or expression; a classicalism.
Corban: An offering of any kind, devoted to God and therefore not to be appropriated to any other use; esp., an offering in fulfillment of a vow.
Catadioptric: Pertaining to, produced by, or involving, both the reflection and refraction of light; as, a catadioptric light.
Carambola: An East Indian tree (Averrhoa Carambola), and its acid, juicy fruit; called also Coromandel gooseberry.
Ch\u00e6todont: Of or pertaining to the Chætodonts or the family Chætodontidæ.
clammyweed: strong-scented herb (Polanisia graveolens) common in the southern U. S. covered with intermixed gland and hairs.
Countor: An advocate or professional pleader; one who counted for his client, that is, orally pleaded his cause.
carful: the quantity that a car will hold.
Circumvest: To cover round, as with a garment; to invest.
Corypheus: The conductor, chief, or leader of the dramatic chorus; hence, the chief or leader of a party or interest.
Compunctious: Of the nature of compunction; caused by conscience; attended with, or causing, compunction.
Cloaca: A sewer; as, the Cloaca Maxima of Rome.
Cabombaceae: A subfamily of plants, in some classifications considered as an independent family of water lilies; it comprises the genera Cabomba and Brasenia.
Celticism: A custom of the Celts, or an idiom of their language.
Collogue: To talk or confer secretly and confidentially; to converse, especially with evil intentions; to plot mischief.
Commingler: One that commingles; specif., a device for noiseless heating of water by steam, in a vessel filled with a porous mass, as of pebbles.
Chirography: The art of writing or engrossing; handwriting; as, skilled in chirography.
Conferruminate: Closely united by the coalescence, or sticking together, of contiguous faces, as in the case of the cotyledons of the live-oak acorn.
Callophis: a genus of Asian coral snakes.
Contranatural: Opposed to or against nature; unnatural.
Chamaeleon: a small constellation in the southern skies between Hydrus and Musca.
Cetacea: An order of marine mammals, including the whales. Like ordinary mammals they breathe by means of lungs, and bring forth living young which they suckle for some time. The anterior limbs are changed to paddles; the tail flukes are horizontal. There are two living suborders:
Cabiri: Certain deities originally worshiped with mystical rites by the Pelasgians in Lemnos and Samothrace and afterwards throughout Greece; -- also called sons of Hephæstus (or Vulcan), as being masters of the art of working metals.
cleansed: having been made clean.  Opposite of dirty.
Coracias: the type genus of the Coraciidae.
Chilean: A native or resident of Chile; Chilian.
Camera obscura: An apparatus in which the images of external objects, formed by a convex lens or a concave mirror, are thrown on a paper or other white surface placed in the focus of the lens or mirror within a darkened chamber, or box, so that the outlines may be traced.
Capilliform: In the shape or form of, a hair, or of hairs.
Crunch: To crush with the teeth; to chew with a grinding noise; to craunch; as, to crunch a biscuit.
Conceal: To hide or withdraw from observation; to cover; to cover or keep from sight; to prevent the discovery of; to withhold knowledge of.
Cat-salt: A sort of salt, finely granulated, formed out of the bittern or leach brine.
cottonmouth: venomous semiaquatic snake (Agkistrodon piscivorus) of swamps in southern U.S.; -- called also water moccasin, cottonmouth moccasin, and cottonmouth water moccasin.  It grows to a length of about 4 feet.  The name refers to the whiteness of the lips and inside of the mouth.
Calcigerous: Holding lime or other earthy salts; as, the calcigerous cells of the teeth.
conditioned emotional response: an emotional response that has been acquired by conditioning.
Colonnade: A series or range of columns placed at regular intervals with all the adjuncts, as entablature, stylobate, roof, etc.
complementation: the grammatical relation of a word or phrase to a predicate.
choc: chocolate; a colloquial British abbreviation; as, a box ov chocs.
Coerce: To restrain by force, especially by law or authority; to repress; to curb.
Chloralism: A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive use of chloral.
Charlock: A cruciferous plant (Brassica sinapistrum) with yellow flowers; wild mustard. It is troublesome in grain fields. Called also chardock, chardlock, chedlock, and kedlock.
Coquina: A soft, whitish, coral-like stone, formed of broken shells and corals, found in the southern United States, and used for roadbeds and for building material, as in the fort at St. Augustine, Florida.
cryptographer: One who writes in cipher, or secret characters.
Cerulein: A fast dyestuff, C20H8O6, made by heating gallein with strong sulphuric acid. It dyes mordanted fabrics green.
Cultch: Empty oyster shells and other substances laid down on oyster grounds to furnish points for the attachment of the spawn of the oyster.
Chitter: To chirp in a tremulous manner, as a bird.
Conchology: The science of Mollusca, and of the shells which they form; malacology.
Covert baron: Under the protection of a husband; married.
Cartage: The act of carrying in a cart.
Cincinnus: A form of monochasium in which the lateral branches arise alternately on opposite sides of the false axis; -- called also scorpioid cyme.
Cnidoblast: One of the cells which, in the Cœlenterata, develop into cnidæ.
Copulation: The act of coupling or joining; union; conjunction.
Codfish: A kind of fish. Same as Cod.
co-opt: To choose or elect in concert with another.
Coucal: A large, Old World, ground cuckoo of the genus Centropus, of several species.
Combination: The act or process of combining or uniting persons and things.
Condescension: The act of condescending; voluntary descent from one's rank or dignity in intercourse with an inferior; courtesy toward inferiors.
Cat-harping: One of the short ropes or iron cramps used to brace in the shrouds toward the masts so a to give freer sweep to the yards.
Coherence: A sticking or cleaving together; union of parts of the same body; cohesion.
Calliophis: a genus comprising the Asian coral snakes.
Corrosibleness: The quality or state of being corrosible.
conidiophore: a specialized fungal hypha (a branch of the fungal mycelium) that produces conidia.
Chastiser: One who chastises; a punisher; a corrector.
Comber: The cabrilla. Also, a name applied to a species of wrasse.
Complimenter: One who compliments; one given to complimenting; a flatterer.
co-worker: One who works with another; a coöperator.
Cephalostyle: The anterior end of the notochord and its bony sheath in the base of cartilaginous crania.
Coquilla nut: The fruit of a Brazilian tree (Attalea funifera of Martius.).
Cormogeny: The embryological history of groups or families of individuals.
Century: A hundred; as, a century of sonnets; an aggregate of a hundred things.
comics: The section of a newspaper containing mostly comic strips; -- called also funnies and funny papers.  Many but not all newspapers have a comics section.
Chromolithograph: A picture printed in tints and colors by repeated impressions from a series of stones prepared by the lithographic process.
Commitment: The act of committing, or putting in charge, keeping, or trust; consignment; esp., the act of committing to prison.
Cocagne: An imaginary country of idleness and luxury.
Crisis: The point of time when it is to be decided whether any affair or course of action must go on, or be modified or terminate; the decisive moment; the turning point.
Compaginate: To unite or hold together; as, the side pieces compaginate the frame.
Coloring: The act of applying color to; also, that which produces color.
Cemetery: A place or ground set apart for the burial of the dead; a graveyard; a churchyard; a necropolis.
Ciderkin: A kind of weak cider made by steeping the refuse pomace in water.
Comicality: The quality of being comical; something comical.
Cutter: One who cuts; as, a stone cutter; a die cutter; esp., one who cuts out garments.
carriage house: a small building usually near a large residence or part of an estate, used for keeping coaches, carriages, or other vehicles; -- also called coach house.  It is now (1998) obsolescent and its function has been taken over by the garage, which is usually attached to a residence or main building.  Carriage houses are still found on older estates, though not usually used for their original purpose.
Chub: A species to fresh-water fish of the Cyprinidæ or Carp family. The common European species is Leuciscus cephalus; the cheven. In America the name is applied to various fishes of the same family, of the genera Semotilus, Squalius, Ceratichthys, etc., and locally to several very different fishes, as the tautog, black bass, etc.
Crimple: To cause to shrink or draw together; to contract; to curl.
Cozen: To deceive; to cheat; to act deceitfully.
Chum: Chopped pieces of fish used as bait.
carjack: to take (a car) by an act of carjacking; as, the three teens carjacked two automobiles in one night.
Carnivorous: Eating or feeding on flesh. The term is applied: (a) to animals which naturally seek flesh for food, as the tiger, dog, etc.; (b) to plants which are supposed to absorb animal food; (c) to substances which destroy animal tissue, as caustics.
Congratulatory: Expressive of sympathetic joy; as, a congratulatory letter.
Catch title: A short expressive title used for abbreviated book lists, etc.
Country: Pertaining to the regions remote from a city; rural; rustic; as, a country life; a country town; the country party, as opposed to city.
Cantabile: A piece or passage, whether vocal or instrumental, peculiarly adapted to singing; -- sometimes called cantilena.
computerized: stored, processed, or analyzed by computer.
Commentatorship: The office or occupation of a commentator.
Chirper: One who chirps, or is cheerful.
Coniferous: Bearing cones, as the pine and cypress.
checkout time: the latest time for vacating a hotel room without being charged for extra time; as, the checkout here is 12 noon.
Critic: To criticise; to play the critic.
Cowbane: A poisonous umbelliferous plant; in England, the Cicuta virosa; in the United States, the Cicuta maculata and the Archemora rigida. See Water hemlock.
Contingentness: The state of being contingent; fortuitousness.
Carpetbag: A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originally made of carpet.
Chemosmotic: Pertaining to, or produced by, chemosmosis.
Cachunde: A pastil or troche, composed of various aromatic and other ingredients, highly celebrated in India as an antidote, and as a stomachic and antispasmodic.
Count-wheel: The wheel in a clock which regulates the number of strokes.
Capri: Wine produced on the island of Capri, commonly a light, dry, white wine.
Capra: A genus of ruminants, including the common goat.
Citole: A musical instrument; a kind of dulcimer.
Circumclusion: Act of inclosing on all sides.
Clover: A plant of different species of the genus Trifolium; as the common red clover, Trifolium pratense, the white, Trifolium repens, and the hare's foot, Trifolium arvense.
Costal: Pertaining to the ribs or the sides of the body; as, costal nerves.
Cruive: A kind of weir or dam for trapping salmon; also, a hovel.
Calycinal: Pertaining to a calyx; resembling or having the nature of a calyx.
calabura: a fast-growing tropical American evergreen (Muntingia calabura) having white flowers and white fleshy edible fruit; bark yields a silky fiber used in cordage and wood is valuable for staves.
Circumfuse: To pour round; to spread round.
Cullyism: The state of being a cully.
Coontie: A cycadaceous plant of Florida and the West Indies, the Zamia integrifolia, from the stems of which a kind of sago is prepared.
Creepy: Crawly; having or producing a sensation like that caused by insects creeping on the skin.
candida: any of the yeastlike imperfect fungi of the genus Candida.
Clouding: A mottled appearance given to ribbons and silks in the process of dyeing.
Carpel: A simple pistil or single-celled ovary or seed vessel, or one of the parts of a compound pistil, ovary, or seed vessel. See Illust of Carpaphore.
Crex: a genus of birds including the corncrake (Crex crex).
Caufle: A gang of slaves. Same as Coffle.
Canard: An extravagant or absurd report or story; a fabricated sensational report or statement; esp. one set afloat in the newspapers to hoax the public.
Correi: A hollow in the side of a hill, where game usually lies.
Cillosis: A spasmodic trembling of the upper eyelid.
Carpet: To cover with, or as with, a carpet; to spread with carpets; to furnish with a carpet or carpets.
Calyon: Flint or pebble stone, used in building walls, etc.
Cephalotrocha: A kind of annelid larva with a circle of cilia around the head.
Cerise: Cherry-colored; a light bright red; -- applied to textile fabrics, especially silk.
Cuculoid: Like or belonging to the cuckoos (Cuculidæ).
Craniometer: An instrument for measuring the size of skulls.
Circler: A mean or inferior poet, perhaps from his habit of wandering around as a stroller; an itinerant poet. Also, a name given to the cyclic poets. See under Cyclic, a.
Churchyard: The ground adjoining a church, in which the dead are buried; a cemetery.
Croze: A cooper's tool for making the grooves for the heads of casks, etc.; also, the groove itself.
Canonicate: The office of a canon; a canonry.
Circlet: A little circle; esp., an ornament for the person, having the form of a circle; that which encircles, as a ring, a bracelet, or a headband.
capitation: A numbering of heads or individuals.
celtuce: a type of lettuce (Lactuca sativa asparagina) valued especially for its edible stems.
Cassava wood: A West Indian tree (Turpinia occidentalis) of the family Staphyleaceæ.
Circled: Having the form of a circle; round.
Cosmoramic: Of or pertaining to a cosmorama.
Craving: Vehement or urgent desire; longing for; beseeching.
Crossbred: Produced by mixing distinct breeds; mongrel.
Cambrian: A native of Cambria or Wales.
Chessman: A piece used in the game of chess.
Corsak: A small foxlike mammal (Cynalopex corsac), found in Central Asia.
Cloister: To confine in, or as in, a cloister; to seclude from the world; to immure.
Cinchonism: A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use of quinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.
Complexness: The state of being complex; complexity.
cathartin: The bitter, purgative principle of senna. It is a glucoside with the properties of a weak acid; -- called also cathartic acid, and cathartina.
Castorin: A white crystalline substance obtained from castoreum.
Cant: A colloquial contraction for can not.
Chopper: One who, or that which, chops.
caladenia: any of various orchids of the genus Caladenia.
Cany: Of or pertaining to cane or canes; abounding with canes.
Capriped: Having feet like those of a goat.
Cloacal: Of or pertaining to a cloaca.
corybantic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Corybantes or their rites; frantic; frenzied; as, a corybantic dance.
commonalty: The common people; those classes and conditions of people who are below the rank of nobility; the commons.
Chop suey: A mélange served in Chinese restaurants to be eaten with rice, noodles, etc. It consists typically of bean sprouts, onions, mushrooms, etc., and sliced meats, fried and flavored with sesame oil.
Casuaridae: a natural family of large ostrichlike birds; the cassowaries.
Cadillac: A large pear, shaped like a flattened top, used chiefly for cooking.
Chauvinism: Blind and absurd devotion to a fallen leader or an obsolete cause; hence, absurdly vainglorious or exaggerated patriotism.
Corrivation: The flowing of different streams into one.
Clangous: Making a clang, or a ringing metallic sound.
cannibalise: to use parts of (something, such as a machine), to repair something else.
conditioned response: a behavioral response to a stimulus that has been acquired by experience or conditioning.
Containment: That which is contained; the extent; the substance.
Callosum: The great band commissural fibers which unites the two cerebral hemispheres. See corpus callosum, under Carpus.
Coryphene: A fish of the genus Coryphæna. See Dolphin. (2)
catechol: any of a group of chemicals having a benzene ring substituted with two hydroxyl groups in ortho position, especially ortho-dihydroxybenzene itself (C6H6O2), also called pyrocatechol, used in photography and as a reagent.
Cowcatcher: A strong inclined frame, usually of wrought-iron bars, in front of a locomotive engine, for catching or throwing off obstructions on a railway, as cattle; the pilot.
Cucurbitaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants of which the cucumber, melon, and gourd are common examples.
Comfortable: A stuffed or quilted coverlet for a bed; a comforter; a comfort.
Comfortably: In a comfortable or comforting manner.
Corruptibility: The quality of being corruptible; the possibility or liability of being corrupted; corruptibleness.
Comfrey: A rough, hairy, perennial plant of several species, of the genus Symphytum.
Complexioned: Having (such) a complexion; -- used in composition; as, a dark-complexioned or a ruddy-complexioned person.
Conscienceless: Without conscience; indifferent to conscience; unscrupulous.
Charitableness: The quality of being charitable; the exercise of charity.
Convexed: Made convex; protuberant in a spherical form.
Cavatina: Originally, a melody of simpler form than the aria; a song without a second part and a da capo; -- a term now variously and vaguely used.
Congress: A meeting of individuals, whether friendly or hostile; an encounter.
Convertibility: The condition or quality of being convertible; capability of being exchanged; convertibleness.
cows: domesticated bovine animals as a group regardless of sex or age; as, wait till the cows come home.
Concupiscible: Exciting to, or liable to be affected by, concupiscence; provoking lustful desires.
Concatenate: To link together; to unite in a series or chain, as things depending on one another.
Cabrerite: An apple-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of nickel, cobalt, and magnesia; -- so named from the Sierra Cabrera, Spain.
Colonizer: One who promotes or establishes a colony; a colonist.
Chrysopa: A genus of neuropterous insects. See Lacewing.
Cranes-bill: The geranium; -- so named from the long axis of the fruit, which resembles the beak of a crane.
Circumduce: To declare elapsed, as the time allowed for introducing evidence.
Cesspipe: A pipe for carrying off waste water, etc., from a sink or cesspool.
Cloff: Formerly an allowance of two pounds in every three hundred weight after the tare and tret are subtracted; now used only in a general sense, of small deductions from the original weight.
Charybdis: A dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily opposite Scylla on the Italian coast. It is personified as a female monster. See Scylla.
criticize: same as criticise; as, The paper criticized the new movie.
Cogitative: Possessing, or pertaining to, the power of thinking or meditating.
Cassino: A game at cards, played by two or more persons, usually for twenty-one points.
Countergage: An adjustable gage, with double points for transferring measurements from one timber to another, as the breadth of a mortise to the place where the tenon is to be made.
Citigrad\u00e6: A suborder of Arachnoidea, including the European tarantula and the wolf spiders (Lycosidae) and their allies, which capture their prey by rapidly running and jumping. See Wolf spider.
chopsticks: a pair of slender sticks made of wood, ivory, plastic, etc., used chiefly by the Chinese and Japanese to lift food into the mouth while dining; -- also commonly used around the world by persons of Oriental heritage or in restaurants serving oriental food.
Couple-beggar: One who makes it his business to marry beggars to each other.
Consecutively: In a consecutive manner; by way of sequence; successively.
Coheiress: A female heir who inherits with other heiresses; a joint heiress.
Consortship: The condition of a consort; fellowship; partnership.
Culmination: The attainment of the highest point of altitude reached by a heavenly body; passage across the meridian; transit.
Chape: The piece by which an object is attached to something, as the frog of a scabbard or the metal loop at the back of a buckle by which it is fastened to a strap.
Choler: The bile; -- formerly supposed to be the seat and cause of irascibility.
committed: Bound or obligated, as under a pledge to a particular cause, action, or attitude.  Opposite of uncommitted.
Corporeally: In the body; in a bodily form or manner.
Confederacy: With the, the Confederate States of America.
cardiovascular: Of or pertaining to or involving the heart and blood vessels; as, cardiovascular conditioning.
carpeted: covered with or as if with carpeting or with carpeting as specified; often used in combination; as, the carpeted hallway; a flower-carpeted hillside.  Opposite of uncarpeted.
corncob pipe: a pipe{3} for smoking tobacco with a bowl made from a corncob.
Co\u00f6peration: The act of coöperating, or of operating together to one end; joint operation; concurrent effort or labor.
Caprella: a genus somprising the skeleton shrimp.
Classicist: One learned in the classics; an advocate for the classics.
Carabus: A genus of ground beetles, including numerous species. They devour many injurious insects.
Chromule: A general name for coloring matter of plants other than chlorophyll, especially that of petals.
Capacious: Having capacity; able to contain much; large; roomy; spacious; extended; broad; as, a capacious vessel, room, bay, or harbor.
Collationer: One who examines the sheets of a book that has just been printed, to ascertain whether they are correctly printed, paged, etc.
coffeeberry: an evergreen shrub of Western U.S. (Rhamnus californicus), bearing small red or black fruits; -- called also the California buckthorn.
Cudden: A clown; a low rustic; a dolt.
Convoy: The act of attending for defense; the state of being so attended; protection; escort.
Cittern: An instrument shaped like a lute, but strung with wire and played with a quill or plectrum.
Circumfusion: The act of pouring or spreading round; the state of being spread round.
Catacoustic: That part of acoustics which treats of reflected sounds or echoes See Acoustics.
Campanula: A large genus of plants bearing bell-shaped flowers, often of great beauty; -- also called bellflower.
Charlatanic: Of or like a charlatan; making undue pretension; empirical; pretentious; quackish.
Conductress: A woman who leads or directs; a directress.
cleaners: a shop where dry cleaning is done.
Cuon: a genus of canids including the Asiatic wild dog.
Caveating: Shifting the sword from one side of an adversary's sword to the other.
Cuinage: The stamping of pigs of tin, by the proper officer, with the arms of the duchy of Cornwall.
Candlepin: A form of bowling pin slender and nearly straight like a candle.
Cinnamene: Styrene (which was formerly called cinnamene because obtained from cinnamic acid). See Styrene.
cascara: the dried bark of the cascara buckthorn used as a laxative; -- called also cascara sagrada.
crampbark: a deciduous thicket-forming Old World shrub (Viburnum opulus) with clusters of white flowers and small bright red berries.
Conspiringly: In the manner of a conspirator; by conspiracy.
conker: the inedible nutlike seed of the horsechestnut.
Cauda galli: A plume-shaped fossil, supposed to be a seaweed, characteristic of the lower Devonian rocks; as, the cauda galli grit.
Crocein: A name given to any one of several yellow or scarlet dyestuffs of artificial production and complex structure.  In general they are diazo and sulphonic acid derivatives of benzene and naphthol.
Codist: A codifier; a maker of codes.
Chromograph: An apparatus by which a number of copies of {ritten katter, kaps, plons, etc., can be made; -- called also hectograph.
Cyperus: A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, and including the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and the Egyptian papyrus.
Clapbread: Oatmeal cake or bread clapped or beaten till it is thin.
Captation: A courting of favor or applause, by flattery or address; a captivating quality; an attraction.
Contamination: The act or process of contaminating; pollution; defilement; taint; also, that which contaminates.
Chemolysis: A term sometimes applied to the decomposition of organic substance into more simple bodies, by the use of chemical agents alone.
Cyclopteridae: a natural family comprising the lumpfishes.
Conscious: Possessing the faculty of knowing one's own thoughts or mental operations.
Conservant: Having the power or quality of conservation.
Croupous: Relating to or resembling croup; especially, attended with the formation of a deposit or membrane like that found in membranous croup; as, croupous laryngitis.
Cyclonoscope: An apparatus to assist in locating the center of a cyclone.
Cholecystotomy: The operation of making an opening in the gall bladder, as for the removal of a gallstone.
Chubby: Like a chub; plump, short, and thick.
Climb: The act of one who climbs; ascent by climbing.
Clime: A climate; a tract or region of the earth. See Climate.
Chromoblast: An embryonic cell which develops into a pigment cell.
Continental drive: A transmission arrangement in which the longitudinal crank shaft drives the rear wheels through a clutch, change-speed gear, countershaft, and two parallel side chains, in order.
Chevet: The extreme end of the chancel or choir; properly the round or polygonal part.
Carrancha: The Brazilian kite (Polyborus Brasiliensis); -- so called in imitation of its notes.
charcuterie: a delicatessen that specializes in dressed meats and meat dishes, particularly pork products.
Comandra: small genus of chiefly North American parasitic plants.
Cocainize: To treat or anæsthetize with cocaine.
Centrally: In a central manner or situation.
Cunette: A drain trench, in a ditch or moat; -- called also cuvette.
Cyphonism: A punishment sometimes used by the ancients, consisting in the besmearing of the criminal with honey, and exposing him to insects. It is still in use among some Oriental nations.
cationic: of or pertaining to cations; having a net positive charge; positively ionic; -- said of ions.  Contrasted with anionic.
Custodianship: Office or duty of a custodian.
Cubhood: The state of being a cub.
Calystegia: a genus of climbing or scrambling herbs; bindweed.
Constituent: The person or thing which constitutes, determines, or constructs.
Chiretta: A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India, having medicinal properties to the gentian, and esteemed as a tonic and febrifuge.
Cleanse: To render clean; to free from fith, pollution, infection, guilt, etc.; to clean.
Ctenophoric: Of or pertaining to the Ctenophora.
centromeric: pertaining to the centromere, the dense specialized portion of a chromosome to which the spindle attaches during mitosis.
Chafery: An open furnace or forge, in which blooms are heated before being wrought into bars.
Cabiric: Of or pertaining to the Cabiri, or to their mystical worship.
Citatory: Having the power or form of a citation; as, letters citatory.
Creeks: A tribe or confederacy of North American Indians, including the Muskogees, Seminoles, Uchees, and other subordinate tribes. They formerly inhabited Georgia, Florida, and Alabama.
Cyst: A pouch or sac without opening, usually membranous and containing morbid matter, which is accidentally developed in one of the natural cavities or in the substance of an organ.
clusia: an aromatic tree of the genus Clusia having large white or yellow or pink flowers.
Creeky: Containing, or abounding in, creeks; characterized by creeks; like a creek; winding.
Catkin: An ament; a species of inflorescence, consisting of a slender axis with many unisexual apetalous flowers along its sides, as in the willow and poplar, and (as to the staminate flowers) in the chestnut, oak, hickory, etc. -- so called from its resemblance to a cat's tail. See Illust. of Ament.
Colloquial: Pertaining to, or used in, conversation, esp. common and familiar conversation; conversational; hence, unstudied; informal; as, colloquial intercourse; colloquial phrases; a colloquial style.
corticoafferent: passing toward the cerebral cortex; -- of nerves and nerve impulses.
Chesterlite: A variety of feldspar found in crystals in the county of Chester, Pennsylvania.
Councilist: One who belongs to a council; one who gives an opinion.
Creosol: A colorless liquid resembling phenol or carbolic acid, homologous with pyrocatechin, and obtained from beechwood tar and gum guaiacum.
contraception: the intentional prevention of conception or impregnation, especially when accomplished by the use of contraceptive medications or devices; a form of birth control.
Chrismatory: A cruet or vessel in which chrism is kept.
coolant: a fluid (gas or liquid) used to cool a device by transferring heat away from one part to another.
chenfish: small silvery marine food fish (Genyonemus lineatus) found off California.
Cis-: A Latin preposition, sometimes used as a prefix in English words, and signifying on this side.
cumbersome: Burdensome or hindering, as a weight or drag; embarrassing; vexatious; cumbrous.
curbside: the edge of a sidewalk that borders a curb; as, policemen stood at intervals along the curbside
Consomm\u00e9: A clear soup or bouillion boiled down so as to be very rich.
Chichling: A leguminous plant (Lathyrus sativus), with broad flattened seeds which are sometimes used for food.
Consecration: The act or ceremony of consecrating; the state of being consecrated; dedication.
Curb roof: A roof having a double slope, or composed, on each side, of two parts which have unequal inclination; a gambrel roof.
Coal tar: A thick, black, tarry liquid, obtained by the distillation of bituminous coal in the manufacture of illuminating gas; used for making printer's ink, black varnish, etc. It is a complex mixture from which many substances have been obtained, especially hydrocarbons of the benzene or aromatic series.
citrulline: an amino acid that is an intermediate in the conversion of ornithine to arginine.
Caddice fly: a small mothlike species of trichopterous insect, whose larva is the caddice;  it has two pairs of hairy membranous wings and aquatic larvae.
Codlin: An apple fit to stew or coddle.
Coptis: small genus of low perennial herbs having yellow rhizomes and white or yellow flowers.
Caller: Cool; refreshing; fresh; as, a caller day; the caller air.
Chief: Highest in office or rank; principal; head.
Coptic: Of or pertaining to the Copts.
Centralism: The state or condition of being central; the combination of several parts into one whole; centralization.
Charterer: One who charters; esp. one who hires a ship for a voyage.
Crevasse: A deep crevice or fissure, as in embankment; one of the clefts or fissure by which the mass of a glacier is divided.
Climatic: Of or pertaining to a climate; depending on, or limited by, a climate.
Chartered: Granted or established by charter; having, or existing under, a charter; having a privilege by charter.
Calumnious: Containing or implying calumny; false, malicious, and injurious to reputation; slanderous; as, calumnious reports.
Cerebrology: The science which treats of the cerebrum or brain.
Compulsion: The act of compelling, or the state of being compelled; the act of driving or urging by force or by physical or moral constraint; subjection to force.
Centumviral: Of or pertaining to the centumviri, or to a centumvir.
Caudate: Having a tail; having a terminal appendage like a tail.  Opposite of acaudate.
Categorical: Of or pertaining to a category.
Cumene: A colorless oily hydrocarbon, C6H5.C3H7, obtained by the distillation of cuminic acid; -- called also cumol.
Chickadee: A small bird, the blackcap titmouse (Parus atricapillus), of North America; -- named from its note.
Capo tasto: A sort of bar or movable nut, attached to the finger board of a guitar or other  fretted instrument for the purpose of raising uniformly the pitch of all the strings.
Continuant: Continuing; prolonged; sustained; as, a continuant sound.
Circumstanced: Placed in a particular position or condition; situated.
Citrange: A citrous fruit produced by a cross between the sweet orange and the trifoliate orange (Citrus trifoliata). It is more acid and has a more pronounced aroma than the orange; the tree is hardier. There are several varieties.
Corpse: A human body in general, whether living or dead; -- sometimes contemptuously.
Coaly: Pertaining to, or resembling, coal; containing coal; of the nature of coal.
Cosmorama: An exhibition in which a series of views in various parts of the world is seen reflected by mirrors through a series of lenses, with such illumination, etc., as will make the views most closely represent reality.
Carbonate: A salt or carbonic acid, as in limestone, some forms of lead ore, etc.
