Catapeltic: Of or pertaining to a catapult.
Centigram: The hundredth part of a gram; a weight equal to .15432 of a grain. See Gram.
Compressibility: The quality of being compressible of being compressible; as, the compressibility of elastic fluids.
chondrichthian: a fish in which the skeleton may be calcified but not ossified; a cartilaginous fish.
Crus: That part of the hind limb between the femur, or thigh, and the ankle, or tarsus; the shank.
Cycadaceae: a natural family of ancient palmlike plants closely related to ferns in that fertilization is by means of spermatozoids.
Colonelcy: The office, rank, or commission of a colonel.
Considerableness: Worthiness of consideration; dignity; value; size; amount.
clocks: European weed naturalized in the southwestern U. S. and Mexico (Erodium cicutarium), having reddish decumbent stems with small fernlike leaves and small deep reddish-lavender flowers followed by slender pinlike fruits that stick straight up; it is often grown for forage.
Cerevis: A small visorless cap, worn by members of German student corps. It is made in the corps colors, and usually bears the insignia of the corps.
Councilman: A member of a council, especially of the common council of a city; a councilor.
corgi: either of two Welsh breeds of long-bodied short-legged dogs with erect ears and a foxlike head.
Calipee: A part of a turtle which is attached to the lower shell. It contains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a light yellowish color, much esteemed as a delicacy.
club moss: a primitive evergreen mosslike plant with spores in club-shaped strobiles, much used in winter decoration. The best known species is Lycopodium clavatum, but other Lycopodia are often called by this name. The spores form a highly inflammable powder.
Catagmatic: Having the quality of consolidating broken bones.
Campfight: A duel; the decision of a case by a duel.
Connutritious: Nutritious by force of habit; -- said of certain kinds of food.
Chivy: To goad, drive, hunt, throw, or pitch; to repeatedly cause annoyance or concern to.
Cephalaspis: A genus of fossil ganoid fishes found in the old red sandstone or Devonian formation. The head is large, and protected by a broad shield-shaped helmet prolonged behind into two lateral points.
Crook: To bend; to curve; to wind; to have a curvature.
Chatoyment: Changeableness of color, as in a mineral; play of colors.
Clypeus: The frontal plate of the head of an insect.
Connoisseur: One well versed in any subject; a skillful or knowing person; a critical judge of any art, particulary of one of the fine arts.
Consternation: Amazement or horror that confounds the faculties, and incapacitates for reflection; terror, combined with amazement; dismay.
Constable: A high officer in the monarchical establishments of the Middle Ages.
Curer: One who cures; a healer; a physician.
Coleperch: A kind of small black perch.
Cystotomy: The act or practice of opening cysts; esp., the operation of cutting into the bladder, as for the extraction of a calculus.
Consciousness: The state of being conscious; knowledge of one's own existence, condition, sensations, mental operations, acts, etc.
Collative: Passing or held by collation; -- said of livings of which the bishop and the patron are the same person.
Continuative: A term or expression denoting continuance.
Curtal friar: A friar who acted as porter at the gate of a monastery.
Cystotome: A knife or instrument used in cystotomy.
Caxton: Any book printed by William Caxton, the first English printer.
Cytogenous: Producing cells; -- applied esp. to lymphatic, or adenoid, tissue.
Convolvulaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of which the bindweed and the morning-glory are common examples.
Christs-thorn: One of several prickly or thorny shrubs found in Palestine, especially the Paliurus aculeatus, Zizyphus Spina-Christi, and Zizyphus vulgaris.  The last bears the fruit called jujube, and may be considered to have been the most readily obtainable for the Crown of Thorns.
cross-sectional: of or pertaining to a cross section; as, a cross-sectional slice.
Cerium: A rare metallic element, occurring in the minerals cerite, allanite, monazite, etc.  Symbol Ce.  Atomic weight 141.5. It resembles iron in color and luster, but is soft, and both malleable and ductile. It tarnishes readily in the air.
Concise: Expressing much in a few words; condensed; brief and compacted; -- used of style in writing or speaking.
Cerebriform: Like the brain in form or substance.
Cabin: To confine in, or as in, a cabin.
catwalk: a narrow walkway projecting from a stage into the seating area of a theater; it is used, e. g. by models displaying clothes on it at a fashion show.  Called also runway.
casaba: a winter melon having a yellowish rind; -- called also casaba melon.
Cyanotype: A photographic picture obtained by the use of a cyanide.
Centaurium: a genus of low-growing herbs mostly of the northern hemisphere having flowers with protruding spirally twisted anthers.
conjugated: formed by the union of two compounds; as, a conjugated protein.
Captivity: The state of being a captive or a prisoner.
Carthamin: A red coloring matter obtained from the safflower, or Carthamus tinctorius.
Chastisement: The act of chastising; pain inflicted for punishment and correction; discipline; punishment.
covariance: a statistical measure of the relationship of two variables, formed by multiplying the difference of each variable from its mean, both variables being measured at the same time, and averaging all such products.
Chthonophagia: A disease characterized by an irresistible desire to eat earth, observed in some parts of the southern United States, the West Indies, etc.
Crinal: Of or pertaining to the hair.
Chuffy: Fat or puffed out in the cheeks.
Capsaicin: A colorless crystalline substance extracted from the Capsicum annuum, and giving off vapors of intense acridity.
Contumelious: Exhibiting contumely; rudely contemptuous; insolent; disdainful.
chelated: combined with a chelator so as to form a chelate; -- of metal ions.
Cursed: Deserving a curse; execrable; hateful; detestable; abominable.
Cornuto: A man that wears the horns; a cuckold.
Conjuncture: The act of joining, or state of being joined; union; connection; combination.
Cornute: To bestow horns upon; to make a cuckold of; to cuckold.
Charlatanry: Undue pretensions to skill; quackery; wheedling; empiricism.
Chemisette: An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck, shoulders, and breast.
cross-file: to register as a candidate for more than one political party in the same election.
Celestine: A monk of the austere branch of the Franciscan Order founded by Celestine V. in the 13th centry.
Christcross: The mark of the cross, as cut, painted, written, or stamped on certain objects, -- sometimes as the sign of 12 o'clock on a dial.
cuticula: the outer body wall of an insect.
Church-ale: A church or parish festival (as in commemoration of the dedication of a church), at which much ale was used.
Crocus: A genus of iridaceous plants, with pretty blossoms rising separately from the bulb or corm. Crocus vernus is one of the earliest of spring-blooming flowers; Crocus sativus produces the saffron, and blossoms in the autumn.
Chickabiddy: A chicken; a fowl; also, a trivial term of endearment for a child.
Choroid: resembling the chorion; as, the choroid plexuses of the ventricles of the brain, and the choroid coat of the eyeball.
Crustacea: One of the classes of the arthropods, including lobsters and crabs; -- so called from the crustlike shell with which they are covered.
Chicle: A gumlike substance obtained from the bully tree (Mimusops globosa) and sometimes also from the naseberry or sapodilla (Sapota zapotilla). It is more plastic than caoutchouc and more elastic than gutta-percha, as an adulterant of which it is used in England. It is used largely in the United States in making chewing gum.
Chilognatha: One of the two principal orders of myriapods. They have numerous segments, each bearing two pairs of small, slender legs, which are attached ventrally, near together.
Commentate: To write comments or notes upon; to make comments.
crumbled: broken into small fragments; as, crumbled cookies.
Cragsman: One accustomed to climb rocks or crags; esp., one who makes a business of climbing the cliffs overhanging the sea to get the eggs of sea birds or the birds themselves.
Cluniac: A monk of the reformed branch of the Benedictine Order, founded in 912 at Cluny (or Clugny) in France. -- Also used as a.
Chesses: The platforms, consisting of two or more planks doweled together, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge.
Cheviot: A valuable breed of mountain sheep in Scotland, which takes its name from the Cheviot hills.
Chessel: The wooden mold in which cheese is pressed.
Corollate: Having a corolla or corollas; like a corolla.
criminalize: to declare (an act) to be illegal.
Cupuliferous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of which the oak and the chestnut are examples, -- trees bearing a smooth, solid nut inclosed in some kind of cup or bur; bearing, or furnished with, a cupule.
Chest founder: A rheumatic affection of the muscles of the breast and fore legs of a horse, affecting motion and respiration.
Clerkship: State, quality, or business of a clerk.
Cromlech: A monument of rough stones composed of one or more large ones supported in a horizontal position upon others. They are found chiefly in countries inhabited by the ancient Celts, and are of a period anterior to the introduction of Christianity into these countries.
Cete: One of the Cetacea, or collectively, the Cetacea.
Contrabass: The lowest stringed instrument of the violin family; the double bass; -- also applied to any instrument of the same deep range as the stringed double bass; as, the contrabass ophicleide; the contrabass tuba or bombardon.
Carabidae: a family of nocturnal, terrestrial insects consisting of the ground beetles, which feed chiefly on other insects.
Ciconiidae: a natural family of birds comprising the storks.
Caliph: Successor or vicar; the civil and religious leader of a Muslim state; -- a title of the successors of Mohammed both as temporal and spiritual rulers, used formerly by the sultans of Turkey.
Choke-full: Full to the brim; quite full; chock-full.
Convent: To call before a judge or judicature; to summon; to convene.
carthorse: a horse kept for pulling carts; a horse bred or used for drawing heavy loads.
Contributional: Pertaining to, or furnishing, a contribution.
collectivise: to bring under collective control; to organize for operation by the principles of collectivism; -- especially of farms and industrial enterprises.  Same as collectivize.
Cerotic: Pertaining to, or derived from, beeswax or Chinese wax; as, cerotic acid or alcohol.
Convene: To cause to assemble; to call together; to convoke.
Collocation: The act of placing; the state of being placed with something else; disposition in place; arrangement.
Cerotin: A white crystalline substance, C27H55.OH, obtained from Chinese wax, and regarded as an alcohol of the paraffin series; -- called also cerotic alcohol, ceryl alcohol.
Crowner: One who, or that which, crowns.
Cavally: A carangoid fish of the Atlantic coast (Caranx hippos): -- called also horse crevallé. [See Illust. under Carangoid.]
conforming: adhering to established customs or doctrines, especially in religion, as e.g. Orthodox Judaism.
Constate: To ascertain; to verify; to establish; to prove.
Casting: The act of one who casts or throws, as in fishing.
Canella-alba: A large evergreen shrub or small tree (Canella alba or Canella winterana) having white aromatic bark and leathery leaves and small purple to red flowers in terminal cymes.  Its bark is called wild cinnamon.
Childermas day: A day (December 28) observed by mass or festival in commemoration of the children slain by Herod at Bethlehem; -- called also Holy Innocent's Day.
catkinate: of, pertaining to, or resembling a catkin.
Chirologist: One who communicates thoughts by signs made with the hands and fingers.
Commodore: An officer who ranks next above a captain; sometimes, by courtesy, the senior captain of a squadron. The rank of commodore corresponds with that of brigadier general in the army.
Catalectic: Wanting a syllable at the end, or terminating in an imperfect foot; as, a catalectic verse.
Catawba: A well known light red variety of American grape.
Cudweed: A small composite plant with cottony or silky stem and leaves, primarily a species of Gnaphalium, but the name is now given to many plants of different genera, as Filago, Antennaria, etc.; cottonweed.
Contumacy: Stubborn perverseness; pertinacious resistance to authority.
Chastened: Corrected; disciplined; refined; purified; toned down.
Craniognomy: The science of the form and characteristics of the skull.
Circumflexion: The act of bending, or causing to assume a curved form.
Copernican: Pertaining to Copernicus, a Prussian by birth (b. 1473, d. 1543), who taught the world the solar system now received, called the Copernican system.
Caliduct: A pipe or duct used to convey hot air or steam.
Crowned: Having or wearing a crown; surmounted, invested, or adorned, with a crown, wreath, garland, etc.; honored; rewarded; completed; consummated; perfected.
carbon-14: a radioactive isotope of carbon with a half-life of 5730 years.  It occurs naturally in minute quantities, and is used as the basis for radiocarbon dating.
Chimerical: Merely imaginary; fanciful; fantastic; wildly or vainly conceived; having, or capable of having, no existence except in thought; as, chimerical projects.
Callosity: A hard or thickened spot or protuberance; a hardening and thickening of the skin or bark of a part, eps. as a result of continued pressure or friction.
Conundrum: A kind of riddle based upon some fanciful or fantastic resemblance between things quite unlike; a puzzling question, of which the answer is or involves a pun.
Crib: To crowd together, or to be confined, as in a crib or in narrow accommodations.
Circassian: Of or pertaining to Circassia, in Asia.
checkage: The act of checking; as, the checkage of a name or of an item in a list.
Close-stool: A utensil to hold a chamber vessel, for the use of the sick and infirm. It is usually in the form of a box, with a seat and tight cover.
Climacteric: A period in human life in which some great change is supposed to take place in the constitution. The critical periods are thought by some to be the years produced by multiplying 7 into the odd numbers 3, 5, 7, and 9; to which others add the 81st year.
Colinus: a genus of birds including the New World quail and the bobwhites.
Carbuncular: Belonging to a carbuncle; resembling a carbuncle; red; inflamed.
Confirm: To make firm or firmer; to add strength to; to establish; as, health is confirmed by exercise.
computer program: a sequence of instructions, stored in any medium, that can be interpreted and executed by a computer; -- called most frequently a program.  This term is used both for the written program (a document) and for its corresponding electronic version stored or executed on the computer.  See instruction; as, Version 1.0 of the program had a serious bug that caused the computer to crash frequently..
Cappeak: The front piece of a cap; -- now more commonly called visor.
Carminic: Of or pertaining to, or derived from, carmine.
cow-cockle: a European annual (Vaccaria hispanica) with pale rose-colored flowers; cultivated flower or self-sown grainfield weed; introduced in North America; sometimes classified as a soapwort.
Choose: To make a selection; to decide.
Cerosin: A waxy substance obtained from the bark of the sugar cane, and crystallizing in delicate white laminæ.
Conformist: One who conforms or complies; esp., one who conforms to the Church of England, or to the Established Church, as distinguished from a dissenter or nonconformist.
Candlenut: The fruit of a euphorbiaceous tree or shrub (Aleurites moluccana), native of some of the Pacific islands. It is used by the natives as a candle, the nut kernels being strung together. The oil from the nut (candlenut oil or kekune oil) has many uses, including as a varnish.
cigar-shaped: cylindrical, tapering at each end; having the shape of a cigar.
Classicalist: One who adheres to what he thinks the classical canons of art.
Cryptography: The act or art of writing in code or secret characters; also, secret characters, codes or ciphers, or messages written in a secret code.
Citrus: A genus of trees including the orange, lemon, lime, tangerine, citron, grapefruit, etc., originally natives of southern Asia.
Clear-cut: To cut (a region of forest) clear of all trees.  It is a method used for efficiently logging a portion of forest, but often has undesirable effects on the environment.
Carefulness: Quality or state of being careful.
Cassinette: A cloth with a cotton warp, and a woof of very fine wool, or wool and silk.
Crochet: To knit with a crochet needle or hook; as, to crochet a shawl.
Circulate: To cause to pass from place to place, or from person to person; to spread; as, to circulate a report; to circulate bills of credit.
Confervoid: Like, or related to, the confervae.
Clinorhombic: Possessing the qualities of a prism, obliquely inclined to a rhombic base; monoclinic.
Columbium: A rare element of the vanadium group, first found in a variety of the mineral columbite occurring in Connecticut, probably at Haddam. Atomic weight 94.2. Symbol Cb or Nb. Now more commonly called niobium.
Cubicular: Belonging to a chamber or bedroom.
chickenshit: a false statement that is considered to indicate timidity or fear.
Cascara buckthorn: The buckthorn (Rhamnus Purshiana) of the Pacific coast of the United States, which yields cascara sagrada.
Crumple: To contract irregularly; to show wrinkles after being crushed together; as, leaves crumple.
Comment: A remark, observation, or criticism; gossip; discourse; talk.
Committer: One who commits; one who does or perpetrates.
Cowpox: A pustular eruptive disease of the cow, which, when communicated to the human system, as by vaccination, protects from the smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox, cowpock, and kinepock.
Cuckooflower: A species of Cardamine (Cardamine pratensis), or lady's smock. Its leaves are used in salads. Also, the ragged robin (Lychnis Flos-cuculi).
Committee: One to whom the charge of the person or estate of another, as of a lunatic, is committed by suitable authority; a guardian.
Curvation: The act of bending or crooking.
classics: the branch of learning concerned with study of the literary works of ancient Greece and Rome.
Charadrius: the type genus of the Charadriidae; the plovers.
Catadicrotism: Quality or state of being catacrotic.
Commark: The frontier of a country; confines.
Curtate: Shortened or reduced; -- said of the distance of a planet from the sun or earth, as measured in the plane of the ecliptic, or the distance from the sun or earth to that point where a perpendicular, let fall from the planet upon the plane of the ecliptic, meets the ecliptic.
Caducous: Dropping off or disappearing early, as the calyx of a poppy, or the gills of a tadpole.
Cormophylogeny: The phylogeny of groups or families of individuals.
Coralline: A submarine, semicalcareous or calcareous plant, consisting of many jointed branches.
Chartometer: An instrument for measuring charts or maps.
Clothespin: A forked piece of wood or plastic, or a small device with a spring clamp, used for fastening clothes on a line.
Composite: That which is made up of parts or compounded of several elements; composition; combination; compound.
Counter-paly: Paly, and then divided fesswise, so that each vertical piece is cut into two, having the colors used alternately or counterchanged. Thus the escutcheon in the illustration may also be blazoned paly of six per fess counterchanged argent and azure.
Caddy: A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in, also called tea caddy.
crash-dive: to descend steeply and rapidly; -- of aircraft.
Cupbearer: One whose office it is to fill and hand the cups at an entertainment.
Cedrat: Properly the citron, a variety of Citrus medica, with large fruits, not acid, and having a high perfume.
Calaveras skull: A human skull reported, by Prof. J. D. Whitney, as found in 1886 in a Tertiary auriferous gravel deposit, lying below a bed of black lava, in Calaveras County, California. It is regarded as very doubtful whether the skull really belonged to the deposit in which it was found. If it did, it indicates an unprecedented antiquity for human beings of an advanced type.
Coccinellidae: a natural family of insects including the ladybugs.
Cowblakes: Dried cow dung used as fuel.
Chief baron: The presiding judge of the court of exchequer.
Conchite: A fossil or petrified conch or shell.
Creaturize: To make like a creature; to degrade
citywide: including or occurring in all parts of a city; as, citywide bussing; a citywide strike.
Consolidate: To grow firm and hard; to unite and become solid; as, moist clay consolidates by drying.
Carbon process: A printing process depending on the effect of light on bichromatized gelatin. Paper coated with a mixture of the gelatin and a pigment is called carbon paper or carbon tissue. This is exposed under a negative and the film is transferred from the paper to some other support and developed by washing (the unexposed portions being dissolved away). If the process stops here it is called single transfer; if the image is afterward transferred in order to give an unreversed print, the method is called double transfer.
Curvilineal: Consisting of, or bounded by, curved lines; as, a curvilinear figure.
Capriccio: A piece in a free form, with frequent digressions from the theme; a fantasia; -- often called caprice.
Curvilinead: An instrument for drawing curved lines.
Cageling: A bird confined in a cage; esp. a young bird.
Chloriodine: A compound of chlorine and iodine.
Clinographic: Pertaining to that mode of projection in drawing in which the rays of light are supposed to fall obliquely on the plane of projection.
Conversationed: Aaquaintea with m`nners aod deportment; behaved.
Clearwing: A lepidopterous insect with partially transparent wings, of the family Ægeriadæ, of which the currant and peach-tree borers are examples.
Campanulaceae: A natural family of flowering plants, which in some classifications includes the Lobeliaciae.
Camelry: Troops that are mounted on camels.
Cleanliness: State of being cleanly; neatness of person or dress.
Cotyledonary: Having a cotyledon; tufted; as, the cotyledonary placenta of the cow.
Cresset: An open frame or basket of iron, filled with combustible material, to be burned as a beacon; an open lamp or firrepan carried on a pole in nocturnal processions.
Circumforanean: Going about or abroad; walking or wandering from house to house.
Circumcision: The act of cutting off the prepuce or foreskin of males, or the internal labia of females.
Calculating: The act or process of making mathematical computations or of estimating results.
Complicity: The state of being an accomplice; participation in guilt.
Cupola: A roof having a rounded form, hemispherical or nearly so; also, a ceiling having the same form. When on a large scale it is usually called dome.
Composit\u00e6: A large family of dicotyledonous plants, having their flowers arranged in dense heads of many small florets and their anthers united in a tube. The daisy, dandelion, and asters, are examples.
Conglutinant: Cementing together; uniting closely; causing to adhere; promoting healing, as of a wound or a broken bone, by adhesion of the parts.
citrous: of or pertaining to a citrus tree; as, a citrous disease.
Chopboat: A licensed lighter employed in the transportation of goods to and from vessels.
Checkroll: A list of servants in a household; -- called also chequer roll.
Conifer: A tree or shrub bearing cones; one of the order Coniferae, which includes the pine, cypress, and (according to some) the yew.
Crippling: Spars or timbers set up as a support against the side of a building.
Coca: The dried leaf of a South American shrub (Erythroxylon Coca). In med., called Erythroxylon.
Cock: A corruption or disguise of the word God, used in oaths.
Checkerwork: Work consisting of or showing checkers varied alternately as to colors or materials.
Circumspective: Looking around every way; cautious; careful of consequences; watchful of danger.
complicating: the act or process of making something more complex.
Cloistral: Of, pertaining to, or confined in, a cloister; recluse.
Corticiform: Resembling, or having the form of, bark or rind.
Cogency: The quality of being cogent; power of compelling conviction; conclusiveness; force.
Comboloio: A Mohammedan rosary, consisting of ninety-nine beads.
Cabalist: One versed in the cabala, or the mysteries of Jewish traditions.
Circumferentially: So as to surround or encircle.
Compressed yeast: A cake yeast made by filtering the cells from the liquid in which they are grown, subjecting to heavy pressure, and mixing with starch or flour.
co-author: to to be an author of, together with another author or authors; to author jointly with others.
Civet: To scent or perfume with civet.
Circumscriptible: Capable of being circumscribed or limited by bounds.
Cinnabarine: Pertaining to, or resembling, cinnabar; consisting of cinnabar, or containing it; as, cinnabarine sand.
Connector: One who, or that which, connects
Calefactory: An apartment in a monastery, warmed and used as a sitting room.
Caracoly: An alloy of gold, silver, and copper, of which an inferior quality of jewelry is made.
Colorado group: A subdivision of the cretaceous formation of western North America, especially developed in Colorado and the upper Missouri region.
clitter: to make a shrill creaking noise by rubbing together special bodily structures, as of male insects such as crickets or grasshoppers.
Crincum-crancum: A twist; a whimsey or whim.
Canister: A small basket of rushes, reeds, or willow twigs, etc.
Caracole: To move in a caracole, or in caracoles; to wheel.
cutlass fish: a peculiar, long, thin, marine fish (Trichiurus lepturus) of the southern United States and West Indies, having a long whiplike scaleless body and sharp daggerlike teeth; -- called also frostfish, saber fish, silver eel, and, improperly, swordfish; also, several related members of the genus Trichiurus.  It is closely related to snake mackerel.
C\u0153nogamy: The state of a community which permits promiscuous sexual intercourse among its members; -- as in certain primitive tribes or communistic societies.
Copygraph: A contrivance for producing manifold copies of a writing or drawing; -- made obsolete by later developments in copying technology; see xerography.
Checkstring: A cord by which a person in a carriage or horse car may signal to the driver.
Concrescible: Capable of being changed from a liquid to a solid state.
Chica: A red coloring matter. extracted from the Bignonia Chica, used by some tribes of South American Indians to stain the skin.
Choliamb: A verse having an iambus in the fifth place, and a spondee in the sixth or last.
Chaussure: A foot covering of any kind.
Charlotte: A kind of pie or pudding made by lining a dish with slices of bread, and filling it with bread soaked in milk, and baked.
counter-subversion: the aspect of counterintelligence designed to detect and prevent subversive activities.
Cosupreme: A partaker of supremacy; one jointly supreme.
Collision: The act of striking together; a striking together, as of two hard bodies; a violent meeting, as of railroad trains; a clashing.
Citroncirus: a cross between Citrus sinensis and Poncirus trifoliata.
Co\u00f6perator: One who labors jointly with others to promote the same end.
Collectanea: Passages selected from various authors, usually for purposes of instruction; miscellany; anthology.
Conger: The conger eel; -- called also congeree.
C\u0153n\u0153cium: The common tissue which unites the various zooids of a bryozoan.
Cloud-capped: Having clouds resting on the top or head; reaching to the clouds; as, cloud-capped mountains.
Congeal: To grow hard, stiff, or thick, from cold or other causes; to become solid; to freeze; to cease to flow; to run cold; to be chilled.
Choleric: Abounding with, or producing choler, or bile.
Cementation: The act or process of cementing.
Cercopithecus: type genus of the Cercopithecidae, consisting of one genus of guenons.
Chartaceous: Resembling paper or parchment; of paper-like texture; papery.
cool-headed: Having a temper not easily excited; free from passion; unshakably calm and collected.
Cumbrian: Pertaining to Cumberland, England, or to a system of rocks found there.
Consensual: Existing, or made, by the mutual consent of two or more parties.
Cleopatra: a queen of Egypt; b. 69 b. c., d. 30 b. c.
Consonantal: Of the nature of a consonant; pertaining to consonants.
copper-bottom: to provide with a copper bottom.
Caldron: A large kettle or boiler of copper, brass, or iron. [Written also cauldron.]
Caseose: A soluble product (proteose) formed in the gastric and pancreatic digestion of casein and caseinogen.
Calceiform: Shaped like a slipper, as one petal of the lady's-slipper; calceolate.
Cyanine: One of a series of artificial blue or red dyes obtained from quinoline and lepidine and used in calico printing.
Celtiberian: Of or pertaining to the ancient Celtiberia (a district in Spain lying between the Ebro and the Tagus) or its inhabitants the Celtiberi (Celts of the river Iberus).
Capelin: Either of two small marine fishes formerly classified in the family Salmonidæ, now within the smelt family Osmeridae: Mallotus villosus, very abundant on the coasts of Greenland, Iceland, Newfoundland, and Alaska; or Mallotus catervarius, found in the North Pacific. The Atlantic variety has been used as a bait for the cod.
Contractedness: The state of being contracted; narrowness; meanness; selfishness.
coloradillo: a handsome shrub (Hamelia patens) with showy orange to scarlet or crimson flowers; it grows from Florida and West Indies to Mexico and Brazil.
Clothesline: A rope or wire on which clothes are hung to dry.
Construct: Formed by, or relating to, construction, interpretation, or inference.
cestode: Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.
Circumvection: The act of carrying anything around, or the state of being so carried.
Cavesson: A kind of noseband used in breaking and training horses.
Caboose: A house on deck, where the cooking is done; -- commonly called the galley.
Catholicize: To make or to become catholic or Roman Catholic.
cavalry-sword: a stout sword with a curved blade and thick back.
Comprehensiveness: The quality of being comprehensive; extensiveness of scope.
Copartnership: The state of being a copartner or of having a joint interest in any matter.
Conducibility: The state or quality of being conducible; conducibleness.
Cephalometry: The measurement of the heads of living persons.
Copperworm: The teredo; -- so called because it injures the bottoms of vessels, where not protected by copper.
Corruptive: Having the quality of tainting or vitiating; tending to produce corruption.
Coolung: The great gray crane of India (Grus cinerea).
Corral: To surround and inclose; to coop up; to put into an inclosed space; -- primarily used with reference to securing horses and cattle in an inclosure of wagons while traversing the plains, but in the Southwestern United States now colloquially applied to the capturing, securing, or penning of anything.
Claire: A small inclosed pond used for gathering and greening oysters.
Cassideous: Helmet-shaped; -- applied to a corolla having a broad, helmet-shaped upper petal, as in aconite.
Craggy: Full of crags; rugged with projecting points of rocks; as, the craggy side of a mountain.
Coracle: A boat made by covering a wicker frame with leather or oilcloth. It was used by the ancient Britons, and is still used by fisherman in Wales and some parts of Ireland. Also, a similar boat used in Tibet and in Egypt.
Circumventive: Tending to circumvent; deceiving by artifices; deluding.
Croaker: One who croaks, murmurs, grumbles, or complains unreasonably; one who habitually forebodes evil.
Coercion: The act or process of coercing.
Cariamidae: a natural family of cranelike South American wading birds.
Cipolin: A whitish marble, from Rome, containiing pale greenish zones. It consists of calcium carbonate, with zones and cloudings of talc.
Curvirostres: A group of passerine birds, including the creepers and nuthatches.
Cruciferae: a natural family of plants with four-petaled flowers; the mustard family.
Clothier: One who makes cloths; one who dresses or fulls cloth.
C Q D: In radiotelegraphy, the letters signified by the code call formerly used (cf. S O S) by ships in distress, formed by combining the code call C Q (formerly used as a general call for all stations) with D for distress.
Chersonese: A peninsula; a tract of land nearly surrounded by water, but united to a larger tract by a neck of land or isthmus; as, the Cimbric Chersonese, or Jutland; the Tauric Chersonese, or Crimea.
Circum-: A Latin preposition, used as a prefix in many English words, and signifying around or about.
Collingual: Having, or pertaining to, the same language.
Crepitus: The noise produced by a sudden discharge of wind from the bowels.
Cudbear: A powder of a violet red color, difficult to moisten with water, used for making violet or purple dye. It is prepared from certain species of lichen, especially Lecanora tartarea.
Cesser: a neglect of a tenant to perform services, or make payment, for two years.
Cataclysmist: One who believes that the most important geological phenomena have been produced by cataclysms.
Cockshut: A kind of net to catch woodcock.
Constructiveness: Tendency or ability to form or construct.
colonnaded: having a series of columns arranged at regular intervals; furnished with a colonnade.
Court-leet: A court of record held once a year, in a particular hundred, lordship, or manor, before the steward of the leet.
Cringe: Servile civility; fawning; a shrinking or bowing, as in fear or servility.
Cauliflower: An annual variety of Brassica oleracea, or cabbage, of which the cluster of young flower stalks and buds is eaten as a vegetable.
Crystal: Consisting of, or like, crystal; clear; transparent; lucid; pellucid; crystalline.
Characterize: To make distinct and recognizable by peculiar marks or traits; to make with distinctive features.
Cenobitic: Of or pertaining to a cenobite.
Chevrotain: A small ruminant of the family Tragulidæ a allied to the musk deer. It inhabits Africa and the East Indies. See Kanchil.
Colt pistol: A self-loading or semi-automatic pistol with removable magazine in the handle holding seven cartridges. The recoil extracts and ejects the empty cartridge case, and reloads ready for another shot. Called also Browning pistol, Colt-Browning pistol, automatic pistol and automatic.
Ceylon: the former name of an island republic in the Indian Ocean off the southeast coast of India, now called Sri Lanka.  It is an independent nation with an area of 25,332 sq. mi. and a population of about 14 million people.
Civilization: The act of civilizing, or the state of being civilized; national culture; refinement.
Cryptonym: A secret name; a name by which a person is known only to the initiated.
Crith: The unit for estimating the weight of aëriform substances; -- the weight of a liter of hydrogen at 0° centigrade, and with a tension of 76 centimeters of mercury. It is 0.0896 of a gram, or 1.38274 grains.
Cymoscope: Any device for detecting the presence of electric waves. The influence of electric waves on the resistance of a particular kind of electric circuit, on the magnetization of steel, on the polarization of an electrolytic cell, or on the electric condition of a vacuum has been applied in the various cymoscopes.
Croak: The coarse, harsh sound uttered by a frog or a raven, or a like sound.
Cladonia: the type genus of Cladoniaceae; lichens characterized by a crustose thallus and capitate fruiting bodies borne on simple or branched podetia.
Cut-off: That which cuts off or shortens, as a nearer passage or road.
Cleanser: One who, or that which, cleanses; especially, a detergent or other preparation used for cleaning.
Cross-birth: Any preternatural labor, in which the body of the child lies across the pelvis of the mother, so that the shoulder, arm, or trunk is the part first presented at the mouth of the uterus.
Crow-quill: A quill of the crow, or a very fine pen made from such a quill.
Chromous: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, chromium, when this element has a valence lower than that in chromic compounds.
Chronologic: Relating to chronology; containing an account of events in the order of time; according to the order of time; as, chronological tables.
Countersunk: Chamfered at the top; -- said of a hole.
Chondrite: A meteoric stone characterized by the presence of chondrules.
Compendious: Containing the substance or general principles of a subject or work in a narrow compass; abridged; summarized.
Celsius: The Celsius thermometer or scale, so called from Anders Celsius, a Swedish astronomer, who invented it. It is the same as the centigrade thermometer or scale.
candela: the basic unit of luminous intensity adopted under the System International d'Unites.
citrin: a vitamin that maintains the resistance of cell and capillary walls to permeation; -- called also vitamin P.
Castanea: A genus of nut-bearing trees or shrubs including the chestnut and chinquapin.
Comprehensibly: With great extent of signification; comprehensively.
Corporality: The state of being or having a body; bodily existence; corporeality; -- opposed to spirituality.
cultivated: marked by refinement in taste and manners; as, cultivated tastes in art.
Chilled: Hardened on the surface or edge by chilling; as, chilled iron; a chilled wheel.
Contractor: One who contracts; one of the parties to a bargain; one who covenants to do anything for another; specifically, one who contracts to perform work on a rather large scale, at a certain price or rate, as in building houses or making a railroad.
Coheirship: The state of being a coheir.
coatroom: a room where coats and other articles can be left temporarily; -- called also cloakroom.
Crofter: One who rents and tills a small farm or holding; as, the crofters of Scotland.
Capitibranchiata: A division of annelids in which the gills arise from or near the head. See Tubicola.
Courche: A square piece of linen used formerly by women instead of a cap; a kerchief.
curatorial: of or pertaining to curator; as, curatorial duties.
Capsular: Of or pertaining to a capsule; having the nature of a capsule; hollow and fibrous.
Cadetship: The position, rank, or commission of a cadet; as, to get a cadetship.
Concentrate: To approach or meet in a common center; to consolidate; as, population tends to concentrate in cities.
CER: a conditioned emotional response, an emotional response that has been acquired by conditioning.
Chopchurch: An exchanger or an exchange of benefices.
Conchal: Pertaining to the concha, or external ear; as, the conchal cartilage.
Cleavers: A species of Galium (Galium Aparine), having a fruit set with hooked bristles, which adhere to whatever they come in contact with; -- called also, goose grass, catchweed, etc.
Crystallology: The science of the crystalline structure of inorganic bodies.
Controlment: The power or act of controlling; the state of being restrained; control; restraint; regulation; superintendence.
Comity: Mildness and suavity of manners; courtesy between equals; friendly civility; as, comity of manners; the comity of States.
Curve: To bend or turn gradually from a given direction; as, the road curves to the right.
Caladium: A genus of aroideous plants, of which some species are cultivated for their immense leaves (which are often curiously blotched with white and red), and others (in Polynesia) for food.
Churchly: Pertaining to, or suitable for, the church; ecclesiastical.
Corroborative: A medicine that strengthens; a corroborant.
Conveyancing: The business of a conveyancer; the act or business of drawing deeds, leases, or other writings, for transferring the title to property from one person to another.
Cosmopolitanism: The quality of being cosmopolitan; cosmopolitism.
Cockhorse: Lifted up, as one is on a tall horse.
Coal-whipper: One who raises coal out of the hold of a ship.
Chromolithography: Lithography adapted to printing in inks of various colors.
Cranium: The skull of an animal; especially, that part of the skull, either cartilaginous or bony, which immediately incloses the brain; the brain case or brainpan. See Skull.
Conscientious: Influenced by conscience; governed by a strict regard to the dictates of conscience, or by the known or supposed rules of right and wrong; -- said of a person.
Coagency: Agency in common; joint agency or agent.
Commutable: Capable of being commuted or interchanged.
Carib: A native of the Caribbee islands or the coasts of the Caribbean sea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of South America, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West India islands.
Coaxingly: In a coaxing manner; by coaxing.
Crasis: A mixture of constituents, as of the blood; constitution; temperament.
Chewink: An american bird (Pipilo erythrophthalmus) of the Finch family, so called from its note; -- called also rufous-sided towhee, towhee, towhee bunting and ground robin.
Calamander wood: A valuable furniture wood from India and Ceylon, of a hazel-brown color, with black stripes, very hard in texture. It is a species of ebony, and is obtained from the Diospyros quæsita. Called also Coromandel wood.
conga: music composed for dancing the conga.
Conduit: A pipe, canal, channel, or passage for conveying water or fluid.
Circumgyrate: To roll or turn round; to cause to perform a rotary or circular motion.
Conspurcation: The act of defiling; defilement; pollution.
Cinque-pace: A lively dance (called also galliard), the steps of which were regulated by the number five.
Cheirotherium: A genus of extinct animals, so named from fossil footprints rudely resembling impressions of the human hand, and believed to have been made by labyrinthodont reptiles. See Illustration in Appendix.
cathectic: of or pertaining to cathexis; invested with mental or emotional energy.
Crofton system: A system of prison discipline employing for consecutive periods cellular confinement, associated imprisonment under the mark system, restraint intermediate between imprisonment and freedom, and liberation on ticket of leave.
Cauma: Great heat, as of the body in fever.
Catalonia: a geographical and administrative region of northeastern Spain.
commutativity: the property of a binary operation or operator such that the result of one term operating on a second is equal to the result of the second term operating on the first.
Clydesdale terrier: One of a breed of small silky-haired terriers related to, but smaller than, the Skye terrier, having smaller and perfectly erect ears.
Congelation: The act or process of passing, or causing to pass, from a fluid to a solid state, as by the abstraction of heat; the act or process of freezing.
clanging: emitting a series of clangs, as of metal objects colliding.
Caoutchin: An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained by the destructive distillation of caoutchouc.
Ceraceous: Having the texture and color of new wax; like wax; waxy.
Canderos: An East Indian resin, of a pellucid white color, from which small ornaments and toys are sometimes made.
Cosmogony: The creation of the world or universe; a theory or account of such creation; as, the poetical cosmogony of Hesoid; the cosmogonies of Thales, Anaxagoras, and Plato.
Confiscation: The act or process of taking property or condemning it to be taken, as forfeited to the public use.
Consecratory: Of or pertaining to the act of consecration; dedicatory.
Connect: To join, unite, or cohere; to have a close relation; as, one line of railroad connects with another; one argument connects with another.
Coreopsis: A genus of herbaceous composite plants, having the achenes two-horned and remotely resembling some insect; tickseed.  Coreopsis tinctoria, of the Western plains, the commonest plant of the genus, has been used in dyeing.
Crispy: Formed into short, close ringlets; frizzed; crisp; as, crispy locks.
Continuance: A holding on, or remaining in a particular state; permanence, as of condition, habits, abode, etc.; perseverance; constancy; duration; stay.
Ciconiiformes: an order of chiefly tropical marsh-dwelling fish-eating wading birds with long legs and bills and (except for flamingos) unwebbed feet, including the herons; storks; spoonbills; flamingos; and ibises.
Chenopodium: a genus of plants comprising the goosefoots and including the pigweed.
Caprification: The practice of hanging, upon the cultivated fig tree, branches of the wild fig infested with minute hymenopterous insects.
Corndodger: A cake made of the meal of Indian corn, wrapped in a covering of husks or paper, and baked under the embers.
Chondrichthyes: the class of fishes comprising the cartilaginous fishes, which includes the sharks.
Cadrans: An instrument with a graduated disk by means of which the angles of gems are measured in the process of cutting and polishing.
Corporeality: The state of being corporeal; corporeal existence.
Canker rash: A form of scarlet fever characterized by ulcerated or putrid sore throat.
Cat-hole: One of two small holes astern, above the gunroom ports, through which hawsers may be passed.
campmate: someone who lives in the same camp as another.
Cheval: A horse; hence, a support or frame.
Compassable: Capable of being compassed or accomplished.
Contract: The agreement of two or more persons, upon a sufficient consideration or cause, to do, or to abstain from doing, some act; an agreement in which a party undertakes to do, or not to do, a particular thing; a formal bargain; a compact; an interchange of legal rights.
Cacoon: One of the seeds or large beans of a tropical vine (Entada scandens) used for making purses, scent bottles, etc.
Caryophyllaceous: Having corollas of five petals with long claws inclosed in a tubular, calyx, as the pink
Clavicle: The collar bone, which is joined at one end to the scapula, or shoulder blade, and at the other to the sternum, or breastbone. In man each clavicle is shaped like the letter &unr_;, and is situated just above the first rib on either side of the neck. In birds the two clavicles are united ventrally, forming the merrythought, or wishbone.
Carousing: That carouses; relating to a carouse.
Counterplot: A plot or artifice opposed to another.
Comfortless: Without comfort or comforts; in want or distress; cheerless.
Comprehensively: In a comprehensive manner; with great extent of scope.
Cobwork: Built of logs, etc., laid horizontally, with the ends dovetailed together at the corners, as in a log house; in marine work, often surrounding a central space filled with stones; as, a cobwork dock or breakwater.
Contracture: A state of permanent rigidity or contraction of the muscles, generally of the flexor muscles.
Catalytic: An agent employed in catalysis, as platinum black, aluminium chloride, etc.
critical point: That combination of volume and pressure, at the critical temperature of the substance, at which the liquid and gaseous phases of a given quantity of a substance have identical values for their densities and other properties.
Canto: One of the chief divisions of a long poem; a book.
Crup: See Croup, the rump of a horse.
Commandment: An order or injunction given by authority; a command; a charge; a precept; a mandate.
Conterminous: Having the same bounds, or limits; bordering upon; contiguous.
carcinogen: Any substance that produces cancer; as, to test for carcinogens in the drinking water.
Chrysophyceae: a class of yellow-green algae, all of which have flagella of unequal length.
comprehendible: able to be understood.  Opposite of incomprehensible.
Conformableness: The quality of being conformable; conformability.
Cubit: The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbow to wrist.
Charadriidae: a natural family of birds comprising the plovers.
Crispation: The act or process of curling, or the state of being curled.
Courage: To inspire with courage; to encourage.
creamer: a small pitcher for serving cream; as, the coffee set included a sugar bowl and creamer.
Cottage: A small house; a cot; a hut.
Coccus: One of the separable carpels of a dry fruit.
Clayes: Wattles, or hurdles, made with stakes interwoven with osiers, to cover lodgments.
Cognomen: The last of the three names of a person among the ancient Romans, denoting his house or family.
Celadon: A pale sea-green color; also, porcelain or fine pottery of this tint.
Coal: To take in coal; as, the steamer coaled at Southampton.
Cingulum: A distinct girdle or band of color; a raised spiral line as seen on certain univalve shells.
C\u0153rulignone: A bluish violet, crystalline substance obtained in the purification of crude wood vinegar. It is regarded as a complex quinone derivative of diphenyl; -- called also cedriret.
Callithrix: the type genus of the Callithricidae; the true marmosets.
Coag: See Coak, a kind of tenon.
Coverer: One who, or that which, covers.
Cosmometry: The art of measuring the world or the universe.
Cl\u00e9ch\u00e9: Charged with another bearing of the same figure, and of the color of the field, so large that only a narrow border of the first bearing remains visible; -- said of any heraldic bearing. Compare Voided.
Carbonyl: The radical (CO)'', occuring, always combined, in many compounds, as the aldehydes, the ketones, urea, carbonyl chloride, etc.
Constructer: One who, or that which, constructs or frames.
Cathode: The part of a voltaic battery by which the electric current leaves substances through which it passes, or the surface at which the electric current passes out of the electrolyte; the negative pole; -- opposed to anode.
Curarine: A deadly alkaloid extracted from the curare poison and from the Strychnos toxifera. It is obtained in crystalline colorless salts.
Cetyl: A radical, C16H33, not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in a series of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derived from spermaceti.
Cordite: A smokeless powder composed of nitroglycerin, guncotton, and mineral jelly, and used by the British army and in other services. In making it the ingredients are mixed into a paste with the addition of acetone and pressed out into cords  (of various diameters) resembling brown twine, which are dried and cut to length. A variety containing less nitroglycerin than the original is known  as cordite M. D.
caning: something made of interlaced slender branches of especially willow.
Continually: Without cessation; unceasingly; continuously; as, the current flows continually.
cowpoke: a hired hand who tends cattle and performs other duties on horseback; -- an informal name for cowboy.
cyclotron:
a particle accelerator that 
imparts energies of several million electron-volts to rapidly moving particles; it is used in investigations in nuclear physics and particle physics.
Commentator: One who writes a commentary or comments; an expositor; an annotator.
C\u00e6sural: Of or pertaining to a cæsura.
Chalcographer: An engraver on copper or brass; hence, an engraver of copper plates for printing upon paper.
Cajuput: A highly stimulating volatile inflammable oil, distilled from the leaves of an East Indian tree (Melaleuca cajuputi, etc.) It is greenish in color and has a camphoraceous odor and pungent taste.
Cr\u0153sus: A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for a very rich man; as, he is a veritable Crœsus.
Codpiece: A part of male dress in front of the breeches, formerly made very conspicuous.
Coleus: A plant of several species of the Mint family, cultivated for its bright-colored or variegated leaves.
Claudent: Shutting; confining; drawing together; as, a claudent muscle.
consternate: to cause to be confused; confuse emotionally; to dismay.
China ware: dishes made of china; porcelain; -- so called in the 17th century because brought from the far East, and differing from the pottery made in Europe at that time; also, loosely, crockery in general.
Chromite: A black submetallic mineral consisting of oxide of chromium and iron; -- called also chromic iron.
Congenerous: Allied in origin or cause; congeneric; as, congenerous diseases.
Croton: A genus of euphorbiaceous plants belonging to tropical countries.
Chian: Of or pertaining to Chios, an island in the Ægean Sea.
Crystallize: To cause to form crystals, or to assume the crystalline form.
Corduroy: To form of logs laid side by side.
Clerisy: The literati, or well educated class.
Clamper: An instrument of iron, with sharp prongs, attached to a boot or shoe to enable the wearer to walk securely upon ice; a creeper.
Cackerel: The mendole; a small worthless Mediterranean fish considered poisonous by the ancients. See Mendole.
Crestless: Without a crest or escutcheon; of low birth.
Commonness: State or quality of being common or usual; as, the commonness of sunlight.
Cottrel: A trammel, or hook to support a pot over a fire.
Christendom: The profession of faith in Christ by baptism; hence, the Christian religion, or the adoption of it.
coverall: a loose-fitting one-piece garment that is worn over other clothing, especially one with trouser-like pants legs.
Complexion: The state of being complex; complexity.
Castrato: A male person castrated for the purpose of improving his voice for singing; an artificial, or male, soprano.
Chalazal: Of or pertaining to the chalaza.
Culler: One who picks or chooses; esp., an inspector who selects wares suitable for market.
Crocidolite: A mineral occuring in silky fibers of a lavender blue color. It is related to hornblende and is essentially a silicate of iron and soda; -- called also blue asbestus. A silicified form, in which the fibers penetrating quartz are changed to oxide of iron, is the yellow brown tiger-eye of the jewelers.
Castrate: To deprive of the testicles; to emasculate; to geld; to alter.
Chattel: Any item of movable or immovable property except the freehold, or the things which are parcel of it. It is a more extensive term than goods or effects.
Curialist: One who belongs to the ultramontane party in the Latin Church.
Catadioptrics: The science which treats of catadioptric phenomena, or of the used of catadioptric instruments.
Cross-garnet: A hinge having one strap perpendicular and the other strap horizontal giving it the form of an Egyptian or T cross.
Chatter: Sounds like those of a magpie or monkey; idle talk; rapid, thoughtless talk; jabber; prattle.
Cochleate: Having the form of a snail shell; spiral; turbinated.
Carpentering: The occupation or work of a carpenter; the act of working in timber; carpentry.
Cambistry: The science of exchange, weight, measures, etc.
Candlebomb: A small glass bubble, filled with water, which, if placed in the flame of a candle, bursts by expansion of steam.
Coursey: A space in the galley; a part of the hatches.
Consequently: By consequence; by natural or logical sequence or connection.
Caseous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, cheese; having the qualities of cheese; cheesy.
Coehorn: A small bronze mortar mounted on a wooden block with handles, and light enough to be carried short distances by two men.
Cyprus: A thin, transparent stuff, the same as, or corresponding to, crape. It was either white or black, the latter being most common, and used for mourning.
Cavalcade: A procession of persons on horseback; a formal, pompous march of horsemen by way of parade.
Conviviality: The good humor or mirth indulged in upon festive occasions; a convivial spirit or humor; festivity.
conveying: the act of transferring a property title from one person to another.
Catchy: Apt or tending to catch the fancy or attention; catching; taking; as, catchy music.
Cysticerce: The larval form of a tapeworm, having the head and neck of a tapeworm attached to a saclike body filled with fluid; -- called also bladder worm, hydatid, and measle (as, pork measle).
Circumambage: A roundabout or indirect course; indirectness.
Cleft: A space or opening made by splitting; a crack; a crevice; as, the cleft of a rock.
Crabbing: The act or art of catching crabs.
Convertend: Any proposition which is subject to the process of conversion; -- so called in its relation to itself as converted, after which process it is termed the converse. See Converse, n. (Logic).
Contention: A violent effort or struggle to obtain, or to resist, something; contest; strife.
Colorless: Without color; not distinguished by any hue; transparent; as, colorless water; a colorless gas.
Cigarette: A little cigar; a little fine tobacco rolled in paper for smoking.
Choralist: A singer or composer of chorals.
Codeine: One of the opium alkaloids; a white crystalline substance, C18H21NO3, similar to and regarded as a derivative of morphine, but much feebler in its action; -- called also codeia.
Contradiction: An assertion of the contrary to what has been said or affirmed; denial of the truth of a statement or assertion; contrary declaration; gainsaying.
chimneypot: a short earthenware pipe on the top of a chimney to increase the draft.
Curio: Any curiosity{3} or article of virtu; any object esteemed for its unusual nature.
Contemplativeness: The state of being contemplative; thoughtfulness.
Caryophyllales: an order of plants which corresponds approximately to the older group Centrospermae.
corticoefferent: directed from the cerebral cortex; -- of nerves and nerve impulses.
Conductibility: Capability of being conducted; as, the conductibility of heat or electricity.
Caterwauling: The cry of cats; a harsh, disagreeable noise or cry like the cry of cats.
candyweed: bog plant (Polygala lutea) of pine barrens of southeastern U.S. having spikes of irregular yellow-orange flowers.
Clericity: The state of being a clergyman.
Conestoga wagon: A kind of large broad-wheeled wagon, usually covered, for traveling in soft soil and on prairies.
Couth: Could; was able; knew or known; understood.
Chairman: The presiding officer of a committee, or of a public or private meeting, or of any organized body.
centralizing: causing to concentrate at a center.  Opposite of decentralizing.
Crossbones: A representation of two of the leg bones or arm bones of a skeleton, laid crosswise, often surmounted with a skull, and serving as a symbol of death.
Circumgyration: The act of turning, rolling, or whirling round.
container ship: a ship designed to hold containerized cargoes.
Castoreum: A peculiar bitter orange-brown substance, with strong, penetrating odor, found in two sacs between the anus and external genitals of the beaver; castor; -- used in medicine as an antispasmodic, and by perfumers.
Cubo-octahedron: A combination of a cube and octahedron, esp. one in which the octahedral faces meet at the middle of the cubic edges.
Consult: The act of consulting or deliberating; consultation; also, the result of consulation; determination; decision.
Crural: Of or pertaining to the thigh or leg, or to any of the parts called crura; as, the crural arteries; crural arch; crural canal; crural ring.
Compony: Divided into squares of alternate tinctures in a single row; -- said of any bearing; or, in the case of a bearing having curved lines, divided into patches of alternate colors following the curve. If there are two rows it is called counter-compony.
Carbonize: To convert (an animal or vegetable substance) into a residue of carbon by the action of fire or some corrosive agent; to char.
Codicil: A clause added to a will.
Chazy epoch: An epoch at the close of the Canadian period of the American Lower Silurian system; -- so named from a township in Clinton Co., New York. See the Diagram under Geology.
Cavendish: Leaf tobacco softened, sweetened, and pressed into plugs or cakes.
Corruptible: That which may decay and perish; the human body.
crushed: treated so as to have a permanently wrinkled appearance; -- of fabrics; as, crushed velvet.
cashed: converted into currency; -- of financial instruments; as, a cashed check.
Conservancy: Conservation, as from injury, defilement, or irregular use.
Complainer: One who complains or laments; one who finds fault; a murmurer.
Calcic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, calcium or lime.
Corrade: To gnaw into; to wear away; to fret; to consume.
Choragic: Of or pertaining to a choragus.
Caprine: Of or pertaining to a goat; as, caprine gambols.
Circumambiency: The act of surrounding or encompassing.
Cologne: A perfumed liquid, composed of alcohol and certain aromatic oils, used in the toilet; -- called also cologne water and eau de cologne.
Clutter: To clot or coagulate, as blood.
clarinetist: a musician who plays the clarinet.
Cadi: An inferior magistrate or judge among the Mohammedans, usually the judge of a town or village.
Crossruff: The play in bridge or whist where partners trump each a different suit, and lead to each other for that purpose; -- called also seesaw.
Chuckle: To laugh in a suppressed or broken manner, as expressing inward satisfaction, exultation, or derision.
Colony counter: an instrument designed to conveniently count or assist counting colonies{9} of microorganisms on a plate containing a gelled growth medium.  One variety uses a pencil-like rod with a metal tip, which is connected by an electrical connection to the gelled growth medium; when touched to a colony{9} on the plate, the completion of the  electrical circuit causes an increment of 1 unit on the readout of the colony counter.
Centricity: The state or quality of being centric; centricalness.
Crack: Of superior excellence; having qualities to be boasted of; as, a crack shot.
Cataian: A native of Cathay or China; a foreigner; -- formerly a term of reproach.
Commemorative: something that commemorates, especially a postage stamp or coin having a design commemorating some event, person, institution, etc.
Cuckoobud: A species of Ranunculus (Ranunculus bulbosus); -- called also butterflower, buttercup, kingcup, goldcup.
Chastity: The state of being chaste; purity of body; freedom from unlawful sexual intercourse.
Cyclostomata: A division of Bryozoa, in which the cells have circular apertures.
Cornflower: A conspicuous wild flower (Centaurea Cyanus), growing in grainfields.
Clever: Possessing quickness of intellect, skill, dexterity, talent, or adroitness; expert.
Coletit: A small European titmouse (Parus ater), so named from its black color; -- called also coalmouse and colemouse.
Cynanthropy: A kind of madness in which men fancy themselves changed into dogs, and imitate the voice and habits of that animal.
Contradistinctive: having the quality of contradistinction; distinguishing by contrast.
Coronoid: Resembling the beak of a crow; as, the coronoid process of the jaw, or of the ulna.
Cretonne: A strong white fabric with warp of hemp and weft of flax.
Centesimation: The infliction of the death penalty upon one person in every hundred, as in cases of mutiny.
Candlewaster: One who consumes candles by being up late for study or dissipation.
coated: covered with an outer layer or film; as, sugar-coated pills.
Chappy: Full of chaps; cleft; gaping; open.
Chinse: To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel , the point of a knife, or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly.
Cessionary: Having surrendered the effects; as, a cessionary bankrupt.
Colliquable: Liable to melt, grow soft, or become fluid.
Chronographer: One who writes a chronography; a chronologer.
Clearance: The act of clearing; as, to make a thorough clearance.
Cinque Ports: Five English ports, to which peculiar privileges were anciently accorded; -- viz., Hastings, Romney, Hythe, Dover, and Sandwich; afterwards increased by the addition of Winchelsea, Rye, and some minor places.
chlortetracycline: a yellow crystalline antibacterial antibiotic used to treat certain bacterial and rickettsial diseases. Aureomycin is one common trademark for chlortetracycline.
Clubhouse: A house occupied by a club.
Cablelaid: Composed of three three-stranded ropes, or hawsers, twisted together to form a cable.
crankcase: the housing for a crankshaft and connecting parts in an internal-combustion engine.
Churchy: Relating to a church; unduly fond of church forms.
Ciliograde: Moving by means of cilia, or cilialike organs; as, the ciliograde Medusæ.
Conspiracy: A combination of people for an evil purpose; an agreement, between two or more persons, to commit a crime in concert, as treason; a plot.
Cenozoic: Belonging to the most recent division of geological time, including the tertiary, or Age of mammals, and the Quaternary, or Age of man. [Written also cænozoic, cainozoic, kainozoic.] See Geology.
Caber: A pole or beam, esp. one used in Gaelic games for tossing as a trial of strength.
cypress-pine: any of several evergreen trees or shrubs of Australia and N Caledonia.
carborundum cloth: Cloth or paper covered with powdered carborundum; -- a foprm of sandpaper.
Cloven-footed: Having the foot or hoof divided into two parts, as the ox.
Cooter: A fresh-water tortoise (Pseudemus concinna) of Florida.
Camera lucida: An instrument which by means of a prism of a peculiar form, or an arrangement of mirrors, causes an apparent image of an external object or objects to appear as if projected upon a plane surface, as of paper or canvas, so that the outlines may conveniently traced. It is generally used with the microscope.
Chouan: One of the royalist insurgents in western France (Brittany, etc.), during and after the French revolution.
Carpathian: Of or pertaining to a range of mountains in Austro-Hungary, called the Carpathians, which partially inclose Hungary on the north, east, and south.
Cardoon: A large herbaceous plant (Cynara Cardunculus) related to the artichoke; -- used in cookery and as a salad.
Crunodal: Possessing, or characterized by, a crunode; -- used of curves.
Clingstone: Having the flesh attached closely to the stone, as in some kinds of peaches.
Ciborium: A canopy usually standing free and supported on four columns, covering the high altar, or, very rarely, a secondary altar.
Coalition: The act of coalescing; union into a body or mass, as of separate bodies or parts; as, a coalition of atoms.
Chamber: To shut up, as in a chamber.
Croatia: a Slavic-speaking country on the Adriatic, part of the Balkan region.  It was formerly part of Yugoslavia.
Concinnate: To place fitly together; to adapt; to clear.
Conglobate: To collect or form into a ball or rounded mass; to gather or mass together.
corn bread: a bread made from corn meal.
Corps: The human body, whether living or dead.
Chafeweed: The cudweed (Gnaphalium), used to prevent or cure chafing.
Commendator: One who holds a benefice in commendam; a commendatary.
Carvol: One of a species of aromatic oils, resembling carvacrol.
Cumacea: An order of marine Crustacea, mostly of small size.
converted: spiritually reborn or converted; as, a converted sinner.
Culpon: A shred; a fragment; a strip of wood.
Cateran: A Highland robber: a kind of irregular soldier.
Cargo: The lading or freight of a ship or other vessel; the goods, merchandise, or whatever is conveyed in a vessel or boat; load; freight.
Codetta: A short passage connecting two sections, but not forming part of either; a short coda.
Carpintero: A california woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus), noted for its habit of inserting acorns in holes which it drills in trees. The acorns become infested by insect larvæ, which, when grown, are extracted for food by the bird.
Cosmoplastic: Pertaining to a plastic force as operative in the formation of the world independently of God; world-forming.
Chufa: A sedgelike plant (Cyperus esculentus) producing edible tubers, native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; the earth almond.
Chopine: A clog, or patten, having a very thick sole, or in some cases raised upon a stilt to a height of a foot or more.
Chief hare: A small rodent (Lagamys princeps) inhabiting the summits of the Rocky Mountains; -- also called crying hare, calling hare, cony, American pika, and little chief hare.
Checkerberry: A spicy plant and its bright red berry; the wintergreen (Gaultheria procumbens).  Also incorrectly applied to the partridge berry (Mitchella repens).
Conveyancer: One whose business is to draw up conveyances of property, as deeds, mortgages, leases, etc.
Cottonary: Relating to, or composed of, cotton; cottony.
conferral: the act of conferring an honor or presenting a gift.
Congregationalism: That system of church organization which vests all ecclesiastical power in the assembled brotherhood of each local church.
Christian Era: The era in use in all Christian countries, which was intended to commence with the birth of Christ. The era as now established was first used by Dionysius Exiguus (died about 540), who placed the birth of Christ on the 25th of December in the year of Rome 754, which year he counted as 1 a. d. This  date for Christ's birth is now generally thought to be about four years too late.
Curvity: The state of being curved; a bending in a regular form; crookedness.
curbed: held back from some action, especially by force.  Opposite of unrestrained.
Congregationalist: One who belongs to a Congregational church or society; one who holds to Congregationalism.
Ciceronianism: Imitation of, or resemblance to, the style or action Cicero; a Ciceronian phrase or expression.
close-grained: dense or compact in structure or texture, as a wood composed of small-diameter cells.
Conacre: A system of letting a portion of a farm for a single crop.
Camail: A neck guard of chain mall, hanging from the bascinet or other headpiece.
Corsica: an island in the Mediterranean; with adjacent islets it constitutes a region of France.
Conferee: One who is conferred with, or who takes part in a conference; as, the conferees on the part of the Senate.
Corrugator: A muscle which contracts the skin of the forehead into wrinkles.
Conjugation: the act of uniting or combining; union; assemblage.
Communism: A scheme of equalizing the social conditions of life; specifically, a scheme which contemplates the abolition of inequalities in the possession of property, as by distributing all wealth equally to all, or by holding all wealth in common for the equal use and advantage of all.
Carcinology: The department of zoölogy which treats of the Crustacea (lobsters, crabs, etc.); -- called also malacostracology and crustaceology.
Corporation: A body politic or corporate, formed and authorized by law to act as a single person, and endowed by law with the capacity of succession; a society having the capacity of transacting business as an individual.
Crepuscular: Pertaining to twilight; glimmering; hence, imperfectly clear or luminous.
Curmudgeonly: Like a curmudgeon; niggardly; churlish; as, a curmudgeonly fellow.
Centerpiece: An ornament to be placed in the center, as of a table, ceiling, atc.; a central article or figure.
Chargeable: That may be charged, laid, imposed, or imputes; as, a duty chargeable on iron; a fault chargeable on a man.
Chicalote: A Mexican prickly poppy (Argemone platyceras), which has migrated into California.
Conversational: Pertaining to conversation; in the manner of one conversing; as, a conversational style.
collaborate: to work together with another toward a common goal, especially in an intellectual endeavor; as, four chemists collaborated on the synthesis of the compound; three authors collaborated in writing the book.
caffein: A white, bitter, crystallizable substance, found in coffee and tea. It is identical with the alkaloid theine from tea leaves, and with guaranine from guarana.  It is responsible for most of the stimulating effect of coffee or tea.
Childishly: In the manner of a child; in a trifling way; in a weak or foolish manner.
comic strip: a brief sequence of drawings, usually with characters drawn only sketchily, as in a cartoon, with dialog written in “balloons” over a character's head, and depicting a fictional and usually comical incident; -- also called a cartoon.  Each comic strip contains typically from four to six panels arranged horizontally, but widely varying arrangements are published.  In modern newspapers, weekly comic strips are in color, and daily strips are usually in black and white. In some, the story depicted may be serialized and continuous, carried over from day to day or week to week.  Stories of adventure, drama, mystery or an otherwise non-comical nature depicted in the same style are also called comic strips.
cashable: able to be converted into ready money; as, a cashable check; cashable gambling chips.
Centumvirate: The office of a centumvir, or of the centumviri.
Consubstantiate: Partaking of the same substance; united; consubstantial.
counsellorship: the position of counselor; same as counselorship.
Cottised: Set between two cottises, -- said of a bend; or between two barrulets, -- said of a bar or fess.
Challis: A soft and delicate woolen, or woolen and silk, fabric, for ladies' dresses.
Colosseum: The amphitheater of Vespasian in Rome.
Carousal: A jovial feast or festival; a drunken revel; a carouse.
Choleraic: Relating to, or resulting from, or resembling, cholera.
Catstick: A stick or club employed in the game of ball called cat or tipcat.
Com\u00e9dienne: A women who plays in comedy.
Cartomancy: The art of telling fortunes with cards.
Counterstep: A contrary method of procedure; opposite course of action.
Certiorari: A writ issuing out of chancery, or a superior court, to call up the records of a inferior court, or remove a cause there depending, in order that the party may have more sure and speedy justice, or that errors and irregularities may be corrected. It is obtained upon complaint of a party that he has not received justice, or can not have an impartial trial in the inferior court.
cytostasis: The inhibition or cessation of cell growth or division.
Canthoplasty: The operation of forming a new canthus, when one has been destroyed by injury or disease.
Chartographer: Same as Cartographer, Cartographic, Cartography, etc.
chutzpa: aggressive boldness or unmitigated effrontery; gall; as, he had the chutzpah to question my decision.
Colicky: Pertaining to, or troubled with, colic; as, a colicky disorder;  a colicky baby.
Caribe: A south American fresh water fish of the genus Serrasalmo of many species, remarkable for its voracity. When numerous they attack man or beast, often with fatal results.
Churchdom: The institution, government, or authority of a church.
Commence: To enter upon; to begin; to perform the first act of.
Conceit: To form an idea; to think.
Clarion: A kind of trumpet, whose note is clear and shrill.
Concremation: The act of burning different things together.
Cortinaria: a large genus of rusty-spored agarics having prominent cortinae.
Curry: To flavor or cook with curry.
Concentrator: An apparatus for the separation of dry comminuted ore, by exposing it to intermittent puffs of air.
Carmelite: A friar of a mendicant order (the Order of Our Lady of Mount Carmel) established on Mount Carmel, in Syria, in the twelfth century; a White Friar.
Correction: The act of correcting, or making that right which was wrong; change for the better; amendment; rectification, as of an erroneous statement.
constantan: a copper-nickel alloy composed of approximately 55 per cent copper and 45 per cent nickel, with high electrical resistance and a low temperature coefficient; it is used as resistance wire and in thermocouples.
Cameronian: A follower of the Rev. Richard Cameron, a Scotch Covenanter of the time of Charles II.
Colloquialism: A colloquial expression, not employed in formal discourse or writing.
Continent: That which contains anything; a receptacle.
Congratulate: To express of feel sympathetic joy; as, to congratulate with one's country.
Chorisis: The separation of a leaf or floral organ into two more parts.
Clarichord: A musical instrument, formerly in use, in form of a spinet; -- called also manichord and clavichord.
Clematis: A genus of flowering plants, of many species, mostly climbers, having feathery styles, which greatly enlarge in the fruit; -- called also virgin's bower.
Cleromancy: A divination by throwing dice or casting lots.
Carnary: A vault or crypt in connection with a church, used as a repository for human bones disintered from their original burial places; a charnel house.
concessioner: someone who holds or operates a concession.
canopic jar: a jar used in ancient Egyptian tombs to contain the intestines of a person who was mummified for burial; -- also called canopic vase.
Corresponding: Answering; conformable; agreeing; suiting; as, corresponding numbers.
Cotangent: The tangent of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.
Carboy: A large, globular glass bottle, esp. one of green glass, inclosed in basket work or in a box, for protection; -- used commonly for carrying corrosive liquids; as sulphuric acid, etc.
Carbon: An elementary substance, not metallic in its nature, which is present in all organic compounds. Atomic weight 11.97. Symbol C. it is combustible, and forms the base of lampblack and charcoal, and enters largely into mineral coals. In its pure crystallized state it constitutes the diamond, the hardest of known substances, occuring in monometric crystals like the octahedron, etc. Another modification is graphite, or blacklead, and in this it is soft, and occurs in hexagonal prisms or tables. When united with oxygen it forms carbon dioxide, commonly called carbonic acid, or carbonic oxide, according to the proportions of the oxygen; when united with hydrogen, it forms various compounds called hydrocarbons. Compare Diamond, and Graphite.
Cullis: A gutter in a roof; a channel or groove.
Cutinization: The conversion of cell walls into a material which repels water, as in cork.
Catcher: One who, or that which, catches.
Cinque: Five; the number five in dice or cards.
Corrugant: Having the power of contracting into wrinkles.
Crocket: An ornament often resembling curved and bent foliage, projecting from the sloping edge of a gable, spire, etc.
Case shot: A collection of small projectiles, inclosed in a case or canister.
Cayo: A small island or ledge of rock in the water; a key.
Coverlet: The uppermost cover of a bed or of any piece of furniture.
Consent: Agreement in opinion or sentiment; the being of one mind; accord.
Cholate: A salt of cholic acid; as, sodium cholate.
Chrome: To treat with a solution of potassium bichromate, as in dyeing.
Conics: That branch of geometry which treats of the cone and the curves which arise from its sections.
Cerebrose: A sugarlike body obtained by the decomposition of the nitrogenous non-phosphorized principles of the brain.
Charterhouse: A well known public school and charitable foundation in the building once used as a Carthusian monastery (Chartreuse) in London.
crystallized: smoothly coated with crystals of sugar; -- used especially of fruits.
Coalfish: The pollock; -- called also, coalsey, colemie, colmey, coal whiting, etc. See Pollock.
Cremor: Cream; a substance resembling cream; yeast; scum.
Cladophyll: A special branch, resembling a leaf, as in the apparent foliage of the broom (Ruscus) and of the common cultivated smilax (Myrsiphillum).
Conflux: A flowing together; a meeting of currents.
Columbate: A salt of columbic acid; a niobate. See Columbium.
cryptocoryne: any plant of the genus Cryptocoryne; evergreen perennials growing in fresh or brackish water; tropical Asia.
