Confederation: The act of confederating; a league; a compact for mutual support; alliance, particularly of princes, nations, or states.
Carriage: That which is carried; burden; baggage.
Cellarer: A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who has charge of procuring and keeping the provisions.
Caaba: The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which all Mohammedans must pray.
Convolute: Rolled or wound together, one part upon another; -- said of the leaves of plants in æstivation.
Constrictor: That which constricts, draws together, or contracts.
Conscionableness: The quality of being conscionable; reasonableness.
Civic: Relating to, or derived from, a city or citizen; relating to man as a member of society, or to civil affairs.
Civil: Pertaining to a city or state, or to a citizen in his relations to his fellow citizens or to the state; within the city or state.
cellulite: small lumpy deposits of body fat esp. on women's thighs and buttocks.  Not used as a technical term.
Coolness: The state of being cool; a moderate degree of cold; a moderate degree, or a want, of passion; want of ardor, zeal, or affection; calmness.
Cheddar: Of or pertaining to, or made at, Cheddar, in England; as, Cheddar cheese.
capitalism: An economic system based on predominantly private (individual or corporate) investment in and ownership of the means of production, distribution, and exchange of goods and wealth; contrasted with socialism or especially communism, in which the state has the predominant role in the economy.
Consound: A name applied loosely to several plants of different genera, esp. the comfrey.
Coagulatory: Serving to coagulate; produced by coagulation; as, coagulatory effects.
Castor bean: The bean or seed of the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi.)
Complexly: In a complex manner; not simply.
Contumely: Rudeness compounded of haughtiness and contempt; scornful insolence; despiteful treatment; disdain; contemptuousness in act or speech; disgrace.
Coalescent: Growing together; cohering, as in the organic cohesion of similar parts; uniting.
confuting: the act of demonstrating that something is false; confutation.
Colostrum: The first milk secreted after delivery; biestings.
Cutting: Adapted to cut; as, a cutting tool.
Cullion: A mean wretch; a base fellow; a poltroon; a scullion.
chigger: a small tropical flea (Tunga penetrans, formerly Pulex penetrans); same as chigoe.
Cerberean: Of or pertaining to, or resembling, Cerberus.
Coronamen: The upper margin of a hoof; a coronet.
Challenge: To assert a right; to claim a place.
Concessionary: Of or pertaining to a concession.
Cycling: The act, art, or practice, of riding a cycle, esp. a bicycle or tricycle.
Catabaptist: One who opposes baptism, especially of infants.
Chalcopyrite: Copper pyrites, or yellow copper ore; a common ore of copper, containing copper, iron, and sulphur. It occurs massive and in tetragonal crystals of a bright brass yellow color.
Contemptuous: Manifesting or expressing contempt or disdain; scornful; haughty; insolent; disdainful.
Cockbill: To tilt up one end of so as to make almost vertical; as, to cockbill the yards as a sign of mourning.
Caird: A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar.
Cairn: A rounded or conical heap of stones erected by early inhabitants of the British Isles, apparently as a sepulchral monument.
Cairo: The capital city of Egypt.  It is the largest city in Africa.  Population (2000) = 7,010,000.
Colonist: A member or inhabitant of a colony.
Crackle: The noise of slight and frequent cracks or reports; a crackling.
Caf\u00e9: A coffeehouse; a restaurant, especially a small restaurant where drinks and snacks are sold; also, a room in a hotel or restaurant where coffee and liquors are served.
Curious: Difficult to please or satisfy; solicitous to be correct; careful; scrupulous; nice; exact.
Cimbric: Pertaining to the Cimbri, an ancient tribe inhabiting Northern Germany.
Croft: A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.
cardiopulmonary: Of or pertaining to or affecting both the heart and the lungs and their functions; as, cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
Conchylaceous: Of or pertaining to shells; resembling a shell; as, conchyliaceous impressions.
Courtiery: The manners of a courtier; courtliness.
Canonicals: The dress prescribed by canon{2} to be worn by a clergyman when officiating.  Sometimes, any distinctive professional dress.
Cyanopathy: A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface, arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes an imperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.
certifiable: presenting symptoms of mental illness sufficient for legal commitment to a mental institution.
Conflicting: Being in conflict or collision, or in opposition; contending; contradictory; incompatible; contrary; opposing; marked by discord.
Cow: A wedge, or brake, to check the motion of a machine or car; a chock.
Chivachie: A cavalry raid; hence, a military expedition.
Caesaropapism: the doctrine that the state is supreme over the church in ecclesiastical matters.
civil right: a legal right or rights belonging to a person by reason of citizenship, including especially the fundamental freedoms and privileges guaranteed by the 13th and 14th amendments and subsequent acts of congress, including the right to legal and social and economic equality.
Carbonite: An explosive consisting essentially of nitroglycerin, wood meal, and some nitrate, as that of sodium.
Cox: A coxcomb; a simpleton; a gull.
Cleavelandite: A variety of albite, white and lamellar in structure.
Caducean: Of or belonging to Mercury's caduceus, or wand.
Colander: A utensil with a bottom perforated with little holes for straining liquids, mashed vegetable pulp, etc.; a strainer of wickerwork, perforated metal, or the like.
Convalesce: To recover health and strength gradually, after sickness or weakness; as, a patient begins to convalesce.
Campaned: Furnished with, or bearing, campanes, or bells.
Criticism: The rules and principles which regulate the practice of the critic; the art of judging with knowledge and propriety of the beauties and faults of a literary performance, or of a production in the fine arts; as, dramatic criticism.
Curt: Characterized by excessive brevity; short; rudely concise; as, curt limits; a curt answer.
Clinton: William Jefferson Clinton, b. 1946.  The 42d president of the United States, from 1993-.  Also known as Bill Clinton.
Criticise: To act as a critic; to pass literary or artistic judgment; to play the critic; -- formerly used with on or upon.
Cragged: Full of crags, or steep, broken rocks; abounding with prominences, points, and inequalities; rough; rugged.
Chalcid fly: One of a numerous family of hymenopterous insects (Chalcididæ. Many are gallflies, others are parasitic on insects.
Counterwork: To work in opposition to; to counteract.
Curd: To become coagulated or thickened; to separate into curds and whey
Cure: To pay heed; to care; to give attention.
Curb: That which curbs, restrains, or subdues; a check or hindrance; esp., a chain or strap attached to the upper part of the branches of a bit, and capable of being drawn tightly against the lower jaw of the horse.
Carbonado: A black variety of diamond, found in Brazil, and used for diamond drills. It occurs in irregular or rounded fragments, rarely distinctly crystallized, with a texture varying from compact to porous.
Corradiate: To converge to one point or focus, as light or rays.
Curl: A ringlet, especially of hair; anything of a spiral or winding form.
Callinectes: a genus of crustaceans comprising the New World blue crabs.
Cayugas: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting western New-York, forming part of the confederacy called the Five Nations.
Cod: An important edible fish (Gadus morrhua), taken in immense numbers on the northern coasts of Europe and America. It is especially abundant and large on the Grand Bank of Newfoundland. It is salted and dried in large quantities.
Checkers: A game, called also draughts, played on a checkerboard by two persons, each having twelve men (counters or checkers) which are moved diagonally.  The game is ended when either of the players has lost all his men, or can not move them.
Celluloid: A substance composed essentially of gun cotton and camphor, and when pure resembling ivory in texture and color, but variously colored to imitate coral, tortoise shell, amber, malachite, etc. It is used in the manufacture of jewelry and many small articles, as combs, brushes, collars, and cuffs; -- originally called xylonite.
curlycue: Some thing curled or spiral, as a flourish made with a pen on paper, or with skates on the ice; a trick; a frolicsome caper.  Same as curlicue.
Cockneyism: The characteristics, manners, or dialect, of a cockney.
Conventionalism: That which is received or established by convention or arbitrary agreement; that which is in accordance with the fashion, tradition, or usage.
Creative: Having the power to create; exerting the act of creation.
cytoskeletal: Of or pertaining to the cytoskeleton; as, cytoskeletal microtubules.
Cannabene: A colorless oil obtained from hemp by distillation, and possessing its intoxicating properties.
Conventionalist: One who adheres to a convention or treaty.
Commentary: A series of comments or annotations; esp., a book of explanations or expositions on the whole or a part of the Scriptures or of some other work.
Contrast: The act of contrasting, or the state of being contrasted; comparison by contrariety of qualities.
Cannulated: Hollow; affording a passage through its interior length for wire, thread, etc.; as, a cannulated (suture) needle.
Canonry: A benefice or prebend in a cathedral or collegiate church; a right to a place in chapter and to a portion of its revenues; the dignity or emoluments of a canon.
chaetal: of or relating to chaetae (setae or bristles).
Conder: One who watches shoals of fish; a balker. See Balker.
Consolidation: The act or process of consolidating, making firm, or uniting; the state of being consolidated; solidification; combination.
Corollary: That which is given beyond what is actually due, as a garland of flowers in addition to wages; surplus; something added or superfluous.
Cunningly: In a cunning manner; with cunning.
Cannel\u00e9: A style of interweaving giving to fabrics a channeled or fluted effect; also, a fabric woven so as to have this effect; a rep.
Converter: One who converts; one who makes converts.
Cero: A large and valuable fish of the Mackerel family, of the genus Scomberomorus.  Two species are found in the West Indies and less commonly on the Atlantic coast of the United States, -- the common cero (Scomberomorus caballa), called also kingfish, and spotted, or king, cero (Scomberomorus regalis).
Creepingly: by creeping slowly; in the manner of a reptile; insidiously; cunningly.
Cahincic: Pertaining to, or derived from, cahinca, the native name of a species of Brazilian Chiococca, perhaps Chiococca racemosa; as, cahincic acid.
Cucumiform: Having the form of a cucumber; having the form of a cylinder tapered and rounded at the ends, and either straight or curved.
Charact: A distinctive mark; a character; a letter or sign. [Obs.] See Character.
Calyptra: A little hood or veil, resembling an extinguisher in form and position, covering each of the small flasklike capsules which contain the spores of mosses; also, any similar covering body.
cattalo: hardy breed of cattle resulting from crossing domestic cattle with the American buffalo; it yields leaner beef than conventional breeds; it is called also beefalo.
Consecrator: One who consecrates; one who performs the rites by which a person or thing is devoted or dedicated to sacred purposes.
Consider: To think seriously; to make examination; to reflect; to deliberate.
Canberra: The capital city of Australia.  Population (2000) = 307,700.
Courteousness: The quality of being courteous; politeness; courtesy.
Chimere: The upper robe worn by a bishop, to which lawn sleeves are usually attached.
Cuckoldly: Having the qualities of a cuckold; mean-spirited; sneaking.
Colin: The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied to other related species. See Bobwhite.
Cr\u00eape Suzette: A rolled or folded crepe{3}, heated in an orange-flavored liqueur (or in a hot orange-butter sauce and moistened with a liqueur) and set on fire when served.
Chimera: A monster represented as vomiting flames, and as having the head of a lion, the body of a goat, and the tail of a dragon.
Coddle: To parboil, or soften by boiling.
Colic: Of or pertaining to colic; affecting the bowels.
contraceptive: a substance or device used to prevent conception.
Constitutionality: The quality or state of being constitutional, or inherent in the natural frame.
Cespitous: Pertaining to, consisting, of resembling, turf; turfy.
Contexture: The arrangement and union of the constituent parts of a thing; a weaving together of parts; structural character of a thing; system; constitution; texture.
Celery: A plant of the Parsley family (Apium graveolens), of which the blanched leafstalks are used as a salad.
Chough: A bird of the Crow family (Fregilus graculus) of Europe. It is of a black color, with a long, slender, curved bill and red legs; -- also called chauk, chauk-daw, chocard, Cornish chough, red-legged crow. The name is also applied to several allied birds, as the Alpine chough.
cytostatic: Having an inhibitory action on cell growth or cell division.
Colliquament: The first rudiments of an embryo in generation.
Checkered: Marked with alternate squares or checks of different color or material.
Coterie: A set or circle of persons who meet familiarly, as for social, literary, or other purposes; a clique.
Centner: A weight divisible first into a hundred parts, and then into smaller parts.
Cumulate: To gather or throw into a heap; to heap together; to accumulate.
Cycad: Any plant of the natural order Cycadaceæ, as the sago palm, etc.
Cirriferous: Bearing cirri, as many plants and animals.
Cutlet: A piece of meat, especially of veal or mutton, cut for broiling.
Cibol: A perennial alliaceous plant (Allium fistulosum), sometimes called Welsh onion. Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.
Clerk-ale: A feast for the benefit of the parish clerk.
Capricious: Governed or characterized by caprice; apt to change suddenly; freakish; whimsical; changeable.
Cutler: One who makes or deals in cutlery, or knives and other cutting instruments.
Cessation: A ceasing or discontinuance, as of action, whether temporary or final; a stop; as, a cessation of the war.
Comet: A member of the solar system which usually moves in an elongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion, and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. A comet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, or coma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequently wanting. See Illustration in Appendix.
Crookbill: A New Zealand plover (Anarhynchus frontalis), remarkable for having the end of the beak abruptly bent to the right.
Cumulation: The act of heaping together; a heap. See Accumulation.
Comes: The answer to the theme (dux) in a fugue.
Comer: One who comes, or who has come; one who has arrived, and is present.
Cheaply: At a small price; at a low value; in a common or inferior manner.
canasta: a form of rummy using two decks and four jokers; jokers and deuces are wild; the object is to meld groups of seven of the same rank.
Charism: A miraculously given power, as of healing, speaking foreign languages without instruction, etc., attributed to some of the early Christians.
Charras: The gum resin of the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa). Same as Churrus.
Copenhagen: A sweetened hot drink of spirit and beaten eggs.
Continuous: Without break, cessation, or interruption; without intervening space or time; uninterrupted; unbroken; continual; unceasing; constant; continued; protracted; extended; as, a continuous line of railroad; a continuous current of electricity.
Carking: Distressing; worrying; perplexing; corroding; as, carking cares.
Curvilinearity: The state of being curvilinear or of being bounded by curved lines.
Carex: A numerous and widely distributed genus of perennial herbaceous plants of the order Cypreaceæ; the sedges.
Cymbium: A genus of marine univalve shells; the gondola.
Catabasion: A vault under altar of a Greek church.
Carmine: A rich red or crimson color with a shade of purple.
Calumny: False accusation of a crime or offense, maliciously made or reported, to the injury of another; malicious misrepresentation; slander; detraction.
Circumcise: To cut off the prepuce of foreskin of, in the case of males, and the internal labia of, in the case of females.
Cribriform: Resembling, or having the form of, a sieve; pierced with holes; as, the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone; a cribriform compress.
Chasse: A small potion of spirituous liquor taken to remove the taste of coffee, tobacco, or the like; -- originally chasse-café, lit., “coffee chaser.”
Capellane: The curate of a chapel; a chaplain.
An abbreviation for Centimeter, Gram, Second. -- applied to a system of units much employed in physical science, based upon the centimeter as the unit of length, the gram as the unit of weight or mass, and the second as the unit of time.
Conidium: A peculiar kind of reproductive cell found in certain fungi, and often containing zoöspores.
Copulate: To unite in sexual intercourse; to come together in the act of generation.
Cercospora: form genus of imperfect fungi that are leaf parasites with long slender spores.
Cisatlantic: On this side of the Atlantic Ocean; -- used of the eastern or the western side, according to the standpoint of the writer.
cartload: as much as will fill or load a cart; the quantity that a cart holds. In excavating and carting sand, gravel, earth, etc., one third of a cubic yard of the material before it is loosened is estimated to be a cart load.
Cryptically: Secretly; occultly; in a manner so as to hide or obscure meaning.
Convergence: The condition or quality of converging; tendency to one point; the occurrence of two or more things coming together.
Chinook State: Washington -- a nickname. See Chinook, n.
Commove: To urge; to persuade; to incite.
Cinclus: the type genus of the bird family Cinclidae.  It includes the water ouzels Cinclus aquaticus of Europe and Cinclus mexicanus of western North America.
Carnival: A festival celebrated with merriment and revelry in Roman Gatholic countries during the week before Lent, esp. at Rome and Naples, during a few days (three to ten) before Lent, ending with Shrove Tuesday.
Confarreation: A form of marriage among the Romans, in which an offering of bread was made, in presence of the high priest and at least ten witnesses.
Circumnavigation: The act of circumnavigating, or sailing round.
chrysopid: a pale green unpleasant-smelling lacewing fly having carnivorous larvae.
Curacy: The office or employment of a curate.
Clubhaul: To put on the other tack by dropping the lee anchor as soon as the wind is out of the sails (which brings the vessel's head to the wind), and by cutting the cable as soon as she pays off on the other tack. Clubhauling is attempted only in an exigency.
Civil Service Reform: The substitution of business principles and methods for political methods in the conduct of the civil service. esp. the merit system instead of the spoils system in making appointments to office.
Centuriator: An historian who distinguishes time by centuries, esp. one of those who wrote the “Magdeburg Centuries.” See under Century.
Conversance: The state or quality of being conversant; habit of familiarity; familiar acquaintance; intimacy.
Comeliness: The quality or state of being comely.
Clinometric: Pertaining to, or ascertained by, the clinometer.
Completion: The act or process of making complete; the getting through to the end; as, the completion of an undertaking, an education, a service.
Corinthian: A native or inhabitant of Corinth.
close-minded: not ready to receive new ideas.
Canaliculate: Having a channel or groove, as in the leafstalks of most palms.
Cremaster: A thin muscle which serves to draw up the testicle.
Crustated: Covered with a crust; as, crustated basalt.
Cointension: The condition of being of equal in intensity; -- applied to relations; as, 3:6 and 6:12 are relations of cointension.
Communicative: Inclined to communicate; ready to impart to others.
Crowstone: The top stone of the gable end of a house.
Carnation: The natural color of flesh; rosy pink.
Crispate: Having a crisped appearance; irregularly curled or twisted.
Connascence: The common birth of two or more at the same tome; production of two or more together.
Cimmerian: Pertaining to the Cimmerii, a fabulous people, said to have lived, in very ancient times, in profound and perpetual darkness.
Chass\u00e9: To make the movement called chassé; as, all chassé; chassé to the right or left.
Choice: Worthly of being chosen or preferred; select; superior; precious; valuable.
Controller: One who, or that which, controls or restraines; one who has power or authority to regulate or control; one who governs.
Cardioid: An algebraic curve, so called from its resemblance to a heart.
Citadel: A fortress in or near a fortified city, commanding the city and fortifications, and intended as a final point of defense.
C: C is the third letter of the English alphabet. It is from the Latin letter C, which in old Latin represented the sounds of k, and g (in go); its original value being the latter. In Anglo-Saxon words, or Old English before the Norman Conquest, it always has the sound of k. The Latin C was the same letter as the Greek Γ, γ, and came from the Greek alphabet. The Greeks got it from the Phœnicians. The English name of C is from the Latin name ce, and was derived, probably, through the French. Etymologically C is related to g, h, k, q, s (and other sibilant sounds). Examples of these relations are in L. acutus, E. acute, ague; E. acrid, eager, vinegar; L. cornu, E. horn; E. cat, kitten; E. coy, quiet; L. circare, OF. cerchier, E. search.
Central: The central, or one of the central, bones of the carpus or or tarsus. In the tarsus of man it is represented by the navicular.
Coregonus: the type genus of the Coregonidae; whitefishes.
Characteristic: A distinguishing trait, quality, or property; an element of character; that which characterized.
Counter: To return a blow while receiving one, as in boxing.
Cow parsnip: A coarse umbelliferous weed of the genus Heracleum (Heracleum sphondylium in England, and Heracleum lanatum in America).
Cytode: A nonnucleated mass of protoplasm, the supposed simplest form of independent life differing from the amoeba, in which nuclei are present.
Chipping: A chip; a piece separated by a cutting or graving instrument; a fragment.
Cryptocrystalline: Indistinctly crystalline; -- applied to rocks and minerals, whose state of aggregation is so fine that no distinct particles are visible, even under the microscope.
Chipmunk: A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias, sometimes called the striped squirrel, chipping squirrel, ground squirrel, hackee. The common species of the United States is the Tamias striatus.
Consummation: The act of consummating, or the state of being consummated; completion; perfection; termination; end (as of the world or of life).
Carcinosys: The affection of the system with cancer.
Cadre: The framework or skeleton upon which a regiment is to be formed; the officers of a regiment forming the staff.
Coleorhiza: A sheath in the embryo of grasses, inclosing the caulicle.
Cowrie: A marine shell of the genus Cypræa.
Cassia: A genus of leguminous plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees) of many species, most of which have purgative qualities. The leaves of several species furnish the senna used in medicine.
Crashing: The noise of many things falling and breaking at once.
Compact: An agreement between parties; a covenant or contract.
Chiococca: a genus of shrubs of tropical and subtropical New World.
Causality: The agency of a cause; the action or power of a cause, in producing its effect.
Crispin: A shoemaker; -- jocularly so called from the patron saint of the craft.
Campanologist: One skilled in campanology; a bell ringer.
Cercaria: The larval form of a trematode worm having the shape of a tadpole, with its body terminated by a tail-like appendage.
Court: To play the lover; to woo; as, to go courting.
Curtail: The scroll termination of any architectural member, as of a step, etc.
chamosite: a greenish gray or black silicate of iron and aluminum.
copycat: someone who copies the words or behavior of another.
Cornstarch: Starch made from Indian corn, esp. a fine white flour used for puddings, etc.
Chevronel: A bearing like a chevron, but of only half its width.
Constantia: A superior wine, white and red, from Constantia, in South Africa.
Cheapen: To ask the price of; to bid, bargain, or chaffer for.
Conglutinate: To unite by the intervention of some glutinous substance; to coalesce.
cecutiency: Partial blindness, or a tendency to blindness.
Core loss: Energy wasted by hysteresis or eddy currents in the core of an armature, transformer, etc.
Conformer: One who conforms; one who complies with established forms or doctrines.
Carte blanche: A blank paper, with a person's signature, etc., at the bottom, given to another person, with permission to superscribe what conditions he pleases. Hence: Unconditional terms; unlimited authority.
Childness: The manner characteristic of a child.
CB: same as citizens' band; that portion of the radio frequency spectrum allocated by the FCC for the use of individual citizens for short-distance personal or business use, from either fixed or mobile stations.  Also used attributively, as CB radio.
CD: an acronym for compact disk, a disk-shaped recording of binary data that is smaller than a phonograph record, and is recorded and played back by a compact disk player, an electronic device containing  a laser.  The term is also used generically to refer to the medium as a data storage medium.
Coltsfoot: A perennial herb (Tussilago Farfara), whose leaves and rootstock are sometimes employed in medicine.
Chevroned: Having a chevron; decorated with an ornamental figure of a zigzag from.
censored: suppressed or subjected to censorship; as, the censored press in some countries.  Opposite of uncensored.
Causationist: One who believes in the law of universal causation.
Claustrum: A thin lamina of gray matter in each cerebral hemisphere of the brain of man.
Co: the chemical formula for cobalt, a ferromagnetic metal of atomic number 27.
Carnivora: An order of Mammallia including the lion, tiger, wolf bear, seal, etc. They are adapted by their structure to feed upon flesh, though some of them, as the bears, also eat vegetable food. The teeth are large and sharp, suitable for cutting flesh, and the jaws powerful.
Cambist: A banker; a money changer or broker; one who deals in bills of exchange, or who is skilled in the science of exchange.
Ca: the chemical symbol for calcium, the fifth most abundant element in the earth's crust.
Chinchillidae: a natural family of small bushy-tailed South American burrowing rodents.
Cd: the chemical suymbol for cadmium, a metallic element of atomic number 48.
Canaan: an ancient country is southwest Asia on the eastern coast of the Mediterranean.
Coercive: Serving or intended to coerce; having power to constrain.
corticotrophin: a growth hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland; it stimulates the adrenal cortex; -- called also adrenocorticotropin and abbreviated ACTH.
Conversazione: A meeting or assembly for conversation, particularly on literary or scientific subjects.
Calcific: Calciferous. Specifically: (Zoöl.) of or pertaining to the portion of the oviduct which forms the eggshell in birds and reptiles.
Chanson de geste: Any Old French epic poem having for its subject events or exploits of early French history, real or legendary, and written originally in assonant verse of ten or twelve syllables. The most famous one is the Chanson de Roland.
Cicutoxin: The active principle of the water hemlock (Cicuta) extracted as a poisonous gummy substance.
Chloritic: Pertaining to, or containing, chlorite; as, chloritic sand.
chiasmal: of or pertaining to a chiasma.
Courtship: The act of paying court, with the intent to solicit a favor.
Cover crop: A catch crop planted, esp. in orchards. as a protection to the soil in winter, as well as for the benefit of the soil when plowed under in spring.
Collectorate: The district of a collector of customs; a collectorship.
Conventionary: Acting under contract; settled by express agreement; as, conventionary tenants.
Cephalotome: An instrument for cutting into the fetal head, to facilitate delivery.
Chamal: The Angora goat. See Angora goat, under Angora.
Collectedness: A collected state of the mind; self-possession.
Cephalotomy: Dissection or opening of the head.
Crotch: To provide with a crotch; to give the form of a crotch to; as, to crotch the ends of ropes in splicing or tying knots.
Congruence: Suitableness of one thing to another; agreement; consistency.
Cubbridge-head: A bulkhead on the forecastle and half deck of a ship.
Candle foot: The illumination produced by a British standard candle at a distance of one foot; -- used as a unit of illumination.
Crinoidal: Of pertaining to crinoids; consisting of, or containing, crinoids.
Coalite: To cause to unite or coalesce.
clothesbrush: a brush used for cleaning clothing.
Comose: Bearing a tuft of soft hairs or down, as the seeds of milkweed.
cloverleaf: a highway interchange between two roads in which the connecting road pattern resembles a four-leaf clover, and which allows moving from one road to another without left-hand turns.  One road passes over the other, and the exit from one highway and entrance into the second highway proceeds from the right-hand lane in all directions.
Cross-tie: A sleeper supporting and connecting the rails, and holding them in place.
Clorox: a commercial bleaching agent, consisting of a 5.25% aqueous solution of sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl).  Other similar solutions of sodium hypochlorite are sometimes referred to as clorox.
Cornification: Conversion into, or formation of, horn; a becoming like horn.
crackbrained: Having an impaired intellect; whimsical; extremely foolish; crazy; as, crackbrained notions.
Chromatin: The deeply staining substance of the nucleus and chromosomes of eukaryotic cells, composed of DNA and basic proteins (such as histones), the DNA of which comprises the predominant physical basis of inheritance.  It was, at the beginning of the 20th century, supposed to be the same substance as was then termed idioplasm or germ plasm.  In most eukaryotic cells, there is also DNA in certain plasmids, such as mitochondria, or (in plant cells) chloroplasts; but with the exception of these cytoplasmic genetic factors, the nuclear DNA of the chromatin is believed to contain all the genetic information required to code for the development of an adult organism.  In the interphase nucleus the chromosomes are dispersed, but during cell division or meiosis they are condensed into the individually recognizable chromosomes.  The set of chromosomes, or a photographic representation of the full set of chromosomes of a cell (often ordered for presentation) is called a karyotype.
Cavilous: Characterized by caviling, or disposed to cavil; quibbing.
Calvinism: The theological tenets or doctrines of John Calvin (a French theologian and reformer of the 16th century) and his followers, or of the so-called calvinistic churches.
Clubbed: Shaped like a club; grasped like, or used as, a club.
Cadge: A circular frame on which cadgers carry hawks for sale.
Coverside: A region of country having covers; a hunting country.
Chromatic: Relating to color, or to colors.
Calendarial: Of or pertaining to the calendar or a calendar.
Chanting: Singing, esp. as a chant is sung.
Censorship: The office or power of a censor; as, to stand for a censorship.
Cinnoline: A nitrogenous organic base, C8H6N2, analogous to quinoline, obtained from certain complex diazo compounds.
Chancery: In England, formerly, the highest court of judicature next to the Parliament, exercising jurisdiction at law, but chiefly in equity; but under the jurisdiction act of 1873 it became the chancery division of the High Court of Justice, and now exercises jurisdiction only in equity.
Calvinist: A follower of Calvin; a believer in Calvinism.
Contrariwise: On the contrary; oppositely; on the other hand.
Carnally: According to the flesh, to the world, or to human nature; in a manner to gratify animal appetites and lusts; sensually.
Collectivity: Quality or state of being collective.
caramelise: to to change into caramel, by the action of heat; as, The sugar caramelized quickly.
Chiefrie: A small rent paid to the lord paramount.
Cupful: As much as a cup will hold.
Cumin: A dwarf umbelliferous plant, somewhat resembling fennel (Cuminum Cyminum), cultivated for its seeds, which have a bitterish, warm taste, with an aromatic flavor, and are used like those of anise and caraway.
Conversely: In a converse manner; with change of order or relation; reciprocally.
Cojuror: One who swears to another's credibility.
Commit: To sin; esp., to be incontinent.
Cuspidate: Having a sharp end, like the point of a spear; terminating in a hard point; as, a cuspidate leaf.
Concernedly: In a concerned manner; solicitously; sympathetically.
Cantatory: Containing cant or affectation; whining; singing.
Contrafagetto: The double bassoon, an octave deeper than the bassoon.
Cisco: The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of the Great Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to Coregonus Hoyi, a related species of Lake Michigan.
Callose: Furnished with protuberant or hardened spots.
Celebrant: One who performs a public religious rite; -- applied particularly to an officiating priest in the Roman Catholic Church, as distinguished from his assistants.
Cartwright: An artificer who makes carts; a cart maker.
Chiloma: The tumid upper lip of certain mammals, as of a camel.
Creatorship: State or condition of a creator.
Cretic: A poetic foot, composed of one short syllable between two long ones (- ˘ -).
Calciform: In the form of chalk or lime.
Cohere: To stick together; to cleave; to be united; to hold fast, as parts of the same mass.
Characidae: a natural family of tropical freshwater fishes of Africa and southern and central America.
Condyloma: A wartlike new growth on the outer skin or adjoining mucous membrane.
Calorimetric: Of or pertaining to the process of using the calorimeter.
Catfish: A name given in the United States to various species of siluroid fishes; as, the yellow cat (Amiurus natalis); the bind cat (Gronias nigrilabrus); the mud cat (Pilodictic oilwaris), the stone cat (Noturus flavus); the sea cat (Arius felis), etc.  This name is also sometimes applied to the wolf fish. See Bullhrad.
Controverter: One who controverts; a controversial writer; a controversialist.
Cric: The ring which turns inward and condenses the flame of a lamp.
Chromogenic: Containing, or capable of forming, chromogen; as, chromogenic bacteria.
criterial: Serving as a basis for evaluation.
Covering: Anything which covers or conceals, as a roof, a screen, a wrapper, clothing, etc.
chelating agent: a compound which forms a chelate with a metal ion.
cheeseboard: a board on which cheeses are served.
cattleship: a cargo ship for the transport of livestock.
cylindricity: The quality or condition of being cylindrical.
Cocculus Indicus: The fruit or berry of the Anamirta Cocculus, a climbing plant of the East Indies. It is a poisonous narcotic and stimulant.
Comitia: A public assembly of the Roman people for electing officers or passing laws.
Corer: That which cores; an instrument for coring fruit; as, an apple corer.
Chantant: Composed in a melodious and singing style.
Convalescently: In the manner of a convalescent; with increasing strength or vigor.
Cheat: Wheat, or bread made from wheat.
Cestoda: A subclass of parasitic worms of the class Cestoidea.  In some classifications, it is not differentiated from the parent class.
Cursorily: In a running or hasty manner; carelessly.
Calendar: To enter or write in a calendar; to register.
Cockade: A badge, usually in the form of a rosette, or knot, and generally worn upon the hat; -- used as an indication of military or naval service, or party allegiance, and in England as a part of the livery to indicate that the wearer is the servant of a military or naval officer.
C\u0153liac: Relating to the abdomen, or to the cavity of the abdomen.
Ceinture: A cincture, girdle, or belt; -- chiefly used in English as a dressmaking term.
Clergyman: An ordained minister; a man regularly authorized to preach the gospel, and administer its ordinances; in England usually restricted to a minister of the Established Church.
Capaciously: In a capacious manner or degree; comprehensively.
Chamberer: One who attends in a chamber; a chambermaid.
cylindrically: In the manner or shape of a cylinder; so as to be cylindrical.
Crustaceous: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, crust or shell; having a crustlike shell.
Chambered: Having a chamber or chambers; as, a chambered shell; a chambered gun.
Caatinga: A forest composed of stunted trees and thorny bushes, found in areas of small rainfall in Brazil.
cotton seed: The seed of the cotton plant.
chelate: a compound formed by combination of a metal ion in solution with a compound containing heteroatoms (such as oxygen or nitrogen), in which at least two heteroatoms are bound to the metal.  The bonds may be covalent or non-covalent.  Chelates in some cases have very low dissociation constants, and organic compounds (chelating agents) which form such chelates are therefore used to reduce the concentration of free metal ions in solution.
corrigenda: a list of printing errors in a book along with their corrections; as, an insert with addenda and corrigenda.
Catch-meadow: A meadow irrigated by water from a spring or rivulet on the side of hill.
Columbine: A plant of several species of the genus Aquilegia; as, Aquilegia vulgaris, or the common garden columbine; Aquilegia Canadensis, the wild red columbine of North America.
Chalchihuitl: The Mexican name for turquoise. See Turquoise.
Chew: That which is chewed; that which is held in the mouth at once; a cud.
Circumstantially: In respect to circumstances; not essentially; accidentally.
christella: any of several tropical ferns of the genus Christella having thin brittle fronds.
Convenience: The state or quality of being convenient; fitness or suitableness, as of place, time, etc.; propriety.
Corticous: Relating to, or resembling, bark; corticose.
Castle-guard: The guard or defense of a castle.
Chacma: A large species of African baboon (Cynocephalus porcarius); -- called also ursine baboon. [See Illust. of Baboon.]
Couplement: Union; combination; a coupling; a pair.
Conditionality: The quality of being conditional, or limited; limitation by certain terms.
Coston lights: Signals made by burning lights of different colors and used by vessels at sea, and in the life-saving service; -- named after their inventor.
Coup\u00e9: The front compartment of a French diligence; also, the front compartment (usually for three persons) of a car or carriage on British railways.
Coralwort: A cruciferous herb of certain species of Dentaria; -- called also toothwort, tooth violet, or pepper root.
Caraboid: Like, or pertaining to the genus Carabus.
Corylaceae: A natural family of shrubs or small trees, used in some classification systems for the genus Corylus.
Conner: A marine European fish (Crenilabrus melops); also, the related American cunner. See Cunner.
Cheverliize: To make as pliable as kid leather.
cytoskeleton: An arrangement of microtubules, microfilaments, and larger filaments within a cell serving to provide structural support of components of the cell, and to transport components from one part of the cell to another; the filaments are composed of protein and form a latticelike arrangement which may change rapidly with time.
Clubhand: A short, distorted hand; also, the deformity of having such a hand.
commuting: the process of travel by a commuter.
cross-division: classification according to more than one attribute at the same time.
Cavalierly: In a supercilious, disdainful, or haughty manner; arrogantly.
Coalgoose: The cormorant; -- so called from its black color.
Corollet: A floret in an aggregate flower.
Calyptriform: Having the form a calyptra, or extinguisher.
Cervus: A genus of ruminants, including the red deer and other allied species.
Ceroon: A bale or package. covered with hide, or with wood bound with hide; as, a ceroon of indigo, cochineal, etc.
Capitan Pasha: The chief admiral of the Turkish fleet.
Constupration: The act of ravishing; violation; defilement.
C\u0153nesthesis: Common sensation or general sensibility, as distinguished from the special sensations which are located in, or ascribed to, separate organs, as the eye and ear. It is supposed to depend on the ganglionic system.
Corrosion: The action or effect of corrosive agents, or the process of corrosive change; as, the rusting of iron is a variety of corrosion.
Canavalia: a genus of herbs or woody vines of mainly American tropics and subtropics.
calceolaria: A genus of showy herbaceous or shrubby plants, brought from South America; slipperwort. It has a yellow or purple flower, often spotted or striped, the shape of which suggests its name.
Citrination: The process by which anything becomes of the color of a lemon; esp., in alchemy, the state of perfection in the philosopher's stone indicated by its assuming a deep yellow color.
Conveyance: The act of conveying, carrying, or transporting; carriage.
Chronographic: Of or pertaining to a chronograph.
carcino-: A combining form meaning cancer, as in carcinogen.
Carrageenan: a colloidal material obtained from seaweed or Irish moss, used as an thickening or emulsifying agent and for stabilizing foods, cosmetics, and pharmaceuticals.
Cabal: To unite in a small party to promote private views and interests by intrigue; to intrigue; to plot.
Color: To acquire color; to turn red, especially in the face; to blush.
Crake: Any species or rail of the genera Crex and Porzana; -- so called from its singular cry. See Corncrake.
candellila: either of two Mexican shrubs Pedilanthus bracteatus or Pedilanthus pavonis.
Colon: That part of the large intestines which extends from the cæcum to the rectum. [See Illust. of Digestion.]
Conjubilant: Shouting together for joy; rejoicing together.
Changeable: Capable of change; subject to alteration; mutable; variable; fickle; inconstant; as, a changeable humor.
Cabas: A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba.
Constitutive: Tending or assisting to constitute or compose; elemental; essential.
Costiveness: An unnatural retention of the fecal matter of the bowels; constipation.
Cannelure: A groove in any cylinder; specif., a groove around the cylinder of an elongated bullet for small arms to contain a lubricant, or around the rotating band of a gun projectile to lessen the resistance offered to the rifling. Also, a groove around the base of a cartridge, where the extractor takes hold.
Carnallite: A hydrous chloride of potassium and magnesium, sometimes found associated with deposits of rock salt.
Categorist: One who inserts in a category or list; one who classifies.
Cespitose: Having the form a piece of turf, i. e., many stems from one rootstock or from many entangled rootstocks or roots.
Chancellorship: The office of a chancellor; the time during which one is chancellor.
Cafetorium: a large room within a building, especially a school, which functions as both a cafeteria and an auditorium.
Castling: A compound move of the king and castle. See Castle, v. i.
Champerty: Partnership in power; equal share of authority.
Confraternity: A society or body of men united for some purpose, or in some profession; a brotherhood.
Chiroplast: An instrument to guid the hands and fingers of pupils in playing on the piano, etc.
Cannery: A place where the business of canning fruit, meat, etc., is carried on.
Candlestick: An instrument or utensil for supporting a candle.
Condottiere: A military adventurer of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, who sold his services, and those of his followers, to any party in any contest.
Crotaphite: The temple or temporal fossa. Also used adjectively.
Cresylic: Pertaining to, or derived from, cresol, creosote, etc.
Cardboard: A stiff compact pasteboard of various qualities, for making cards, etc., often having a polished surface.
Cussedness: Disposition to willful wrongdoing; malignity; perversity; cantankerousness; obstinacy.
Coalsack: Any one of the spaces in the Milky Way which are very black, owing to the nearly complete absence of stars; esp., the large space near the Southern Cross sometimes called the Black Magellanic Cloud.
Clause: See Letters clause or Letters close, under Letter.
Claret: The name first given in England to the red wines of Médoc, in France, and afterwards extended to all the red Bordeaux wines. The name is also given to similar wines made in the United States.
Corymb: A flat-topped or convex cluster of flowers, each on its own footstalk, and arising from different points of a common axis, the outermost blossoms expanding first, as in the hawthorn.
Collier: One engaged in the business of digging mineral coal or making charcoal, or in transporting or dealing in coal.
Cornice: Any horizontal, molded or otherwise decorated projection which crowns or finishes the part to which it is affixed; as, the cornice of an order, pedestal, door, window, or house.
Contretemps: An unexpected and untoward accident; something inopportune or embarrassing; a hitch.
Conduce: To conduct; to lead; to guide.
Crown: To cover, decorate, or invest with a crown; hence, to invest with royal dignity and power.
Chops: The jaws; also, the fleshy parts about the mouth.
Cordwain: A term used in the Middle Ages for Spanish leather (goatskin tanned and dressed), and hence, any leather handsomely finished, colored, gilded, or the like.
Creamy: Full of, or containing, cream; resembling cream, in nature, appearance, or taste; creamlike; unctuous.
Croker: A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron.
Conduct: To act as a conductor (as of heat, electricity, etc.); to carry.
Consecutive: Following in a train; succeeding one another in a regular order; successive; uninterrupted in course or succession; with no interval or break; as, fifty consecutive years.
Clubfoot: A short, variously distorted foot; also, the deformity, usually congenital, which such a foot exhibits; talipes.
Charcoal: Impure carbon prepared from vegetable or animal substances; esp., coal made by charring wood in a kiln, retort, etc., from which air is excluded. It is used for fuel and in various mechanical, artistic, and chemical processes.
Chondropterygii: A group of fishes, characterized by cartilaginous fins and skeleton. It includes both ganoids (sturgeons, etc.) and selachians (sharks), but is now often restricted to the latter.
Chastely: In a chaste manner; with purity.
Connotatively: In a connotative manner; expressing connotation.
Cerebellar: of or pertaining to the cerebellum; as, the cerebellar artery.
Capsicum: A genus of plants of many species, producing capsules or dry berries of various forms, which have an exceedingly pungent, biting taste, and when ground form the red or Cayenne pepper of commerce.
Counterglow: An exceedingly faint roundish or somewhat oblong nebulous light near the ecliptic and opposite the sun, best seen during September and October, when in the constellations Sagittarius and Pisces. Its cause is not yet understood. Called also Gegenschein.
Crustiness: The state or quality of having crust or being like crust; hardness.
Civility: The state of society in which the relations and duties of a citizen are recognized and obeyed; a state of civilization.
cushioning: soft or resilient material used to fill or give shape or protect or add comfort.
Chordal: Of or pertaining to a chord.
Chateau: A castle or a fortress in France.
Carline: A short timber running lengthwise of a ship, from one transverse desk beam to another; also, one of the cross timbers that strengthen a hath; -- usually in pl.
Changer: One who changes or alters the form of anything.
Cruor: The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion of coagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
Codille: A term at omber, signifying that the game is won.
Chartism: The principles of a political party in England (1838-48), which contended for universal suffrage, the vote by ballot, annual parliaments, equal electoral districts, and other radical reforms, as set forth in a document called the People's Charter.
Commensal: Having the character of a commensal.
Codilla: The coarse tow of flax and hemp.
Chromoplastid: A protoplasmic granule of some other color than green; -- also called chromoleucite.
corynebacterium: Any member of the genus Corynebacterium, consisting of gram-positive usually nonmotile irregularly rod-shaped bacteria, some of which are pathogenic or parasitic in humans and domestic animals, such as Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria.
Command: An authoritative order requiring obedience; a mandate; an injunction.
Chartist: A supporter or partisan of chartism.
Corollifloral: Having the stamens borne on the petals, and the latter free from the calyx. Compare Calycifloral and Thalamifloral.
Clipper: One who clips; specifically, one who clips off the edges of coins.
Covet: To have or indulge inordinate desire.
close-knit: bound together by intimate ties, social, personal, cultural or political; as, closely-knit little villages; a close-knit family.
ceras: one of the often brightly colored and branching hornlike structures on the backs of nudibranchs and other related mollusks that serve as gills.
Capreoline: Of or pertaining to the roebuck.
Concettism: The use of concetti or affected conceits.
Cymule: A small cyme, or one of very few flowers.
Ceratophyllaceae: a natural family coextensive with the genus Ceratophyllum; the hornworts.
Carbolic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from coal tar and other sources; as, carbolic acid (called also phenic acid, and phenol{1}). See Phenol.
Cantiniere: A woman who carries a canteen for soldiers; a vivandière.
cachalot: The sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus).  It has in the top of its head a large cavity, containing an oily fluid, which, after death, concretes into a whitish crystalline substance called spermaceti. See Sperm whale.
Curcuma: A genus of plants of the order Scitamineæ, including the turmeric plant (Curcuma longa).
checkout: the latest time for vacating a hotel room without being charged for extra time; as, the checkout here is 12 noon.
Carpophyte: A flowerless plant which forms a true fruit as the result of fertilization, as the red seaweeds, the Ascomycetes, etc.
Centumvir: One of a court of about one hundred judges chosen to try civil suits. Under the empire the court was increased to 180, and met usually in four sections.
Constraint: The act of constraining, or the state of being constrained; that which compels to, or restrains from, action; compulsion; restraint; necessity.
Cygnus: A constellation of the northern hemisphere east of, or following, Lyra; the Swan.
Customhouse: The building where customs and duties are paid, and where vessels are entered or cleared.
Coloradoite: Mercury telluride, an iron-black metallic mineral, found in Colorado.
Cispadane: On the hither side of the river Po with reference to Rome; that is, on the south side.
Chlamydiaceae: a natural family of gram-negative bacteria which are parasites in warm-blooded vertebrates.
Clinkstone: An igneous rock of feldspathic composition, lamellar in structure, and clinking under the hammer. See Phonolite.
Colchicaceae: one of many subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Liliaceae but not widely accepted: Colchicum; Gloriosa.
Cabezon: A California fish (Hemilepidotus spinosus), allied to the sculpin.
Cerumen: The yellow, waxlike secretion from the glands of the external ear; the earwax.
Cathodograph: A picture produced by the Röntgen rays; a radiograph.
Calculative: Of or pertaining to calculation; involving calculation.
confused: same as confounded; as, bewildered and confused.
Cougar: An American feline quadruped (Felis concolor), resembling the African panther in size and habits. Its color is tawny, without spots; hence writers often called it the American lion. Called also puma, panther, mountain lion, and catamount. See Puma.
Cephaloptera: One of the generic names of the gigantic ray (Manta birostris) of the family Mobulidae, known as devilfish, sea devil, manta and manta ray.  It is common on the coasts of South Carolina, Florida, and farther south, and is sometimes found as far north as New York Bay.  Some of them grow to enormous size, becoming twenty feet of more across the body, and weighing more than a ton.
Coefficient: That which unites in action with something else to produce the same effect.
Circar: A district, or part of a province. See Sircar.
Corridor train: A train whose coaches are connected so as to have through its entire length a continuous corridor, into which the compartments open.
coonhound: any of several breeds of hound developed for hunting raccoons.
Chokedar: A watchman; an officer of customs or police.
cared-for: having needed care and attention; as, well-cared-for children.  Opposite of uncared-for.
Camponotus: a genus comprising the carpenter ants.
Chylifactive: Producing, or converting into, chyle; having the power to form chyle.
Comforter: One who administers comfort or consolation.
Contestation: The act of contesting; emulation; rivalry; strife; dispute.
Comprehensibility: The quality or state of being comprehensible; capability of being understood.
commitedness: the trait of sincere and steadfast fixity of purpose.
Costeaning: The process by which miners seek to discover metallic lodes. It consist in sinking small pits through the superficial deposits to the solid rock, and then driving from one pit to another across the direction of the vein, in such manner as to cross all the veins between the two pits.
Cockfight: A match or contest of gamecocks.
Carunculate: Having a caruncle or caruncles; caruncular.
Conventual: One who lives in a convent; a monk or nun; a recluse.
Cucullate: Hooded; cowled; covered, as with a hood.
Convocationist: An advocate or defender of convocation.
Caretta: a genus consisting of the loggerhead turtles.
Covered: Under cover; screened; sheltered; not exposed; hidden.
Cometarium: An instrument, intended to represent the revolution of a comet round the sun.
Congius: A liquid measure containing about three quarts.
Chlorate: A salt of chloric acid; as, chlorate of potassium.
Cullet: A small central plane in the back of a cut gem. See Collet, 3 (b).
Callow: A kind of duck. See Old squaw.
Chamade: A signal made for a parley by beat of a drum.
Callot: A plant coif or skullcap. Same as Calotte.
Chishona: one of the two major languages of Zimbabwe.
coaching: the job of a professional coach.
Carlovingian: Pertaining to, founded by, of descended from, Charlemagne; as, the Carlovingian race of kings.
captivated: having an affection or admiration, caused by charm of the person or object.
Carnify: To form flesh; to become like flesh.
Cookbook: A book of directions and receipts for cooking; a cookery book.
Croquante: A brittle cake or other crisp pastry.
ceratopsian: any of several four-footed herbivorous horned dinosaurs with enormous beaked skulls, of the late Cretaceous in North America and Mongolia.
Corsned: The morsel of execration; a species of ordeal consisting in the eating of a piece of bread consecrated by imprecation. If the suspected person ate it freely, he was pronounced innocent; but if it stuck in his throat, it was considered as a proof of his guilt.
Crocoite: Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth red color; -- called also red lead ore.
cross-purpose: A counter or opposing purpose; a contrary aim; hence, that which is inconsistent or contradictory.
Cittern-head: Blockhead; dunce; -- so called because the handle of a cittern usually ended with a carved head.
Carpellary: Belonging to, forming, or containing carpels.
Cream-colored: Of the color of cream; light yellow.
Conditionally: In a conditional manner; subject to a condition or conditions; not absolutely or positively.
Chartreuse: A Carthusian monastery; esp. La Grande Chartreuse, mother house of the order, in the mountains near Grenoble, France.
Crimpage: The act or practice of crimping; money paid to a crimp for shipping or enlisting men.
checkerbloom: a perennial purple-flowered wild mallow of West North America (Sidalcea malviflora) that is also cultivated.
Crusty: Having the nature of crust; pertaining to a hard covering; as, a crusty coat; a crusty surface or substance.
Coriaceous: Consisting of or resembling, leather; leatherlike; tough.
Consolation: The act of consoling; the state of being consoled; allevation of misery or distress of mind; refreshment of spirit; comfort; that which consoles or comforts the spirit.
Cross-question: To cross-examine; to subject to close questioning.
Cadilesker: A chief judge in the Turkish empire, so named originally because his jurisdiction extended to the cases of soldiers, who are now tried only by their own officers.
Calvatia: a genus of puffballs having outer casings whose upper parts break at maturity into angular pieces to expose the spores.
Circumvallate: Surrounded with a wall; inclosed with a rampart.
Cicero: Pica type; -- so called by French printers.
Chasing: The art of ornamenting metal by means of chasing tools; also, a piece of ornamental work produced in this way.
curved: not straight; having or marked by curves.  Opposite of straight.
Chalaza: The place on an ovule, or seed, where its outer coats cohere with each other and the nucleus.
Close-fights: Barriers with loopholes, formerly erected on the deck of a vessel to shelter the men in a close engagement with an enemy's boarders; -- called also close quarters.
Clapboard: To cover with clapboards; as, to clapboard the sides of a house.
Crape: To form into ringlets; to curl; to crimp; to friz; as, to crape the hair; to crape silk.
Crenature: A rounded tooth or notch of a crenate leaf, or any part that is crenate; -- called also crenelle.
Cystocarp: A minute vesicle in a red seaweed, which contains the reproductive spores.
Cac\u00e6mia: A degenerated or poisoned condition of the blood.
Craps: A gambling game with dice.  It is one of the more popular games in casinos.
Cr\u00eame: Cream; -- a term used esp. in cookery, names of liqueurs, etc.
Cacodemon: An evil spirit; a devil or demon.
Caryatid: A draped female figure supporting an entablature, in the place of a column or pilaster.
Chiff-chaff: A species of European warbler (Sylvia hippolais); -- called also chip-chap, and pettychaps.
Ciselure: The process of chasing on metals; also, the work thus chased.
commercialize: to make something commercial in character, either by placing it for sale on the open market, or by emphasizing its profit-making aspects; as, the Olympics have been excessively commercialized.
Childish: Of, pertaining to, befitting, or resembling, a child.
Corporeal: Having a body; consisting of, or pertaining to, a material body or substance; material; -- opposed to spiritual or immaterial.
Cebus: the type genus of the Cebidae.
Conoidic: Pertaining to a conoid; having the form of a conoid.
Calends: The first day of each month in the ancient Roman calendar.
Coinsurance: Insurance jointly with another or others; specif., that system of fire insurance in which the insurer is treated as insuring himself to the extent of that part of the risk not covered by his policy, so that any loss is apportioned between him and the insurance company on the principle of average, as in marine insurance or between other insurers.
Crusher: One who, or that which, crushes.
Calando: Gradually diminishing in rapidity and loudness.
Canidae: a natural family of doglike mammals including the domestic dogs, wolves, jackals, foxes, hyenas, and coyotes.
Crepon: A thin stuff made of the finest wool or silk, or of wool and silk.
calanthe: any of various showy orchids of the genus Calanthe having white or yellow or rose-colored flowers and broad leaves folded lengthwise.
Calmness: The state of quality of being calm; quietness; tranquillity; self-repose.
Concession: The act of conceding or yielding; usually implying a demand, claim, or request, and thus distinguished from giving, which is voluntary or spontaneous.
Ctenophora: A phylum of invertebrates, commonly ellipsoidal in shape, swimming by means of eight longitudinal rows of paddles.  They are commonly called the comb jellies, because the separate paddles somewhat resemble combs.  This phylum was formerly classified as a subdivision (class) within the Cœlenterata.
Catfall: A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead.
Calorifere: An apparatus for conveying and distributing heat, especially by means of hot water circulating in tubes.
Coating: A coat or covering; a layer of any substance, as a cover or protection; as, the coating of a retort or vial.
Casehardened: Having the surface hardened, as iron tools.
Canyon: The English form of the Spanish word Cañon.
Contrabandist: One who traffics illegally; a smuggler.
Cabbling: The process of breaking up the flat masses into which wrought iron is first hammered, in order that the pieces may be reheated and wrought into bar iron.
Comatulid: Any crinoid of the genus Antedon or allied genera.
Commissarial: Of or pertaining to a commissary.
Chack: To toss up the head frequently, as a horse to avoid the restraint of the bridle.
coconut: the edible white meat of a coconut{3}; often shredded for use in e.g. cakes and curries.
Container: One who, or that which, contains; particularly, an artifactual object that is designed to contain some fluid or solid material, object or objects, especially for convenience in transporting the contained objects.
Chace: To pursue. See Chase v. t.
Conure: An American parrakeet of the genus Conurus.  Many species are known.  See Parrakeet.
Courb: To bend; to stop; to bow.
Creatural: Belonging to a creature; having the qualities of a creature.
Conodont: A peculiar toothlike fossil of many forms, found especially in carboniferous rocks. Such fossils are supposed by some to be the teeth of marsipobranch fishes, but they are probably the jaws of annelids.
Conicalness: State or quality of being conical.
convictfish: a type of greenling (Oxylebius pictus) with a whitish body marked with black bands.
cooing: emitting a cry like that of a dove; as, The cooing pigeons.
consumer price index: An index of the cost of all goods and services to a typical consumer, calculated and published by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics; abbreviated CPI, and usually referred to by that acronym.  The Bureau maintains several indices for different groups of consumers, but the most commonly referred to is the index for “All urban consumers”, called the CPI-U. The increase of this value each year is one measure of monetary inflation.
catalase: an enzyme found in most plant and animal cells that functions as an oxidative catalyst; it decomposes hydrogen peroxide into hydrogen and water.
Coxcombry: The manners of a coxcomb; foppishness.
Chauffer: A table stove or small furnace, usually a cylindrical box of sheet iron, with a grate at the bottom, and an open top.
Croche: A little bud or knob at the top of a deer's antler.
Contemptibleness: The state or quality of being contemptible, or of being despised.
Caricaceae: a natural family of trees native to tropical America and Africa with milky juice and large palmately lobed leaves.
Credulousness: Readiness to believe on slight evidence; credulity.
Catch crop: Any crop grown between the rows of another crop or intermediate between two crops in ordinary rotation in point of time.
Colorado beetle: A yellowish beetle (Doryphora decemlineata), with ten longitudinal, black, dorsal stripes. It has migrated eastwards from its original habitat in Colorado, and is very destructive to the potato plant; -- called also potato beetle and potato bug. See Potato beetle.
Campanology: The art of ringing bells, or a treatise on the art.
Corbiestep: One of the steps in which a gable wall is often finished in place of a continuous slope; -- also called crowstep.
Clearing: The act or process of making clear.
Choke pear: A kind of pear that has a rough, astringent taste, and is swallowed with difficulty, or which contracts the mucous membrane of the mouth.
coelogyne: any of various orchids of the genus Coelogyne which may have clusters of fragrant lacy snow-white flowers; sinister salmon-pink solitary flowers; chainlike racemes of topaz and chocolate brown flowers; spikes of delicate white spice-scented flowers; or emerald green flowers marked with blue-black.
Contrivable: Capable of being contrived, planned, invented, or devised.
Contortionist: One who makes or practices contortions;
Chamberlain: An officer or servant who has charge of a chamber or chambers.
cheeseburger: a hamburger with melted cheese on it.
Circumstantiality: The state, characteristic, or quality of being circumstantial; particularity or minuteness of detail.
cold-heartedness: an absence of concern for the welfare of others; indifference to the suffering of others.
Ceroma: The unguent (a composition of oil and wax) with which wrestlers were anointed among the ancient Romans.
Casserole: A small round dish with a handle, usually of porcelain.
Cohesive: Holding the particles of a homogeneous body together; as, cohesive attraction; producing cohesion; as, a cohesive force.
cyclopropane: a colorless flammable gas (C3H6) with a three-carbon ring, sometimes used as an anesthetic.
Canaster: A kind of tobacco for smoking, made of the dried leaves, coarsely broken; -- so called from the rush baskets in which it is packed in South America.
catecholamine: any of a group of chemicals including epinephrine and norepinephrine that are produced in the medulla of the adrenal gland.  They function as nerotransmitters in the sympathetic nervous system.  Also, any structurally related chemical substance, whether natural or synthetic.
Condensible: Capable of being condensed; as, a gas condensible to a liquid by cold.
Cognate: One who is related to another on the female side.
Cornel: The cornelian cherry (Cornus Mas), a European shrub with clusters of small, greenish flowers, followed by very acid but edible drupes resembling cherries.
Cornea: The transparent part of the coat of the eyeball which covers the iris and pupil and admits light to the interior. See Eye.
Cravat: A neckcloth; a piece of silk, fine muslin, or other cloth, worn by men about the neck.
Czarish: Of or pertaining to the czar.
cryoscope: an instrument for measuring freezing and melting points.
Coolly: In a cool manner; without heat or excessive cold; without passion or ardor; calmly; deliberately; with indifference; impudently.
Christian Scientist: A believer in Christian Science; one who practices its teachings.
Cornet: An obsolete rude reed instrument (Ger. Zinken), of the oboe family.
Cavalry: That part of military force which serves on horseback.
Credibility: The quality of being credible; credibleness; as, the credibility of facts; the credibility of witnesses.
Centaurus: a conspicuous constellation in the southern hemisphere near the Southern Cross.
Contort: To twist, or twist together; to turn awry; to bend; to distort; to wrest.
Corporally: In or with the body; bodily; as, to be corporally present.
Colature: The process of straining; the matter strained; a strainer.
Cassiterite: Native tin dioxide; tin stone; a mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of reddish brown color, and brilliant adamantine luster; also massive, sometimes in compact forms with concentric fibrous structure resembling wood (wood tin), also in rolled fragments or pebbly (Stream tin). It is the chief source of metallic tin. See Black tin, under Black.
Cricoid: Resembling a ring; -- said esp. of the cartilage at the larynx, and the adjoining parts.
an abbreviation of collect on delivery; a method of payment by which goods are paid for when they are delivered to the customer's home or place of business.  Contrasted to payment in advance or terms or credit.
Chlorinate: To treat, or cause to combine, with chlorine.
Civil Service Commission: In the United States, a commission appointed by the President, consisting of three members, not more than two of whom may be adherents of the same party, which has the control, through examinations, of appointments and promotions in the classified civil service. It was created by act of Jan, 16, 1883 (22 Stat. 403).
Cognizor: One who acknowledged the right of the plaintiff or cognizee in a fine; the defendant.
Contingently: In a contingent manner; without design or foresight; accidentally.
Chimney-breast: The horizontal projection of a chimney from the wall in which it is built; -- commonly applied to its projection in the inside of a building only.
Carver: One who carves; one who shapes or fashions by carving, or as by carving; esp. one who carves decorative forms, architectural adornments, etc.
Corrective: That which has the power of correcting, altering, or counteracting what is wrong or injurious; as, alkalies are correctives of acids; penalties are correctives of immoral conduct.
Closereefed: Having all the reefs taken in; -- said of a sail.
Cloakroom: A room, attached to any place of public resort, where cloaks, overcoats, etc., may be deposited for a time.
Cuckoopint: A plant of the genus Arum (Arum maculatum); the European wake-robin.
Cercopod: One of the jointed antenniform appendages of the posterior somites of certain insects.
Carven: Wrought by carving; ornamented by carvings; carved.
Chorepiscopal: Pertaining to a chorepiscopus or his charge or authority.
Crabbed: Characterized by or manifesting, sourness, peevishness, or moroseness; harsh; cross; cynical; -- applied to feelings, disposition, or manners.
Cockneyfy: To form with the manners or character of a cockney.
Carat: The weight by which precious stones and pearls are weighed.
Corked: having acquired an unpleasant taste from the cork; as, a bottle of wine is corked.
Clammy: Having the quality of being viscous or adhesive; soft and sticky; glutinous; damp and adhesive, as if covered with a cold perspiration.
Cranioclast: An instrument for crushing the head of a fetus, to facilitate delivery in difficult eases.
Cosmos: A genus of composite plants closely related to Bidens, usually with very showy flowers, some with yellow, others with red, scarlet, purple, white, or lilac rays.  They are natives of the warmer parts of America, and many species are cultivated.  Cosmos bipinnatus and Cosmos diversifolius are among the best-known species; Cosmos caudatus, of the West Indies, is widely naturalized.
Coition: A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation.
cattail: A tall erect rush or flag (Typha latifolia) growing widely in fresh and salt marshes, with long, flat, sword-shaped leaves, having clusters of small brown flowers in a dense cylindrical spike at the top of the stem; -- called also bulrush and reed mace. The leaves are frequently used for seating chairs, making mats, etc. See Catkin.
conceptualization: the act of formulating or making a concept of something.
castrated: deprived of reproductive organs or sexual attributes.
Catheter: The name of various instruments for passing along mucous canals, esp. applied to a tubular instrument to be introduced into the bladder through the urethra to draw off the urine.
Compulsorily: In a compulsory manner; by force or constraint.
Carabid: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the genus Carabus or family Carabidae.
Coparcener: One who has an equal portion with others of an inheritance.
Crenelle: An embrasure or indentation in a battlement; a loophole in a fortress; an indentation; a notch. See Merlon, and Illust. of Battlement.
Churrworm: An insect that turns about nimbly; the mole cricket; -- called also fan cricket.
conferment: the act of conferring an honor or presenting a gift.  Same as conferral.
crinkle root: a North American herb (Dentaria diphylla) with pungent scaly or toothed roots; -- called also toothwort.
Cantlet: A piece; a fragment; a corner.
Clocklike: Like a clock or like clockwork; mechanical.
Chouka: The Indian four-horned antelope; the chikara.
Conciergerie: The office or lodge of a concierge or janitor.
centerfield: the part of the outfield directly ahead of the catcher.
Causer: One who or that which causes.
Casket: To put into, or preserve in, a casket.
Cocobolo: A very beautiful and hard wood, obtained in the West India Islands. It is used in cabinetmaking, for the handles of tools, and for various fancy articles.
Colleterium: An organ of female insects, containing a cement to unite the ejected ova.
Clinoid: Like a bed; -- applied to several processes on the inner side of the sphenoid bone.
Cheapness: Lowness in price, considering the usual price, or real value.
Chirograph: A writing which, requiring a counterpart, was engrossed twice on the same piece of parchment, with a space between, in which was written the word chirographum, through which the parchment was cut, and one part given to each party. It answered to what is now called a charter party.
Cycadales: an order of primitive tropical gymnosperms abundant in the Mesozoic, now reduced to a few scattered tropical forms.
Chlorodyne: A patent anodyne medicine, containing opium, chloroform, Indian hemp, etc.
coherent light: Light in which the phases of all electromagnetic waves at each point on a line normal to the direction of the the beam are identical.  Coherent light is usually monochromatic, and the most common source of such light for practical uses is from a laser.
creaky: worn down with age or use; in poor condition.
Cicatrix: The pellicle which forms over a wound or breach of continuity and completes the process of healing in the latter, and which subsequently contracts and becomes white, forming the scar.
Collator: One who collates manuscripts, books, etc.
Cousinhood: The state or condition of a cousin; also, the collective body of cousins; kinsfolk.
Coarct: To press together; to crowd; to straiten; to confine closely.
Clamatores: A division of passerine birds in which the vocal muscles are but little developed, so that they lack the power of singing.
Crotophaga: a genus of birds including the anis.  See ani.
Commandery: The office or rank of a commander.
Coati: A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to the raccoon, having a ringed tail but with a longer body, tail, and nose; -- called also coati mondi and coati mundi.
CD-R: a recordable compact disk; a compact disc on which you can write only once and thereafter is read-only.
clingfish: very small (to 3 inches) flattened marine fish with a sucking disc on the abdomen for clinging to rocks etc.
carriageway: one of the two sides of a motorway where traffic travels in one direction only, usually in two or three lanes.
Chalybeous: Steel blue; of the color of tempered steel.
Canticle: A song; esp. a little song or hymn.
Camphor: To impregnate or wash with camphor; to camphorate.
Cassareep: A condiment made from the sap of the bitter cassava (Manihot utilissima) deprived of its poisonous qualities, concentrated by boiling, and flavored with aromatics. See Pepper pot.
clean-living: living in a manner above moral reproach; especially, abstaining from unlawful sexual intercourse and excessive drunkenness.
Centralization: The act or process of centralizing, or the state of being centralized; the act or process of combining or reducing several parts into a whole; as, the centralization of power in the general government; the centralization of commerce in a city.
connotational: Having the power of implying or suggesting something in addition to what is explicit.  Contrasted with denotative.
Cordylus: the type genus of the Cordylidae; they are spiny lizards somewhat resembling tiny crocodiles.
Cessavit: A writ given by statute to recover lands when the tenant has for two years failed to perform the conditions of his tenure.
Chord: To accord; to harmonize together; as, this note chords with that.
Confide: To intrust; to give in charge; to commit to one's keeping; -- followed by to.
Conventioner: One who belongs to a convention or assembly.
Christian Science: A system of healing disease of mind and body which teaches that all cause and effect is mental, and that sin, sickness, and death will be destroyed by a full understanding of the Divine Principle of Jesus' teaching and healing. The system was founded by Rev. Mary Baker Glover Eddy, of Concord, N. H., in 1866, and bases its teaching on the Scriptures as understood by its adherents.
Clavier: The keyboard of an organ, pianoforte, or harmonium.
Cotton batting: Cotton prepared in sheets or rolls for quilting, upholstering, and similar purposes.
Caroche: A kind of pleasure carriage; a coach.
carboxylic: of or pertaining to the carboxyl group; having a carboxyl group (written -COOH, -CO2H or -CO.OH); as, carboxylic acids are weakly acidic.
chimneystack: the part of the chimney that is above the roof; it usually has several flues.
Cancroid: Resembling a crab; pertaining to the Cancroidea, one of the families of crabs, including the genus Cancer.
Coit: To throw, as a stone. [Obs.] See Quoit.
Coir: A material for cordage, matting, etc., consisting of the prepared fiber of the outer husk of the cocoanut.
Cephalotribe: An obstetrical instrument for performing cephalotripsy.
Compressibleness: The quality of being compressible; compressibility.
Coif: To cover or dress with, or as with, a coif.
Contline: The space between the strands on the outside of a rope.
Cretacic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the period of time following the Jurassic and preceding the Tertiary, generally given as from 144 million years b. p. to 65 million years b. p..  Also called Cre*tac"ic.
Coil: A noise, tumult, bustle, or confusion.
Cedrine: Of or pertaining to cedar or the cedar tree.
Cornopean: An obsolete name for the cornet-à-piston.
Crotcheted: Marked or measured by crotchets; having musical notation.
chainsaw: a portable power saw having teeth that are linked to form an endless chain, rotated about two pivot points by a power mechanism, such as an electric motor or a gasoline engine.
Condiment: Something used to give relish to food, and to gratify the taste; a pungment and appetizing substance, as pepper or mustard; seasoning.
Castor and Pollux: See Saint Elmo's fire, under Saint.
crock: nonsense; balderdash; humbug; -- usually used in the phrase a crock.
Collagen: The chemical basis of ordinary connective tissue, as of tendons or sinews and of bone. On being boiled in water it becomes gelatin or glue.
Childe: A cognomen formerly prefixed to his name by the oldest son, until he succeeded to his ancestral titles, or was knighted; as, Childe Roland.
Crystallogeny: The science which pertains to the production of crystals.
Confirmee: One to whom anything is confirmed.
Congeries: A collection of particles or bodies into one mass; a heap; an aggregation.
Corcle: The heart of the seed; the embryo or germ.
