Chock-full: Quite full; full to capacity; choke-full; as, chowder chock-full of clams.
Crummable: Capable of being crumbed or broken into small pieces.
Confirmer: One who, or that which, confirms, establishes, or ratifies; one who corroborates.
Carnate: Invested with, or embodied in, flesh.
Convict: To prove or find guilty of an offense or crime charged; to pronounce guilty, as by legal decision, or by one's conscience.
carboxylic acid: an organic compound whose acidity is due to the presence of a carboxyl gorup.  Monocarboxylic acids (such as acetic acid or butyric acid) have one carboxyl group, dicarboxylic acids (such as oxalic acid or malonic acid) have two, tricarboxylic acids (such as citric acid) have three.
Curial: Of or pertaining to the papal curia; as, the curial etiquette of the Vatican.
Curassow: A large gallinaceous bird of the American genera Crax, Ourax, etc., of the family Cracidæ.
Commissional: Of, pertaining to, or conferring, a commission; conferred by a commission or warrant.
Cultrivorous: Devouring knives; swallowing, or pretending to swallow, knives; -- applied to persons who have swallowed, or have seemed to swallow, knives with impunity.
cyanobacterium: any of a group of photosynthetic autotrophic prokaryotic microorganisms possessing characteristics of both bacteria and plants.  When classed as bacteria, they are assigned to the Cyanobacteria; when classed as plants, they are assigned to the Cyanophyta.  They were earlier named blue-green algae, a term less used now in technical discussions.  Since the chlorophyll within the cyanobacteria is diffused throughout the cell, rather than being contained in chloroplasts, they are no longer thought of as true plants.
Configuration: Form, as depending on the relative disposition of the parts of a thing; shape; figure.
Columnarity: The state or quality of being columnar.
Chapter: To divide into chapters, as a book.
Calcavella: A sweet wine from Portugal; -- so called from the district of Carcavelhos.
coachbuilder: a craftsman who makes the bodies of motor vehicles.
Chinese Exclusion Act: Any of several acts forbidding the immigration of Chinese laborers into the United States, originally from 1882 to 1892 by act of May 6, 1882, then from 1892 to 1902 by act May 5, 1892. By act of April 29, 1902, all existing legislation on the subject was reënacted and continued, and made applicable to the insular possessions of the United States.
Coping: The highest or covering course of masonry in a wall, often with sloping edges to carry off water; -- sometimes called capping.
Chippeways: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern and western shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.
Contented: Content; easy in mind; satisfied; quiet; willing.
Corrugate: To form or shape into wrinkles or folds, or alternate ridges and grooves, as by drawing, contraction, pressure, bending, or otherwise; to wrinkle; to purse up; as, to corrugate plates of iron; to corrugate the forehead.
Camberkeeled: Having the keel arched upwards, but not actually hogged; -- said of a ship.
Calaverite: A bronze-yellow massive mineral with metallic luster; a telluride of gold; -- first found in Calaveras County California.
Conine: A powerful and very poisonous vegetable alkaloid found in the hemlock (Conium maculatum) and extracted as a colorless oil, C8H17N, of strong repulsive odor and acrid taste. It is regarded as a derivative of piperidine and likewise of one of the collidines. It occasions a gradual paralysis of the motor nerves. Called also coniine, coneine, conia, etc.  See Conium, 2.
Containable: Capable of being contained or comprised.
Circumferential: Pertaining to the circumference; encompassing; encircling; circuitous.
Crucible steel: Cast steel made by fusing in crucibles crude or scrap steel, wrought iron, and other ingredients and fluxes.
Capacity: The power of receiving or containing; extent of room or space; passive power; -- used in reference to physical things.
Chrysarobin: A bitter, yellow substance forming the essential constituent of Goa powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid proper; hence formerly called also chrysphanic acid.
Chondrodite: A fluosilicate of magnesia and iron, yellow to red in color, often occurring in granular form in a crystalline limestone.
Capitalness: The quality of being capital; preeminence.
Cassowary: A large bird, of the genus Casuarius, found in the east Indies. It is smaller and stouter than the ostrich. Its head is armed with a kind of helmet of horny substance, consisting of plates overlapping each other, and it has a group of long sharp spines on each wing which are used as defensive organs. It is a shy bird, and runs with great rapidity. Other species inhabit New Guinea, Australia, etc.
Chemically: According to chemical principles; by chemical process or operation.
Consolidative: Tending or having power to consolidate; healing.
Conductor: One who, or that which, conducts; a leader; a commander; a guide; a manager; a director.
Centerboard: A retractable or sliding keel used on sailboats, formed of a broad board or slab of wood or metal which may be raised into a water-tight case amidships, when in shallow water, or may be lowered to increase the area of lateral resistance and prevent drifting to leeward when the vessel is beating to windward. It is used in vessels of all sizes along the coast of the United States
Citiner: One who is born or bred in a city; a citizen.
Coridine: A colorless or yellowish oil, C10H15N, of a leathery odor, occuring in coal tar, Dippel's oil, tobacco smoke, etc., regarded as an organic base, homologous with pyridine. Also, one of a series of metameric compounds of which coridine is a type.
Charactery: The art or means of characterizing; a system of signs or characters; symbolism; distinctive mark.
Confess: To make confession; to disclose sins or faults, or the state of the conscience.
copyreader: an editor who prepares text for publication.
Chrysogen: A yellow crystalline substance extracted from crude anthracene.
Catamount: The cougar. Applied also, in some parts of the United States, to the lynx.
Canterbury: A city in England, giving its name various articles.  It is the seat of the Archbishop of Canterbury (primate of all England), and contains the shrine of Thomas à Becket, to which pilgrimages were formerly made.
Cucquean: A woman whose husband is unfaithful to her.
Castle: To move the castle to the square next to king, and then the king around the castle to the square next beyond it, for the purpose of covering the king.
Crissal: Pertaining to the crissum; as, crissal feathers.
Constructure: That which is constructed or formed; an edifice; a fabric.
Controvertist: One skilled in or given to controversy; a controversialist.
Cultivable: Capable of being cultivated or tilled.
Compunctive: Sensitive in respect of wrongdoing; conscientious.
Coloration: The act or art of coloring; the state of being colored.
Curviserial: Distributed in a curved line, as leaves along a stem.
Conclusive: Belonging to a close or termination; decisive; convincing; putting an end to debate or question; leading to, or involving, a conclusion or decision.
Chokecherry: The astringent fruit of a species of wild cherry (Prunus Virginiana); also, the bush or tree which bears such fruit.
Cacodyl: Alkarsin; a colorless, poisonous, arsenical liquid, As2(CH3)4, spontaneously inflammable and possessing an intensely disagreeable odor. It is the type of a series of compounds analogous to the nitrogen compounds called hydrazines.
Couple-close: A diminutive of the chevron, containing one fourth of its surface. Couple-closes are generally borne one on each side of a chevron, and the  blazoning may then be either a chevron between two couple-closes or chevron cottised.
Carcharias: The type and sole genus of Carchariidae; the sand sharks.
Collatitious: Brought together; contributed; done by contributions.
Crucial: Having the form of a cross; appertaining to a cross; cruciform; intersecting; as, crucial ligaments; a crucial incision.
Contraction: The act or process of contracting, shortening, or shrinking; the state of being contracted; as, contraction of the heart, of the pupil of the eye, or of a tendon; the contraction produced by cold.
Confluent: A small steam which flows into a large one.
Cordovan: Same as Cordwain.  In England the name is applied to leather made from horsehide.
Cahinca root: The root of an American shrub (Chiococca racemosa), found as far north as Florida Keys, from which cahincic acid is obtained; also, the root of the South American Chiococca anguifuga, a celebrated antidote for snake poison.
Constructional: Pertaining to, or deduced from, construction or interpretation.
Cespitine: An oil obtained by distillation of peat, and containing various members of the pyridine series.
Couchant: Lying down with head erect; squatting.
Cheek: To be impudent or saucy to.
custom-made: made specially for a specific purpose; -- of articles of manufacture.  Contrasted with mass-produced, standardized.
cocuswood: A West Indian wood obtained from the granadilla tree, used for making flutes, clarinets, and other musical instruments.
Cheep: A chirp, peep, or squeak, as of a young bird or mouse.
Comprehensibleness: The quality of being comprehensible; comprehensibility.
Cheer: To grow cheerful; to become gladsome or joyous; -- usually with up.
Clich\u00e9: A stereotype plate or any similar reproduction of ornament, or lettering, in relief.
Concertina: A small musical instrument on the principle of the accordion. It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on the inside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the two hexagonal heads.
Crusader: One engaged in a crusade; as, the crusaders of the Middle Ages.
Comitiva: A body of followers; -- applied to the lawless or brigand bands in Italy and Sicily.
cytotaxonomy: A branch of taxonomy which uses the characteristics of cellular structures, such as somatic chromosomes, to classify organisms.
crucifer: Any plant of the family Cruciferæ.
Concertino: A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; -- more concise than the concerto.
Calender: One of a sect or order of fantastically dressed or painted dervishes.
Chancellor: A judicial court of chancery, which in England and in the United States is distinctively a court with equity jurisdiction.
Cyperaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large family of plants of which the sedge is the type.
Coteau: A hilly upland including the divide between two valleys; a divide.
Canvas: Made of, pertaining to, or resembling, canvas or coarse cloth; as, a canvas tent.
Customableness: Quality of being customable; conformity to custom.
circuit breaker: A device contained within an electrical circuit designed to interrupt the circuit when the current exceeds a preset value; it is sometimes called a contact breaker.  Its function is to prevent fire or damage to the circuit or the devices on the circuit which could be caused by excess current, such as that caused by a short-circuit.  It differs from a fuse in not having a conducting element which melts (see 2nd fuse, n.).  Circuit breakers are designed to be easily reset, i. e. to reclose the circuit after it has been opened by the circuit breaker; this is usually accomplished by simply moving a switch back and forth. They are commonly used in buildings to protect individual electrical lines, and are often contained in groups within a box called a circuit breaker panel, which divides the current from a main electrical line into multiple circuits each protected by a separate circuit breaker. Less commonly they may be found on individual devices.
Consecution: A following, or sequel; actual or logical dependence.
Cigar fish: a small fusiform fish (Decapterus punctatus), allied to the mackerel, found in the West Atlantic and on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.
Centroid: The center of mass, inertia, or gravity of a body or system of bodies.
Confiture: Composition; preparation, as of a drug, or confection; a sweetmeat.
Case knife: A knife carried in a sheath or case.
Chemosynthesis: Synthesis of organic compounds by energy derived from chemical changes or reactions. Chemosynthesis of carbohydrates occurs in the nitrite bacteria through the oxidation of ammonia to nitrous acid, and in the nitrate bacteria through the conversion of nitrous into nitric acid.
Championship: State of being champion; leadership; supremacy.
Crookedly: In a curved or crooked manner; in a perverse or untoward manner.
Catechismal: Of or pertaining to a catechism, having the form of questions and answers; catechetical.
Coscoroba: A large, white, South American duck, of the genus Cascoroba, resembling a swan.
Cystic: Having the form of, or living in, a cyst; as, the cystic entozoa.
carefree: Free of trouble and worry and care; as, the carefree joys of childhood; carefree millionaires, untroubled financially.
Ceratopogon: the type genus of the Ceratopogonidae.
Comatose: Relating to, or resembling, coma; drowsy; lethargic; as, comatose sleep; comatose fever.
Crystallomancy: Divination by means of a crystal or other transparent body, especially a beryl.
Convergent: tending to one point of focus; tending to approach each other; converging.
Condyloid: Shaped like or pertaining to a condyle.
Cruller: A kind of sweet cake cut in strips and curled or twisted, and fried crisp in boiling fat.
Concierge: One who keeps the entrance to an edifice, public or private; a doorkeeper; a janitor, male or female.
Course: To run as in a race, or in hunting; to pursue the sport of coursing; as, the sportsmen coursed over the flats of Lancashire.
Cogger: A flatterer or deceiver; a sharper.
Credential: That which gives a title to credit or confidence.
Canalization: Construction of, or furnishing with, a canal or canals.
chandelle: to perform a chandelle, as of an airplane.
Cremation: A burning; esp., the act or practice of cremating the dead.
Copulatory: Pertaining to copulation; tending or serving to unite; copulative.
Cornemuse: A wind instrument nearly identical with the bagpipe.
chaeta: a stiff chitinous seta or bristle especially of an annelid worm.
Coalesce: To grow together; to unite by growth into one body; as, the parts separated by a wound coalesce.
Car mile: A mile traveled by a single car, taken as a unit of computation, as in computing the average travel of each car of a system during a given period.
Converge: To cause to tend to one point; to cause to incline and approach nearer together.
crown-of-the-field: a European annual (Agrostemma githago) having large trumpet-shaped reddish-purple flowers and poisonous seed; a common weed in grainfields and beside roadways; naturalized in America.
Contredanse: A dance in which the partners are arranged face to face, or in opposite lines.
Coquelicot: The wild poppy, or red corn rose.
Catty: An East Indian Weight of 11/3 pounds.
Contact: A close union or junction of bodies; a touching or meeting.
capacitor: a device used in electronic circuits to hold electrical charge, consisting of two conducting plates separated by a nonconducting (dielectric) medium; it is characterized by its capacitance.
Circumscriber: One who, or that which, circumscribes.
Cerecloth: A cloth smeared with melted wax, or with some gummy or glutinous matter.
chipped: having a small piece broken off; as, a chipped tooth.
cataclinal: running in the direction of the dip in surrounding rock strata; -- of valleys and rivers.  Opposite of anaclinal.
Combat: A fight; a contest of violence; a struggle for supremacy.
Clare: A nun of the order of St. Clare.
crows-nest: A box or platform near the top of a mast, esp. in whalers, to shelter the man on the lookout.
Caress: To treat with tokens of fondness, affection, or kindness; to touch or speak to in a loving or endearing manner; to fondle.
Clary: A plant (Salvia sclarea) of the Sage family, used in flavoring soups.
Charry: Pertaining to charcoal, or partaking of its qualities.
Cavernous: Full of caverns; resembling a cavern or large cavity; hollow.
Contortuplicate: Plaited lengthwise and twisted in addition, as the bud of the morning-glory.
Concoct: To digest; to convert into nourishment by the organs of nutrition.
Constitution: The act or process of constituting; the action of enacting, establishing, or appointing; enactment; establishment; formation.
Camper: One who lodges temporarily in a hut or camp, especially who sleeps in a wilderness for recreation.
cacaine: The essential principle of cacao; -- now called theobromine.
Coastwise: By way of, or along, the coast; following a coastline; as, coastwise winds contributed to the storm.
Carbone: To broil. [Obs.] “We had a calf's head carboned”.
Cord: To bind with a cord; to fasten with cords; to connect with cords; to ornament or finish with a cord or cords, as a garment.
Cora: The Arabian gazelle (Gazella Arabica), found from persia to North Africa.
Corb: A basket used in coal mines, etc. see Corf.
Corm: A solid bulb-shaped root, as of the crocus. See Bulb.
Corn: To preserve and season with salt in grains; to sprinkle with salt; to cure by salting; now, specifically, to salt slightly in brine or otherwise; as, to corn beef; to corn a tongue.
Conveyor: A contrivance for carrying objects from place to place; esp., one for conveying grain, coal, etc., -- as a spiral or screw turning in a pipe or trough, an endless belt with buckets, or a truck running along a rope.
Cork: To stop with a cork, as a bottle.
Canaanitish: Of or pertaining to Canaan or the Canaanites.
Cloth: A fabric made of fibrous material (or sometimes of wire, as in wire cloth); commonly, a woven fabric of cotton, woolen, or linen, adapted to be made into garments; specifically, woolen fabrics, as distinguished from all others.
Counterplead: To plead the contrary of; to plead against; to deny.
Coming: Approach; advent; manifestation; as, the coming of the train.
Christophany: An appearance of Christ, as to his disciples after the crucifixion.
Chichevache: A fabulous cow of enormous size, whose food was patient wives, and which was therefore in very lean condition.
Coiffure: A headdress, or manner of dressing the hair.
Co\u00f6rdinate: A thing of the same rank with another thing; one two or more persons or things of equal rank, authority, or importance.
Castellation: The act of making into a castle.
Culling: The act of one who culls.
Centenarian: Of or relating to a hundred years.
cedarn: Of or pertaining to the cedar or its wood.
Cyprinodont: One of the Cyprinodontidae, a family of fishes including the killifishes or minnows. See Minnow.
Cyclopterus: the type genus of the Cyclopteridae, consisting of lumpfishes.  It includes Cyclopterus lumpus of the North Atlantic.
Corniplume: A hornlike tuft of feathers on the head of some birds.
Cor-: A prefix signifying with, together, etc. See Com-.
Cassel brown: A brown pigment of varying permanence, consisting of impure lignite. It was found originally near Cassel (now Kassel), Germany.
cattleya: any orchid of the genus Cattleya characterized by a hood-shaped three-lobed lip enclosing the column; they are among the most popular and most extravagantly beautiful orchids known.  Called also cattleya orchid.
corncob: The cob or axis on which the kernels of Indian corn grow.
Contemptuousness: Disposition to or manifestion of contempt; insolence; haughtiness.
Cabala: A kind of occult theosophy or traditional interpretation of the Scriptures among Jewish rabbis and certain mediæval Christians, which treats of the nature of god and the mystery of human existence.  It assumes that every letter, word, number, and accent of Scripture contains a hidden sense; and it teaches the methods of interpretation for ascertaining these occult meanings.  The cabalists pretend even to foretell events by this means.
Cushion tire: A thick solid-rubber tire, as for a bicycle, with a hollow groove running lengthwise on the inside.
cloth-bound: having rigid front and back covers, covered with cloth; -- of books.  Contrasted to softcover.
Cornigerous: Horned; having horns; as, cornigerous animals.
Corroboratory: Tending to strengthen; corroborative; as, corroboratory facts.
Calin: An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make tea canisters.
Cataractous: Of the nature of a cataract in the eye; affected with cataract.
Clamor: To utter loud sounds or outcries; to vociferate; to talk in a loud voice; to complain; to make importunate demands.
Co\u00f6perative: Operating jointly to the same end.
Chordee: A painful erection of the penis, usually with downward curvature, occurring in gonorrhea.
Chasmy: Of or pertaining to a chasm; abounding in chasms.
Chirm: To chirp or to make a mournful cry, as a bird.
Carpenter: An artificer who works in timber; a framer and builder of houses, ships, etc.
cephalin: One of a group of phospholipids (nitrogenous phosphorized fatty substances), present in all living cells and particularly evident in nervous tissue.  The cephalins consist of glycerol phosphate in which the two free hydroxyls of the glycerol are esterified with fatty acids, and the phosphate forms an ester linkage to the hydroxyl of ethanolamine.  The phosphate may be linked to the alpha (end) or beta (middle) hydroxyl of the glycerol portion. The natural isomers are of the alpha form, and have the general formula R.O.CH2.CHOR′.CH2.O.PO2.O.CH2.CH2.NH2, where R and R′ are the acyl residues of long-chain fatty acids, which may be the same or different.
Craunch: To crush with the teeth; to chew with violence and noise; to crunch.
Chirp: A short, sharp note, as of a bird or insect.
Cockney: Of or relating to, or like, cockneys.
Costume: Dress in general; esp., the distinctive style of dress of a people, class, or period.
Chapfallen: Having the lower chap or jaw drooping, -- an indication of humiliation and dejection; crestfallen; discouraged. See Chopfallen.
Chloranil: A yellow crystalline substance, C6Cl4.O2, regarded as a derivative of quinone, obtained by the action of chlorine on certain benzene derivatives, as aniline.
Cootfoot: The phalarope; -- so called because its toes are like the coot's.
Cartbote: Wood to which a tenant is entitled for making and repairing carts and other instruments of husbandry.
Carry: A tract of land, over which boats or goods are carried between two bodies of navigable water; a carrying place; a portage.
chromesthesia: a form of synesthesia in which nonvisual stimulation results in the experience of color sensations.
Cherish: To treat with tenderness and affection; to nurture with care; to protect and aid.
cairngorm: A smoky yellow or brown variety of rock crystal, or crystallized quartz, found especially, in the mountain of Cairngorm, in Scotland.
catalufa: a type of brightly colored carnivorous fish (Priacanthus arenatus) of the West Atlantic and West Indies waters.
Copts: An Egyptian race thought to be descendants of the ancient Egyptians.
Confucianist: A follower of Confucius; a Confucian.
Cocaine: A powerful narcotic alkaloid, C17H21NO4, obtained from the leaves of coca. It is a bitter, white, crystalline substance, and is remarkable for producing local insensibility to pain.  It is classified as addictive and is not available in the U. S. without a prescription, but is nevertheless one of the most widespread illegal drugs of abuse.  It is used in several forms, including small pellets of free base, called crack.  Most of the cacaine illegally used in the U.S. is imported.
Clubroom: The apartment in which a club meets.
Coudee: A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end of the middle finger; a cubit.
Coadapted: Adapted one to another; as, coadapted pulp and tooth.
Calcaneal: Pertaining to the calcaneum; as, calcaneal arteries.
Coloboma: A defect or malformation; esp., a fissure of the iris supposed to be a persistent embryonic cleft.
Cohabitant: One who dwells with another, or in the same place or country.
Cuppy: Hollow; cuplike; also, full of cups, or small depressions.
Canonize: To declare (a deceased person) a saint; to put in the catalogue of saints; as, Thomas a Becket was canonized.
Chalice: A cup or bowl; especially, the cup used in the sacrament of the Lord's Supper.
claxon: to sound loudly; -- of car horns.
Cone-in-cone: Consisting of a series of parallel cones, each made up of many concentric cones closely packed together; -- said of a kind of structure sometimes observed in sedimentary rocks.
Chronopher: An instrument signaling the correct time to distant points by electricity.
Catamaran: A kind of raft or float, consisting of two or more logs or pieces of wood lashed together, and moved by paddles or sail; -- used as a surf boat and for other purposes on the coasts of the East and West Indies and South America. Modified forms are much used in the lumber regions of North America, and at life-saving stations.
Crumbcloth: A cloth to be laid under a dining table to receive falling fragments, and keep the carpet or floor clean.
Cancelli: An interwoven or latticed wall or inclosure; latticework, rails, or crossbars, as around the bar of a court of justice, between the chancel and the nave of a church, or in a window.
corticoid: a steroid compound produced by the adrenal cortex, or a synthetic analog of such a compound.
Cultrate: Sharp-edged and pointed; shaped like a pruning knife, as the beak of certain birds.
Castlebuilder: Fig.: one who builds castles in the air or forms visionary schemes.
Cyamelide: A white amorphous substance, regarded as a polymeric modification of isocyanic acid.
Choreic: Of the nature of, or pertaining to, chorea; convulsive.
Capsidae: a natural family comprising the leaf bugs.
Conquer: To gain the victory; to overcome; to prevail.
Commissural: Of or pertaining to a commissure.
Copula: The word which unites the subject and predicate.
Condite: To pickle; to preserve; as, to condite pears, quinces, etc.
Culturable: Capable of, or fit for, being cultivated; capable or becoming cultured.
Cetin: A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part of spermaceti.
Curvicaudate: Having a curved or crooked tail.
Configurate: To take form or position, as the parts of a complex structure; to agree with a pattern.
Cetic: Of or pertaining to a whale.
Coruscation: A sudden flash or play of light.
Chartless: Without a chart; having no guide.
Catechumenical: Of or pertaining to catechumens; as, catechumenical instructions.
Coyote: A carnivorous animal (Canis latrans), allied to the dog, found in the western part of North America; -- called also prairie wolf. Its voice is a snapping bark, followed by a prolonged, shrill howl.
Caburn: A small line made of spun yarn, to bind or worm cables, seize tackles, etc.
coffeecake: a cake or sweet bread usually glazed after baking, and having added nuts and fruits; it is often served with coffee.
chairlift: a ski lift on which riders are seated.
Crucigerous: Bearing the cross; marked with the figure of a cross.
Cutwal: The chief police officer of a large city.
Cytoplasm: The substance of the body of a cell, as distinguished from the karyoplasma, or substance of the nucleus.
Chunk: A short, thick piece of anything.
corticofugal: same as corticoefferent; as, corticofugal discharges.
convect: to circulate hot air by convection, as of certain ovens.
Commoner: One of the common people; one having no rank of nobility.
Carene: A fast of forty days on bread and water.
Confitent: One who confesses his sins and faults.
canecutter: a type of rabbit (Sylvilagus aquaticus) inhabiting southeastern U.S. swamps and lowlands; -- called also swamp rabbit.
Cosine: The sine of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.
Collate: To place in a benefice, when the person placing is both the patron and the ordinary.
Criminal: One who has commited a crime; especially, one who is found guilty by verdict, confession, or proof; a malefactor; a felon.
Conciator: The person who weighs and proportions the materials to be made into glass, and who works and tempers them.
Coop: To confine in a coop; hence, to shut up or confine in a narrow compass; to cramp; -- usually followed by up, sometimes by in.
Coot: A wading bird with lobate toes, of the genus Fulica.  The common European or bald coot is Fulica atra (see under bald); the American is Fulica Americana
Cepheus: A northern constellation near the pole. Its head, which is in the Milky Way, is marked by a triangle formed by three stars of the fourth magnitude. See Cassiopeia.
coauthor: a writer who collaborates with others in writing something.
Construction: The process or art of constructing; the act of building; erection; the act of devising and forming; fabrication; composition.
Characinidae: former name of the family Characidae.
Contrivance: The act or faculty of contriving, inventing, devising, or planning.
Cook: To prepare food for the table.
Calliope: The Muse that presides over eloquence and heroic poetry; mother of Orpheus, and chief of the nine Muses.
Chylify: To make chyle of; to be converted into chyle.
Cercarian: Of, like, or pertaining to, the Cercariæ.
Coom: Soot; coal dust; refuse matter, as the dirty grease which comes from axle boxes, or the refuse at the mouth of an oven.
Cool: To become less hot; to lose heat.
carposporic: of or relating to a carpospore.
Cordyline: a genus of Asiatic and Pacific trees or shrubs remarkable for the fact that fragments of the trunk will regrow to form whole plants.
Chrysoberyl: A mineral, found in crystals, of a yellow to green or brown color, and consisting of aluminia and glucina. It is very hard, and is often used as a gem.
Carburize: To combine with carbon or a carbon compound; -- said esp. of a process for conferring a higher degree of illuminating power on combustible gases by mingling them with a vapor of volatile hydrocarbons.
Ciliata: One of the orders of Infusoria, characterized by having cilia. In some species the cilia cover the body generally, in others they form a band around the mouth.
Chapelet: A pair of straps, with stirrups, joined at the top and fastened to the pommel or the frame of the saddle, after they have been adjusted to the convenience of the rider.
Cubile: The lowest course of stones in a building.
Chiltern Hundreds: A tract of crown land in Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, England, to which is attached the nominal office of steward. As members of Parliament cannot resign, when they wish to go out they accept this stewardship, which legally vacates their seats.
Cocktail: A beverage made of brandy, whisky, or gin, iced, flavored, and sweetened.
Cockshead: A leguminous herb (Onobrychis Caput-galli), having small spiny-crested pods.
Churchmanship: The state or quality of being a churchman; attachment to the church.
Cutaway: Having a part cut off or away; having the corners rounded or cut away.
corkscrew: shaped like a corkscrew; spiral; helical.
Charismatic: Of or pertaining to a charism.
Contempt: The act of contemning or despising; the feeling with which one regards that which is esteemed mean, vile, or worthless; disdain; scorn.
Consular: Of or pertaining to a consul; performing the duties of a consul; as, consular power; consular dignity; consular officers.
Commensurably: In a commensurable manner; so as to be commensurable.
chevvy: to repeatedly cause annoyance or concern to; to chevy; -- same as chivy.
chipboard: a cheap hard material made from wood chips that are pressed together and bound with synthetic resin.
Croquet: In the game of croquet, to drive away an opponent's ball, after putting one's own in contact with it, by striking one's own ball with the mallet.
Commensurable: Having a common measure; capable of being exactly measured by the same number, quantity, or measure.
Clonus: A series of muscular contractions due to sudden stretching of the muscle, -- a sign of certain neuropathies.
Concubine: A woman who cohabits with a man without being his wife; a paramour.
Crystallite: A minute mineral form like those common in glassy volcanic rocks and some slags, not having a definite crystalline outline and not referable to any mineral species, but marking the first step in the crystallization process. According to their form crystallites are called trichites, belonites, globulites, etc.
Cheery: Displaying evident cheerfulness; cheerful; lively; gay; bright; pleasant; as, a cheery person; a cheery hello.
Chiliagon: A plane figure of a thousand angles and sides.
Circumterraneous: Being or dwelling around the earth.
Cutwater: The fore part of a ship's prow, which cuts the water.
Conjectural: Dependent on conjecture; fancied; imagined; guessed at; undetermined; doubtful.
Chetvert: A measure of grain equal to 0.7218 of an imperial quarter, or 5.95 Winchester bushels.
Colluder: One who conspires in a fraud.
Concurrentness: The state or quality of being concurrent; concurrence.
Carvist: A hawk which is of proper age and training to be carried on the hand; a hawk in its first year.
constructive-metabolic: causing buildup of body tissues or tissue components.
Concentration: The act or process of concentrating; the process of becoming concentrated, or the state of being concentrated; concentration.
Carnalize: To make carnal; to debase to carnality.
Cockup: A large, highly esteemed, edible fish of India (Lates calcarifer); -- also called begti.
Cascaron: Lit., an eggshell; hence, an eggshell filled with confetti to be thrown during balls, carnivals, etc.
Cypr\u00e6a: A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.
Chagas disease: a form of trypanosomiasis caused by infection with Trypamosoma cruzi, found principally in South America.  It is transmitted by certain species of reduviid bugs, and has natural reservoirs in dogs, armadillos, rodents and other domestic and wild mammals.
Cut-out: A species of switch for changing the current from one circuit to another, or for shortening a circuit.
Censorious: Addicted to censure; apt to blame or condemn; severe in making remarks on others, or on their writings or manners.
Carboxyl: The complex radical, CO.OH, regarded as the essential and characteristic constituent which all oxygen acids of carbon (as formic, acetic, benzoic acids, etc.) have in common; -- called also oxatyl.
Chicane: To use shifts, cavils, or artifices.
Confusion: The state of being mixed or blended so as to produce indistinctness or error; indistinct combination; disorder; tumult.
Chelonian: Of or pertaining to animals of the tortoise kind.
Clearer: One who, or that which, clears.
Chyometer: An instrument for measuring liquids. It consists of a piston moving in a tube in which is contained the liquid, the quantity expelled being indicated by the graduation upon the piston rod.
Candroy: A machine for spreading out cotton cloths to prepare them for printing.
Chloriodic: Compounded of chlorine and iodine; containing chlorine and iodine.
Cithara: An ancient stringed musical instrument resembling the harp.
Ch\u00e6tognath: Of or pertaining to the Chætognatha.
Cruorin: The coloring matter of the blood in the living animal; hæmoglobin.
Coaction: Force; compulsion, either in restraining or impelling.
Cantle: To cut in pieces; to cut out from.
Courtepy: A short coat of coarse cloth.
Common: To converse together; to discourse; to confer.
Coreplasty: A plastic operation on the pupil, as for forming an artificial pupil.
C\u0153lentera: A comprehensive group of Invertebrata, mostly marine, comprising the Anthozoa, Hydrozoa, and Ctenophora. The name implies that the stomach and body cavities are one. The group is sometimes enlarged so as to include the sponges.
Consistent: Possessing firmness or fixedness; firm; hard; solid.
Crate: A large basket or hamper of wickerwork, used for the transportation of china, crockery, and similar wares.
cramped: inconveniently small; restricting movement; -- of living quarters or workspace; as, cramped quarters; a cramped office.
Cross-crosslet: A cross having the three upper ends crossed, so as to from three small crosses.
Caryophyllidae: a group of families of mostly flowers having basal or free-central placentation and trinucleate pollen (binucleate pollen is commoner in flowering plants); it contains 14 families including: Caryophyllaceae (carnations and pinks); Aizoaceae; Amaranthaceae; Batidaceae; Chenopodiaceae; Cactaceae (order Opuntiales); Nyctaginaceae; Phytolaccaceae; it corresponds approximately to order Caryophyllales; it is sometimes classified as a superorder.
Catastrophe: An event producing a subversion of the order or system of things; a final event, usually of a calamitous or disastrous nature; hence, sudden calamity; great misfortune.
chloral hydrate: a chemical substance (CCl3.CH(OH)2) which is a hydrate of trichloroacetaldehyde.  It crystallizes as white monoclinic plates, obtained by treating chloral with water. It produces sleep when taken internally or hypodermically, and is used in medicine as a hypnotic and sedative; -- called also chloral
choo-choo: a train or a locomotive; -- a child's word.
Consultary: Formed by consultation; resulting from conference.
Craspedota: The hydroid or naked-eyed medusæ. See Hydroidea.
Condurrite: A variety of the mineral domeykite, or copper arsenide, from the Condurra mine in Cornwall, England.
Craspedote: Of or pertaining to the Craspedota.
Caracara: A south American bird of several species and genera, resembling both the eagles and the vultures. The caracaras act as scavengers, and are also called carrion buzzards.
Covetous: Very desirous; eager to obtain; -- used in a good sense.
Caterpillar: The larval state of a butterfly or any lepidopterous insect; sometimes, but less commonly, the larval state of other insects, as the sawflies, which are also called false caterpillars. The true caterpillars have three pairs of true legs, and several pairs of abdominal fleshy legs (prolegs) armed with hooks. Some are hairy, others naked. They usually feed on leaves, fruit, and succulent vegetables, being often very destructive, Many of them are popularly called worms, as the cutworm, cankerworm, army worm, cotton worm, silkworm.
Conceptibility: The quality of being conceivable; conceivableness.
Caseharden: To subject to a process which converts the surface of iron into steel.
Ctenocyst: An organ of the Ctenophora, supposed to be sensory.
Corky: Consisting of, or like, cork; dry shriveled up.
Crucible: A vessel or melting pot, composed of some very refractory substance, as clay, graphite, platinum, and used for melting and calcining substances which require a strong degree of heat, as metals, ores, etc.
Canoness: A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter.
Combatable: Such as can be, or is liable to be, combated; as, combatable foes, evils, or arguments.
Carpus: The wrist; the bones or cartilages between the forearm, or antibrachium, and the hand or forefoot; in man, consisting of eight short bones disposed in two rows.
Childship: The state or relation of being a child.
country-style: of a style associated with rural areas; as, country-style sausage.
Corporify: To embody; to form into a body.
Crotchet: To play music in measured time.
Complier: One who complies, yields, or obeys; one of an easy, yielding temper.
Crick: A painful, spasmodic affection of the muscles of some part of the body, as of the neck or back, rendering it difficult to move the part.
Calculable: That may be calculated or ascertained by calculation.
Colloidal: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, colloids.
Create: To bring into being; to form out of nothing; to cause to exist.
Chaos: An empty, immeasurable space; a yawning chasm.
Comport: Manner of acting; behavior; conduct; deportment.
Crownpiece: A piece or part which passes over the head, as in a bridle.
Cats-eye: A variety of quartz or chalcedony, exhibiting opalescent reflections from within, like the eye of a cat. The name is given to other gems affording like effects, esp. the chrysoberyl.
Cesspool: A cistern in the course, or the termination, of a drain, to collect sedimentary or superfluous matter; a privy vault; any receptacle of filth.
Clytie knot: In hair dressing, a loose, low coil at the back of the head, like the knot on the head of the bust of Clytie by G. F. Watts.
Compounder: One who, or that which, compounds or mixes; as, a compounder of medicines.
Conciliable: Capable of being conciliated or reconciled.
Cannibalism: The act or practice of eating human flesh by mankind. Hence; Murderous cruelty; barbarity.
chastize: same as chastise; -- a variant spelling; as, She chastized him for his insensitive remarks.
Calamite: A fossil plant of the coal formation, having the general form of plants of the modern Equiseta (the Horsetail or Scouring Rush family) but sometimes attaining the height of trees, and having the stem more or less woody within. See Acrogen, and Asterophyllite.
Cosurety: One who is surety with another.
Calamity: Any great misfortune or cause of misery; -- generally applied to events or disasters which produce extensive evil, either to communities or individuals.
Commentation: The act or process of commenting or criticising; exposition.
Chlorophane: A variety of fluor spar, which, when heated, gives a beautiful emerald green light.
Cazique: A chief or petty king among some tribes of Indians in America.
Cinnamyl: The hypothetical radical, (C6H5.C2H2)2C, of cinnamic compounds.
Cometography: A description of, or a treatise concerning, comets.
Carving: The act or art of one who carves.
Crotchetiness: The state or character of being crotchety, or whimsical.
Cyclosporeae: in more recent classifications superseded by the order Fucales.
Collie: The Scotch shepherd dog. There are two breeds, the rough-haired and smooth-haired. It is remarkable for its intelligence, displayed especially in caring for flocks.
Cat o nine tails: a whip used as an instrument of punishment consisting of nine pieces of knotted line or cord fastened to a handle; -- formerly used to flog offenders on the bare back; -- called also the cat.  It was used in the British Navy to maintain discipline on board sailing ships.
Cartogram: A map showing geographically, by shades or curves, statistics of various kinds; a statistical map.
Collin: A very pure form of gelatin.
Cauterization: The act of searing some morbid part by the application of a cautery or caustic; also, the effect of such application.
Capybara: A large South American rodent (Hydrochærus capybara) Living on the margins of lakes and rivers. It is the largest extant rodent, being about three feet long, and half that in height. It somewhat resembles the Guinea pig, to which it is related; -- called also cabiai and water hog.
Checky: Divided into small alternating squares of two tinctures; -- said of the field or of an armorial bearing.
Consequential: Following as a consequence, result, or logical inference; consequent.
Crap: to defecate.  Same as take a crap.
consuming: taking up most of one's attention; ardent; as, politics is his consuming passion.
Cossas: Plain India muslin, of various qualities and widths.
chiseler: a person who swindles you by means of deception or fraud.
Cirriform: Formed like a cirrus or tendril; -- said of appendages of both animals and plants.
Crackling: The making of small, sharp cracks or reports, frequently repeated.
Conchitic: Composed of shells; containing many shells.
Comptograph: A machine for adding numbers and making a printed record of the sum.  An older term for an adding machine.
collaborator: An associate in labor, especially in literary or scientific labor.
Commensalism: The act of eating together; table fellowship.
Croceous: Of, pertaining to, or like, saffron; deep reddish yellow.
Casing: The act or process of inclosing in, or covering with, a case or thin substance, as plaster, boards, etc.
Crewelwork: Embroidery in crewels, commonly done upon some plain material, such as linen.
Criosphinx: A sphinx with the head of a ram.
Craven: To make recreant, weak, spiritless, or cowardly.
cheeseflower: an erect or decumbent Old World perennial (Malva sylvestris) with axillary clusters of rosy-purple flowers; introduced into the U. S.
communicational: used in communication; as, he had few communicational grooves available for use.
Conveniently: In a convenient manner, form, or situation; without difficulty.
Classic: A work of acknowledged excellence and authority, or its author; -- originally used of Greek and Latin works or authors, but now applied to authors and works of a like character in any language.
Cobalt: A tough, lustrous, reddish white metal of the iron group, not easily fusible, and somewhat magnetic. Atomic weight 59.1. Symbol Co.
College: A collection, body, or society of persons engaged in common pursuits, or having common duties and interests, and sometimes, by charter, peculiar rights and privileges; as, a college of heralds; a college of electors; a college of bishops.
Classis: A class or order; sort; kind.
Cyphonautes: The free-swimming, bivalve larva of certain Bryozoa.
coracan: an East Indian cereal grass (Eleusine coracana) whose seeds yield a somewhat bitter flour, a staple in the Orient.
constipated: having difficult or incomplete or infrequent evacuation of the bowels; costive.
Clove: One of the small bulbs developed in the axils of the scales of a large bulb, as in the case of garlic.
cypripedia: a plant or flower of the genus Cypripedium.
Clandestine: Conducted with secrecy; withdrawn from public notice, usually for an evil purpose; kept secret; hidden; private; underhand; as, a clandestine marriage.
Cheiloplasty: The process of forming an artificial tip or part of a lip, by using for the purpose a piece of healthy tissue taken from some neighboring part.
Cran: A measure for fresh herrings, -- as many as will fill a barrel.
comparison-shop: to compare prices for a given item from different vendors; -- usually for the purpose of finding the lowest price.
Caterpillar track: an endless belt looped over several wheels, used in pairs in place of wheels to propel vehicles, such as tractors or military tanks, over rough ground.
Coralloid: Having the form of coral; branching like coral.
Crow-trodden: Marked with crow's-feet, or wrinkles, about the eyes.
Celastrus: the type genus of the Celastraceae, comprising the plants called climbing bittersweet; bittersweet and shrubby bittersweet; they are woody vines and shrubs native chiefly to Asia and Australia, bearing yellow to orange capsules which open to expose red-coated seeds.  See also bittersweet{3b}.
Cops: The connecting crook of a harrow.
Carrying: The act or business of transporting from one place to another.
Caloriduct: A tube or duct for conducting heat; a caliduct.
Copy: To make a copy or copies; to imitate.
Cachectic: Having, or pertaining to, cachexia; as, cachectic remedies; cachectical blood.
Cyrenian: A native or inhabitant of Cyrene.
Cosmopolitan: Having no fixed residence; at home in any place; free from local attachments or prejudices; not provincial; liberal.
Coffin: To inclose in, or as in, a coffin.
Cutlass: A short, heavy, curving sword, used in the navy. See Curtal ax.
Capsquare: A metal covering plate which passes over the trunnions of a cannon, and holds it in place.
Chulan: The fragrant flowers of the Chloranthus inconspicuus, used in China for perfuming tea.
cross-reference: a reference at one place in a work to information at another place in the same work.
Carolus: An English gold coin of the value of twenty or twenty-three shillings. It was first struck in the reign of Charles I.
Centipede: A species of the Myriapoda; esp. the large, flattened, venomous kinds of the order Chilopoda, found in tropical climates. they are many-jointed, and have a great number of feet.
Copesmate: An associate or companion; a friend; a partner.
Commode: A kind of headdress formerly worn by ladies, raising the hair and fore part of the cap to a great height.
Capeline: A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stump of an amputated limb.
Conscionable: Governed by, or according to, conscience; reasonable; just.
Compellable: Capable of being compelled or constrained.
Cheliform: Having a movable joint or finger closing against a preceding joint or a projecting part of it, so that the whole may be used for grasping, as the claw of a crab; pincherlike.
Coliseum: The amphitheater of Vespasian at Rome, the largest in the world.
Cockboat: A small boat, esp. one used on rivers or near the shore.
Comedo: A small nodule or cystic tumor, common on the nose, etc., which on pressure allows the escape of a yellow wormlike mass of retained oily secretion, with a black head (dirt).
Chrysolite: A mineral, composed of silica, magnesia, and iron, of a yellow to green color. It is common in certain volcanic rocks; -- called also olivine and peridot. Sometimes used as a gem. The name was also early used for yellow varieties of tourmaline and topaz.
Claque: A collection of persons employed to applaud at a theatrical exhibition.
Corsepresent: An offering made to the church at the interment of a dead body.
Comedy: A dramatic composition, or representation of a bright and amusing character, based upon the foibles of individuals, the manners of society, or the ludicrous events or accidents of life; a play in which mirth predominates and the termination of the plot is happy; -- opposed to tragedy.
Ceratobranchia: A group of nudibranchiate Mollusca having on the back papilliform or branched organs serving as gills.
Cremate: To burn; to reduce to ashes by the action of fire, either directly or in an oven or retort; to incremate or incinerate; as, to cremate a corpse, instead of burying it.
Cottier: In Great Britain and Ireland, a person who hires a small cottage, with or without a plot of land. Cottiers commonly aid in the work of the landlord's farm.
Courtlike: After the manner of a court; elegant; polite; courtly.
Creance: To get on credit; to borrow.
Cruet: A bottle or vessel; esp., a vial or small glass bottle for holding vinegar, oil, pepper, or the like, for the table; a caster.
Commons: The mass of the people, as distinguished from the titled classes or nobility; the commonalty; the common people.
Croconate: A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.
Cruel: Disposed to give pain to others; willing or pleased to hurt, torment, or afflict; destitute of sympathetic kindness and pity; savage; inhuman; hard-hearted; merciless.
Catnip: A well-know plant of the genus Nepeta (Nepeta Cataria), somewhat like mint, having a string scent, and sometimes used in medicine. It is so called because cats have a peculiar fondness for it.
Charless Wain: The group of seven stars, commonly called the Big Dipper, in the constellation Ursa Major, or Great Bear. See Ursa major, under Ursa.
Cella: The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, as distinguished from the open porticoes.
Commonage: The right of pasturing on a common; the right of using anything in common with others.
Carbonarism: The principles, practices, or organization of the Carbonari.
coarsened: made coarse or crude by lack of skill; -- sometimes used to mean inferior.
Chay root: The root of the Oldenlandia umbellata, native in India, which yieds a durable red dyestuff.
Catechetics: The science or practice of instructing by questions and answers.
Clergyable: Entitled to, or admitting, the benefit of clergy; as, a clergyable felony.
Couplet: Two taken together; a pair or couple; especially two lines of verse that rhyme with each other.
Comelily: In a suitable or becoming manner.
Cruciate: To torture; to torment. [Obs.] See Excruciate.
Causal: A causal word or form of speech.
Candied: Preserved in or with sugar; incrusted with a candylike substance; as, candied fruits.
Controllable: Capable of being controlled, checked, or restrained; amenable to command.
Capcase: A small traveling case or bandbox; formerly, a chest.
Chosen: One who, or that which is the object of choice or special favor.
Culinary: Relating to the kitchen, or to the art of cookery; used in kitchens; as, a culinary vessel; the culinary art.
Celidography: A description of apparent spots on the disk of the sun, or on planets.
Colombier: A large size of paper for drawings. See under Paper.
Concludent: Bringing to a close; decisive; conclusive.
Crocose: A white crystalline sugar, metameric with glucose, obtained from the coloring matter of saffron.
Centric: Placed in the center or middle; central; situated at or near a center.
Coulomb meter: Any instrument by which electricity can be measured in coulombs.
Chemung period: A subdivision in the upper part of the Devonian system in America, so named from the Chemung River, along which the rocks are well developed. It includes the Portage and Chemung groups or epochs. See the Diagram under Geology.
Cockroach: An orthopterous insect of the genus Blatta, and allied genera.
Cycloganoidei: An order of ganoid fishes, having cycloid scales. The bowfin (Amia calva) is a living example.
Condenser: One who, or that which, condenses.
Cyanogen: A colorless, inflammable, poisonous gas, C2N2, with a peach-blossom odor, so called from its tendency to form blue compounds; obtained by heating ammonium oxalate, mercuric cyanide, etc. It is obtained in combination, forming an alkaline cyanide when nitrogen or a nitrogenous compound is strongly ignited with carbon and soda or potash. It conducts itself like a member of the halogen group of elements, and shows a tendency to form complex compounds. The name is also applied to the univalent radical, CN (the half molecule of cyanogen proper), which was one of the first compound radicals recognized.
Ceresin: A white wax, made by bleaching and purifying ozocerite, and used as a substitute for beeswax.
Corruption: The act of corrupting or making putrid, or state of being corrupt or putrid; decomposition or disorganization, in the process of putrefaction; putrefaction; deterioration.
Casuistry: The science or doctrine of dealing with cases of conscience, of resolving questions of right or wrong in conduct, or determining the lawfulness or unlawfulness of what a man may do by rules and principles drawn from the Scriptures, from the laws of society or the church, or from equity and natural reason; the application of general moral rules to particular cases.
Copperas: Green vitriol, or sulphate of iron; a green crystalline substance, of an astringent taste, used in making ink, in dyeing black, as a tonic in medicine, etc. It is made on a large scale by the oxidation of iron pyrites. Called also ferrous sulphate.
candidiasis: an infection caused by fungi of the genera Monilia or Candida, especially Candida albicans.
Continuously: In a continuous maner; without interruption.
cryometer: A thermometer for the measurement of low temperatures, esp. such an instrument containing alcohol or some other liquid of a lower freezing point than mercury.
Choctaws: A tribe of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian), in early times noted for their pursuit of agriculture, and for living at peace with the white settlers. They are now one of the civilized tribes of the Indian Territory.
Cochineal: A dyestuff consisting of the dried bodies of females of the Coccus cacti, an insect native in Mexico, Central America, etc., and found on several species of cactus, esp. Opuntia cochinellifera.
camelia: any of several shrubs or small evergreen trees having solitary white or pink or reddish flowers; the camellia.
Cysticule: An appendage of the vestibular ear sac of fishes.
Chef-d\u0153uvre: A masterpiece; a capital work in art, literature, etc.
Cocoa: A preparation made from the seeds of the chocolate tree, and used in making, a beverage; also the beverage made from cocoa or cocoa shells.
Chrysochlore: A South African mole of the genus Chrysochloris; the golden mole, the fur of which reflects brilliant metallic hues of green and gold.
Caducibranchiate: With temporary gills: -- applied to those Amphibia in which the gills do not remain in adult life.
Copestone: A stone for coping. See Coping.
Classmate: One who is in the same class with another, as at school or college.
Colical: Of, pertaining to, or of the nature of, colic.
Contriver: One who contrives, devises, plans, or schemas.
Caruncular: Of, pertaining to, or like, a caruncle; furnished with caruncles.
Catachrestic: Belonging to, or in the manner of, a catachresis; constituting,  characterized by or given to catachresis; wrested from its natural sense or form; forced; far-fetched.
calming: tending to soothe or calm or tranquilize.
Cirrobranchiata: A division of Mollusca having slender, cirriform appendages near the mouth; the Scaphopoda.
Causticily: The quality of being caustic; corrosiveness; as, the causticity of potash.
Chirognomy: The art of judging character by the shape and appearance of the hand.
Coverage: the range of items covered.  Coverage may be small (narrow coverage}, or large (broad coverage or wide coverage).
Coma: The envelope of a comet; a nebulous covering, which surrounds the nucleus or body of a comet.
Claggy: Adhesive; -- said of a roof in a mine to which coal clings.
corticosterone: any of several steroid compounds secreted by the adrenal cortex; they are involved in regulating water and electrolyte balance in the body.
Carvene: An oily substance, C10H16, extracted from oil caraway.
Compasses: An instrument for describing circles, measuring figures, etc., consisting of two, or (rarely) more, pointed branches, or legs, usually joined at the top by a rivet on which they move.
Chinoiserie: Chinese conduct, art, decoration, or the like; also, a specimen of Chinese manners, art, decoration, etc.
Com-: A prefix from the Latin preposition cum, signifying with, together, in conjunction, very, etc. It is used in the form com- before b, m, p, and sometimes f, and by assimilation becomes col- before l, cor- before r, and con- before any consonant except b, h, l, m, p, r, and w. Before a vowel com- becomes co-; also before h, w, and sometimes before other consonants.
Cataloguer: A maker of catalogues; esp. one skilled in the making of catalogues.
capitalistic: Of or relating to capitalism or capitalists.
Canteen: A small vessel used by soldiers or hikers for carrying water, liquor, or other drink.
conenose: A large bloodsucking hemipterous insect of the family Reduviidæ, often found in houses, esp. in the southern and western United States. It bites severely, and is one of the species called kissing bugs. It is also called big bedbug.
Coigne: The practice of quartering one's self as landlord on a tenant; a quartering of one's self on anybody.
Calandrinia: a large genus of low-growing herbs; widespread throughout tropical and warm temperate regions having usually basal leaves and panicles of purplish ephemeral flowers.
Conform: To be in accord or harmony; to comply; to be obedient; to submit; -- with to or with.
Conveyable: Capable of being conveyed or transferred.
Cucurbit: A vessel or flask for distillation, used with, or forming part of, an alembic; a matrass; -- originally in the shape of a gourd, with a wide mouth. See Alembic.
Cemental: Of or pertaining to cement, as of a tooth; as, cemental tubes.
Countertime: The resistance of a horse, that interrupts his cadence and the measure of his manege, occasioned by a bad horseman, or the bad temper of the horse.
Commissioner: A person who has a commission or warrant to perform some office, or execute some business, for the government, corporation, or person employing him; as, a commissioner to take affidavits or to adjust claims.
Confessionary: Pertaining to auricular confession; as, a confessionary litany.
Corniferous: Of or pertaining to the lowest period of the Devonian age. (See the Diagram, under Geology.) The Corniferous period has been so called from the numerous seams of hornstone which characterize the later part of the period, as developed in the State of New York.
Crescentwise: In the form of a crescent; like a crescent.
Courtly: In the manner of courts; politely; gracefully; elegantly.
Cinchonine: One of the quinine group of alkaloids isomeric with and resembling cinchonidine; -- called also cinchonia.
cabochon: Of, pertaining to, containing, or in the style of, a cabochon.
Crisper: One who, or that which, crisps or curls; an instrument for making little curls in the nap of cloth, as in chinchilla.
Contourniated: Having furrowed edges, as if turned in a lathe.
Comprovincial: Belonging to, or associated in, the same province.
Cast: The act of casting or throwing; a throw.
Carrier: One who, or that which, carries or conveys; a messenger.
Cass: To render useless or void; to quash; to annul; to reject; to send away.
Colcothar: Polishing rouge; a reddish brown oxide of iron, used in polishing glass, and also as a pigment; -- called also crocus Martis.
Calumbin: A bitter principle extracted as a white crystalline substance from the calumba root.
Childbearing: The act of producing or bringing forth children; parturition.
Circularity: The quality or state of being circular; a circular form.
Carnality: The state of being carnal; fleshly lust, or the indulgence of lust; grossness of mind.
choanocyte: any of the flagellated cells in sponges having a collar of cytoplasm around base of the flagellum; they maintain a flow of water through the body.
Contemperature: The condition of being tempered; proportionate mixture; temperature.
Crossness: The quality or state of being cross; peevishness; fretfulness; ill humor.
Chondroganoidea: An order of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons; -- so called on account of their cartilaginous skeleton.
Crowflower: A kind of campion; according to Gerarde, the Lychnis Flos-cuculi.
Chuck-Wills-widow: A large whippoorwill-like bird (a species of goatsucker) (Caprimulgus carolinensis, formerly Antrostomus Carolinensis), of the southern United States; -- so called from its note.
Crippler: A wooden tool used in graining leather.
Capnomor: A limpid, colorless oil with a peculiar odor, obtained from beech tar.
Caravansary: A kind of inn, in the East, where caravans rest at night, being a large, rude, unfurnished building, surrounding a court.
Clique: To To associate together in a clannish way; to act with others secretly to gain a desired end; to plot; -- used with together.
Compesce: To hold in check; to restrain.
cortisone: a corticosteroid hormone (C21H28O5) produced by the adrenal cortex.  It is used in medicine as an antiinflammatory agent.
chagrined: feeling vexed, especially due to feeling inferior or unworthy and hence embarrassed; as, chagrined at the poor sales of his book.
Cautious: Attentive to examine probable effects and consequences of acts with a view to avoid danger or misfortune; prudent; circumspect; wary; watchful; as, a cautious general.
Colza: A variety of cabbage (Brassica oleracea), cultivated for its seeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricating purposes; summer rape.
Cognition: The act of knowing; knowledge; perception.
Ceylanite: A dingy blue, or grayish black, variety of spinel. It is also called pleonaste.
Constitutional: A walk or other exercise taken for one's health or constitution.
Clearstarch: To stiffen with starch, and then make clear by clapping with the hands; as, to clearstarch muslin.
Coachman: A man whose business is to drive a coach or carriage.
Chorally: In the manner of a chorus; adapted to be sung by a choir; in harmony.
Cutling: The art of making edged tools or cutlery.
Crimpy: Having a crimped appearance; frizzly; as, the crimpy wool of the Saxony sheep.
Cunner: A small edible fish of the Atlantic coast (Ctenolabrus adspersus); -- called also chogset, burgall, blue perch, and bait stealer.
Concourse: A moving, flowing, or running together; confluence.
Crumble: To fall into small pieces; to break or part into small fragments; hence, to fall to decay or ruin; to become disintegrated; to perish.
Cavalryman: One of a body of cavalry.
Crave: To desire strongly; to feel an insatiable longing; as, a craving appetite.
Cobweb: The network spread by a spider to catch its prey.
Craniologist: One proficient in craniology; a phrenologist.
Cacographic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, cacography; badly written or spelled.
Complication: The act or process of complicating; the state of being complicated; intricate or confused relation of parts; entanglement; complexity.
Co-lessee: A partner in a lease taken.
Coppery: Mixed with copper; containing copper, or made of copper; like copper.
Contra: A Latin adverb and preposition, signifying against, contrary, in opposition, etc., entering as a prefix into the composition of many English words. Cf. Counter, adv. & pref.
Consectary: That which follows by consequence or is logically deducible; deduction from premises; corollary.
Catarrhal: Pertaining to, produced by, or attending, catarrh; of the nature of catarrh.
Calcite: Calcium carbonate, or carbonate of lime. It is rhombohedral in its crystallization, and thus distinguished from aragonite.  It includes common limestone, chalk, and marble. Called also calc-spar and calcareous spar.
Chainless: Having no chain; not restrained or fettered.
Chelonia: An order of reptiles, including the tortoises and turtles, peculiar in having a part of the vertebræ, ribs, and sternum united with the dermal plates so as to form a firm shell. The jaws are covered by a horny beak. See Reptilia; also, Illust. in Appendix.
Cotyledon: One of the patches of villi found in some forms of placenta.
Colation: The act or process of straining or filtering.
clipboard: a small writing board with a clip attached at the top for holding papers.
Ceremonialism: Adherence to external rites; fondness for ceremony.
Chortle: A word coined by Lewis Carroll (Charles L. Dodgson), and usually explained as a combination of chuckle and snort.
Chyme: The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestines just after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in the intestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.
Canary bird: A small singing bird of the Finch family (Serinus Canarius), a native of the Canary Islands. It was brought to Europe in the 16th century, and made a household pet. It generally has a yellowish body with the wings and tail greenish, but in its wild state it is more frequently of gray or brown color. It is sometimes called canary finch.
Cassius: A brownish purple pigment, obtained by the action of some compounds of tin upon certain salts of gold. It is used in painting and staining porcelain and glass to give a beautiful purple color. Commonly called Purple of Cassius.
Conchometer: An instrument for measuring shells, or the angle of their spire.
Cottonseed oil: A fixed, semidrying oil extracted from cottonseed. It is pale yellow when pure (sp. gr., .92-.93). and is extensively used in soap making, in cookery, and as an adulterant of other oils.
Chinese: A native or natives of China, or one of that yellow race with oblique eyelids who live principally in China.
Cerebroid: Resembling, or analogous to, the cerebrum or brain.
Crier: One who cries; one who makes proclamation.
crystallize: To be converted into a crystal; to take on a crystalline form, through the action of crystallogenic or cohesive attraction; to precipitate from a solution in the form of crystals.
Cadaverine: A sirupy, nontoxic ptomaine, H2N.(CH2)5.NH2 (chemically pentamethylene diamine), formed in putrefaction of flesh, etc.
Calligrapher: One skilled in calligraphy; a good penman.
Clamminess: State of being clammy or viscous.
Costrel: A bottle of leather, earthenware, or wood, having ears by which it was suspended at the side.
Cantata: A poem set to music; a musical composition comprising choruses, solos, interludes, etc., arranged in a somewhat dramatic manner; originally, a composition for a single noise, consisting of both recitative and melody.
Caloyer: A monk of the Greek Church; a cenobite, anchoret, or recluse of the rule of St. Basil, especially, one on or near Mt. Athos.
clockwise: in the same direction as the hands of a clock rotate, as viewed from in front of the clock face; -- said of that direction of a rotation about an axis, or about a point in a plane, which is ordinarily reckoned negative.  Also said of the direction of a spiral, in which case the term right-handed is more common.  Opposite of counterclockwise, and left-handed.
clocking: the time taken to traverse a measured course; as, it was a world record clocking.
companionate: companionlike; as, companionate marriage; a companionate dog.
Confinement: Restraint within limits; imprisonment; any restraint of liberty; seclusion.
Crossbow: A weapon, used in discharging arrows or bolts, formed by placing a bow crosswise on a stock.
Caliginous: Affected with darkness or dimness; dark; obscure.
Cornucopia: The horn of plenty, from which fruits and flowers are represented as issuing. It is an emblem of abundance.
Collutory: A medicated wash for the mouth.
Capstan: A vertical cleated drum or cylinder, revolving on an upright spindle, and surmounted by a drumhead with sockets for bars or levers. It is much used, especially on shipboard, for moving or raising heavy weights or exerting great power by traction upon a rope or cable, passing around the drum. It is operated either by steam power or by a number of men walking around the capstan, each pushing on the end of a lever fixed in its socket.
Cuminol: A liquid, C3H7.C6H4.CHO, obtained from oil of caraway; -- called also cuminic aldehyde.
Calabarine: An alkaloid resembling physostigmine and occurring with it in the calabar bean.
Cinder: Partly burned or vitrified coal, or other combustible, in which fire is extinct.
Conventicle: A small assembly or gathering; esp., a secret assembly.
Clog: To become clogged; to become loaded or encumbered, as with extraneous matter.
Commissionnaire: An agent or factor; a commission merchant.
Cardol: A yellow oily liquid, extracted from the shell of the cashew nut.
Cippus: A small, low pillar, square or round, commonly having an inscription, used by the ancients for various purposes, as for indicating the distances of places, for a landmark, for sepulchral inscriptions, etc.
chin-wag: a light informal conversation for social occasions.
Cats-foot: A plant (Nepeta Glechoma) of the same genus with catnip; ground ivy.
Cordaitales: an order of extinct plants having tall arborescent trunks comparable to or more advanced than cycads; known from the Pennsylvanian; probably extinct since the Mesozoic.
Cocculus: a genus of climbing plants or shrubs.
Clot: To form into a slimy mass.
Conglobe: To collect, unite, or coalesce in a round mass.
Credibly: In a manner inducing belief; as, I have been credibly informed of the event.
Cloy: To fill or choke up; to stop up; to clog.
Codify: To reduce to a code, as laws.
Collop: A small slice of meat; a piece of flesh.
Cymbiform: Shaped like a boat; (Bot.) elongated and having the upper surface decidedly concave, as the glumes of many grasses.
Cockeye: The socket in the ball of a millstone, which sits on the cockhead.
Clubbist: A member of a club; a frequenter of clubs.
Constrainable: Capable of being constrained; liable to constraint, or to restraint.
Commuter: of or pertaining to commuting, in the sense of traveling; used for commuting; as, a commuter airline.
Chrestomathy: A selection of passages, with notes, etc., to be used in acquiring a language; as, a Hebrew chrestomathy.
Compulsatory: Operating with force; compelling; forcing; constraining; resulting from, or enforced by, compulsion.
Communicate: To share or participate; to possess or enjoy in common; to have sympathy.
Clift: A cleft of crack; a narrow opening.
Compurgation: The act or practice of justifying or confirming a man's veracity by the oath of others; -- called also wager of law. See Purgation; also Wager of law, under Wager.
Cadmium: A comparatively rare element related to zinc, and occurring in some zinc ores. It is a white metal, both ductile and malleable. Symbol Cd. Atomic weight 111.8. It was discovered by Stromeyer in 1817, who named it from its association with zinc or zinc ore.
Cardiac: A medicine which excites action in the stomach; a cardial.
Comprador: A kind of steward or agent.
Clear-sighted: Seeing with clearness; acutely perceptive, discerning; as, clear-sighted reason.
Choleic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, bile; as, choleic acid.
Continuity: the state of being continuous; uninterrupted connection or succession; close union of parts; cohesion; as, the continuity of fibers.
Chondrify: To convert, or be converted, into cartilage.
Chiefly: In the first place; principally; preëminently; above; especially.
Conservatism: The disposition and tendency to preserve what is established; opposition to change; the habit of mind; or conduct, of a conservative.
Corrector: One who, or that which, corrects; as, a corrector of abuses; a corrector of the press; an alkali is a corrector of acids.
Corvine: Of or pertaining to the crow; crowlike.
Cropful: Having a full crop or belly; satiated.
cuddling: holding close in a tender and afectionate manner.
Casanova: an Italian adventurer (Giovanni Giacomo Casanova; b. 1725; d. 1798) who wrote vivid accounts of his sexual encounters.
Constipation: Act of crowding anything into a less compass, or the state of being crowded or pressed together; condensation.
Calliphoridae: a natural family comprising the blowflies.
Cuckoldry: The state of being a cuckold; the practice of making cuckolds.
Chaldron: An English dry measure, being, at London, 36 bushels heaped up, or its equivalent weight, and more than twice as much at Newcastle. Now used exclusively for coal and coke.
Capable: Possessing ability, qualification, or susceptibility; having capacity; of sufficient size or strength; as, a room capable of holding a large number; a castle capable of resisting a long assault.
Caned: Filled with white flakes; mothery; -- said vinegar when containing mother.
Competitor: One who seeks what another seeks, or claims what another claims; one who competes; a rival.
catabolism: the breakdown of more complex substances into simpler ones with release of energy, in living organisms; destructive or downward metabolism; -- a form of metabolism, opposed to anabolism. See also Disassimilation.
Cover-point: The fielder in the games of cricket and lacrosse who supports “point.”
chemotherapeutic: of or pertaining to chemotherapy; using chemotherapy; having properties beneficial for chemotherapy.
Circulator: One who, or that which, circulates.
Cove: A boy or man of any age or station.
Constructive: Having ability to construct or form; employed in construction; as, to exhibit constructive power.
Cheeselep: A bag in which rennet is kept.
Cymar: A slight covering; a scarf. See Simar.
circumspectly: In a circumspect manner; cautiously; warily.
Cathead: A projecting piece of timber or iron near the bow of vessel, to which the anchor is hoisted and secured.
Chitterlings: The smaller intestines of swine, etc., fried for food.
Concertante: A concert for two or more principal instruments, with orchestral accompaniment. Also adjectively; as, concertante parts.
Crabstick: A stick, cane, or cudgel, made of the wood of the crab tree.
caskful: the quantity a cask will hold.
Cold-short: Brittle when cold (that is, below a red heat); as, cold-short iron.
Cytula: The fertilized egg cell or parent cell, from the development of which the child or other organism is formed.
Crotaline: Resembling, or pertaining to, the Crotalidae, or Rattlesnake family.
Coussinet: A stone placed on the impost of a pier for receiving the first stone of an arch.
Clyster: A liquid injected into the lower intestines by means of a syringe; an injection; an enema.
Coarticulation: The union or articulation of bones to form a joint.
Catskill period: The closing subdivision of the Devonian age in America. The rocks of this period are well developed in the Catskill mountains, and extend south and west under the Carboniferous formation. See the Diagram under Geology.
Crosslet: Crossed again; -- said of a cross the arms of which are crossed. SeeCross-crosslet.
Chilomycterus: a genus of fish, consisting of the burrfishes.
Circulatorious: Travelling from house to house or from town to town; itinerant.
Cellepore: A genus of delicate branching corals, made up of minute cells, belonging to the Bryozoa.
Carpinaceae: a natural family used in some classification systems to include the genera Carpinus; Ostryopsis; and Ostryopsis.
Capitalize on: To turn (an opportunity) to one's advantage; to take advantage of (a situation); to profit from; as, to capitalize on an opponent's mistakes.
Controvertible: Capable of being controverted; disputable; admitting of question.
crookneck: Either of two varieties of squash, distinguished by their tapering, recurved necks. The summer crookneck is botanically a variety of the pumpkin (Cucurbita pepo) and matures early in the season. It is pale yellow in color, with warty excrescences. The winter crookneck belongs to a distinct species (Cucurbita moschata) and is smooth and often striped.
Clinic: One confined to the bed by sickness.
Chelonethida: an order comprising the false scorpions.
Chine: To cut through the backbone of; to cut into chine pieces.
Chilopoda: One of the orders of myriapods, including the centipedes. They have a single pair of elongated legs attached laterally to each segment; well developed jaws; and a pair of thoracic legs converted into poison fangs. They are insectivorous, very active, and some species grow to the length of a foot.
Chink: To make a slight, sharp, metallic sound, as by the collision of little pieces of money, or other small sonorous bodies.
Congenital: Existing at, or dating from, birth; pertaining to one from birth; born with one; connate; constitutional; natural; as, a congenital deformity; a congenital liar. See Connate and native.
Contemplation: The act of the mind in considering with attention; continued attention of the mind to a particular subject; meditation; musing; study.
contrarian: a person who habitually takes a view opposite to that held by the majority; as, the contrarians in the stock market prefer to sell when most analysts advise us to buy.
Char-a-bancs: A long, light, open vehicle, with benches or seats running lengthwise.
Countercheck: A check; a stop; a rebuke, or censure to check a reprover.
Ch\u00e6totaxy: The arrangement of bristles on an insect.
carcinoid: A small tumor (benign or malignant) arising from the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract; it is usually associated with excessive secretion of serotonin.
Cross-vaulting: Vaulting formed by the intersection of two or more simple vaults.
Cleistogamic: Having, beside the usual flowers, other minute, closed flowers, without petals or with minute petals; -- said of certain species of plants which possess flowers of two or more kinds, the closed ones being so constituted as to insure self-fertilization.
Cetene: An oily hydrocarbon, C16H32, of the ethylene series, obtained from spermaceti.
Coincident: One of two or more coincident events; a coincidence.
Congeneric: Belonging to the same genus; allied in origin, nature, or action; of or pertaining to a congener.
Custody: A keeping or guarding; care, watch, inspection, for keeping, preservation, or security.
Ceremony: Ar act or series of acts, often of a symbolical character, prescribed by law, custom, or authority, in the conduct of important matters, as in the performance of religious duties, the transaction of affairs of state, and the celebration of notable events; as, the ceremony of crowning a sovereign; the ceremonies observed in consecrating a church; marriage and baptismal ceremonies.
Christianness: Consonance with the doctrines of Christianity.
Carpophore: A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between the carpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.
