Crosspiece: A piece of any structure which is fitted or framed crosswise.
Cholagogue: Promoting the discharge of bile from the system.
Cotyla: A cuplike cavity or organ. Same as Acetabulum.
Claptrap: Contrived for the purpose of making a show, or gaining applause; deceptive; unreal.
Coendoo: The Brazilian porcupine (Cercolades prehensiles syn. Sphingurus prehensiles), remarkable for its prehensile tail.
chased: a person who is being chased; as, better to be the chaser than the chased.
Coast: To draw near to; to approach; to keep near, or by the side of.
Cuscus: A soft grass (Pennisetum typhoideum) found in all tropical regions, used as food for men and cattle in Central Africa.
Carinat\u00e6: A grand division of birds, including all existing flying birds; -- So called from the carina or keel on the breastbone.
Crossopterygian: Of or pertaining to the Crossopterygii.
Coextensive: Equally extensive; having equal extent; as, consciousness and knowledge are coextensive.
Culcita: a genus that includes some plants usually placed in e.g. genus Dicksonia; terrestrial brackenlike ferns of tropical America, Malasia to Australia and Polynesia; also native in southwestern Europe and Atlantic islands.
Cucullus: A hood-shaped organ, resembling a cowl or monk's hood, as certain concave and arched sepals or petals.
Canker bloom: The bloom or blossom of the wild rose or dog-rose.
Concolor: Of the same color; of uniform color.
Crociary: One who carries the cross before an archbishop.
coccoid: spherical; like a coccus; as, a coccoid microorganism.
Conversationist: One who converses much, or who excels in conversation.
Calcareo-siliceous: Consisting of, or containing calcareous and siliceous earths.
Churchlike: Befitting a church or a churchman; becoming to a clergyman.
Chatter mark: One of the fine undulations or ripples which are formed on the surface of work by a cutting tool which chatters.
Cluster: To collect into a cluster or clusters; to gather into a bunch or close body.
Crimeful: Criminal; wicked; contrary to law, right, or dury.
Codling: A young cod; also, a hake.
Clinostat: An apparatus consisting of a slowly revolving disk, usually regulated by  clockwork, by means of wich the action of external agents, as light and gravity, on growing plants may be regulated or eliminated.
Costmary: A garden plant (Chrysanthemum Balsamita) having a strong balsamic smell, and nearly allied to tansy. It is used as a pot herb and salad plant and in flavoring ale and beer. Called also alecost.
Churn: To perform the operation of churning.
Censorial: Belonging to a censor, or to the correction of public morals.
Caviar: The roes of the sturgeon, prepared and salted; -- used as a relish, esp. in Russia.
Counsel: To give advice to; to advice, admonish, or instruct, as a person.
Cyclometer: A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of a bicycle.
Clustery: Growing in, or full of, clusters; like clusters.
Combattant: In the position of fighting; -- said of two lions set face to face, each rampant.
Circumventor: One who circumvents; one who gains his purpose by cunning.
Chrysotype: A photographic picture taken upon paper prepared by the use of a sensitive salt of iron and developed by the application of chloride of gold.
Cuckolds knot: A hitch or knot, by which a rope is secured to a spar, the two parts of the rope being crossed and seized together; -- called also cuckold's neck.
Credo: The creed, as sung or read in the Roman Catholic church.
Chuckleheaded: Having a large head; thickheaded; dull; stupid.
Cauterize: To burn or sear with a cautery or caustic.
Carinate: Shaped like the keel or prow of a ship; having a carina or keel; as, a carinate calyx or leaf; a carinate sternum (of a bird).
Curable: Capable of being cured; admitting remedy.
Combatant: One who engages in combat.  IN military use, opposed to noncombatant.
Colloquist: A speaker in a colloquy or dialogue.
Confucius: a Chinese philosopher (circa 551-478 BC), the founder of Confucianism.
Craftsmaster: One skilled in his craft or trade; one of superior cunning.
callable: subject to a demand for payment or redemption before the due date; -- of financial instruments; as, callable bonds.
Chert: An impure, massive, flintlike quartz or hornstone, of a dull color.
Coafforest: To convert into, or add to, a forest.
Countess: The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count in the Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignity in her own right. See the Note under Count.
Catholicos: The spiritual head of the Armenian church, who resides at Etchmiadzin, Russia, and has ecclesiastical jurisdiction over, and consecrates the holy oil for, the Armenians of Russia, Turkey, and Persia, including the Patriarchs of Constantinople, Jerusalem, and Sis.
Curialism: The view or doctrine of the ultramontane party in the Latin Church.
Crotalus: A genus of poisonous serpents, including the rattlesnakes.
Cone pulley: A pulley for driving machines, etc., having two or more parts or steps of different diameters; a pulley having a conical shape.
Catholicness: The quality of being catholic; universality; catholicity.
Caledonian: Of or pertaining to Caledonia or Scotland; Scottish; Scotch.
Crotalum: A kind of castanet used by the Corybantes.
Catholicon: A remedy for all diseases; a panacea.
Constriction: The act of constricting by means of some inherent power or by movement or change in the thing itself, as distinguished from compression.
Chanuka: same as Hanukka; -- a variant spelling.
Consonance: Accord or agreement of sounds produced simultaneously, as a note with its third, fifth, and eighth.
Cupper: One who performs the operation of cupping.
Candlemas: The second day of February, on which is celebrated the feast of the Purification of the Virgin Mary; -- so called because the candles for the altar or other sacred uses are blessed on that day.
Cyanosed: Rendered blue, as the surface of the body, from cyanosis or deficient aëration of the blood.
Credible: Capable of being credited or believed; worthy of belief; entitled to confidence; trustworthy.
Chrome steel: Same as Chromium steel, under Steel.
Chaparral: A thicket of low evergreen oaks.
Cobblestone: A large pebble; a rounded stone not too large to be handled; a small boulder; -- used for paving streets and for other purposes.
Casque: A piece of defensive or ornamental armor (with or without a vizor) for the head and neck; a helmet.
cortege: A train of attendants; a group following and attending to some important person.
Conscientiousness: The quality of being conscientious; a scrupulous regard to the dictates of conscience.
Conservator: One who preserves from injury or violation; a protector; a preserver.
comparability: a similarity allowing comparison; an approximate equivalence.
Ceromancy: Divination by dropping melted wax in water.
Compages: A system or structure of many parts united.
Cauf: A chest with holes for keeping fish alive in water.
Coshering: A feudal prerogative of the lord of the soil entitling him to lodging and food at his tenant's house.
crane: to reach forward with head and neck, in order to see better; as, a hunter cranes forward before taking a leap.
Caul: A covering of network for the head, worn by women; also, a net.
Cracknel: A hard brittle cake or biscuit.
combretum: any of numerous shrubs or small trees of the genus Combretum having spikes of small flowers.
Cleaner: One who, or that which, cleans.
Consulter: One who consults, or asks counsel or information.
Comparate: One of two things compared together.
Coturnix: a genus of birds comprising the Old World quail.
Cloisterer: One belonging to, or living in, a cloister; a recluse.
Contrabasso: The largest kind of bass viol. See Violone.
Conscription: Belonging to, or of the nature of, a conspiration.
Courthouse: A house in which established courts are held, or a house appropriated to courts and public meetings.
Crown wheel: A wheel with cogs or teeth set at right angles to its plane; -- called also a contrate wheel or face wheel.
Confidant: One to whom secrets, especially those relating to affairs of love, are confided or intrusted; a confidential or bosom friend.
Commingle: To mingle together; to mix in one mass, or intimately; to blend.
Chironomy: The art of moving the hands in oratory or in pantomime; gesture
Constat: A certificate showing what appears upon record touching a matter in question.
Cassioberry: The fruit of the Viburnum obovatum, a shrub which grows from Virginia to Florida.
centrifugation: the process of separating substances by the use of a centrifuge.
Cast-off: Cast or laid aside; thrown away; discarded; as, cast-off clothes.
Condemnation: The act of condemning or pronouncing to be wrong; censure; blame; disapprobation.
counter-sabotage: counterintelligence designed to detect and counteract sabotage.
corking pin: A pin of a large size, formerly used attaching a woman's headdress to a cork mold.
Coppering: The act of covering with copper.
Cogently: In a cogent manner; forcibly; convincingly; conclusively.
Cicatricial: Relating to, or having the character of, a cicatrix.
cecum: The caecum, the cavity in which the large intestine begins and into which the ileum opens.
Corno di bassetto: A tenor clarinet; -- called also basset horn, and sometimes confounded with the English horn, which is a tenor oboe.
Canescent: Growing white, or assuming a color approaching to white.
Catoptrics: That part of optics which explains the properties and phenomena of reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected from mirrors or polished bodies; -- formerly called anacamptics.
Commissionaire: One intrusted with a commission, now only a small commission, as an errand; esp., an attendant or subordinate employee in a public office, hotel, or the like.
Cabassou: A species of armadillo of the genus Xenurus (Xenurus unicinctus and Xenurus hispidus); the tatouay.
Clake: The bernicle goose; -- now called barnacle goose and also called clack goose.
Conscience: Knowledge of one's own thoughts or actions; consciousness.
Cycloscope: A machine for measuring at any moment velocity of rotation, as of a wheel of a steam engine.
Cocker spaniel: One of a breed of small or medium-sized spaniels kept for hunting or retrieving game or for household pets. They usually weigh from eighteen to twenty-eight pounds. They have the head of fair length, with square muzzle, the ears long and set low, the legs short or of medium length, and the coat fine and silky, wavy but not curly. Various colors are bred, as black, liver, red, black and white, black and tan, etc.
CV: Same as curriculum vitae; -- a commonly used initialism.
Cadaveric: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a corpse, or the changes produced by death; cadaverous; as, cadaveric rigidity.
Consign: To submit; to surrender or yield one's self.
Constringent: Having the quality of contracting, binding, or compressing.
Coyness: The quality of being coy; feigned o&unr_; bashful unwillingness to become familiar; reserve.
copied: reproducing the features of an original especially in an inferior manner.
Chirographer: One who practice the art or business of writing or engrossing.
Crania: A genus of living Brachiopoda; -- so called from its fancied resemblance to the cranium or skull.
Closure: The act of shutting; a closing; as, the closure of a chink.
Center: To place or fix in the center or on a central point.
Cloaking: The act of covering with a cloak; the act of concealing anything.
Courteous: Of courtlike manners; pertaining to, or expressive of, courtesy; characterized by courtesy; civil; obliging; well bred; polite; affable; complaisant.
Cahenslyism: A plan proposed to the Pope in 1891 by P. P. Cahensly, a member of the German parliament, to divide the foreign-born population of the United States, for ecclesiastical purposes, according to European nationalities, and to appoint bishops and priests of like race and speaking the same language as the majority of the members of a diocese or congregation. This plan was successfully opposed by the American party in the Church.
Chiragrical: Having the gout in the hand, or subject to that disease.
Companionable: Fitted to be a companion; fit for good fellowship; agreeable; sociable.
Crux ansata: A cross in the shape of the ankh.
C\u0153nosarc: The common soft tissue which unites the polyps of a compound hydroid. See Hydroidea.
Cafenet: A humble inn or house of rest for travelers, where coffee is sold.
crepitant: Having a crackling sound; crackling; rattling.
Clockwork: The machinery of a clock, or machinery resembling that of a clock; machinery which produces regularity of movement.
Cutwork: An ancient term for embroidery, esp. applied to the earliest form of lace, or to that early embroidery on linen and the like, from which the manufacture of lace was developed.
Conchifera: That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; the Lamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.
Circumscriptly: In a literal, limited, or narrow manner.
Confidence: The act of confiding, trusting, or putting faith in; trust; reliance; belief; -- formerly followed by of, now commonly by in.
Contribute: To give a part to a common stock; to lend assistance or aid, or give something, to a common purpose; to have a share in any act or effect.
Crooked: Characterized by a crook or curve; not straight; turning; bent; twisted; deformed.
Coronel: The iron head of a tilting spear, divided into two, three, or four blunt points.
Coroner: An officer of the peace whose principal duty is to inquire, with the help of a jury, into the cause of any violent, sudden or mysterious death, or death in prison, usually on sight of the body and at the place where the death occurred.
Corydalidae: A natural family of insects including the dobsonflies.
Cryptogamian: Of or pertaining to the series Cryptogamia, or to plants of that series.
Cowpea: The seed of one or more leguminous plants of the genus Dolichos; also, the plant itself. Many varieties are cultivated in the southern part of the United States.
Carte: A position in thrusting or parrying, with the inside of the hand turned upward and the point of the weapon toward the adversary's right breast.
Coemption: The act of buying the whole quantity of any commodity.
Crossjack: The lowest square sail, or the lower yard of the mizzenmast.
Clearstory: The upper story of the nave of a church, containing windows, and rising above the aisle roofs.
counterfactuality: the quality of being contrary to fact.
Civilian: One skilled in the civil law.
Copeck: A Russian copper coin. See Kopeck.
Confiner: One who lives on confines, or near the border of a country; a borderer; a near neighbor.
Cowalker: A phantasmic or “astral” body deemed to be separable from the physical body and capable of acting independently; a doppelgänger.
Counterpassant: Passant in opposite directions; -- said of two animals.
Caduceus: The official staff or wand of Hermes or Mercury, the messenger of the gods. It was originally said to be a herald's staff of olive wood, but was afterwards fabled to have two serpents coiled about it, and two wings at the top.
Caboched: Showing the full face, but nothing of the neck; -- said of the head of a beast in armorial bearing.
Concretionary: Pertaining to, or formed by, concretion or aggregation; producing or containing concretions.
Compassionate: To have compassion for; to pity; to commiserate; to sympathize with.
Chanticleer: A cock, so called from the clearness or loudness of his voice in crowing.
Cross-buttock: A throw in which the wrestler turns his left side to his opponent, places his left leg across both legs of his opponent, and pulls him forward over his hip; hence, an unexpected defeat or repulse.
Cordylidae: a small family of spiny ovoviviparous African lizards.
Crowberry: A heathlike plant of the genus Empetrum, and its fruit, a black, scarcely edible berry; -- also called crakeberry.
Cuff: A blow; esp.,, a blow with the open hand; a box; a slap.
Cucking stool: A kind of chair formerly used for punishing scolds, and also dishonest tradesmen, by fastening them in it, usually in front of their doors, to be pelted and hooted at by the mob, but sometimes to be taken to the water and ducked; -- called also a castigatory, a tumbrel, and a trebuchet; and often, but not so correctly, a ducking stool.
Contrapuntal: Pertaining to, or according to the rules of, counterpoint.
Chophouse: A customhouse where transit duties are levied.
circumstance: That which attends, or relates to, or in some way affects, a fact or event; an attendant thing or state of things.
Cope-chisel: A narrow chisel adapted for cutting a groove.
Caplin: The cap or coupling of a flail, through which the thongs pass which connect the handle and swingel.
Circumjovial: One of the moons or satellites of the planet Jupiter.
Chikara: The goat antelope (Tragops Bennettii) of India.
Clepsine: A genus of fresh-water leeches, furnished with a proboscis. They feed upon mollusks and worms.
Cryer: The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
Contagionist: One who believes in the contagious character of certain diseases, as of yellow fever.
Convenient: Fit or adapted; suitable; proper; becoming; appropriate.
Chessboard: The board used in the game of chess, having eight rows of alternate light and dark squares, eight in each row. See Checkerboard.
Cupid: The god of love, son of Venus; usually represented as a naked, winged boy with bow and arrow.
clinid: any fish of the family Clinidae, of temperate and tropical seas.
Cerastium: a genus of weedy plants of the pink family, comprising the mouse-ear chickweeds.
Cash railway: A form of cash carrier in which a small carrier or car travels upon a kind of track.
Cosset: To treat as a pet; to fondle.
cedilla: A mark placed under the letter c [thus, ç], to show that it is to be sounded like s, as in façade.
Cepaceous: Of the nature of an onion, as in odor; alliaceous.
Coble: A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudder extending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originally used on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.
Coiner: One who makes or stamps coin; a maker of money; -- usually, a maker of counterfeit money.
Castilian: An inhabitant or native of Castile, in Spain.
Cylindric: Having the form of a cylinder, or of a section of its convex surface; partaking of the properties of the cylinder.
Comradeship: The state of being a comrade; intimate fellowship.
Colet: An inferior church servant. [Obs.] See Acolyte.
Cypsela: A one-seeded, one-celled, indehiscent fruit; an achene with the calyx tube adherent.
Crossbite: To deceive; to trick; to gull.
Collect: A short, comprehensive prayer, adapted to a particular day, occasion, or condition, and forming part of a liturgy.
Celticize: To render Celtic; to assimilate to the Celts.
Cracowes: Long-toed boots or shoes formerly worn in many parts of Europe; -- so called from Cracow, in Poland, where they were first worn in the fourteenth century.
czarina: The title of the empress of Russia.
Consequent: That which follows, or results from, a cause; a result or natural effect.
catty-corner: having a slanted or oblique direction.
Compliable: Capable of bending or yielding; apt to yield; compliant.
Chlamydate: Having a mantle; -- applied to certain gastropods.
contentedness: acceptance of one's situation in life.
Chlorometry: The process of testing the bleaching power of any combination of chlorine.
Capitulate: To surrender or transfer, as an army or a fortress, on certain conditions.
Crosswort: A name given to several inconspicuous plants having leaves in whorls of four, as species of Crucianella, Valantia, etc.
Catacaustic: A caustic curve formed by reflection of light.
Comedietta: A dramatic sketch; a brief comedy.
Childishness: The state or quality of being childish; simplicity; harmlessness; weakness of intellect.
Carton: Pasteboard for paper boxes; also, a pasteboard box.
Consecutiveness: The state or quality of being consecutive.
Coffee: The “beans” or “berries” (pyrenes) obtained from the drupes of a small evergreen tree of the genus Coffea, growing in Abyssinia, Arabia, Persia, and other warm regions of Asia and Africa, and also in tropical America.
Coffea: the genus comprising the coffee trees.
Chain stitch: An ornamental stitch like the links of a chain; -- used in crocheting, sewing, and embroidery.
Cachiri: A fermented liquor made in Cayenne from the grated root of the manioc, and resembling perry.
Chandelier: A candlestick, lamp, stand, gas fixture, or the like, having several branches; esp., one hanging from the ceiling.
Corniform: Having the shape of a horn; horn-shaped.
chains: metal shackles connected by chains, used to bind hands or legs; as, he was kept two weeks in chains.
Conceive: To have an embryo or fetus formed in the womb; to breed; to become pregnant.
Circuity: A going round in a circle; a course not direct; a roundabout way of proceeding.
Coamings: Raised pieces of wood of iron around a hatchway, skylight, or other opening in the deck, to prevent water from running bellow; esp. the fore-and-aft pieces of a hatchway frame as distinguished from the transverse head ledges.
Coupstick: A stick or switch used among some American Indians in making or counting a coup.
Currish: Having the qualities, or exhibiting the characteristics, of a cur; snarling; quarrelsome; snappish; churlish; hence, also malicious; malignant; brutal.
Christology: A treatise on Christ; that department of theology which treats of the personality, attributes, or life of Christ.
Concentric: That which has a common center with something else.
Cauter: A hot iron for searing or cauterizing.
caterpillar-tracked: having caterpillar treads or tracks on the wheels; as, a caterpillar-tracked earthmover.
Caravan: A company of travelers, pilgrims, or merchants, organized and equipped for a long journey, or marching or traveling together, esp. through deserts and countries infested by robbers or hostile tribes, as in Asia or Africa.
Crepis: A genus of plants including the hawk's beard; cosmopolitan in the northern hemisphere.
Carbohydrate: One of a group of compounds including the sugars, starches, and gums, which contain six (or some multiple of six) carbon atoms, united with a variable number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, but with the two latter always in proportion as to form water; as dextrose, C6H12O6.
Centrifugal filter: A filter, as for sugar, in which a cylinder with a porous or foraminous periphery is rapidly rotated so as to drive off liquid by centrifugal action.
Cathexis: the process of investing mental, emotional, or libidinal energy or significance in an object, person, or idea.
Court-plaster: Sticking plaster made by coating taffeta or silk on one side with some adhesive substance, commonly a mixture of isinglass and glycerin.
Cercopithecidae: a natural family of Old World monkeys including the guenon, baboon, colobus monkey, langur, macaque, mandrill, mangabey, patas, and proboscis monkey.
Conchometry: The art of measuring shells or their curves; conchyliometry.
Chaetognatha: a phylum consisting of the arrowworms, a group of small active transparent free-swimming marine worms, of which the genus Sagitta is the type. They have groups of curved spines on each side of the head.
Cashew: A tree (Anacardium occidentale) of the same family which the sumac. It is native in tropical America, but is now naturalized in all tropical countries. Its fruit, a kidney-shaped nut, grows at the extremity of an edible, pear-shaped hypocarp, about three inches long.
Camellia: An Asiatic genus of small shrubs, often with shining leaves and showy flowers. Camellia Japonica is much cultivated for ornament, and Camellia Sassanqua and Camellia oleifera are grown in China for the oil which is pressed from their seeds. The tea plant is now referred to this genus under the name of Camellia Thea.
Cuticle: The scarfskin or epidermis. See Skin.
chemists: a retail shop where medicine and other articles are sold; a drugstore.
cancerous: Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer; affected with cancer; as, a cancerous growth.
Cerebripetal: Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the spinal cord to the brain and so transfer sensations (centripetal impressions) from the exterior inwards.
Carabao: The water buffalo of the Philippines.
cross-fertilisation: fertilization by the union of male and female gametes from different individuals of the same species.
Candelabrum: A lamp stand of any sort.
Circumposition: The act of placing in a circle, or round about, or the state of being so placed.
Chorister: One of a choir; a singer in a chorus.
Child: To give birth; to produce young.
Chili: A kind of red pepper. See Capsicum
Chill: To become surface-hardened by sudden cooling while solidifying; as, some kinds of cast iron chill to a greater depth than others.
Colorable: Specious; plausible; having an appearance of right or justice.
Cyclops: One of a race of giants, sons of Neptune and Amphitrite, having but one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead. They were fabled to inhabit Sicily, and to assist in the workshops of Vulcan, under Mt. Etna.
Circumfusile: Capable of being poured or spread round.
Compare: To get; to procure; to obtain; to acquire
Corpuscular: Pertaining to, or composed of, corpuscles, or small particles.
Camelot: the legendary site of King Arthur's court and castle.
Crazedness: A broken state; decrepitude; an impaired state of the intellect.
Chalcocite: Native copper sulphide, called also copper glance, and vitreous copper; a mineral of a black color and metallic luster.
Cleftgraft: To ingraft by cleaving the stock and inserting a scion.
Compart: To divide; to mark out into parts or subdivisions.
Come-outer: One who comes out or withdraws from a religious or other organization; a radical reformer.
Chenopodiales: an order which corresponds approximately to the older group Centrospermae.
Ctenoidei: A group of fishes, established by Agassiz, characterized by having scales with a pectinated margin, as in the perch. The group is now generally regarded as artificial.
Copple: Something rising in a conical shape; specifically, a hill rising to a point.
Chiropodist: One who treats diseases of the hands and feet; especially, one who removes corns and bunions.
Cross-examiner: One who cross-examines or conducts a crosse-examination.
Comprehensible: Capable of being comprehended, included, or comprised.
confounding: a mistake that results from taking one thing to be another.
clanswoman: a female member of a clan.
Caducity: Tendency to fall; the feebleness of old age; senility.
Carpospore: A kind of spore formed in the conceptacles of red algæ.
Confusive: Confusing; having a tendency to confusion.
Coprolitic: Containing, pertaining to, or of the nature of, coprolites.
Cawky: Of or pertaining to cawk; like cawk.
Cellular: Consisting of, or containing, cells; of or pertaining to a cell or cells.
Clan-na-Gael: A secret society of Irish Fenians founded in Philadelphia in 1881.
Centrum: The body, or axis, of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
Coarseness: The quality or state of being coarse; roughness; inelegance; vulgarity; grossness; as, coarseness of food, texture, manners, or language.
Coactive: Serving to compel or constrain; compulsory; restrictive.
Conjointly: In a conjoint manner; untitedly; jointly; together.
Catechetic: Relating to or consisting in, asking questions and receiving answers, according to the ancient manner of teaching.
Cardamine: A genus of cruciferous plants, containing the lady's-smock, cuckooflower, bitter cress, meadow cress, etc.
Chimney-piece: A decorative construction around the opening of a fireplace; also, the shelf that projects from wall above fireplace; mantlepiece.
considerateness: kind and considerate regard for others; consideration.
Confessor: One who confesses; one who acknowledges a fault, or the truth of a charge, at the risk of suffering; specifically, one who confesses himself a follower of Christ and endures persecution for his faith.
Cyprinodontidae: a large family of small soft-finned fishes; killifishes; flagfishes; swordtails; guppies.
Cantalever: A bracket to support a balcony, a cornice, or the like.
Concitation: The act of stirring up, exciting, or agitating.
Chiliahedron: A figure bounded by a thousand plane surfaces
Chassepot: A kind of breechloading, center-fire rifle, or improved needle gun.
Compensator: One who, or that which, compensates; -- a name applied to various mechanical devices.
Coparceny: An equal share of an inheritance.
cytosol: The soluble components of the fluid matter enclosed within the cellular membrane; the portion of the cytoplasm which remains after removal of particulate components.
Chemosis: Inflammatory swelling of the conjunctival tissue surrounding the cornea.
Coppled: Rising to a point; conical; copped.
Continental: A soldier in the Continental army. See Continental, a., 3.
Coque: A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.
Communist: An advocate for the theory or practice of communism.
cushy: not requiring strong efforts; easy; -- said of paid employment; as, He got a cushy job in a large company.
Cystolith: A concretion of mineral matter within a leaf or other part of a plant.
Collophore: A suckerlike organ at the base of the abdomen of insects belonging to the Collembola.
Cobwall: A wall made of clay mixed with straw.
Cardinalship: The condition, dignity, of office of a cardinal
Counterman: A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.
Chancrous: Of the nature of a chancre; having chancre.
Chilly: Moderately cold; cold and raw or damp so as to cause shivering; causing or feeling a disagreeable sensation of cold, or a shivering.
Concrescence: Coalescence of particles; growth; increase by the addition of particles.
Carbonic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, carbon; as, carbonic oxide.
Calumniate: To propagate evil reports with a design to injure the reputation of another; to make purposely false charges of some offense or crime.
Cotidal: Marking an equality in the tides; having high tide at the same time.
Conglutination: A gluing together; a joining by means of some tenacious substance; junction; union.
Chloro-: A prefix denoting that chlorine is an ingredient in the substance named.
Ceroplastics: The art of modeling in wax.
Countershaft: An intermediate shaft; esp., one which receives motion from a line shaft in a factory and transmits it to a machine.
contemporize: to arrange or represent events so that they co-occur.
Creamery: A place where butter and cheese are made, or where milk and cream are put up in cans for market.
Cowpers glands: Two small glands discharging into the male urethra.
crudites: an appetizer consisting of raw vegetables cut into bite-sized strips and served with a dip.
Crazy: Characterized by weakness or feebleness; decrepit; broken; falling to decay; shaky; unsafe.
Counter-roll: A duplicate roll (record or account) kept by an officer as a check upon another officer's roll.
Camphene: One of a series of substances C10H16, resembling camphor, regarded as modified terpenes.
Camisated: Dressed with a shirt over the other garments.
Coaptation: The adaptation or adjustment of parts to each other, as of a broken bone or dislocated joint.
Collaboration: The act of working together; united labor.
commemorating: of or pertaining to a commemoration; serving to commemorate.
Cyclopean: Pertaining to the Cyclops; characteristic of the Cyclops; huge; gigantic; vast and rough; massive; as, Cyclopean labors; Cyclopean architecture.
Cautionary: Conveying a caution, or warning to avoid danger; as, cautionary signals.
Chaplain: An ecclesiastic who has a chapel, or who performs religious service in a chapel.
Cawk: An opaque, compact variety of barite, or heavy spar.
Cynicism: The doctrine of the Cynics; the quality of being cynical; the mental state, opinions, or conduct, of a cynic; morose and contemptuous views and opinions.
Courlan: A South American bird, of the genus Aramus, allied to the rails.
Colluvies: A collection or gathering, as of pus, or rubbish, or odds and ends.
Colporteur: A hawker; specifically, one who travels about selling and distributing religious tracts and books.
cata-cornered: having a slanted or oblique direction.
Crematory: Pertaining to, or employed in, cremation.
Chalcanthite: Native blue vitriol. See Blue vitriol, under Blue.
Cichoraceous: Belonging to, or resembling, a suborder of composite plants of which the chicory (Cichorium) is the type.
Cleopatras needle: Either of two obelisks which were moved in ancient times from Heliopolis to Alexandria, one of which is now on the Thames Embankment in London, and the other in Central Park, in the City of New York.
Coryphodont: Pertaining to, or resembling, the genus Coryphodon.
Ciceronian: Resembling Cicero in style or action; eloquent.
Chondrule: A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral, usually enstatite or chrysolite, found imbedded more or less abundantly in the mass of many meteoric stones, which are hence called chondrites.
Contravention: The act of contravening; opposition; obstruction; transgression; violation.
Conceptacle: That in which anything is contained; a vessel; a receiver or receptacle.
Calorificient: Having, or relating to the power of producing heat; -- applied to foods which, being rich in carbon, as the fats, are supposed to give rise to heat in the animal body by oxidation.
Consoling: Adapted to console or comfort; cheering; as, this is consoling news.
classicistic: of or pertaining to classicism; as, classicistic tradition.
Cholera: One of several diseases affecting the digestive and intestinal tract and more or less dangerous to life, esp. the one commonly called Asiatic cholera.
Cadaver: A dead human body; a corpse.
Coparcenary: Partnership in inheritance; joint heirship; joint right of succession to an inheritance.
Canachites: a genus of birds including the spruce grouse Canachites canadensis.
Cancellate: Consisting of a network of veins, without intermediate parenchyma, as the leaves of certain plants; latticelike.
Clairvoyant: One who is able, when in a mesmeric state, to discern objects not present to the senses.
Churchmanly: Pertaining to, or becoming, a churchman.
Coalescence: The act or state of growing together, as similar parts; the act of uniting by natural affinity or attraction; the state of being united; union; concretion.
Cypres: A rule for construing written instruments so as to conform as nearly to the intention of the parties as is consistent with law.
Cycnoches: a genus of epiphytic or terrestrial tropical American orchids.
Coulure: A disease affecting grapes, esp. in California, manifested by the premature dropping of the fruit.
Claim: A demand of a right or supposed right; a calling on another for something due or supposed to be due; an assertion of a right or fact.
Checkless: That can not be checked or restrained.
Crowd: To play on a crowd; to fiddle.
candelabra: a branched, ornamental candlestick having several sockets for candles.
Cinctured: Having or wearing a cincture or girdle.
chelation: the process of removing a heavy metal from a solution by means of a chelate;
Crows: A tribe of Indians of the Dakota stock, living in Montana; -- also called Upsarokas.
Cistern: An artificial reservoir or tank for holding water, beer, or other liquids.
cromorna: A certain reed stop in the organ, of a quality of tone resembling that of the oboe.
Carboniferous: Producing or containing carbon or coal.
Concordat: A compact, covenant, or agreement concerning anything.
chainlike: having a form resembling a chain; as, chainlike clusters of bacteria.
Convention: The act of coming together; the state of being together; union; coalition.
Concretion: The process of concreting; the process of uniting or of becoming united, as particles of matter into a mass; solidification.
Cynegetics: The art of hunting with dogs.
Cindery: Resembling, or composed of, cinders; full of cinders.
Coquettish: Practicing or exhibiting coquetry; alluring; enticing.
Convexo-convex: Convex on both sides; double convex. See under Convex, a.
Canna: A genus of tropical plants, with large leaves and often with showy flowers. The Indian shot (Canna Indica) is found in gardens of the northern United States.
Cormorant: Any species of Phalacrocorax, a genus of sea birds having a sac under the beak; the shag. Cormorants devour fish voraciously, and have become the emblem of gluttony. They are generally black, and hence are called sea ravens, and coalgeese.
Carchariidae: a natural family comprising the sand sharks; in some classifications coextensive with the family Carcharhinidae.
Chapman: One who buys and sells; a merchant; a buyer or a seller.
Coeducation: An educating together, of different sexes or races; -- now used almost exclusively in reference to the education males and females together.
Commendable: Worthy of being commended or praised; laudable; praiseworthy.
Conspire: To plot; to plan; to combine for.
Contagion: The transmission of a disease from one person to another, by direct or indirect contact.
Coincidence: The condition of occupying the same place in space; as, the coincidence of circles, surfaces, etc.
Corrigent: A substance added to a medicine to mollify or modify its action.
Connature: Participation in a common nature or character.
Cattle: Quadrupeds of the Bovine family; sometimes, also, including all domestic quadrupeds, as sheep, goats, horses, mules, asses, and swine.
Cradleland: Land or region where one was cradled; hence, land of origin.
Cablegram: A message sent by a submarine telegraphic cable.
Calisaya bark: A valuable kind of Peruvian bark obtained from the Cinchona Calisaya, and other closely related species.
coenobite: a member of a religious order living in common.  Same as Cenobite.
Cicatrization: The process of forming a cicatrix, or the state of being cicatrized.
Continuer: One who continues; one who has the power of perseverance or persistence.
Chivalrously: In a chivalrous manner; gallantly; magnanimously.
Coeternity: Existence from eternity equally with another eternal being; equal eternity.
Continued: Having extension of time, space, order of events, exertion of energy, etc.; extended; protracted; uninterrupted; also, resumed after interruption; extending through a succession of issues, session, etc.; as, a continued story.
Cancriform: Having the form of, or resembling, a crab; crab-shaped.
Countersign: The signature of a secretary or other officer to a writing signed by a principal or superior, to attest its authenticity.
Cubited: Having the measure of a cubit.
Creatinin: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous body closely related to creatin but more basic in its properties, formed from the latter by the action of acids, and occurring naturally in muscle tissue and in urine.
Coachfellow: One of a pair of horses employed to draw a coach; hence (Fig.), a comrade.
Circensial: Of or pertaining to, or held in, the Circus, In Rome.
Chrysophane: A glucoside extracted from rhubarb as a bitter, yellow, crystalline powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid on decomposition.
Cabinetmaker: One whose occupation is to make cabinets or other choice articles of household furniture, as tables, bedsteads, bureaus, etc.
Coxcomb: A strip of red cloth notched like the comb of a cock, which licensed jesters formerly wore in their caps.
Chionanthus: a genus of deciduous trees or shrubs: fringe tree.
Crinicultural: Relating to the growth of hair.
coralroot: a European bittercress (Dentaria bulbifera) having a knotted white rootstock.
Cellulitis: An inflammantion of the cellular or areolar tissue, esp. of that lying immediately beneath the skin.
Cacoxene: A hydrous phosphate of iron occurring in yellow radiated tufts. The phosphorus seriously injures it as an iron ore.
Carnal: Of or pertaining to the body or its appetites; animal; fleshly; sensual; given to sensual indulgence; lustful; human or worldly as opposed to spiritual.
Cocoonery: A building or apartment for silkworms, when feeding and forming cocoons.
Camisard: One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled against Louis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so called from the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.
Cervix: The neck; also, the necklike portion of any part, as of the womb. See Illust. of Bird.
Cold-blooded: Having cold blood; -- said of fish or animals whose blood is but little warmer than the water or air about them.
Cognac: A kind of French brandy, so called from the town of Cognac.
Corpus: A body, living or dead; the corporeal substance of a thing.
Cimbal: A kind of confectionery or cake.
Confiteor: A form of prayer in which public confession of sins is made.
Cogitable: Capable of being brought before the mind as a thought or idea; conceivable; thinkable.
Convincingness: The power of convincing, or the quality of being convincing.
collaborationist: someone who collaborates with an enemy occupying force.
Cowhage: A leguminous climbing plant of the genus Mucuna, having crooked pods covered with sharp hairs, which stick to the fingers, causing intolerable itching. The spiculæ are sometimes used in medicine as a mechanical vermifuge.
Coniferophyta: a class of cone-bearing gymnosperms dating from the Carboniferous; most are substantial trees; it includes the classes Pinopsida (subdivision Pinophytina) and Ginkgopsida (subdivision Ginkgophytina) and Taxopsida (subdivision Taxophytina) which in turn include the surviving orders Coniferales and Taxales (yews) and sometimes Ginkgoales as well as extinct orders such as Cordaitales (of the Carboniferous and Permian) and Volztiales (of the Permian-Jurassic).
Cochineal fig: A plant of Central and Southern America, of the Cactus family, extensively cultivated for the sake of the cochineal insect, which lives on it.
Cuban: Of or pertaining to Cuba or its inhabitants.
Cooler: That which cools, or abates heat or excitement.
Cerrial: Of or pertaining to the cerris.
Circumjacent: Lying round; bordering on every side.
crackerberry: a creeping red-berried perenial herb (Cornus canadensis) distinguished by clustered leaf whorls at tips of shoots; Greenland to Alaska.
Capitulary: Relating to the chapter of a cathedral; capitular.
casava: any of several plants of the genus Manihot having fleshy roots yielding a nutritious starch.
Chain: To fasten, bind, or connect with a chain; to fasten or bind securely, as with a chain; as, to chain a bulldog.
Calculator: One who computes or reckons: one who estimates or considers the force and effect of causes, with a view to form a correct estimate of the effects.
Coaita: The native name of certain South American monkeys of the genus Ateles, esp. Ateles paniscus. The black-faced coaita is Ateles ater. See Illustration in Appendix.
conceding: the act of conceding or yielding.
copybook: a book containing models of good penmanship; used in teaching penmanship.
Curtal: A horse with a docked tail; hence, anything cut short.
Caddice: The larva of a caddice fly. These larvæ generally live in cylindrical cases, open at each end, and covered externally with pieces of broken shells, gravel, bits of wood, etc.  They are a favorite bait with anglers. Called also caddice worm, or caddis worm.
Cohort: A body of about five or six hundred soldiers; the tenth part of a legion.
Canceration: The act or state of becoming cancerous or growing into a cancer.
Cyclamen: A genus of plants of the Primrose family, having depressed rounded corms, and pretty nodding flowers with the petals so reflexed as to point upwards, whence it is called rabbits' ears. It is also called sow bread, because hogs are said to eat the corms.
Carbolize: To apply carbolic acid to; to wash or treat with carbolic acid.
Coversed sine: The versed sine of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.
Cultivation: The art or act of cultivating; improvement for agricultural purposes or by agricultural processes; tillage; production by tillage.
Cordwainer: A worker in cordwain, or cordovan leather; a shoemaker.
Curtain: To inclose as with curtains; to furnish with curtains.
Cystolithic: Relating to stone in the bladder.
Classify: To distribute into classes; to arrange according to a system; to arrange in sets according to some method founded on common properties or characters.
Consistorial: Of or pertaining to a consistory.
Consistorian: Pertaining to a Presbyterian consistory; -- a contemptuous term of 17th century controversy.
Cozy: A wadded covering, often decorative, for a teakettle or other vessel to keep the contents hot.  Also called tea cozy
Capitalization: The act or process of capitalizing.
caucasoid: belonging to the caucasian racial group.
Calypso: A small and beautiful species of orchid, having a flower variegated with purple, pink, and yellow. It grows in cold and wet localities in the northern part of the United States. The Calypso borealis is the only orchid which reaches 68° N.
Condensation: The act or process of condensing or of being condensed; the state of being condensed.
Contango: The premium or interest paid by the buyer to the seller, to be allowed to defer paying for the stock purchased until the next fortnightly settlement day.
centered: being or placed in the center.
Cloggy: Clogging, or having power to clog.
Corylopsis: small genus of deciduous shrubs of temperate regions of Asia.
Chloroplast: A plastid containing chlorophyll, developed only in cells exposed to the light. Chloroplasts are minute flattened granules, usually occurring in great numbers in the cytoplasm near the cell wall, and consist of a colorless ground substance saturated with chlorophyll pigments. Under light of varying intensity they exhibit phototactic movements. In animals chloroplasts occur only in certain low forms.
Cotemporaneous: Living or being at the same time; contemporaneous.
Cotarnine: A white, crystalline substance, C12H13NO3, obtained as a product of the decomposition of narcotine. It has weak basic properties, and is usually regarded as an alkaloid.
Confession: Acknowledgment; avowal, especially in a matter pertaining to one's self; the admission of a debt, obligation, or crime.
Concinnity: Internal harmony or fitness; mutual adaptation of parts; elegance; -- used chiefly of style of discourse.
Clathrus: the type genus of the Clathraceae.
Cupule: A cuplet or little cup, as of the acorn; the husk or bur of the filbert, chestnut, etc.
Catamenial: Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.
Colorature: Vocal music colored, as it were, by florid ornaments, runs, or rapid passages.
Constrictive: Serving or tending to bind or constrict.
Circulatory: A chemical vessel consisting of two portions unequally exposed to the heat of the fire, and with connecting pipes or passages, through which the fluid rises from the overheated portion, and descends from the relatively colder, maintaining a circulation.
Capsicin: A red liquid or soft resin extracted from various species of capsicum.
Cephalalgic: Relating to, or affected with, headache.
Chaser: One who chases or engraves. See 5th Chase, and Enchase.
canafistola: a deciduous or semi-evergreen tree (Cassia fistula) having scented sepia to yellow flowers in drooping racemes and pods whose pulp is used medicinally; it grows in tropical Asia, Central and South America, and Australia.
Corrivate: To cause to flow together, as water drawn from several streams.
Cosening: Anything done deceitfully, and which could not be properly designated by any special name, whether belonging to contracts or not.
Comtism: Positivism; the positive philosophy. See Positivism.
Co\u00f6ptate: To choose; to elect; to coöpt.
Cirrostomi: The lowest group of vertebrates; -- so called from the cirri around the mouth; the Leptocardia. See Amphioxus.
Cinematograph: an older name for a movie projector, a machine, combining magic lantern and kinetoscope features, for projecting on a screen a series of pictures, moved rapidly (25 to 50 frames per second) and intermittently before an objective lens, and producing by persistence of vision the illusion of continuous motion; a moving-picture projector; also, any of several other machines or devices producing moving pictorial effects. Other older names for the movie projector are animatograph, biograph, bioscope, electrograph, electroscope, kinematograph, kinetoscope, veriscope, vitagraph, vitascope, zoögyroscope, zoöpraxiscope, etc.
Circumscissile: Dehiscing or opening by a transverse fissure extending around (a capsule or pod). See Illust. of Pyxidium.
Carbide: A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical, in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termed carburet.
Comtist: A disciple of Comte; a positivist.
Convert: A person who is converted from one opinion or practice to another; a person who is won over to, or heartily embraces, a creed, religious system, or party, in which he has not previously believed; especially, one who turns from the controlling power of sin to that of holiness, or from unbelief to Christianity.
Centerbit: An instrument turning on a center, for boring holes. See Bit, n., 3.
Cocainism: A morbid condition produced by the habitual and excessive use of cocaine.
carcinoma: A form of malignant cancer arising from epithelial tissue.  The term was earlier applied to all forms of cancer, or to certain non-malignant forms. It is contrasted with sarcoma, a malignant form of cancer arising from connective tissue.  See Cancer.
Communistic: Of or pertaining to communism or communists; as, communistic theories.
Coarctate: Pressed together; closely connected; -- applied to insects having the abdomen separated from the thorax only by a constriction.
Chrematistics: The science of wealth; the science, or a branch of the science, of political economy.
cuckoo bee: a bee, parasitic in the larval stage in the nests of other bees, feeding either upon their food or larvae. They belong to the genera Nomada, Melecta, Epeolus, and others.
Catbird: An American bird (Galeoscoptes Carolinensis), allied to the mocking bird, and like it capable of imitating the notes of other birds, but less perfectly. Its note resembles at times the mewing of a cat.
Cogman: A dealer in cogware or coarse cloth.
Canis: A genus of carnivorous mammals, of the family Canidæ, including the dogs and wolves.
Cucurbita: the type genus of the Cucurbitaceae.
Caulicle: A short caulis or stem, esp. the rudimentary stem seen in the embryo of a seed; -- otherwise called a radicle.
Creolean: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Creoles.
Cabriolet: A one-horse carriage with two seats and a calash top.
Clear-headed: Having a clear understanding; quick of perception; intelligent.
colors: a flag flown by a ship to show its nationality.
Chaise: A two-wheeled carriage for two persons, with a calash top, and the body hung on leather straps, or thorough-braces. It is usually drawn by one horse.
Crownwork: A work consisting of two or more bastioned fronts, with their outworks, covering an enceinte, a bridgehead, etc., and connected by wings with the main work or the river bank.
Captivating: Having power to captivate or charm; fascinating; as, captivating smiles.
Conduit system: A system of electric traction, esp. for light railways, in which the actuating current passes along a wire or rail laid in an underground conduit, from which the current is “picked up” by a plow or other device fixed to the car or electric locomotive.  Hence Conduit railway.
Contradictory: A proposition or thing which denies or opposes another; contrariety.
Coldly: In a cold manner; without warmth, animation, or feeling; with indifference; calmly.
curriculae: Same as curricula, plural of curriculum.  This is used commonly in the same sense as curricula, and appears to have arisen due to an incorrect assumption that curricula is a Latin-derived singular word.
Cognitive: Knowing, or apprehending by the understanding; as, cognitive power.
canoeman: One who uses a canoe; one who travels in a canoe.
Corticine: A material for carpeting or floor covering, made of ground cork and caoutchouc or India rubber.
Coign: A var. spelling of Coin, Quoin, a corner, wedge; -- chiefly used in the phrase coign of vantage, a position advantageous for action or observation.
Cannae: the name of a battle in which Hannibal defeated the Romans in 216 b. c.  Called also battle of Cannae.
Chlorometer: An instrument to test the decoloring or bleaching power of chloride of lime.
Chirogymnast: A mechanical contrivance for exercising the fingers of a pianist.
Counterirritate: To produce counter irritation in; to treat with one morbid process for the purpose of curing another.
Canicular: Pertaining to, or measured, by the rising of the Dog Star.
Capper: One whose business is to make or sell caps.
caesura: A metrical break in a verse, occurring in the middle of a foot and commonly near the middle of the verse; a sense pause in the middle of a foot. Also, a long syllable on which the cæsural accent rests, or which is used as a foot.
commercialization: the act or process of making something commercial in character.  See commercialize.
Concertmeister: The head violinist or leader of the strings in an orchestra; the sub-leader of the orchestra; concert master.
Conakry: The capital city of Guinea.  Population (2000) = 1,508,000.
Caribbean: Of or pertaining to the Caribs, to their islands (the eastern and southern West Indies), or to the sea (called the Caribbean sea) lying between those islands and Central America.
Carbonaceous: Pertaining to, containing, or composed of, carbon.
Couvade: A custom, among certain barbarous tribes, that when a woman gives birth to a child her husband takes to his bed, as if ill.
cesarean section: the operation of taking a child from the womb by cutting through the walls of the abdomen and uterus; -- so called because Julius Cæsar is reported to have been brought into the world by such an operation; -- called also caesarean.
Chromatrope: An instrument for exhibiting certain chromatic effects of light (depending upon the persistence of vision and mixture of colors) by means of rapidly rotating disks variously colored.
Cracovienne: A lively Polish dance, in 2-4 time.
Cunabula: The earliest abode; original dwelling place; originals; as, the cunabula of the human race.
Cachinnatory: Consisting of, or accompanied by, immoderate laughter.
Copland: A piece of ground terminating in a point or acute angle.
Cony-catch: To deceive; to cheat; to trick.
Commorancy: A dwelling or ordinary residence in a place; habitation.
Colored: Having color; tinged; dyed; painted; stained.
Calorimetry: Measurement of the quantities of heat in bodies.
Circumvention: The act of prevailing over another by arts, address, or fraud; deception; fraud; imposture; delusion.
Cheve: To come to an issue; to turn out; to succeed; as, to cheve well in a enterprise.
Clavichord: A keyed stringed instrument, now superseded by the pianoforte. See Clarichord.
Convolve: To roll or wind together; to roll or twist one part on another.
Constrain: To secure by bonds; to chain; to bond or confine; to hold tightly; to constringe.
Caribou: The American reindeer, especially the common or woodland species (Rangifer Caribou).
Concionator: An haranguer of the people; a preacher.
Cruiser: One who, or a vessel that, cruises;
cloud-cuckoo-land: an imaginary place where fantasy and illusion predominate; it is a place where you say people are when they seem optimistically out of touch with reality.
Cod liver: The liver of the common cod and allied species.
Cardinalize: To exalt to the office of a cardinal.
Chancel: That part of a church, reserved for the use of the clergy, where the altar, or communion table, is placed.
Ceratosaurus: A swift-running bipedal carnivorous American Jurassic dinosaur allied to the European Megalosaurus. The animal was nearly twenty feet in length, and the skull bears a bony short horn between the nostrils on the united nasal bones. See Illustration in Appendix.
Conservatoire: A public place of instruction in any special branch, esp. music and the arts. [See Conservatory, 3].
Cimbia: A fillet or band placed around the shaft of a column as if to strengthen it.
Courtbred: Bred, or educated, at court; polished; courtly.
Catheterism: The operation of introducing a catheter.
Carpogenic: Productive of fruit, or causing fruit to be developed.
Cyanite: A mineral occuring in thin-bladed crystals and crystalline aggregates, of a sky-blue color. It is a silicate of aluminium.
Circumesophagal: Surrounding the esophagus; -- in (Zoöl.) said of the nerve commissures and ganglia of arthropods and mollusks.
Culverkey: A bunch of the keys or samaras of the ash tree.
Catalepsy: A sudden suspension of sensation and volition, the body and limbs preserving the position that may be given them, while the action of the heart and lungs continues.
Calorification: Production of heat, esp. animal heat.
Cockcrow: The time at which cocks first crow; the early morning; the first light of day.
Credulity: Readiness of belief; a disposition to believe on slight evidence.
Concussive: Having the power or quality of shaking or agitating.
Crosstrees: Pieces of timber at a masthead, to which are attached the upper shrouds.  At the head of lower masts in large vessels, they support a semicircular platform called the “top.”
Complement: To supply a lack; to supplement.
Conscript: To enroll, by compulsion, for military service.
Combativeness: The quality of being combative; propensity to contend or to quarrel.
Chlamydomonas: the type genus of the Chlamydomonadaceae; they are solitary biflagellated plantlike algae common in fresh water and damp soil.  They multiply freely and are often a pest around filtration plants.
Crosswise: In the form of a cross; across; transversely.
Cyanophyll: A blue coloring matter supposed by some to be one of the component parts of chlorophyll.
Carvacrol: A thick oily liquid, C10H13.OH, of a strong taste and disagreeable odor, obtained from oil of caraway (Carum carui).
Congestion: The act of gathering into a heap or mass; accumulation.
Cuterebridae: a natural family of New World botflies.
coenobitic: of or relating to or befitting cenobites or their practices of communal living.  Opposite of eremitic.
Cebuano: The language of the people of Cebu in the Philippines; its lexicon contributes to the official languag of the Philippines.
Coalpit: A pit where coal is dug.
Coagent: An associate in an act; a coworker.
Cry: A loud utterance; especially, the inarticulate sound produced by one of the lower animals; as, the cry of hounds; the cry of wolves.
climb-down: a retraction of a previously held position.
Carrion: Of or pertaining to dead and putrefying carcasses; feeding on carrion.
Concept: An abstract general conception; a notion; a universal.
Cowwheat: A weed of the genus Melampyrum, with black seeds, found on European wheatfields.
Cohobate: To repeat the distillation of, pouring the liquor back upon the matter remaining in the vessel.
Cypriot: of or relating to Cyprus or its people or culture; as, Cypriote monasteries.
Chaperon: To attend in public places as a guide and protector; to matronize.
Clinometer: An instrument for determining the dip of beds or strata, pr the slope of an embankment or cutting; a kind of plumb level.
Coulisse: A fluting in a sword blade.
Ceraunoscope: An instrument or apparatus employed in the ancient mysteries to imitate thunder and lightning.
Ceratopogonidae: a natural family of insects including the biting midges and sand flies.
Constablewick: The district to which a constable's power is limited.
catalatic: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of catalases.
Centranthus: a genus of southern European herbs and subshrubs.
Celature: The act or art of engraving or embossing.
Chuprassy: A messenger or servant wearing an official badge.
Corrigibility: Quality of being corrigible; capability of being corrected; corrigibleness.
cardsharp: a professional card player who makes a living by cheating at card games.
Coneflower: Any plant of the genus Rudbeckia; -- so called from the cone-shaped disk of the flower head. They are cultivated for their large usually yellow daisies with prominent central cones.  Also, any plant of the related genera Ratibida and Brauneria, the latter usually known as purple coneflower.
Chaped: Furnished with a chape or chapes.
cross-country: a race over a course including countryside, rather than over roads or prepared paths.
Commeasurable: Having the same measure; commensurate; proportional.
Clumps: A game in which questions are asked for the purpose of enabling the questioners to discover a word or thing previously selected by two persons who answer the questions; -- so called because the players take sides in two “clumps” or groups, the “clump” which guesses the word winning the game.
Chapel: To deposit or inter in a chapel; to enshrine.
Chalybean: Of or pertaining to the Chalybes, an ancient people of Pontus in Asia Minor, celebrated for working in iron and steel.
Confront: To stand facing or in front of; to face; esp. to face hostilely; to oppose with firmness.
Chryselephantine: Composed of, or adorned with, gold and ivory.
Castellated: Inclosed within a building; as, a fountain or cistern castellated.
Clart: To daub, smear, or spread, as with mud, etc.
Cowberry: A species of Vaccinium (Vaccinium Vitis-idæa), which bears acid red berries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally called mountain cranberry.
Curtesy: the life estate which a husband has in the lands of his deceased wife, which by the common law takes effect where he has had issue by her, born alive, and capable of inheriting the lands.
cycle: To cause to pass through a cycle{2}.
Cyclosis: The circulation or movement of protoplasmic granules within a living vegetable cell.
co-optation: The act of choosing; selection; choice.
Comparatively: According to estimate made by comparison; relatively; not positively or absolutely.
Chaplaincy: The office, position, or station of a chaplain.
Coziness: The state or quality of being cozy.
Carbamine: An isocyanide of a hydrocarbon radical. The carbamines are liquids, usually colorless, and of unendurable odor.
Croup: An inflammatory affection of the larynx or trachea, accompanied by a hoarse, ringing cough and stridulous, difficult breathing; esp., such an affection when associated with the development of a false membrane in the air passages (also called membranous croup). See False croup, under False, and Diphtheria.
Counteract: To act in opposition to; to hinder, defeat, or frustrate, by contrary agency or influence; as, to counteract the effect of medicines; to counteract good advice.
Clothing: Garments in general; clothes; dress; raiment; covering.
Coccosteus: An extinct genus of Devonian ganoid fishes, having the broad plates about the head studded with berrylike tubercles.
Ceratopsia: a suborder of extinct animals including triceratops.
Console: A bracket whose projection is not more than half its height.
Cannaceae: A natural family of plants coextensive with the genus Canna.
Canon bone: The shank bone, or great bone above the fetlock, in the fore and hind legs of the horse and allied animals, corresponding to the middle metacarpal or metatarsal bone of most mammals. See Horse.
Cloak: To cover with, or as with, a cloak; hence, to hide or conceal.
Consols: The leading British funded government security.
Corylus: a genus of deciduous monoecious nut-bearing shrubs or small trees: hazel; sometimes placed in the subfamily or family Corylaceae.
Chromosphere: An atmosphere of rare matter, composed principally of incandescent hydrogen gas, surrounding the sun and enveloping the photosphere. Portions of the chromosphere are here and there thrown up into enormous tongues of flame.
crowded: overfilled or compacted or concentrated; filled to excess; as, a crowded program.  Opposite of uncrowded.
clupeid: any of numerous soft-finned schooling food fishes of the family Clupeidae, inhabiting the shallow waters of northern seas.  The group includes the herrings, menhaden, sardines, and shad.
Conversative: Relating to intercourse with men; social; -- opposed to contemplative.
Chimonanthus: a small genus of Asian deciduous or evergreen shrubs having fragrant flowers: winter sweet.
Cerebropathy: A hypochondriacal condition verging upon insanity, occurring in those whose brains have been unduly taxed; -- called also brain fag.
collard: a variety of kale (Brassica oleracea) having smooth leaves; a type of colewort.  It is grown in the southern U. S.
Cantillate: To chant; to recite with musical tones.
Corse: A living body or its bulk.
Camorra: A secret organization formed at Naples, Italy, early in the 19th century, and used partly for political ends and partly for practicing extortion, violence, etc.
Captivate: Taken prisoner; made captive; insnared; charmed.
Chicanery: Mean or unfair artifice to perplex a cause and obscure the truth; stratagem; sharp practice; sophistry.
Cinchonaceous: Allied or pertaining to cinchona, or to the plants that produce it.
Corona: A crown or garland bestowed among the Romans as a reward for distinguished services.
Conn: See Con, to direct a ship.
Crebrisulcate: Marked with closely set transverse furrows.
Cowslip: A common flower in England (Primula veris) having yellow blossoms and appearing in early spring. It is often cultivated in the United States.
Chrysalis: The pupa state of certain insects, esp. of butterflies, from which the perfect insect emerges. See Pupa, and Aurelia (a).
Contrarily: In a contrary manner; in opposition; on the other side; in opposite ways.
Canon bit: That part of a bit which is put in a horse's mouth.
Carpetway: A border of greensward left round the margin of a plowed field.
Conglaciation: The act or process of changing into ice, or the state of being converted to ice; a freezing; congelation; also, a frost.
Counterflory: Adorned with flowers (usually fleurs-de-lis) so divided that the tops appear on one side and the bottoms on the others; -- said of any ordinary.
Chasseur: One of a body of light troops, cavalry or infantry, trained for rapid movements.
Ceratophyllum: the sole genus constituting the family Ceratophyllaceae; the hornworts.
Cercosporella: form genus of imperfect fungi lacking pigment in the spores and conidiophores.
Capellet: A swelling, like a wen, on the point of the elbow (or the heel of the hock) of a horse, caused probably by bruises in lying down.
Coal-black: As black as coal; jet black; very black.
Condylar: Of or pertaining to a condyle.
chesty: marked by a large or well-developed chest.
Champagne: A light wine, of several kinds, originally made in the province of Champagne, in France.
Cube: To raise to the third power; to obtain the cube of.
Counterfort: A kind of buttress of masonry to strengthen a revetment wall.
Cuba: a country on the island of Cuba.
Crown-saw: A saw in the form of a hollow cylinder, with teeth on the end or edge, and operated by a rotative motion.
Cassolette: a box, or vase, with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.
counterfactual: contrary to fact; -- of assertions, ideas, assumptions.
Chigoe: A species of flea (Tunga penetrans, formerly Pulex penetrans), common in the West Indies and South America, which often attacks the feet or any exposed part of the human body, and burrowing beneath the skin produces great irritation. When the female is allowed to remain and breed, troublesome sores result, which are sometimes dangerous. See Jigger.
Confiscable: Capable of being confiscated; liable to forfeiture.
Camous: Flat; depressed; crooked; -- said only of the nose.
cherrystone: small quahog larger than a littleneck.
Camara: Chamber; house; -- used in Ca"ma*ra dos Pa"res (&unr_;), and Ca"ma*ra dos De`pu*ta"dos (&unr_;). See Legislature.
Coleslaw: A salad made of sliced cabbage.
cardiopulmonary resuscitation: An emergency procedure to revive heart and lung function in persons whose heart has apparently stopped beating, involving forced respiration, periodic pressure on the heart by pushing on the chest, and sometimes electrical or mechanical equipment.  It is often referred to by the acronym CPR.
Coexistence: Existence at the same time with another; -- contemporary existence.
Commute: To obtain or bargain for exemption or substitution; to effect a commutation.
coiled: curled or wound especially in concentric rings or spirals; as, a coiled snake ready to strike; the rope lay coiled on the deck.  Opposite of uncoiled.
Crase: To break in pieces; to crack.
cannibalic: resembling a beast; showing lack of human sensibility.
Clio: The Muse who presided over history.
Copper-faced: Faced or covered with copper; as, copper-faced type.
Calippic: Of or pertaining to Calippus, an Athenian astronomer.
Cupel: To refine by means of a cupel.
Crenation: A rounded tooth on the edge of a leaf.
cilial: of or pertaining to a cilium or cilia.
Conduplication: A doubling together or folding; a duplication.
Celtium: The first proposed name for a supposed new element of the rare-earth group, accompanying lutecium and scandium in the gadolinite earths. It is now considered identical to Lutetium. The proposed symbol was Ct (no period), but this name and symbol are no longer used.
Chicken-breasted: Having a narrow, projecting chest, caused by forward curvature of the vertebral column.
Copper-fastened: Fastened with copper bolts, as the planks of ships, etc.; as, a copper-fastened ship.
Chambermaid: A maidservant who has the care of chambers, making the beds, sweeping, cleaning the rooms, etc.
Coextension: The act of extending equally, or the state of being equally extended.
Cetrarin: A white substance extracted from the lichen, Iceland moss (Cetraria Islandica). It consists of several ingredients, among which is cetraric acid, a white, crystalline, bitter substance.
Carlock: A sort of Russian isinglass, made from the air bladder of the sturgeon, and used in clarifying wine.
Chined: Pertaining to, or having, a chine, or backbone; -- used in composition.
Cetraric: Pertaining to, or derived from, the lichen, Iceland moss (Cetaria Islandica).
Calcedon: A foul vein, like chalcedony, in some precious stones.
Chronometric: Pertaining to a chronometer; measured by a chronometer.
Conjunctiveness: The state or quality of being conjunctive.
Cilician: Of or pertaining to Cilicia in Asia Minor.
Champertor: One guilty of champerty; one who purchases a suit, or the right of suing, and carries it on at his own expense, in order to obtain a share of the gain.
Contain: To restrain desire; to live in continence or chastity.
Clownage: Behavior or manners of a clown; clownery.
Constellate: To unite in one luster or radiance, as stars.
Cannikin: A small can or drinking vessel.
Choreography: The art of representing dancing by signs, as music is represented by notes; -- also called choregraphy.
Censurable: Deserving of censure; blamable; culpable; reprehensible; as, a censurable person, or censurable conduct.
Conquest: The act or process of conquering, or acquiring by force; the act of overcoming or subduing opposition by force, whether physical or moral; subjection; subjugation; victory.
Cowish: An umbelliferous plant (Peucedanum Cous) with edible tuberous roots, found in Oregon.
Cestidae: A family of invertebrates coextensive with the order Cestida; ctenophores having a greatly flattened and elongated body.
Cephalo: A combining form denoting the head, of the head, connected with the head; as, cephalosome, cephalopod.
Courant: A piece of music in triple time; also, a lively dance; a coranto.
chapleted: provided with a chaplet; wearing a chaplet.
Church modes: The modes or scales used in ancient church music. See Gregorian.
Cardiolgy: The science which treats of the heart and its functions.
Curvative: Having the margins only a little curved; -- said of leaves.
Compatriot: Of the same country; having a common sentiment of patriotism.
Conclusively: In the way of conclusion; decisively; positively.
Cozenage: The art or practice of cozening; artifice; fraud.
Coccobacterium: One of the round variety of bacteria, a vegetable organism, generally less than a thousandth of a millimeter in diameter.
Coxa: The first joint of the leg of an insect or crustacean.
Cottonseed meal: A meal made from hulled cotton seeds after the oil has been expressed.
Costa: A rib of an animal or a human being.
Carline thistle: A prickly plant of the genus Carlina (Carlina vulgaris), found in Europe and Asia.
Chordata: A comprehensive division of animals including all Vertebrata together with the Tunicata, or all those having a dorsal nervous cord.
cambric: A fine, thin, and white fabric made of flax or linen.
Cosher: To levy certain exactions or tribute upon; to lodge and eat at the expense of. See Coshering.
Capsulate: Inclosed in a capsule, or as in a chest or box;
coydog: the offspring of a coyote and a dog.
Chateaubriand: a double-thick center cut of beef tenderloin, broiled and served with a sauce and potatoes.
Concenter: To draw or direct to a common center; to bring together at a focus or point, as two or more lines; to concentrate.
Caravel: A name given to several kinds of vessels.
Chickweed: The name of several caryophyllaceous weeds, especially Stellaria media, the seeds and flower buds of which are a favorite food of small birds.
common room: a room, usually at a school or university, set aside for the common use of everyone.  It usually has comfortable chairs for reading or conversation, and some provision for obtaining refreshments.
Cabaret: A tavern; a house where liquors are retailed.
Cerotene: A white waxy solid obtained from Chinese wax, and by the distillation of cerotin.
Capapie: From head to foot; at all points.
Chaomancy: Divination by means of appearances in the air.
Crookes space: The dark space within the negative-pole glow at the cathode of a vacuum tube, observed only when the pressure is low enough to give a striated discharge; -- called also Crookes layer.
Conflict: To strike or dash together; to meet in violent collision; to collide.
Columbia: America; the United States; -- a poetical appellation given in honor of Columbus, the discoverer.
Columbin: A white, crystalline, bitter substance. See Calumbin.
Commissariat: The organized system by which armies and military posts are supplied with food and daily necessaries.
Chasten: To correct by punishment; to inflict pain upon the purpose of reclaiming; to discipline; as, to chasten a son with a rod.
Cancerate: To grow into a cancer; to become cancerous.
Commenter: One who makes or writes comments; a commentator; an annotator.
Conjurement: Serious injunction; solemn demand or entreaty.
Cassumunar: A pungent, bitter, aromatic, gingerlike root, obtained from the East Indies.
Ceterach: A species of fern with fronds (Asplenium Ceterach).
Cestraciont: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the genus Cestracion.
Circumspect: Attentive to all the circumstances of a case or the probable consequences of an action; cautious; prudent; wary.
Cit: A citizen; an inhabitant of a city; a pert townsman; -- used contemptuously.
Coronary: A small bone in the foot of a horse.
Conspectuity: The faculty of seeing; sight; eye.
ceibo: a small South American spiny tree (Erythrina crista-galli) with dark crimson and scarlet flowers solitary or clustered.
Chinchona: any of several trees of the genus Cinchona. Same as Cinchona.
Canoe: A boat used by rude nations, formed of trunk of a tree, excavated, by cutting of burning, into a suitable shape. It is propelled by a paddle or paddles, or sometimes by sail, and has no rudder.
Clavigerous: Bearing a club or a key.
Culdee: One of a class of anchorites who lived in various parts of Scotland, Ireland, and Wales.
Columbella: A genus of univalve shells, abundant in tropical seas. Some species, as Columbella mercatoria, were formerly used as shell money.
Convexo-concave: Convex on one side, and concave on the other. The curves of the convex and concave sides may be alike or may be different. See Meniscus.
Cherimoyer: A small downy-leaved tree (Anona Cherimolia), with fragrant flowers. It is a native of Peru.
Calced: Wearing shoes; calceated; -- in distintion from discalced or barefooted; as the calced Carmelites.
Claymore: A large two-handed sword used formerly by the Scottish Highlanders.
Concatenation: A series of links united; a series or order of things depending on each other, as if linked together; a chain, a succession.
Carolinian: A native or inhabitant of north or South Carolina.
Conjurer: One who practices magic arts; one who pretends to act by the aid super natural power; also, one who performs feats of legerdemain or sleight of hand.
Coccygeal: Of or pertaining to the coccyx; as, the coccygeal vertebræ.
Comprint: The surreptitious printing of another's copy or book; a work thus printed.
Cundurango: The bark of a South American vine (Gonolobus Condurango) of the Milkweed family. It has been supposed, but erroneously, to be a cure for cancer.
Champion: One who engages in any contest; especially one who in ancient times contended in single combat in behalf of another's honor or rights; or one who now acts or speaks in behalf of a person or a cause; a defender; an advocate; a hero.
Commendation: The act of commending; praise; favorable representation in words; recommendation.
Continental system: The system of commercial blockade aiming to exclude England from commerce with the Continent instituted by the Berlin decree, which Napoleon I. issued from Berlin Nov. 21, 1806, declaring the British Isles to be in a state of blockade, and British subjects, property, and merchandise subject to capture, and excluding British ships from all parts of Europe under French dominion. The retaliatory measures of England were followed by the Milan decree, issued by Napoleon from Milan Dec. 17, 1807, imposing further restrictions, and declaring every ship going to or from a port of England or her colonies to be lawful prize.
Coursing: The pursuit or running game with dogs that follow by sight instead of by scent.
Cousinship: The relationship of cousins; state of being cousins; cousinhood.
Classicalism: A classical idiom, style, or expression; a classicism.
cytosine: A pyrimidine (C4H5N3O) which is one of the four major basic components of DNA and RNA in most organisms, forming glyosides with ribose and deoxyribose.  It is the basic component of cytidine, deoxycytidine, cytosine, cytidine monophosphate, and derivatives of those compounds.
Chute: A framework, trough, or tube, upon or through which objects are made to slide from a higher to a lower level, or through which water passes to a wheel.
Cimeliarch: A superintendent or keeper of a church's valuables; a churchwarden.
Cecidomyidae: A natural family comprising the gall midges.
Cascalho: A deposit of pebbles, gravel, and ferruginous sand, in which the Brazilian diamond is usually found.
Controversy: Contention; dispute; debate; discussion; agitation of contrary opinions.
check in: To register as a guest at a hotel, inn, motel. etc.   Converse of check out.
Caoutchouc: A tenacious, elastic, gummy substance obtained from the milky sap of several plants of tropical South America (esp. the euphorbiaceous tree Siphonia elastica or Hevea caoutchouc), Asia, and Africa. Being impermeable to liquids and gases, and not readly affected by exposure to air, acids, and alkalies, it is used, especially when vulcanized, for many purposes in the arts and in manufactures. Also called India rubber (because it was first brought from India, and was formerly used chiefly for erasing pencil marks) and gum elastic. See Vulcanization.
Calymene: A genus of trilobites characteristic of the Silurian age.
Cavernulous: Full of little cavities; as, cavernulous metal.
Climber: To climb; to mount with effort; to clamber.
