Clotter: To concrete into lumps; to clot.
Couped: Cut off smoothly, as distinguished from erased; -- used especially for the head or limb of an animal. See Erased.
Cypris: A genus of small, bivalve, fresh-water Crustacea, belonging to the Ostracoda; also, a member of this genus.
Clotted: Composed of clots or clods; having the quality or form of a clot; sticky; slimy; foul.
Crimea: a Ukrainian peninsula between the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov.
Capellmeister: The musical director in a royal or ducal chapel; a choir-master.
Cloddish: Resembling clods; gross; low; stupid; boorish.
Cast-iron: Made of cast iron. Hence, Fig.: like cast iron; hardy; unyielding.
Circumpolar: About the pole; -- applied to stars that revolve around the pole without setting; as, circumpolar stars.
Communion: The act of sharing; community; participation.
Contraband: To import illegally, as prohibited goods; to smuggle.
Curfew: The ringing of an evening bell, originally a signal to the inhabitants to cover fires, extinguish lights, and retire to rest, -- instituted by William the Conqueror; also, the bell itself.
Countinghouse: The house or room in which a merchant, trader, or manufacturer keeps his books and transacts business; the offices used by the accountants of a business.
Cupboard: To collect, as into a cupboard; to hoard.
Caranx: A genus of fishes, common on the Atlantic coast, including the yellow or golden mackerel.
Comprehensor: One who comprehends; one who has attained to a full knowledge.
Caste: One of the hereditary classes into which the Hindu are divided according to the laws of Brahmanism.
Cursorial: Adapted to running or walking, and not to prehension; as, the limbs of the horse are cursorial. See Illust. of Aves.
cased: covered or protected with or as if with a case; as, knights cased in steel.
Calling: The act of one who calls; a crying aloud, esp. in order to summon, or to attact the attention of, some one.
Compression projectile: A projectile constructed so as to take the grooves of a rifle by means of a soft copper band firmly attached near its base or, formerly, by means of an envelope of soft metal. In small arms the modern projectile, having a soft core and harder jacket, is subjected to compression throughout the entire cylindrical part.
Cornu Ammonis: A fossil shell, curved like a ram's horn; an obsolete name for an ammonite.
Collocate: To set or place; to set; to station.
Calibrate: To ascertain the caliber of, as of a thermometer tube; also, more generally, to determine or rectify the graduation of, as of the various standards or graduated instruments.
citizens band: that portion of the radio frequency spectrum allocated by the FCC for the use of individual citizens for short-distance personal or business use, from either fixed or mobile stations.  Abreviated CB.  Called also Citizens Radio Service.
Commandeer: To compel to perform military service; to seize for military purposes; -- orig. used of the Boers.
Chol\u00e6maa: A disease characterized by severe nervous symptoms, dependent upon the presence of the constituents of the bile in the blood.
Commeasure: To be commensurate with; to equal.
Cotemporary: One who lives at the same time with another; a contemporary.
Conciliate: To win ower; to gain from a state of hostility; to gain the good will or favor of; to make friendly; to mollify; to propitiate; to appease.
Corruptful: Tending to corrupt; full of corruption.
Cheetah: A species of leopard (Cynælurus jubatus) tamed and used for hunting in India. The woolly cheetah of South Africa is Cynælurus laneus.  It runs very fast in short spurts while hunting.
Characterism: A distinction of character; a characteristic.
Cloddy: Consisting of clods; full of clods.
Concerning: That in which one is concerned or interested; concern; affair; interest.
Catalpa: A genus of American and East Indian trees, of which the best known species are the Catalpa bignonioides, a large, ornamental North American tree, with spotted white flowers and long cylindrical pods, and the Catalpa speciosa, of the Mississipi valley; -- called also Indian bean.
Cardinalate: The office, rank, or dignity of a cardinal.
Chick-pea: A Small leguminous plant (Cicer arietinum) of Asia, Africa, and the south of Europe; the chich; the dwarf pea; the gram.
Coat: To cover with a coat or outer garment.
Cyanotic: Relating to cyanosis; affected with cyanosis; as, a cyanotic patient; having the hue caused by cyanosis; as, a cyanotic skin.
chorioallantois: a very vascular fetal membrane composed of the fused chorion and adjacent wall of the allantois.
Corchorus: The common name of the Kerria Japonica or Japan globeflower, a yellow-flowered, perennial, rosaceous plant, seen in old-fashioned gardens.
Concha: The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entire apse.
Crampet: A cramp iron or cramp ring; a chape, as of a scabbard.
clone: to make a clone from; to make identical copies of an organism by a non-sexual process of reproduction.
Cordonnet: Doubled and twisted thread, made of coarse silk, and used for tassels, fringes, etc.
Ceres: The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn and tillage.
Cicadidae: a family of insects comprising the cicadas.
Crabsidle: To move sidewise, as a crab. [Jocular].
cosmology: The branch of science or philosophy dealing with the origin and nature of the universe as a whole.
Counterjumper: A salesman in a shop; a shopman; -- used contemptuously.
Ceraunics: That branch of physics which treats of heat and electricity.
Coherer: Any device in which an imperfectly conducting contact between pieces of metal or other conductors loosely resting against each other is materially improved in conductivity by the influence of Hertzian waves; -- so called by Sir O. J. Lodge in 1894 on the assumption that the impact of the electic waves caused the loosely connected parts to cohere, or weld together, a condition easily destroyed by tapping. A common form of coherer as used in wireless telegraphy consists of a tube containing filings (usually a pinch of nickel and silver filings in equal parts) between terminal wires or plugs (called conductor plugs).
Coak: To unite, as timbers, by means of tenons or dowels in the edges or faces.
Contuse: To beat, pound, or bray together.
Coopering: Work done by a cooper in making or repairing barrels, casks, etc.; the business of a cooper.
Cotinga: A bird of the family Cotingidæ, including numerous bright-colored South American species; -- called also chatterers.
coordinating: joining together words or phrases of equal grammatical rank.
computerize: to provide with computers; as, Our office is fully computerized now.
centrolecithal: Having the food yolk placed at the center of the ovum, segmentation being either regular or unequal.
Cursedly: In a cursed manner; miserably; in a manner to be detested; enormously.
Coequal: Being on an equality in rank or power.
Conically: In the form of a cone.
Country seat: A dwelling in the country, used as a place of retirement from the city.
cock-a-hoop: Boastful; defiant; exulting. Also used adverbially.
Cymbal: A musical instrument used by the ancients. It is supposed to have been similar to the modern kettle drum, though perhaps smaller.
Crissum: That part of a bird, or the feathers, surrounding the cloacal opening; the under tail coverts.
Confute: To overwhelm by argument; to refute conclusively; to prove or show to be false or defective; to overcome; to silence.
coordinated: dexterous in the use of more than one set of muscle movements.
Commiserate: To feel sorrow, pain, or regret for; to pity.
Cable: To telegraph by a submarine cable
corydalis: a plant of the genus Corydalis, with beautiful compound foliage and spurred tubular flowers.
Coextend: To extend through the same space or time with another; to extend to the same degree.
cowering: characterized by or showing abject fear.
Cossic: Of or relating to algebra; as, cossic numbers, or the cossic art.
Cineraria: A Linnæan genus of free-flowering composite plants, mostly from South Africa. Several species are cultivated for ornament.
Clamp: To tread heavily or clumsily; to clump.
clannishness: a tendency to associate with only a select group.
Chayote: a tropical West Indian vine (Sechium edule) of the gourd family, which bears small white flowers and produces an edible fruit.
Catastrophist: One who holds the theory or catastrophism.
Consonantness: The quality or condition of being consonant, agreeable, or consistent.
Chaliced: Having a calyx or cup; cup-shaped.
Counterview: An opposite or opposing view; opposition; a posture in which two persons front each other.
Cue: A small portion of bread or beer; the quantity bought with a farthing or half farthing.
Creaser: A tool, or a sewing-machine attachment, for making lines or creases on leather or cloth, as guides to sew by.
Compatibility: The quality or power of being compatible or congruous; congruity; as, a compatibility of tempers; a compatibility of properties.
Claqueur: One of the claque employed to applaud at a theater.
check-in: The act of registering as a guest at a hotel, inn, motel. etc; the act of checking in.  Used also attributively, as the check-in counter at a hotel.
Clarigate: To declare war with certain ceremonies.
Cottony: Covered with hairs or pubescence, like cotton; downy; nappy; woolly.
Concert of Europe: An agreement or understanding between the chief European powers to take only joint action in the (European) Eastern Question.
Complexedness: The quality or state of being complex or involved; complication.
Catastrophism: The doctrine that the geological changes in the earth's crust have been caused by the sudden action of violent physical causes; -- opposed to the doctrine of uniformism.
Chromolithographer: One who is engaged in chromolithography.
Corroboration: The act of corroborating, strengthening, or confirming; addition of strength; confirmation; as, the corroboration of an argument, or of information.
Clock: A large beetle, esp. the European dung beetle (Scarabæus stercorarius).
cross-examination: The interrogating or questioning of a witness by the party against whom he has been called and examined. See Examination.
Clitocybe: a genus of white-spored agarics with flat or funnel-shaped cap and elastic stem.
Chabasite: A mineral occuring in glassy rhombohedral crystals, varying in color from white to yellow or red. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime. Called also chabasie.
Concorporation: Union of things in one mass or body.
Curiologic: Pertaining to a rude kind of hieroglyphics, in which a thing is represented by its picture instead of by a symbol.
Chinchilla: A small rodent (Chinchilla lanigera), of the size of a large squirrel, remarkable for its fine fur, which is very soft and of a pearly gray color. It is a native of Peru and Chili.
Cutose: A variety of cellulose, occuring as a fine transparent membrane covering the aerial organs of plants, and forming an essential ingredient of cork; by oxidation it passes to suberic acid.
Chevronwise: In the manner of a chevron; as, the field may be divided chevronwise.
Contradance: A dance in which the partners are arranged face to face, or in opposite lines.
Columb\u00e6: An order of birds, including the pigeons.
Chafewax: Formerly a chancery officer who fitted wax for sealing writs and other documents.
Compo: Short for Composition; -- used, esp. in England, colloq. in various trade applications;
Calcarine: Pertaining to, or situated near, the calcar of the brain.
Collaterally: Side by side; by the side.
Chaetodontidae: a natural family comprising the butterfly fishes.
Carack: A kind of large ship formerly used by the Spaniards and Portuguese in the East India trade; a galleon.
Carolitic: Adorned with sculptured leaves and branches.
Cervidae: a natural family of deer including the reindeer, moose, elks, muntjacs, and roe deer.
Consignatory: One of several that jointly sign a written instrument, as a treaty.
Chief justice: The presiding justice, or principal judge, of a court.
Connive: To shut the eyes to; to overlook; to pretend not to see.
Counselable: Willing to receive counsel or follow advice.
Contingency: Union or connection; the state of touching or contact.
Chloroplastid: A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.
Cockatoo: A bird of the Parrot family, of the subfamily Cacatuinæ, having a short, strong, and much curved beak, and the head ornamented with a crest, which can be raised or depressed at will. There are several genera and many species; as the broad-crested cockatoo (Plictolophus cristatus or  Cacatua cristatus), the sulphur-crested (Cacatua galerita or Plictolophus galeritus), etc. The palm cockatoo or great black cockatoo of Australia is Probosciger aterrimus (formerly Microglossus aterrimus).
connote: To mark along with; to suggest or indicate as additional; to designate by implication; to include in the meaning; to imply.
Chievance: An unlawful bargain; traffic in which money is exported as discount.
Comedian: An actor or player in comedy.
Camphoric: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, camphor.
close-set: arranged close together; as, close-set eyes; close-set teeth.
Crustaceousness: The state or quality of being crustaceous or having a crustlike shell.
Clepe: To make appeal; to cry out.
Calcographic: Relating to, or in the style of, calcography.
Conglaciate: To turn to ice; to freeze.
Class day: In American colleges and universities, a day of the commencement season on which the senior class celebrates the completion of its course by exercises conducted by the members, such as the reading of the class histories and poem, the delivery of the class oration, the planting of the class ivy, etc.
Calfskin: The hide or skin of a calf; or leather made of the skin.
Choriambus: A foot consisting of four syllables, of which the first and last are long, and the other short (- ˘ ˘ -); that is, a choreus, or trochee, and an iambus united.
cheekless: having no cheek.  Opposite of cheeked.
Circumfluent: Flowing round; surrounding in the manner of a fluid.
Circumcursation: The act of running about; also, rambling language.
Culm: Mineral coal that is not bituminous; anthracite, especially when found in small masses.
Calvaria: The bones of the cranium; more especially, the bones of the domelike upper portion.
Colicroot: A bitter American herb of the Bloodwort family, with the leaves all radical, and the small yellow or white flowers in a long spike (Aletris farinosa and Aletris aurea).  Called sometimes star grass, blackroot, blazing star, and unicorn root.
Chamaemelum: a small genus of plants sometimes included in genus Anthemis; chamomile.
Corno Inglese: A reed instrument, related to the oboe, but deeper in pitch; the English horn.
caf\u00e9 latte: A type of espresso coffee topped with foamy steamed milk, and usually served in a tall glass or mug; also called latte.
Commercial: Of or pertaining to commerce; carrying on or occupied with commerce or trade; mercantile; as, commercial advantages; commercial relations.
Changan: the capital of the ancient Chinese empire.
Consulage: A duty or tax paid by merchants for the protection of their commerce by means of a consul in a foreign place.
Co-meddle: To mix; to mingle, to temper.
Cataclysm: An extensive overflow or sweeping flood of water; a deluge.
Cervical: Of or pertaining to the neck; as, the cervical vertebræ.
chamaephyte: a perennial plant that sets its dormant vegetative buds just at or above the surface of the ground.
cradlesong: a quiet song that lulls a child to sleep.
cardiosclerosis: Induration of the heart, caused by development of fibrous tissue in the cardiac muscle.
Circulation: The act of moving in a circle, or in a course which brings the moving body to the place where its motion began.
Capful: As much as will fill a cap.
Croupy: Of or pertaining to croup; resembling or indicating croup; as, a croupy cough.
Counter-salient: Leaping from each other; -- said of two figures on a coat of arms.
Cosmolabe: An instrument resembling the astrolabe, formerly used for measuring the angles between heavenly bodies; -- called also pantacosm.
Cubital: A sleeve covering the arm from the elbow to the hand.
Client: A citizen who put himself under the protection of a man of distinction and influence, who was called his patron.
Cinnamon: The inner bark of the shoots of Cinnamomum Zeylanicum, a tree growing in Ceylon. It is aromatic, of a moderately pungent taste, and is one of the best cordial, carminative, and restorative spices.
Colubrine: like or related to snakes of the genus Coluber.
chintzy: resembling chintz or decorated with chintz.
Colubrina: a genus of mostly tropical American shrubs or small trees with small yellowish flowers and yellow or red fruits.
C\u00e6cilian: A limbless amphibian belonging to the order Cæciliæ or Ophimorpha. See Ophiomorpha.
Carney: A disease of horses, in which the mouth is so furred that the afflicted animal can not eat.
Correspondently: In a a corresponding manner; conformably; suitably.
Colorado: Reddish; -- often used in proper names of rivers or creeks.
Cylindrometric: Belonging to a scale used in measuring cylinders.
Conceptualism: A theory, intermediate between realism and nominalism, that the mind has the power of forming for itself general conceptions of individual or single objects.
Concrescive: Growing together, or into union; uniting.
Conceptualist: One who maintains the theory of conceptualism.
Cockswain: The steersman of a boat; a petty officer who has charge of a boat and its crew.
change-ringing: ringing tuned bells in a fixed order that is continually changing.  See change{9}, n.
Caucasus: a large region between the Black and Caspian seas.
Cypripedium: A genus of orchidaceous plants including the lady's slipper.
cowherb: a European annual with pale rose-colored flowers; cultivated flower or self-sown grainfield weed; introduced in North America; sometimes classified as a soapwort; -- also called the cow-cockle.
Cheloniidae: a natural family including the green turtles; hawksbills.
Clink: A prison cell; a lockup; -- probably orig. the name of the noted prison in Southwark, England.
Cartridge: A complete charge for a firearm, contained in, or held together by, a case, capsule, or shell of metal, pasteboard, or other material.
cross section: to create one or a series of cross sections{3} by cutting (an object) into thin slices.
conga line: a line of persons dancing the conga{2}.
Cynosure: The constellation of the Lesser Bear (Ursa Minor), to which, as containing the polar star, the eyes of mariners and travelers were often directed.
Clumber: A kind of field spaniel, with short legs and stout body, which, unlike other spaniels, hunts silently.
Columbic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the columbo root.
Cottagely: Cottagelike; suitable for a cottage; rustic.
Clatch: To daub or smear, as with lime; to make or finish in a slipshod way.
Certainty: The quality, state, or condition, of being certain.
Copatain: Having a high crown, or a point or peak at top.
coccidium: any sporozoan of the order Coccidia, parasitic on the digestive epithelium of vertebrates and higher invertebrates.  It is the causative agent of coccidiosis, which can be a problem in poultry rearing.
Cubeb: The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper (Piper Cubeba; in (Med.), Cubeba officinalis), native in Java and Borneo, but now cultivated in various tropical countries.  The dried unripe fruit is much used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.
Cleavage: The act of cleaving or splitting.
Confabulate: To talk familiarly together; to chat; to prattle.
Colliquation: A melting together; the act of melting; fusion.
critical temperature: A certain temperature, different for different gases, but always the same for each gas, regarded as the temperature above which no amount of pressure can produce condensation to a liquid; the temperature above which a gas cannot be liquified.
Camleted: Wavy or undulating like camlet; veined.
Coaster: A vessel employed in sailing along a coast, or engaged in the coasting trade.
Carpale: One of the bones or cartilages of the carpus; esp. one of the series articulating with the metacarpals.
Clericalism: An excessive devotion to the interests of the sacerdotal order; undue influence of the clergy; sacerdotalism.
Chiaroscurist: A painter who cares for and studies light and shade rather than color.
Chaus: a lynxlike animal of Asia and Africa (Lynx Lybicus).
Cresselle: A wooden rattle sometimes used as a substitute for a bell, in the Roman Catholic church, during the latter part of Holy Week, or the last week of Lent.
Carmagnole: A popular or Red Rebublican song and dance, of the time of the first French Revolution.
Callid: Characterized by cunning or shrewdness; crafty.
Conquerable: Capable of being conquered or subdued.
\u00c7ariama: A large, long-legged cranelike South American wading bird (Cariama cristata, formerly Dicholophus cristatus) which preys upon snakes, etc.; it is also called the seriema, but that latter name is also applied to another South American bird.  See Seriema.
Counterwheel: To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.
Cadger: One who carries hawks on a cadge.
Causeway: A way or road raised above the natural level of the ground, serving as a dry passage over wet or marshy ground.
Citizen: Having the condition or qualities of a citizen, or of citizens; as, a citizen soldiery.
Cetaceous: Of or pertaining to the Cetacea.
Canarese: Pertaining to Canara, a district of British India.
Cornish: The dialect, or the people, of Cornwall.
Chloridate: To treat or prepare with a chloride, as a plate with chloride of silver, for the purposes of photography.
Chromotype: A sheet printed in colors by any process, as a chromolithograph. See Chromolithograph.
Cincinnati epoch: An epoch at the close of the American lower Silurian system. The rocks are well developed near Cincinnati, Ohio. The group includes the Hudson River and Lorraine shales of New York.
Coupe-gorge: Any position giving the enemy such advantage that the troops occupying it must either surrender or be cut to pieces.
Concurrent: One who, or that which, concurs; a joint or contributory cause.
Cystose: Containing, or resembling, a cyst or cysts; cystic; bladdery.
Catoptromancy: A species of divination, which was performed by letting down a mirror into water, for a sick person to look at his face in it. If his countenance appeared distorted and ghastly, it was an ill omen; if fresh and healthy, it was favorable.
Chalcedony: A cryptocrystalline, translucent variety of quartz, having usually a whitish color, and a luster nearly like wax.
Cornist: A performer on the cornet or horn.
Corncutter: A machine for cutting up stalks of corn for food of cattle.
Compendium: A brief compilation or composition, containing the principal heads, or general principles, of a larger work or system; an abridgment; an epitome; a compend; a condensed summary.
Clupeoid: Of or pertaining to the Herring family.
Coyly: In a coy manner; with reserve.
Cully: To trick, cheat, or impose on; to deceive.
Cuckold: To make a cuckold of, as a husband, by seducing his wife, or by her becoming an adulteress.
Calorescence: The conversion of obscure radiant heat into light; the transmutation of rays of heat into others of higher refrangibility.
contraclockwise: in the direction opposite to the rotation of the hands of a clock; counterclockwise.  Opposite of clockwise.
choc-ice: colloquial British abbreviation for chocolate ice cream.
Celeriac: Turnip-rooted celery, a from of celery with a large globular root, which is used for food.
Cistercian: A monk of the prolific branch of the Benedictine Order, established in 1098 at Cîteaux, in France, by Robert, abbot of Molesme. For two hundred years the Cistercians followed the rule of St. Benedict in all its rigor.
Curtail dog: A dog with a docked tail; formerly, the dog of a person not qualified to course, which, by the forest laws, must have its tail cut short, partly as a mark, and partly from a notion that the tail is necessary to a dog in running; hence, a dog not fit for sporting.
Collector: One who collects things which are separate; esp., one who makes a business or practice of collecting works of art, objects in natural history, etc.; as, a collector of coins.
Cytogenic: Of or pertaining to cytogenesis or cell development.
Carapace: The thick shell or shield which covers the back of the tortoise, or turtle, the crab, and other crustaceous animals.
Corporal: A fine linen cloth, on which the sacred elements are consecrated in the eucharist, or with which they are covered; a communion cloth.
Clothes: Covering for the human body; dress; vestments; vesture; -- a general term for whatever covering is worn, or is made to be worn, for decency or comfort.
Commentitious: Fictitious or imaginary; unreal; as, a commentitious system of religion.
Colonel: The chief officer of a regiment; an officer ranking next above a lieutenant colonel and next below a brigadier general.
Chatwood: Little sticks; twigs for burning; fuel.
Cronartium: A genus of rust fungi having aecia produced in raised or swollen sori and teliospores borne in waxy columns.
Calamanco: A glossy woolen stuff, plain, striped, or checked.
Calmucks: A branch of the Mongolian race inhabiting parts of the Russian and Chinese empires; also (sing.), the language of the Calmucks.
Conception: The act of conceiving in the womb; the initiation of an embryonic animal life.
Counter-couchant: Lying down, with their heads in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in a coat of arms.
Culls: Refuse timber, from which the best part has been culled out.
Catechuic: Of or pertaining to catechu or its derivatives. See catechin.
Commensurate: Having a common measure; commensurable; reducible to a common measure; as, commensurate quantities.
Contextural: Pertaining to contexture or arrangement of parts; producing contexture; interwoven.
circulating: moving or flowing in a circuit and returning to the same point; as, steam circulating through the pipes; the circulating thyroid hormones.
chordamesoderm: the area of the mesoderm that forms the notochord.
clayware: Objects made from clay and baked in a kiln.
Close-bodied: Fitting the body exactly; setting close, as a garment.
Commensurateness: The state or quality of being commensurate.
Colocynth: The light spongy pulp of the fruit of the bitter cucumber (Citrullus colocynthis, or Cucumis colocynthis), an Asiatic plant allied to the watermelon; coloquintida. It comes in white balls, is intensely bitter, and a powerful cathartic. Called also bitter apple, bitter cucumber, bitter gourd.
cortisol: a steroid hormone (C21H30O5) active in carbohydrate and protein metabolism; -- called also hydrocortisone.  It is used in medicine as an antiinflammatory agent
Cranioclasm: The crushing of a child's head, as with the cranioclast or craniotomy forceps in cases of very difficult delivery.
Candiot: Of or pertaining to Candia; Cretary.
Carnots cycle: An ideal heat-engine cycle in which the working fluid goes through the following four successive operations: (1) Isothermal expansion to a desired point; (2) adiabatic expansion to a desired point; (3) isothermal compression to such a point that (4) adiabatic compression brings it back to its initial state.
Catchword: Among theatrical performers, the last word of the preceding speaker, which reminds one that he is to speak next; cue.
Culicidae: a family of insects comprising the mosquitoes.
Constituency: A body of constituents, as the body of citizens or voters in a representative district.
Cobaltic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cobalt; -- said especially of those compounds in which cobalt has higher valence; as, cobaltic oxide.
Catchwork: A work or artificial water-course for throwing water on lands that lie on the slopes of hills; a catchdrain.
Cestus: A covering for the hands of boxers, made of leather bands, and often loaded with lead or iron.
Curtilage: A yard, courtyard, or piece of ground, included within the fence surrounding a dwelling house.
Chronic: Relating to time; according to time.
columnist: a journalist who writes or edits a regularly scheduled column{8} in a periodical, usually in editorial style; a type of editorialist.
C\u0153lospermous: Hollow-seeded; having the ventral face of the seedlike carpels incurved at the ends, as in coriander seed.
Contrecoup: A concussion or shock produced by a blow or other injury, in a part or region opposite to that at which the blow is received, often causing rupture or disorganisation of the parts affected.
Carbostyril: A white crystalline substance, C9H6N.OH, of acid properties derived from one of the amido cinnamic acids.
Cephalosome: The anterior region or head of insects and other arthropods.
Custard: A mixture of milk and eggs, sweetened, and baked or boiled.
Coumarou: The tree (Dipteryx odorata) which bears the tonka bean; also, the bean itself.
Contraplex: Pertaining to the sending of two messages in opposite directions at the same time.
Crottles: A name given to various lichens gathered for dyeing.  See crottal.
Carpology: That branch of botany which relates to the structure of seeds and fruit.
Crotalaria: A genus of leguminous plants; rattlebox.
Chaparajos: Overalls of sheepskin or leather, usually open at the back, worn, esp. by cowboys, to protect the legs from thorny bushes, as in the chaparral; -- called also chapareras or colloq. chaps.
Corruptionist: One who corrupts, or who upholds corruption.
Centistere: The hundredth part of a stere, equal to 0.353 cubic feet.
Copyholder: One possessed of land in copyhold.
cryophorus: An instrument used to illustrate the freezing of water by its own evaporation. The ordinary form consists of two glass bulbs, connected by a tube of the same material, and containing only a quantity of water and its vapor, devoid of air. The water is in one of the bulbs, and freezes when the other is cooled below 32° Fahr.
Conglomeration: The act or process of gathering into a mass; the state of being thus collected; collection; accumulation.
Conchiform: Shaped like one half of a bivalve shell; shell-shaped.
cords: trousers made of corduroy cloth; corduroys.
C\u00f3rdoba: The monetary unit of Nicaragua, equivalent to the United States gold dollar.  It is divided into 100 centavos.
Considerate: Given to consideration or to sober reflection; regardful of consequences or circumstances; circumspect; careful; esp. careful of the rights, claims, and feelings of others.
Coheir: A joint heir; one of two or more heirs; one of several entitled to an inheritance.
Crithomancy: A kind of divination by means of the dough of the cakes offered in the ancient sacrifices, and the meal strewed over the victims.
Creaking: A harsh grating or squeaking sound, or the act of making such a sound.
Country cousin: A relative from the country visiting the city and unfamiliar with city manners and sights.
Callithump: A somewhat riotous parade, accompanied with the blowing of tin horns, and other discordant noises; also, a burlesque serenade; a charivari.
Churning: The act of one who churns.
Centrobaric: Relating to the center of gravity, or to the process of finding it.
Crusade: To engage in a crusade; to attack in a zealous or hot-headed manner.
Cento: A literary or a musical composition formed by selections from different authors disposed in a new order.
Crusado: An old Portuguese coin, worth about seventy cents.
Crystallography: The doctrine or science of crystallization, teaching the system of forms among crystals, their structure, and their methods of formation.
coenzyme A: a coenzyme (C21H36N7O16P3S) that participates in the transfer of acetyl groups in biochemical reactions; -- abbreviated CoA.  It contains adenosine, phosphate, pantothenic acid and cysteamine groups.  The acetyl group to be transferred during biosynthesis is temporarily attached to the free sulhydryl of the cysteamine group to form a thioester, in which state it is called acetyl coenzyme A.  The strength of a preparation of coenzyme A may be expressed by the Lippman unit; one milligram of CoA contains 413 Lippman units.
Cacophony: An uncouth or disagreable sound of words, owing to the concurrence of harsh letters or syllables.
coupled: joined together especially in a pair or pairs.
Congeniality: The state or quality of being congenial; natural affinity; adaptation; suitableness.
cliquism: The tendency to associate in cliques; the spirit of cliques.
cliquish: Of or pertaining to a clique; disposed to from cliques; exclusive in spirit.
Content: Rest or quietness of the mind in one's present condition; freedom from discontent; satisfaction; contentment; moderate happiness.
Chilliness: A state or sensation of being chilly; a disagreeable sensation of coldness.
Cyme: A flattish or convex flower cluster, of the centrifugal or determinate type, differing from a corymb chiefly in the order of the opening of the blossoms.
Chasselas: A white grape, esteemed for the table.
Characteristically: In a characteristic manner; in a way that characterizes.
Correspondence: Friendly intercourse; reciprocal exchange of civilities; especially, intercourse between persons by means of letters.
Chimpanzee: An african ape (Pan troglodytes, formerly Anthropithecus troglodytes, or Troglodytes niger) which approaches more nearly to man, in most respects, than any other ape. It is the most intelligent of non-human animals, and when full grown, it is from three to four feet high.  A variant called the pygmy chimpanzee, or bonobo, has been recently recognized as a separate species.
Cycloidei: An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for those with thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as the herring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.
Cambial: Belonging to exchanges in commerce; of exchange.
Consopite: To lull to sleep; to quiet; to compose.
Commodity: Convenience; accommodation; profit; benefit; advantage; interest; commodiousness.
Contradict: To oppose in words; to gainsay; to deny, or assert the contrary of, something.
canistel: a tropical tree of Florida and West Indies (Pouteria campechiana nervosa) yielding edible fruit.
Compellation: Style of address or salutation; an appellation.
Conferrer: One who confers; one who converses.
Colonize: To remove to, and settle in, a distant country; to make a colony.
caressing: the act of embracing; holding in one's arms .
Cognominal: One bearing the same name; a namesake.
Conscientiously: In a conscientious manner; as a matter of conscience; hence; faithfully; accurately; completely.
Cantabrian: Of or pertaining to Cantabria on the Bay of Biscay in Spain.
Casual: One who receives relief for a night in a parish to which he does not belong; a vagrant.
Capitalist: One who has capital; one who has money for investment, or money invested; esp. a person of large property, which is employed in business.
Clavellated: Said of potash, probably in reference to its having been obtained from billets of wood by burning.
Crateriform: Having the form of a shallow bowl; -- said of a corolla.
Cow parsley: An umbelliferous plant of the genus Chærophyllum (Chærophyllum temulum and Chærophyllum sylvestre).
Chemigraphy: Any mechanical engraving process depending upon chemical action; specif., a process of zinc etching not employing photography.
Conductive: Having the quality or power of conducting; as, the conductive tissue of a pistil.
Chaffinch: A bird of Europe (Fringilla cœlebs), having a variety of very sweet songs, and highly valued as a cage bird; -- called also copper finch.
Convocational: Of or pertaining to a convocation.
Cowan: One who works as a mason without having served a regular apprenticeship.
Concision: A cutting off; a division; a schism; a faction.
caecum: A cavity open at one end, as the blind end of a canal or duct.
conceptualisation: the act of formulating or making a concept of something.
Compositive: Having the quality of entering into composition; compounded.
Change: Any variation or alteration; a passing from one state or form to another; as, a change of countenance; a change of habits or principles.
Countless: Incapable of being counted; not ascertainable; innumerable.
Camp: To pitch or prepare a camp; to encamp; to lodge in a camp; -- often with out.
Cabotage: Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.
Correspond: To be like something else in the dimensions and arrangement of its parts; -- followed by with or to; as, concurring figures correspond with each other throughout.
confined: having movement restricted to within a certain area; -- usually a building.  Opposite of unconfined.
correcting: the act of offering an improvement to replace a mistake.
Crafty: Relating to, or characterized by, craft or skill; dexterous.
Couching: The operation of putting down or displacing the opaque lens in cataract.
Consul: One of the two chief magistrates of the republic.
cottonwick: a type of grunt (Haemulon melanurum) of warm Atlantic waters.
Creationism: The doctrine that a soul is specially created for each human being as soon as it is formed in the womb; -- opposed to traducianism.
collapsible: Capable of collapsing or being collapsed; as, a collapsible boat.
Counterpane: A duplicate part or copy of an indenture, deed, etc., corresponding with the original; -- now called counterpart.
Crypt: A vault wholly or partly under ground; especially, a vault under a church, whether used for burial purposes or for a subterranean chapel or oratory.
Capote: A long cloak or overcoat, especially one with a hood.
Concavity: A concave surface, or the space bounded by it; the state of being concave.
ceratozamia: a small cycad of the genus Ceratozamia having a short scaly woody trunk and fernlike foliage and woody cones; Mexico.
Committible: Capable of being committed; liable to be committed.
Cisted: Inclosed in a cyst. See Cysted.
Compote: A preparation of fruit in sirup in such a manner as to preserve its form, either whole, halved, or quartered; as, a compote of pears.
Court-baron: An inferior court of civil jurisdiction, attached to a manor, and held by the steward; a baron's court; -- now fallen into disuse.
Catel: Property; -- often used by Chaucer in contrast with rent, or income.
Contrarotation: Circular motion in a direction contrary to some other circular motion.
Calcimine: To wash or cover with calcimine; as, to calcimine walls.
Ceil: To overlay or cover the inner side of the roof of; to furnish with a ceiling; as, to ceil a room.
Cates: Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food; delicacies; dainties.
Colleterial: Of or pertaining to the colleterium of insects.
Cymophanous: Having a wavy, floating light; opalescent; chatoyant.
Confidentially: In confidence; in reliance on secrecy.
Cackling: The broken noise of a goose or a hen.
Cancrinite: A mineral occurring in hexagonal crystals, also massive, generally of a yellow color, containing silica, alumina, lime, soda, and carbon dioxide.
Costive: Retaining fecal matter in the bowels; having too slow a motion of the bowels; constipated.
Caprimulgiformes: an order of birds including the goatsuckers (Caprimulgidae), frogmouths, and the oilbird (guacharo) (family Steatornithidae).
Ceriph: One of the fine lines of a letter, esp. one of the fine cross strokes at the top and bottom of letters.
Chlorocruorin: A green substance, supposed to be the cause of the green color of the blood in some species of worms.
Categorematic: Capable of being employed by itself as a term; -- said of a word.
curtainless: not provided with curtains; as, blank, curtainless windows stared back at her.  Opposite of curtained.
Crocodile: A large reptile of the genus Crocodilus, of several species.  They grow to the length of sixteen or eighteen feet, and inhabit the large rivers of Africa, Asia, and America.  The eggs, laid in the sand, are hatched by the sun's heat.  The best known species is that of the Nile (Crocodilus vulgaris, or Crocodilus Niloticus).  The Florida crocodile (Crocodilus Americanus) is much less common than the alligator and has longer jaws.  The name is also sometimes applied to the species of other related genera, as the gavial and the alligator.
Clack: A sharp, abrupt noise, or succession of noises, made by striking an object.
conessi: a tropical Asian tree (Holarrhena pubescens or Holarrhena antidysenterica) with hard white wood and bark formerly used as a remedy for dysentery and diarrhea.
chive: A perennial plant (Allium Schoenoprasum), allied to the onion,  having hollow cylindrical leaves used for seasoning. The young leaves are used in omelets, etc.
Cudgeler: One who beats with a cudgel.
Consanguineal: Of the same blood; related by birth.
Curled: Having curls; curly; sinuous; wavy; as, curled maple (maple having fibers which take a sinuous course).
Cubism: A movement or phase in post-impressionism (which see, below).
Cynosural: Of or pertaining to a cynosure.
Corticiferous: Producing bark or something that resembling that resembles bark.
Carbazotate: A salt of carbazotic or picric acid; a picrate.
Carriageable: Passable by carriages; that can be conveyed in carriages.
Convenable: Consistent; accordant; suitable; proper; as, convenable remedies.
Chih fu: An official administering a prefecture of China; a prefect, supervising the civil business of the hsiens or districts comprised in his fu (which see).
Caricature: To make or draw a caricature of; to represent with ridiculous exaggeration; to burlesque.
Collish: A tool to polish the edge of a sole.
Calendula: A genus of composite herbaceous plants. One species, Calendula officinalis, is the common marigold, and was supposed to blossom on the calends of every month, whence the name.
Colymbiformes: an order of birds, including the family Podicipedidae, which consitutes the grebes.
Clinanthium: The receptacle of the flowers in a composite plant; -- also called clinium.
Clanship: A state of being united together as in a clan; an association under a chieftain.
Canker-bit: Eaten out by canker, or as by canker.
Coupling: The act of bringing or coming together; connection; sexual union.
Cowboy: A cattle herder; a drover; specifically, one of an adventurous class of herders and drovers on the plains of the Western and Southwestern United States.
Correspondence school: A school that teaches by correspondence, the instruction being based on printed instruction sheets and the recitation papers written by the student in answer to the questions or requirements of these sheets. In the broadest sense of the term correspondence school may be used to include any educational institution or department for instruction by correspondence, as in a university or other educational bodies, but the term is commonly applied to various educational institutions organized on a commercial basis, some of which offer a large variety of courses in general and technical subjects, conducted by specialists.
Cinclidae: a natural family of birds comprising the water ouzels, also called dippers, which dive under water in flowing streams.
Chautauqua system: The system of home study established in connection with the summer schools assembled at Chautauqua, N. Y., by the Methodist Episcopal bishop, J. H. Vincent.
Cotqueanity: The condition, character, or conduct of a cotquean.
Carboxide: A compound of carbon and oxygen, as carbonyl, with some element or radical; as, potassium carboxide.
Creepiness: An uneasy sensation as of insects creeping on the skin.
Citified: Aping, or having, the manners of a city.
Crinitory: Of or relating to hair; as, a crinitory covering.
Colophene: A colorless, oily liquid, formerly obtained by distillation of colophony. It is regarded as a polymeric form of terebenthene. Called also diterebene.
Circumflex: To mark or pronounce with a circumflex.
closely-held: owned by a relatively few shareholders; -- of business organizations; as, a closely-held corporation.
Chauffeur: Brigands in bands, who, about 1793, pillaged, burned, and killed in parts of France; -- so called because they used to burn the feet of their victims to extort money.
Change gear: A gear by means of which the speed of machinery or of a vehicle may be changed while that of the propelling engine or motor remains constant; -- called also change-speed gear.
Complot: To plot or plan together; to conspire; to join in a secret design.
Crying: Calling for notice; compelling attention; notorious; heinous; as, a crying evil.
Cognizee: One to whom a fine of land was acknowledged.
cinema: the art of creating motion pictures; as, this story would be good cinema; -- often used in the phrase the cinema.
Colorimetry: The quantitative determination of the depth of color of a substance.
Concussion: A shaking or agitation; a shock; caused by the collision of two bodies.
Consultation: The act of consulting or conferring; deliberation of two or more persons on some matter, with a view to a decision.
Catechistic: Of or pertaining to a catechist or to a catechism.
Courtier: One who is in attendance at the court of a prince; one who has an appointment at court.
Conditory: A repository for holding things; a hinding place.
Carcass: A dead body, whether of man or beast; a corpse; now commonly the dead body of a beast.
Cigar: A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking.
Cirrhosis: A disease of the liver in which it usually becomes smaller in size and more dense and fibrous in consistence; hence sometimes applied to similar changes in other organs, caused by increase in the fibrous framework and decrease in the proper substance of the organ.
Cleaver: One who cleaves, or that which cleaves; especially, a butcher's instrument for cutting animal bodies into joints or pieces.
Chronicle: To record in a history or chronicle; to record; to register.
Cordon: A cord or ribbon bestowed or borne as a badge of honor; a broad ribbon, usually worn after the manner of a baldric, constituting a mark of a very high grade in an honorary order. Cf. Grand cordon.
Cashbook: A book in which is kept a register of money received or paid out.
Concaved: Bowed in the form of an arch; -- called also arched.
cordless: operating without a wire connection to the companion communicating unit; -- of telephones and other devices using e.g. radio or infrared signals to allow communication between devices without a direct wire link; as, cordless telephones have a very restricted range compared with cellular phones.
Cornage: An ancient tenure of land, which obliged the tenant to give notice of an invasion by blowing a horn.
Carder: One who, or that which cards wool flax, etc.
Cromwellian: of or pertaining to Oliver Cromwell.
Cyclopedist: A maker of, or writer for, a cyclopedia.
Coryphodon: A genus of extinct mammals from the eocene tertiary of Europe and America. Its species varied in size between the tapir and rhinoceros, and were allied to those animals, but had short, plantigrade, five-toed feet, like the elephant.
C\u0153nenchym: The common tissue which unites the polyps or zooids of a compound anthozoan or coral. It may be soft or more or less ossified. See Coral.
Clew: To direct; to guide, as by a thread.
Calcine: To be converted into a powder or friable substance, or into a calx, by the action of heat.
Co-lessor: A partner in giving a lease.
Clef: A character used in musical notation to determine the position and pitch of the scale as represented on the staff.
Catawbas: An Appalachian tribe of Indians which originally inhabited the regions near the Catawba river and the head waters of the Santee.
Circuition: The act of going round; circumlocution.
cardiogram: Any instrumental record made of heart activity, especially the curve or tracing made by a cardiograph.  Sometimes used synonymously with electrocardiogram.
Cartist: In Spain and Portugal, one who supports the constitution.
Choral: A stately hymn tune; a simple sacred tune, sung in unison by the congregation, used mostly in Protestant (especially Lutheran) churches; as, the Lutheran chorals.
Clucking: The noise or call of a brooding hen.
Carron oil: A lotion of linseed oil and lime water, used as an application to burns and scalds; -- first used at the Carron iron works in Scotland.
Calicular: Relating to, or resembling, a cup; also improperly used for calycular, calyculate.
Ceiling: The inside lining of a room overhead; the under side of the floor above; the upper surface opposite to the floor.
Custodian: One who has care or custody, as of some public building; a keeper or superintendent.
Convincingly: in a convincing manner; in a manner to compel assent.
Cucurbitive: Having the shape of a gourd seed; -- said of certain small worms.
Carnelian: A variety of chalcedony, of a clear, deep red, flesh red, or reddish white color. It is moderately hard, capable of a good polish, and often used for seals.
Cross-tail: A bar connecting the ends of the side rods or levers of a backaction or side-lever engine.
Counterlath: A batten laid lengthwise between two rafters to afford a bearing for laths laid crosswise.
Camelina: a genus of annual and biennial herbs of Mediterranean to Central Asia.
crenelated: having repeated square indentations like those in a battlement; as, a crenelated molding.
Cabriole: A curvet; a leap. See Capriole.
cheoplasty: molding artificial teeth using low-fusing metals or alloys.
Cologne earth: An earth of a deep brown color, containing more vegetable than mineral matter; an earthy variety of lignite, or brown coal.
Commonty: A common; a piece of land in which two or more persons have a common right.
Cataphracted: Covered with a cataphract, or armor of plates, scales, etc.; or with that which corresponds to this, as horny or bony plates, hard, callous skin, etc.
caesium: A rare alkaline metal found in mineral water; -- so called from the two characteristic blue lines in its spectrum. It was the first element discovered by spectrum analysis, and is the most strongly basic and electro-positive substance known. Symbol Cs.  Atomic number 55.  Atomic weight 132.6.
Culvertailed: United or fastened by a dovetailed joint.
Chomp: To chew loudly and greedily; to champ.
Cadastral: Of or pertaining to landed property.
Countermark: To apply a countermark to; as, to countermark silverware; to countermark a horse's teeth.
Clasp: An adjustable catch, bent plate, or hook, for holding together two objects or the parts of anything, as the ends of a belt, the covers of a book, etc.
Chasm: A deep opening made by disruption, as a breach in the earth or a rock; a yawning abyss; a cleft; a fissure.
Calade: A slope or declivity in a manege ground down which a horse is made to gallop, to give suppleness to his haunches.
Chase: To ornament (a surface of metal) by embossing, cutting away parts, and the like.
Cyclorama: A pictorial view which is extended circularly, so that the spectator is surrounded by the objects represented as by things in nature. The realistic effect is increased by putting, in the space between the spectator and the picture, things adapted to the scene represented, and in some places only parts of these objects, the completion of them being carried out pictorially.
Caloricity: A faculty in animals of developing and preserving the heat necessary to life, that is, the animal heat.
canalize: to provide with a canal, as of a city.
capitatim: Of so much per head; as, a capitatim tax; a capitatim grant.
Circle: To move circularly; to form a circle; to circulate.
Cambium: A series of formative cells lying outside of the wood proper and inside of the inner bark. The growth of new wood takes place in the cambium, which is very soft.
Clarify: To grow or become clear or transparent; to become free from feculent impurities, as wine or other liquid under clarification.
central nervous system: the portion of the vertebrate nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord; -- abbreviated CNS.
Compound: That which is compounded or formed by the union or mixture of elements ingredients, or parts; a combination of simples; a compound word; the result of composition.
Colter: A knife or cutter, attached to the beam of a plow to cut the sward, in advance of the plowshare and moldboard.
Confessionalism: An exaggerated estimate of the importance of giving full assent to any particular formula of the Christian faith.
condensed: representing two or more ideas or emotions by a single symbol; as, a condensed expression of various feelings and ideas.
Centrospermae: used in former classification systems; approximately synonymous with order Caryophyllales.
Cloudy: Overcast or obscured with clouds; clouded; as, a cloudy sky.
Cognovit: An instrument in writing whereby a defendant in an action acknowledges a plaintiff's demand to be just.
Carolin: A former gold coin of Germany worth nearly five dollars; also, a gold coin of Sweden worth nearly five dollars.
Catilinarian: Pertaining to Catiline, the Roman conspirator; resembling Catiline's conspiracy.
Cottolene: A product from cotton-seed, used as lard.
Contemptibility: The quality of being contemptible; contemptibleness.
Captious: Apt to catch at faults; disposed to find fault or to cavil; eager to object; difficult to please.
Ciliate: Provided with, or surrounded by, cilia; as, a ciliate leaf; endowed with vibratory motion; as, the ciliated epithelium of the windpipe.
Chiliarchy: A body consisting of a thousand men.
Ceremoniousness: The quality, or practice, of being ceremonious.
Communication: The act or fact of communicating; as, communication of smallpox; communication of a secret.
Convival: pertaining to a feast or to festivity; convivial.
Congolese: a native or inhabitant of the Republic of Congo.
Calorie: The unit of heat according to the French standard; the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one kilogram (sometimes, one gram) of water one degree centigrade, or from 0° to 1°. Compare the English standard unit, Foot pound.
conditioning: a learning process in which an organism's behavior becomes dependent on the occurrence of a stimulus in its environment.  See conditioned response.
Chaconne: An old Spanish dance in moderate three-four measure, like the Passacaglia, which is slower. Both are used by classical composers as themes for variations.
Coryanthes: a small genus of tropical American epiphytic or lithophytic orchids.
Connotate: To connote; to suggest or designate (something) as additional; to include; to imply.
Certificate: A written testimony to the truth of any fact; as, certificate of good behavior.
Carbine: A short, light musket or rifle, esp. one used by mounted soldiers or cavalry.
Cathetus: One line or radius falling perpendicularly on another; as, the catheti of a right-angled triangle, that is, the two sides that include the right angle.
chorine: a woman who dances in a chorus line.
Circ: An amphitheatrical circle for sports; a circus.
Chorea: St. Vitus's dance; a disease attended with convulsive twitchings and other involuntary movements of the muscles or limbs.
Chloric: Pertaining to, or obtained from, chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of five, or the next to its highest; as, chloric acid, HClO3.
Caroteel: A tierce or cask for dried fruits, etc., usually about 700 lbs.
Couscousou: A favorite dish in Barbary. See Couscous.
Cuneiform: The wedge-shaped characters used in ancient Persian and Assyrian inscriptions.
Crop-ear: A person or animal whose ears are cropped.
Cactaceous: Belonging to, or like, the family of plants of which the prickly pear is a common example.
Crudity: The condition of being crude; rawness.
Ceorl: A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of the servile classes; a churl.
Congruity: The state or quality of being congruous; the relation or agreement between things; fitness; harmony; correspondence; consistency.
Contrayerva: A species of Dorstenia (Dorstenia Contrayerva), a South American plant, the aromatic root of which is sometimes used in medicine as a gentle stimulant and tonic.
Cider: The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, for making vinegar, and for other purposes.
Condonation: The act of condoning or pardoning.
Cognizance: Apprehension by the understanding; perception; observation.
Climatology: The science which treats of climates and investigates their phenomena and causes.
Control theory: That branch of Mathematics and Engineering which deals with the design, identification and analysis of systems with a view towards controlling them, i. e., to make them perform specific tasks or make them behave in a desired way.
Chagres fever: A form of malarial fever occurring along the Chagres River, Panama.
Capias: A writ or process commanding the officer to take the body of the person named in it, that is, to arrest him; -- also called writ of capias.
Careworn: Worn or burdened with care; as, careworn look or face.
Crayon: To sketch, as with a crayon; to sketch or plan.
Caries: Ulceration of bone; a process in which bone disintegrates and is carried away piecemeal, as distinguished from necrosis, in which it dies in masses.
Centaurea: A large genus of composite plants, related to the thistles and including the cornflower or bluebottle (Centaurea Cyanus) and the star thistle (Centaurea Calcitrapa).
Chondrostei: An order of fishes, including the sturgeons; -- so named because the skeleton is cartilaginous.
Calopogon: a genus of terrestrial orchids of North America.
Calcar: A hollow tube or spur at the base of a petal or corolla.
counselor-at-law: a lawyer who pleads cases in court.
challenging: requiring full use of one's abilities or resources; as, challenging task.
Ciliform: Having the form of cilia; very fine or slender.
cytotaxis: The movement of cells toward or away from other cells, as a result of some stimulation, such as chemical signals transmitted and received by the cells.
Collimation: The act of collimating; the adjustment of the line of the sights, as the axial line of the telescope of an instrument, into its proper position relative to the other parts of the instrument.
Caucasian: A native or inhabitant of the Caucasus, esp. a Circassian or Georgian.
Consonantly: In a consonant, consistent, or congruous manner; agreeably.
Cannot: Am, is, or are, not able; -- written either as one word or two.
Clamber: To ascend by climbing with difficulty.
chinchillon: a gregarious burrowing rodent (Lagostomus maximus) larger than the chinchillas.
Crocodilia: An order of reptiles including the crocodiles, gavials, alligators, and many extinct kinds.
Contractive: Tending to contract; having the property or power or power of contracting.
cannelloni: a tubular pasta filled with meat or cheese.
Cobnut: A large roundish variety of the cultivated hazelnut.
Correlate: One who, or that which, stands in a reciprocal relation to something else, as father to son; a correlative.
Cercal: Of or pertaining to the tail.
Carpetbagger: An adventurer; -- a term of contempt for a Northern man seeking private gain or political advancement in the southern part of the United States after the Civil War (1865).
Capitularly: In the manner or form of an ecclesiastical chapter.
Compensation: The act or principle of compensating.
Careless: Free from care or anxiety. hence, cheerful; light-hearted.
Cranberry: A red, acid berry, much used for making sauce, etc.; also, the plant producing it (several species of Vaccinum or Oxycoccus.) The high cranberry or cranberry tree is a species of Viburnum (Viburnum Opulus), and the other is sometimes called low cranberry or marsh cranberry to distinguish it.
chancroidal: of or pertaining to a chancroid.
Congenially: In a congenial manner; as, congenially married or employed.
Carotic: Of or pertaining to stupor; as, a carotic state.
Cumulostratus: A form of cloud. See Cloud.
Cutgrass: A grass with leaves having edges furnished with very minute hooked prickles, which form a cutting edge; one or more species of Leersia.
Carotid: Pertaining to, or near, the carotids or one of them; as, the carotid gland.
Carotin: A red crystallizable tasteless substance, extracted from the carrot.
Crawl stroke: A racing stroke, in which the swimmer, lying flat on the water with face submerged, takes alternate overhand arm strokes while moving his legs up and down alternately from the knee.
Contralto: Of or pertaining to a contralto, or to the part in music called contralto; as, a contralto voice.
Cyanin: The blue coloring matter of flowers; -- called also anthokyan and anthocyanin.
Campylorhynchus: an alternative genus classification for the cactus wrens.
Comestible: Something suitable to be eaten; -- commonly in the plural.
Curdy: Like curd; full of curd; coagulated.
Captainship: The condition, rank, post, or authority of a captain or chief commander.
Culasse: The lower faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond.
Convincible: Capable of being convinced or won over.
Callithumpian: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a callithump.
co-ordinate: To make coördinate; to put in the same order or rank; as, to coördinate ideas in classification.
Capaciousness: The quality of being capacious, as of a vessel, a reservoir a bay, the mind, etc.
conformist: marked by conformity or convention; not corresponding to current customs or rules or styles; as, underneath the radical image teenagers are surprisingly conformist.  Opposite of nonconformist.
Cephalad: Forwards; towards the head or anterior extremity of the body; opposed to caudad.
Cleave: To part; to open; to crack; to separate; as parts of bodies; as, the ground cleaves by frost.
Corozo: The name in Central America for the seed of a true palm; also, a commercial name for the true ivory nut. See Ivory nut.
clutch hitter: a batter who hits safely more frequently when men are on base or the team is behind in the score.
clippers: a type of shears for cutting grass or shrubbery; as, hedge clippers.
Cup-moss: A kind of lichen, of the genus Cladonia.
Cohesion: The act or state of sticking together; close union.
Chlamys: A loose and flowing outer garment, worn by the ancient Greeks; a kind of cloak.
Chemotaxis: The sensitiveness exhibited by small free-swimming organisms, as bacteria, zoöspores of algæ, etc., to chemical substances held in solution. They may be attracted (positive chemotaxis) or repelled (negative chemotaxis).
crap out: to throw a 2, 3, or 12 on the first throw in the game of craps, thereby losing that turn.
Curative: Relating to, or employed in, the cure of diseases; tending to cure.
Cracked: Coarsely ground or broken; as, cracked wheat.
Capsulotomy: The incision of a capsule, esp. of that of the crystalline lens, as in a cataract operation.
Calyciform: Having the form or appearance of a calyx.
Counselorship: The function and rank or office of a counselor.
chivaree: a noisy mock serenade (made by banging pans and kettles) to a newly married couple.
Cobwebby: Abounding in cobwebs, or any fine web; resembling a cobweb.
Chastisable: Capable or deserving of chastisement; punishable.
Cnidaria: A comprehensive group equivalent to the true Cœlenterata, i. e., exclusive of the sponges. They are so named from presence of stinging cells (cnidae) in the tissues. See Coelenterata.
characterized: stated precisely; -- of the meaning of words or concepts.
Cadency: Descent of related families; distinction between the members of a family according to their ages.
Craterous: Pertaining to, or resembling, a crater.
Cappaper: See cap, n., also Paper, n.
Caperer: One who capers, leaps, and skips about, or dances.
Crepitation: The act of crepitating or crackling.
Comprehend: To contain; to embrace; to include; as, the states comprehended in the Austrian Empire.
Colchicum: A genus of bulbous-rooted plants found in many parts of Europe, including the meadow saffron.
Complex: Assemblage of related things; collection; complication.
Compos mentis: Sane in mind; being of sound mind, memory, and understanding.
Collapse: A falling together suddenly, as of the sides of a hollow vessel.
Cerement: A cerecloth used for the special purpose of enveloping a dead body when embalmed.
Crinkled: Having short bends, turns, or wrinkles; wrinkled; wavy; zigzag.
Crotch chain: A form of tackle for loading a log sideways on a sled, skidway, etc.
Coral: The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a few Hydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
Ceria: Cerium oxide, CeO2, a white infusible substance constituting about one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
Cherup: A short, sharp, cheerful noise; a chirp; a chirrup; as, the cherup of a cricket.
Cerin: A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork; sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble in alcohol.
Commandant: A commander; the commanding officer of a place, or of a body of men; as, the commandant of a navy-yard.
Caprice: An abrupt change in feeling, opinion, or action, proceeding from some whim or fancy; a freak; a notion.
Corah: Plain; undyed; -- applied to Indian silk.
Confrere: Fellow member of a fraternity; intimate associate.
Cherub: A mysterious composite being, the winged footstool and chariot of the Almighty, described in Ezekiel i. and x.
Chronograph: An instrument for measuring or recording intervals of time, upon a revolving drum or strip of paper moved by clockwork. The action of the stylus or pen is controlled by electricity.
Complexus: A complex; an aggregate of parts; a complication.
Crypturi: An order of flying, dromæognathous birds, including the tinamous of South America. See Tinamou.
Calciner: One who, or that which, calcines.
Congratulation: The act of congratulating; an expression of sympathetic pleasure.
Centiloquy: A work divided into a hundred parts.
Calefacient: A substance that excites warmth in the parts to which it is applied, as mustard.
Corrigibleness: The state or quality of being corrigible; corrigibility.
Compluvium: A space left unroofed over the court of a Roman dwelling, through which the rain fell into the impluvium or cistern.
Consumers goods: Economic goods that directly satisfy human wants or desires, such as food, clothes, pictures, etc.; -- called also consumption goods, or goods of the first order, and opposed to producer's goods.
Characterless: Destitute of any distinguishing quality; without character or force.
Curia: One of the thirty parts into which the Roman people were divided by Romulus.
Camera: A chamber, or instrument having a chamber.  Specifically: The camera obscura when used in photography. See Camera, and Camera obscura.
Crannied: Having crannies, chinks, or fissures; as, a crannied wall.
Chrysanthemum: A genus of composite plants, mostly perennial, and of many species including the many varieties of garden chrysanthemums (annual and perennial), and also the feverfew and the oxeye daisy.
Cottonwood: An American tree of the genus Populus or poplar, having the seeds covered with abundant cottonlike hairs; esp., the Populus monilifera and Populus angustifolia of the Western United States.
Comminute: To reduce to minute particles, or to a fine powder; to pulverize; to triturate; to grind; as, to comminute chalk or bones; to comminute food with the teeth.
Compurgatorial: Relating to a compurgator or to compurgation.
Codder: A gatherer of cods or peas.
Cloudberry: A species of raspberry (Rubus Chamæmerous) growing in the northern regions, and bearing edible, amber-colored fruit.
Carnifex: The public executioner at Rome, who executed persons of the lowest rank; hence, an executioner or hangman.
Corradial: Radiating to or from the same point.
cockatiel: A small gray and white Australian parrot (Leptolophus hollandicus, formerly Calopsitta Novæ-Hollandiæ) with a prominent crest; the male has bright yellow cheeks and crest, but the female has only a pale yellow in the face; -- it is so called from its note.
Crimination: The act of accusing; accusation; charge; complaint.
Cofferer: One who keeps treasures in a coffer.
Cerusite: Native lead carbonate; a mineral occurring in colorless, white, or yellowish transparent crystals, with an adamantine, also massive and compact.
Cone clutch: A friction clutch with conical bearing surfaces.
Chaplet: To adorn with a chaplet or with flowers.
Coumarin: The concrete essence of the tonka bean, the fruit of Dipterix (formerly Coumarouna) odorata and consisting essentially of coumarin proper, which is a white crystalline substance, C9H6O2, of vanilla-like odor, regarded as an anhydride of coumaric acid, and used in flavoring. Coumarin in also made artificially.
cross-link: to create cross links in; -- of polymeric molecules.
Chickasaws: A tribe of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian) allied to the Choctaws. They formerly occupied the northern part of Alabama and Mississippi, but now live in the Indian Territory.
Commodious: Adapted to its use or purpose, or to wants and necessities; serviceable; spacious and convenient; roomy and comfortable; as, a commodious house.
Croon: A low, continued moan; a murmur.
Constructively: In a constructive manner; by construction or inference.
Collineation: The act of aiming at, or directing in a line with, a fixed object.
clickety-clack: a fast and rhythmic clicking sound, as of “click-clack”; as, the clickety-clack of the typewriters.
capeweed: a European weed (Hypochaeris radicata) widely naturalized in North America, having yellow flower heads and leaves resembling a cat's ears.
Cantharidin: The active principle of the cantharis, or Spanish fly, a volatile, acrid, bitter solid, crystallizing in four-sided prisms.
Ceratohyal: Pertaining to the bone, or cartilage, below the epihyal in the hyoid arch.
Cayman: The south America alligator. See Alligator.
currawong: any of several bluish black fruit-eating birds of Australia of the genus Strepera having a bell-like call.
cropped: cut very short; as, her cropped hair.
Coumaric: Relating to, derived from, or like, the Dipterix odorata, a tree of Guiana.
Cymry: A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called by themselves .
Corival: To rival; to pretend to equal.
Chandlerly: Like a chandler; in a petty way.
Coventry: A town in the county of Warwick, England.
Chainwork: Work looped or linked after the manner of a chain; chain stitch work.
Cactus: Any plant of the order Cactacæ, as the prickly pear and the night-blooming cereus. See Cereus. They usually have leafless stems and branches, often beset with clustered thorns, and are mostly natives of the warmer parts of America.
Cross-banded: A term used when a narrow ribbon of veneer is inserted into the surface of any piece of furniture, wainscoting, etc., so that the grain of it is contrary to the general surface.
Crampfish: The torpedo, or electric ray, the touch of which gives an electric shock. See Electric fish, and Torpedo.
Creation: The act of creating or causing to exist. Specifically, the act of bringing the universe or this world into existence.
Conventionalize: To make designs in art, according to conventional principles. Cf. Conventionalize, v. t., 2.
Chiaroscuro: The arrangement of light and dark parts in a work of art, such as a drawing or painting, whether in monochrome or in color.
Cretaceous-Tertiary boundary: a thin layer of geologic deposits, of varying thickness in different parts of the world, found between the geological strata identified as Cretaceous and the strata above, identified as Tertiary; also, the time point or period marking the boundary between the Cretaceous and Tertiary periods.
Cascabel: The projection in rear of the breech of a cannon, usually a knob or breeching loop connected with the gun by a neck. In old writers it included all in rear of the base ring. [See Illust. of Cannon.]
Castrametation: The art or act of encamping; the making or laying out of a camp.
Calamistration: The act or process of curling the hair.
Cerebral: One of a class of lingual consonants in the East Indian languages. See Lingual, n.
Cognizable: Capable of being known or apprehended; as, cognizable causes.
Cyclobranchiate: Having the gills around the margin of the body, as certain limpets.
Chondrigen: The chemical basis of cartilage, converted by long boiling in water into a gelatinous body called chondrin.
carboxylate: to treat a chemical compound with carboxyl or carboxylic acid.
Carnin: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, found in extract of meat, and related to xanthin.
Cannabin: A poisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, variety Indica).  The euphoric and narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin; the active ingredient is tetrahydrocannabinol, THC.  See Cannabis Indica, below.
Creosote bush: A shrub (Covillea mexicana) found in desert regions from Colorado to California and southward through Mexico. It has yellow flowers and very resinous foliage with a strong odor of creosote.
Candite: A variety of spinel, of a dark color, found at Candy, in Ceylon.
Commodiousness: State of being commodious; suitableness for its purpose; convenience; roominess.
Cornshuck: The husk covering an ear of Indian corn.
Categorize: To insert in a category or list; to class; to catalogue.
Cosmography: A description of the world or of the universe; or the science which teaches the constitution of the whole system of worlds, or the figure, disposition, and relation of all its parts.
Coral fish: Any bright-colored fish of the genera Chætodon, Pomacentrus, Apogon, and related genera, which live among reef corals.
Connivance: Intentional failure or forbearance to discover a fault or wrongdoing; voluntary oversight; passive consent or coöperation.
Colliery: The place where coal is dug; a coal mine, and the buildings, etc., belonging to it.
Chinky: Full of chinks or fissures; gaping; opening in narrow clefts.
Consequentially: With just deduction of consequence; with right connection of ideas; logically.
calaba: a West Indian tree (Calophyllum calaba) having racemes of fragrant white flowers and yielding a durable timber and resinous juice.
Circumnutation: The successive bowing or bending in different directions of the growing tip of the stems of many plants, especially seen in climbing plants.
Cubic: A curve of the third degree.
Carbonometer: An instrument for detecting and measuring the amount of carbon which is present, or more esp. the amount of carbon dioxide, by its action on limewater or by other means.
Conjecturable: Capable of being conjectured or guessed.
Contraposition: A placing over against; opposite position.
Cambria: The ancient Latin name of Wales. It is used by modern poets.
Compone: To compose; to settle; to arrange.
Chromascope: An instrument for showing the optical effects of color.
Crosier: The pastoral staff of a bishop (also of an archbishop, being the symbol of his office as a shepherd of the flock of God.
Could: Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible. Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditional present.
confiscated: taken without permission or consent, especially by or as if by a public authority; as, the confiscated liquor was poured down the drain; teh customs agents confiscated the banned fruits.
Crinite: Having the appearance of a tuft of hair; having a hairlike tail or train.
Chaunter: A street seller of ballads and other broadsides.
Case system: The system of teaching law in which the instruction is primarily a historical and inductive study of leading or selected cases, with or without the use of textbooks for reference and collateral reading.
Cretaceously: In a chalky manner; as chalk.
Consubstantiation: An identity or union of substance.
Calumniation: False accusation of crime or offense, or a malicious and false representation of the words or actions of another, with a view to injure his good name.
condo: one of the units in a condominium.
cosmetologist: an expert in the use of cosmetics.
Crowbar: A bar of iron sharpened at one end, and used as a lever.
Cephalization: Domination of the head in animal life as expressed in the physical structure; localization of important organs or parts in or near the head, in animal development.
Carotte: A cylindrical roll of tobacco; as, a carotte of perique.
Crined: Having the hair of a different tincture from the rest of the body; as, a charge crined of a red tincture.
Collectively: In a mass, or body; in a collected state; in the aggregate; unitedly.
Cornfield: A field where corn is or has been growing; -- in England, a field of wheat, rye, barley, or oats; in America, a field of Indian corn.
Comprehension: The act of comprehending, containing, or comprising; inclusion.
Coastal: Of or pertaining to a coast.
Commerce: To carry on trade; to traffic.
Cubicle: A loding room; esp., a sleeping place partitioned off from a large dormitory.
Cotton: To rise with a regular nap, as cloth does.
Connaturalness: Participation of the same nature; natural union.
Convallarin: A white, crystalline glucoside, of an irritating taste, extracted from the convallaria or lily of the valley.
Clicker: One who stands before a shop door to invite people to buy.
Convulsive: Producing, or attended with, convulsions or spasms; characterized by convulsions; convulsionary.
Compossible: Able to exist with another thing; consistent.
Conclave: The set of apartments within which the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church are continuously secluded while engaged in choosing a pope.
Cirrose: Bearing a tendril or tendrils; as, a cirrose leaf.
Cement: To become cemented or firmly united; to cohere.
Crowfoot: The genus Ranunculus, of many species; some are common weeds, others are flowering plants of considerable beauty.
Centrifugence: The property or quality of being centrifugal.
Cobourg: A thin worsted fabric for women's dresses.
chummy: having the relationship of friends or pals.
Canzonet: A short song, in one or more parts.
Coypu: A South American rodent (Myopotamus coypus), allied to the beaver. It produces a valuable fur called nutria.
Cismontane: On this side of the mountains. See under Ultramontane.
Conversible: Capable of being converted or reversed.
Corinth: A city of Greece, famed for its luxury and extravagance.
Coldness: The state or quality of being cold.
Chess-apple: The wild service of Europe (Purus torminalis).
Commencement: The first existence of anything; act or fact of commencing; rise; origin; beginning; start.
cither: a musical instrument resembling a harp with strings stretch over a flat sounding box; the zither.  It is played with a plectrum and with fingers.
Concomitant: One who, or that which, accompanies, or is collaterally connected with another; a companion; an associate; an accompaniment.
Classification: The act of forming into a class or classes; a distribution into groups, as classes, orders, families, etc., according to some common relations or affinities.
Custos: A keeper; a custodian; a superintendent.
Curculionidous: Pertaining to the Curculionideæ, or weevil tribe.
Cinura: The group of Thysanura which includes Lepisma and allied forms; the bristletails. See Bristletail, and Lepisma.
Coalitionist: One who joins or promotes a coalition; one who advocates coalition.
Cylindraceous: Cylindrical, or approaching a cylindrical form.
Collocution: A speaking or conversing together; conference; mutual discourse.
chuckhole: a pit or hole produced by wear or weathering especially in a road surface.
City: Of or pertaining to a city.
Conduction: The act of leading or guiding.
Centrality: The state of being central; tendency towards a center.
Cockal: A game played with sheep's bones instead of dice.
Constitutionally: In accordance with the constitution or natural disposition of the mind or body; naturally; as, he was constitutionally timid.
Commensuration: The act of commensurating; the state of being commensurate.
Co-: A form of the prefix com-, signifying with, together, in conjunction, joint. It is used before vowels and some consonants. See Com-.
