Cite: To call upon officially or authoritatively to appear, as before a court; to summon.
Contextured: Formed into texture; woven together; arranged; composed.
Cellaret: A receptacle, as in a dining room, for a few bottles of wine or liquor, made in the form of a chest or coffer, or a deep drawer in a sideboard, and usually lined with metal.
Chicken pox: A mild, eruptive disease, generally attacking children only; varicella.
Chrysoprase: An apple-green variety of chalcedony, colored by nickel. It has a dull flinty luster, and is sometimes used in jewelry.
Cackle: The sharp broken noise made by a goose or by a hen that has laid an egg.
Counterirritant: See Counter irritant, etc., under Counter, a.
Catachresis: A figure by which one word is wrongly put for another, or by which a word is wrested from its true signification; as, “To take arms against a sea of troubles”. Shak. “Her voice was but the shadow of a sound.” Young.
Complicacy: A state of being complicate or intricate.
Castanopsis: a genus of evergreen trees and shrubs of warm regions valued for their foliage; found in southeastern U.S. and eastern Australia and northern New Zealand.
Coagulated: Changed into, or contained in, a coagulum or a curdlike mass; curdled.
Crotonylene: A colorless, volatile, pungent liquid, C4H6, produced artificially, and regarded as an unsaturated hydrocarbon of the acetylene series, and analogous to crotonic acid.
Courageous: Possessing, or characterized by, courage; brave; bold.
Cop: The top of a thing; the head; a crest.
Cor: A Hebrew measure of capacity; a homer.
Cot: A sleeping place of limited size; a little bed; a cradle; a piece of canvas extended by a frame, used as a bed.
Concrement: A growing together; the collection or mass formed by concretion, or natural union.
Coy: To behave with reserve or coyness; to shrink from approach or familiarity.
Chiffonier: One who gathers rags and odds and ends; a ragpicker.
Coroneted: Wearing, or entitled to wear, a coronet; of noble birth or rank.
Crossing: The act by which anything is crossed; as, the crossing of the ocean.
Col: A short ridge connecting two higher elevations or mountains; the pass over such a ridge.
Coo: To make a low repeated cry or sound, like the characteristic note of pigeons or doves.
Con: To conduct, or superintend the steering of (a vessel); to watch the course of (a vessel) and direct the helmsman how to steer.
Cura\u00e7ao: A liqueur, or cordial, flavored with the peel from the sour orange, and sometimes with cinnamon and mace; -- first made at the island of Curaçcao.
Criminatory: Relating to, or involving, crimination; accusing; as, a criminatory conscience.
Curmudgeon: An avaricious, grasping fellow; a miser; a niggard; a churl.
Continuator: One who, or that which, continues; esp., one who continues a series or a work; a continuer.
Craniology: The department of science (as of ethnology or archæology) which deals with the shape, size, proportions, indications, etc., of skulls; the study of skulls.
Cycadophyta: a class or subdivision of plants comprising palmlike gymnosperms: it includes the surviving order Cycadales and several extinct orders; possibly not a natural group; in some systems considered a class (Cycadopsida) and in others a subdivision (Cycadophytina or Cycadophyta).
Culture myth: A myth accounting for the discovery of arts and sciences or the advent of a higher civilization, as in the Prometheus myth.
Constitutionist: One who adheres to the constitution of the country.
Cephalous: Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a division of mollusks.
Ci-devant: Former; previous; of times gone by; as, a ci-devant governor.
Castoridae: a natural family comprising the beavers.
Cantaloupe: A muskmelon of several varieties, having when mature, a yellowish skin, and flesh of a reddish orange color.
corroborated: supported or established by evidence or proof; as, corroborated testimony is especially convincing.
Chocolate: A paste or cake composed of the roasted seeds of the Theobroma Cacao ground and mixed with other ingredients, usually sugar, and cinnamon or vanilla.
Constantinople: the former capital of the Eastern Roman Empire; it was built on the site of ancient Byzantium, and the name was changed to Istanbul by the Turks.
Chincha: A south American rodent of the genus Lagotis.
coreligionist: One of the same religion with another.
chromaticity: the quality of a color as determined by its dominant wavelength.
Confessant: One who confesses to a priest.
Creese: A dagger or short sword used by the Malays, commonly having a serpentine blade.
Cannonade: To discharge cannon; as, the army cannonaded all day.
Curator: One who has the care and superintendence of anything, as of a museum; a custodian; a keeper.
Counterterm: A term or word which is the opposite of, or antithesis to, another; an antonym; -- the opposite of synonym; as, “foe” is the counterterm of “friend”.
cardiograph: An instrument which, when placed in contact with the chest, will register graphically the comparative duration and intensity of the heart's movements.
Cyclostomi: A glass of fishes having a suckerlike mouth, without jaws, as the lamprey; the Marsipobranchii.
Colony: A company of people transplanted from their mother country to a remote province or country, and remaining subject to the jurisdiction of the parent state; as, the British colonies in America.
Commutableness: The quality of being commutable; interchangeableness.
Cycloidal: Pertaining to, or resembling, a cycloid; as, the cycloidal space is the space contained between a cycloid and its base.
Come-along: A gripping device, as for stretching wire, etc., consisting of two jaws so attached to a ring that they are closed by pulling on the ring.
Concomitantly: In company with others; unitedly; concurrently.
Cinchonic: Belonging to, or obtained from, cinchona.
catalyze: to cause (a chemical reaction) to proceed more quickly by contacting the reactant(s) with another substance; as, moisture catalyzes the oxidation of iron in air.
Cold wave: In the terminology of the United States Weather Bureau, an unusual fall in temperature, to or below the freezing point, exceeding 16° in twenty-four hours or 20° in thirty-six hours, independent of the diurnal range.
Champlain period: A subdivision of the Quaternary age immediately following the Glacial period; -- so named from beds near Lake Champlain.
Calotte: A close cap without visor or brim.
Chloral: A colorless oily liquid, CCl3.CHO, of a pungent odor and harsh taste, obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethyl alcohol.
Channel: To form a channel in; to cut or wear a channel or channels in; to groove.
Chaeronea: either of two battles in ancient Greece, one in which Philip of Macedon defeated the Athenians and Thebans (338 BC), or another in which Sulla defeated Mithridates (86 BC).
carjacking: the forcible taking of a car while the driver is in it; the robber may force the driver out, force the driver to drive while under threat of harm, or be forced to relinquish the controls while also being forced to remain in the car.  In the latter two cases, the act also constitutes a kidnapping.
Corybantiasm: A kind of frenzy in which the patient is tormented by fantastic visions and want of sleep.
Chondrification: Formation of, or conversion into, cartilage.
Cade: A species of juniper (Juniperus Oxycedrus) of Mediterranean countries.
Clairvoyance: A power, attributed to some persons while in a mesmeric state, of discerning objects not perceptible by the senses in their normal condition.
Chitinous: Having the nature of chitin; consisting of, or containing, chitin.
Calvinistic: Of or pertaining to Calvin, or Calvinism; following Calvin; accepting or Teaching Calvinism.
Cycadaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, an order of plants like the palms, but having exogenous wood. The sago palm is an example.
Coagmentation: The act of joining, or the state of being joined, together; union.
civies: civilian garb as opposed to a military uniform.
Cineration: The reducing of anything to ashes by combustion; cinefaction.
caseate: to turn into cheese; -- of milk.
carriage bolt: a type of bolt threaded only at the end opposite the head, used mostly for fastening pieces of timber together, and inserted into pre-drilled holes.
careerism: The practice of advancing one's career at the expense of one's personal integrity.
Collocutor: One of the speakers in a dialogue.
Cleavable: Capable of cleaving or being divided.
careerist: A professional who follows a career.
Calenture: To see as in the delirium of one affected with calenture.
Classific: Characterizing a class or classes; relating to classification.
Cross-bearer: A subdeacon who bears a cross before an archbishop or primate on solemn occasions.
conserving: the preservation and careful management of the environment and of natural resources.
Copaiba: A more or less viscid, yellowish liquid, the bitter oleoresin of several species of Copaifera, a genus of trees growing in South America and the West Indies. It is stimulant and diuretic, and was formerly much used in affections of the mucous membranes.  It is also used in varnishes and lacquers, and in cleaning oil paintings. -- called also balsam of copaiba, copaiba balsam, balsam capivi, and Jesuits' resin.
Cryptidine: One of the quinoline bases, obtained from coal tar as an oily liquid, C11H11N; also, any one of several substances metameric with, and resembling, cryptidine proper.
Corbeil: A sculptured basket of flowers; a corbel.
Chelidon: The hollow at the flexure of the arm.
Consultative: Pertaining to consultation; having the privilege or right of conference.
Compotation: The act of drinking or tippling together.
Clubbable: Suitable for membership in a club; sociable.
Cryptogram: A cipher writing. Same as Cryptograph.
Conveyer: One who, or that which, conveys or carries, transmits or transfers.
Casal: Of or pertaining to case; as, a casal ending.
capacitance: an electrical phenomenon whereby an electric charge is stored.
Channeling: The act or process of forming a channel or channels.
Caput: The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
Culvers physic: The root of a handsome erect herb (Leptandra Virginica syn. Veronica Virginica) common in most moist woods of North America , used as an active cathartic and emetic; also, the plant itself.
Caricous: Of the shape of a fig; as, a caricous tumor.
Chrysene: One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied to naphthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance, C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow by impurities.
cancerweed: a sage of eastern U. S. (Salvia lyrata).
Corolla: The inner envelope of a flower; the part which surrounds the organs of fructification, consisting of one or more leaves, called petals. It is usually distinguished from the calyx by the fineness of its texture and the gayness of its colors. See the Note under Blossom.
Chiminage: A toll for passage through a forest.
Cerulenin: an antifungal antibiotic, C12H17NO3.  It inhibits the growth of yeasts by interfering with the synthesis of sterols and fatty acids.
Cremationist: One who advocates the practice of cremation.
Calamistrum: A comblike structure on the metatarsus of the hind legs of certain spiders (Ciniflonidæ), used to curl certain fibers in the construction of their webs.
Calendric: Of or pertaining to a calendar.
Congeable: Permissible; done lawfully; as, entry congeable.
city-like: having the customs or manners or dress of city people.
cha-cha: a modern ballroom dance from Latin America; it uses two slow steps followed by three quick small steps, with swaying movements of the hips, and has many variations of movements based on that rhythm.
Cassate: To render void or useless; to vacate or annul.
Corrupter: One who corrupts; one who vitiates or taints; as, a corrupter of morals.
Cruise: A voyage made in various directions, as of an armed vessel, for the protection of other vessels, or in search of an enemy; a sailing to and fro, as for exploration or for pleasure.
crape myrtle: an tall East Indian and Chinese shrub (Lagerstroemia indica of the loosestrife family, commonly planted in Southern and Western  U. S. as an ornamental shrub.  It has clusters of red, white, purple, or pink flowers.
Countercaster: A caster of accounts; a reckoner; a bookkeeper; -- used contemptuously.
Chronophotograph: One of a set of photographs of a moving object, taken for the purpose of recording and exhibiting successive phases of the motion.
Castanospermum: a genus consisting of one species, the Moreton Bay chestnut.
Corposant: St. Elmo's fire. See under Saint.
Centauromachy: A fight in which centaurs take part, -- a common theme for relief sculpture, as in the Parthenon metopes.
Cribellum: A peculiar perforated organ of certain spiders (Ciniflonidæ), used for spinning a special kind of silk.
chickeree: the far western U.S. counterpart of the red squirrel.
Crankle: A bend or turn; a twist; a crinkle.
Carminated: Of, relating to, or mixed with, carmine; as, carminated lake.
Chorometry: The art of surveying a region or district.
Cui bono: Lit., for whose benefit; incorrectly understood, it came to be used in the sense, of what good or use; and hence, (what) purpose; object; specif., the ultimate object of life.
Colstaff: A staff by means of which a burden is borne by two persons on their shoulders.
Cross-staff: An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes of celestial bodies.
Cost: The amount paid, charged, or engaged to be paid, for anything bought or taken in barter; charge; expense; hence, whatever, as labor, self-denial, suffering, etc., is requisite to secure benefit.
Contemptuously: In a contemptuous manner; with scorn or disdain; despitefully.
Coal works: A place where coal is dug, including the machinery for raising the coal.
Caraway: A biennial plant of the Parsley family (Carum Carui). The seeds have an aromatic smell, and a warm, pungent taste. They are used in cookery and confectionery, and also in medicine as a carminative.
Caporal: One who directs work; an overseer.
Churlish: Like a churl; rude; cross-grained; ungracious; surly; illiberal; niggardly.
Crab-yaws: A disease in the West Indies. It is a kind of ulcer on the soles of the feet, with very hard edges. See Yaws.
Contrafissure: A fissure or fracture on the side opposite to that which received the blow, or at some distance from it.
Cerite: A mineral of a brownish of cherry-red color, commonly massive. It is a hydrous silicate of cerium and allied metals.
Chilling: Making chilly or cold; depressing; discouraging; cold; distant; as, a chilling breeze; a chilling manner.
Connivent: Forbearing to see; designedly inattentive; as, connivent justice.
Curling: The act or state of that which curls; as, the curling of smoke when it rises; the curling of a ringlet; also, the act or process of one who curls something, as hair, or the brim of hats.
Citric: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the citron or lemon; as, citric acid.
Cephalometer: An instrument measuring the dimensions of the head of a fetus during delivery.
Curmurring: Murmuring; grumbling; -- sometimes applied to the rumbling produced by a slight attack of the gripes.
Chorograph: An instrument for constructing triangles in marine surveying, etc.
Casualty: That which comes without design or without being foreseen; contingency.
Convulse: To contract violently and irregulary, as the muscular parts of an animal body; to shake with irregular spasms, as in excessive laughter, or in agony from grief or pain.
Causative: A word which expresses or suggests a cause.
Cooling: Adapted to cool and refresh; allaying heat.
Carbunculation: The blasting of the young buds of trees or plants, by excessive heat or cold.
Chrysophrys: a genus of fishes consisting of the australian snapper.
Cardamom: The aromatic fruit, or capsule with its seeds, of several plants of the Ginger family growing in the East Indies and elsewhere, and much used as a condiment, and in medicine.
Carpologist: One who describes fruits; one versed in carpology.
Cony-catcher: A cheat; a sharper; a deceiver.
Cucumis: A genus of plants including the cucumber, melon, and same kinds of gourds.
colubrid: any member of a large family (Colubridae) of mostly harmless temperate-to-tropical terrestrial or arboreal or aquatic snakes.
Crapulent: Surcharged with liquor; sick from excessive indulgence in liquor; drunk; given to excesses.
Cariole: A small, light, open one-horse carriage
Commanding: Exercising authority; actually in command; as, a commanding officer.
Croustade: Bread baked in a mold, and scooped out, to serve minces upon.
Crisp: That which is crisp or brittle; the state of being crisp or brittle; as, burned to a crisp; specifically, the rind of roasted pork; crackling.
Counterstroke: A stroke or blow in return.
Calvin: John Calvin, a French theologian and reformer; born 1509, died 1564.
Cameralistics: The science of finance or public revenue.
Corbeling: Corbel work or the construction of corbels; a series of corbels or piece of continuous corbeled masonry, sometimes of decorative purpose, as in the stalactite ornament of the Moslems.
Composed: Free from agitation; calm; sedate; quiet; tranquil; self-possessed.
Cobaltous: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cobalt; -- said esp. of cobalt compounds in which the metal has its lower valence.
Chrysopidae: a natural family of flies comprising the green lacewings.
Chicky: A chicken; -- used as a diminutive or pet name, especially in calling fowls.
Chamfret: A small gutter; a furrow; a groove.
Crackled: Covered with minute cracks in the glaze; -- said of some kinds of porcelain and fine earthenware.
Competition: The act of seeking, or endeavoring to gain, what another is endeavoring to gain at the same time; common strife for the same objects; strife for superiority; emulous contest; rivalry, as for approbation, for a prize, or as where two or more persons are engaged in the same business and each seeking patronage; -- followed by for before the object sought, and with before the person or thing competed with.
Cosmographer: One who describes the world or universe, including the heavens and the earth.
Composer: One who composes; an author. Specifically, an author of a piece of music.
Contrate: Having cogs or teeth projecting parallel to the axis, instead of radiating from it.
Cavort: To prance ostentatiously; -- said of a horse or his rider.
Columbite: A mineral of a black color, submetallic luster, and high specific specific gravity. It is a niobate (or columbate) of iron and manganese, containing tantalate of iron; -- first found in New England.
colliding-beam machine: a particle accelerator in which two separate beams of particles (usually of opposite charge) are circulated in opposite directions and directed so as to collide head on; -- called also colliding-beam accelerator and collider.
Culverin: A long cannon of the 16th century, usually an 18-pounder with serpent-shaped handles.
Cellarage: The space or storerooms of a cellar; a cellar.
Crossbar: A transverse bar or piece, as a bar across a door, or as the iron bar or stock which passes through the shank of an anchor to insure its turning fluke down.
COMINT: an abbreviation for communications intelligence; technical and intelligence information derived from foreign communications by other than the intended recipients.
Consultive: Determined by, or pertaining to, consultation; deliberate; consultative.
Comanches: A warlike, savage, and nomadic tribe of the Shoshone family of Indians, inhabiting Mexico and the adjacent parts of the United States; -- called also Paducahs. They are noted for plundering and cruelty.
Clitoris: A small organ at the upper part of the vulva in females, homologous to the penis in the male.
Cinnamic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, cinnamon.
Coherent: Sticking together; cleaving; as the parts of bodies; solid or fluid.
capital: The head or uppermost member of a column, pilaster, etc.  It consists generally of three parts, abacus, bell (or vase), and necking.  See these terms, and Column.
Clitoria: a genus of tropical shrubs or vines having pinnate leaves and large axillary flowers.
Continental pronunciation: A method of pronouncing Latin and Greek in which the vowels have their more familiar Continental values, as in German and Italian, the consonants being pronounced mostly as in English. The stricter form of this method of pronouncing Latin approaches the Roman, the modified form the English, pronunciation. The Continental method of Greek pronunciation is often called Erasmian.
Cahier: A number of sheets of paper put loosely together; esp. one of the successive portions of a work printed in numbers.
Clan: A tribe or collection of families, united under a chieftain, regarded as having the same common ancestor, and bearing the same surname; as, the clan of Macdonald.
Clam: To produce, in bell ringing, a clam or clangor; to cause to clang.
Copra: The dried meat of the cocoanut, from which cocoanut oil is expressed.
Chim\u00e6ra: A cartilaginous fish of several species, belonging to the order Chimaeriformes of the class Holocephali.  The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished with appendages, and the tail terminates in a point.
Chaud-medley: The killing of a person in an affray, in the heat of blood, and while under the influence of passion, thus distinguished from chance-medley or killing in self-defense, or in a casual affray.
Clay: To cover or manure with clay.
Claw: To scrape, scratch, or dig with a claw, or with the hand as a claw.
Copal: A resinous substance flowing spontaneously from trees of Zanzibar, Madagascar, and South America (Trachylobium Hornemannianum, Trachylobium verrucosum, and Hymenæa Courbaril), and dug from earth where forests have stood in Africa; -- used chiefly in making varnishes.
Caruncle: A small fleshy prominence or excrescence; especially the small, reddish body, the caruncula lacrymalis, in the inner angle of the eye.
CBC: the complete blood count; a clinical test which counts the number of white and red blood cells and the number of platelets in one cubic milimeter of blood.
Catenulate: Consisting of little links or chains.
Compartition: The act of dividing into parts or compartments; division; also, a division or compartment.
Copepoda: An order of Entomostraca, including many minute Crustacea, both fresh-water and marine.
Controvert: To make matter of controversy; to dispute or oppose by reasoning; to contend against in words or writings; to contest; to debate.
Commissaryship: The office or employment of a commissary.
Conjurator: One who swears or is sworn with others; one bound by oath with others; a compurgator.
cracker-barrel: characteristic of country life; as, cracker-barrel philosophy.
cesium: the chemical element of atomic number 55.  It is a univalent element, the most electropositive metal.  Symbol Cs; atomic weight 132.905.  IT has a melting point of 28.4° C.
Chronometry: The art of measuring time; the measuring of time by periods or divisions.
Crosse: The implement with which the ball is thrown and caught in the game of lacrosse.
Clumper: To form into clumps or masses.
Countermine: To make a countermine or counterplot; to plot secretly.
crumpet: A kind of large, thin, unsweetened muffin or cake, light and spongy, and cooked on a griddle or spider, or sometimes toasted.
Corallaceous: Like coral, or partaking of its qualities.
Closemouthed: Cautious in speaking; secret; wary; uncommunicative.
Cow tree: A tree (Galactodendron utile or Brosimum Galactodendron) of South America, which yields, on incision, a nourishing fluid, resembling milk.
Cumulus: One of the four principal forms of clouds. SeeCloud.
Cuesta: A sloping plain, esp. one with the upper end at the crest of a cliff; a hill or ridge with one face steep and the opposite face gently sloping.
Conflagrant: Burning together in a common flame.
Count: A nobleman on the continent of Europe, equal in rank to an English earl.
Claymore mine: an antipersonnel land mine designed to produce a high-velocity spray of steel fragments in a relatively narrow fan-shaped cone, directed toward the enemy.  They are usually detonated by an electrical remote control.
Concubinage: The cohabiting of a man and a woman who are not legally married; the state of being a concubine.
Copple-crown: A created or high-topped crown or head.
Cremasteric: Of or pertaining to the cremaster; as, the cremasteric artery.
Chuck: A piece of the backbone of an animal, from between the neck and the collar bone, with the adjoining parts, cut for cooking; as, a chuck steak; a chuck roast.
Choir: A band or organized company of singers, especially in church service.
Careen: To incline to one side, or lie over, as a ship when sailing on a wind; to be off the keel.
Conciliation: The act or process of conciliating; the state of being conciliated.
Charlatan: One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantable pretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.
Calumet: A kind of pipe, used by the North American Indians for smoking tobacco. The bowl is usually made of soft red stone, and the tube is a long reed often ornamented with feathers.
Characterization: The act or process of characterizing.
Convalescence: The recovery of heath and strength after disease; the state of a body renewing its vigor after sickness or weakness; the time between the subsidence of a disease and complete restoration to health.
condominium: one of the units in a condominium{2}.
Crown colony: A colony of the British Empire not having an elective magistracy or a parliament, but governed by a chief magistrate (called Governor) appointed by the Crown, with executive councilors nominated by him and not elected by the people.
Canvass: Close inspection; careful review for verification; as, a canvass of votes.
Covenantor: The party who makes a covenant.
Contraindication: An indication or symptom which forbids the method of treatment usual in such cases.
Counterprove: To take a counter proof of, or a copy in reverse, by taking an impression directly from the face of an original.  See Counter proof, under Counter.
Court-martial: To subject to trial by a court-martial.
Constantly: With constancy; steadily; continually; perseveringly; without cessation; uniformly.
Calliopsis: A popular name given to a few species of the genus Coreopsis, especially to Coreopsis tinctoria of Arkansas.
Creux: Used in English only in the expression en creux. Thus, engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio, or by sinking or hollowing out the design.
Coraciidae: a family of birds comprising the rollers.
Chignon: A knot, boss, or mass of hair, natural or artificial, worn by a woman at the back of the head.
Collidine: One of a class of organic bases, C8H11N, usually pungent oily liquids, belonging to the pyridine series, and obtained from bone oil, coal tar, naphtha, and certain alkaloids.
Condescend: To stoop or descend; to let one's self down; to submit; to waive the privilege of rank or dignity; to accommodate one's self to an inferior.
cliched: repeated regularly without thought or originality.
Clinker-built: Having the side planks (af a boat) so arranged that the lower edge of each overlaps the upper edge of the plank next below it like clapboards on a house. See Lapstreak.
Crazing: Fine cracks resulting from shrinkage on the surface of glazed pottery, concrete, or other material. The admired crackle in some Oriental potteries and porcelains is crazing produced in a foreseen and regulated way. In common pottery it is often the result of exposure to undue heat, and the beginning of disintegration.
cleistothecium: the closed spore-bearing structure of some fungi (especially Aspergillaceae and Eurysiphaceae) from which spores are released only by decay or disintegration; -- called also cleistocarp.
Cometary: Pertaining to, or resembling, a comet.
Contemptible: Worthy of contempt; deserving of scorn or disdain; mean; vile; despicable.
Corrigendum: A fault or error to be corrected.
Cyanosite: Native sulphate of copper. Cf. Blue vitriol, under Blue.
Cocoon: An oblong case in which the silkworm lies in its chrysalis state. It is formed of threads of silk spun by the worm just before leaving the larval state. From these the silk of commerce is prepared.
Chieftain: A captain, leader, or commander; a chief; the head of a troop, army, or clan.
Convolution: The act of rolling anything upon itself, or one thing upon another; a winding motion.
Collusive: Characterized by collusion; done or planned in collusion.
Coasting: A sailing along a coast, or from port to port; a carrying on a coasting trade.
Catenary: The curve formed by a rope or chain of uniform density and perfect flexibility, hanging freely between two points of suspension, not in the same vertical line.
Carrot: An umbelliferous biennial plant (Daucus Carota), of many varieties.
Cursedness: The state of being under a curse or of being doomed to execration or to evil.
cross-dress: to dress in the clothes of the other sex.
Cointense: Equal in intensity or degree; as, the relations between 6 and 12, and 8 and 16, are cointense.
Cajuputene: A colorless or greenish oil extracted from cajuput.
call-back: a return call, especially a telephone call.
Commendam: A vacant living or benefice commended to a cleric (usually a bishop) who enjoyed the revenue until a pastor was provided. A living so held was said to be held in commendam. The practice was abolished by law in 1836.
Carnauba: The Brazilian wax palm. See Wax palm.
Cachepot: An ornamental casing for a flowerpot, of porcelain, metal, paper, etc.
Caisson disease: A disease frequently induced by remaining for some time in an atmosphere of high pressure, as in caissons, diving bells, etc. It is characterized by neuralgic pains and paralytic symptoms. It is caused by the release of bubbles of gas, usually nitrogen, from bodily fluids into the blood and tissues, when a person, having been in an environment with high air pressure, moves to a lower pressure environment too rapidly for the excess dissolved gases to be released through normal breathing.  It may be fatal, but can be reversed or alleviated by returning the affected person to a high air pressure, and then gradually decreasing the pressure to allow the gases to be released from the body fluids.  It is a danger well known to divers.  It is also called the bends and decompression sickness.  It can be prevented in divers by a slow return to normal pressure, or by using a breathing mixture of oxygen combined with a gas having low solubility in water, such as helium.
Cyathophylloid: A fossil coral of the family Cyathophyllidæ; sometimes extended to fossil corals of other related families belonging to the group Rugosa; -- also called cup corals. Thay are found in paleozoic rocks.
Cockhead: The rounded or pointed top of a grinding mill spindle, forming a pivot on which the stone is balanced.
Chromophore: Any chemical group or residue (as NO2; N2; or O2) which imparts some decided color to the compound of which it is an ingredient.
Combless: Without a comb or crest; as, a combless cock.
Chlormethane: A colorless gas, CH3Cl, of a sweet odor, easily condensed to a liquid; -- called also methyl chloride.
Concoction: A change in food produced by the organs of nutrition; digestion.
Child study: A scientific study of children, undertaken for the purpose of discovering the laws of development of the body and the mind from birth to manhood.
Commorient: Dying together or at the same time.
Concord buggy: A kind of buggy having a body with low sides, and side springs.
Car: A small vehicle moved on wheels; usually, one having but two wheels and drawn by one horse; a cart.
Caw: The cry made by the crow, rook, or raven.
Cat: To bring to the cathead; as, to cat an anchor. See Anchor.
Coagulation: The change from a liquid to a thickened, curdlike, insoluble state, not by evaporation, but by some kind of chemical reaction; as, the spontaneous coagulation of freshly drawn blood; the coagulation of milk by rennet, or acid, and the coagulation of egg albumin by heat.  Coagulation is generally the change of an albuminous body into an insoluble modification.
Cab: A Hebrew dry measure, containing a little over two (2.37) pints.
Callistephus: a genus of plants having only one species, an erect Asiatic herb with large flowers.
Cad: A person who stands at the door of an omnibus to open and shut it, and to receive fares; an idle hanger-on about innyards.
Cicatrizant: A medicine or application that promotes the healing of a sore or wound, or the formation of a cicatrix.
C\u00e6sar: A Roman emperor, as being the successor of Augustus Cæsar. Hence, a kaiser, or emperor of Germany, or any emperor or powerful ruler. See Kaiser, Kesar.
Calculation: The act or process, or the result, of calculating; computation; reckoning, estimate.
Cymene: A colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbon, CH3.C6H4.C3H7, of pleasant odor, obtained from oil of cumin, oil of caraway, carvacrol, camphor, etc.; -- called also paracymene, and formerly camphogen.
Compurgator: One who bears testimony or swears to the veracity or innocence of another. See Purgation; also Wager of law, under Wager.
Cantoral: Of or belonging to a cantor.
Clumsily: In a clumsy manner; awkwardly; as, to walk clumsily.
Condemn: To pronounce to be wrong; to disapprove of; to censure.
Chasuble: The outer vestment worn by the priest in saying Mass, consisting, in the Roman Catholic Church, of a broad, flat, back piece, and a narrower front piece, the two connected over the shoulders only. The back has usually a large cross, the front an upright bar or pillar, designed to be emblematical of Christ's sufferings. In the Greek Church the chasuble is a large round mantle.
Conterminable: Having the same bounds; terminating at the same time or place; conterminous.
Convolvulin: A glucoside occurring in jalap (the root of a convolvulaceous plant), and extracted as a colorless, tasteless, gummy mass of powerful purgative properties.
crosscurrent: a stretch of turbulent water in the sea.
Croissant\u00e9: Terminated with crescents; -- said of a cross the ends of which are so terminated.
Chantry: An endowment or foundation for the chanting of masses and offering of prayers, commonly for the founder.
Cognation: Relationship by blood; descent from the same original; kindred.
cladode: a flattened stem resembling and functioning as a leaf.
Cadastre: An official statement of the quantity and value of real estate for the purpose of apportioning the taxes payable on such property; a public register showing the details of ownership and value of land.
canavanine: An amino acid found in the jack bean.
Choric: Of or pertaining to a chorus.
Crepance: An injury in a horse's leg, caused by the shoe of one hind foot striking and cutting the other leg. It sometimes forms an ulcer.
Currency: A continued or uninterrupted course or flow like that of a stream; as, the currency of time.
Chrysophanic: Pertaining to, or derived from, or resembling, chrysophane.
Constant: That which is not subject to change; that which is invariable.
Catoptric: Of or pertaining to catoptrics; produced by reflection.
Cardigan: a slightly bow-legged variety of corgi having rounded ears and a long tail.
Conglobation: The act or process of forming into a ball.
Cirsotomy: Any operation for the removal of varices by incision.
Cradle: To lie or lodge, as in a cradle.
Charivari: A mock serenade of discordant noises, made with kettles, tin horns, etc., designed to annoy and insult; -- called also shivaree.
Constrict: To draw together; to render narrower or smaller; to bind; to cramp; to contract or cause to shrink.
Crinoline: A kind of stiff cloth, used chiefly by women, for underskirts, to expand the gown worn over it; -- so called because originally made of hair.
Catarrh: An inflammatory affection of any mucous membrane, in which there are congestion, swelling, and an altertion in the quantity and quality of mucus secreted; as, catarrh of the stomach; catarrh of the bladder.
Choker: One who, or that which, chokes.
Caulis: An herbaceous or woody stem which bears leaves, and may bear flowers.
Contraindicant: Something, as a symptom, indicating that the usual mode of treatment is not to be followed.
Consolatory: That which consoles; a speech or writing intended for consolation.
Casse Paper: Broken paper; the outside quires of a ream.
chemotherapy: the use of chemical agents to treat or control disease (or mental illness); -- also used especially in reference to the use of chemicals to treat cancer.
Colemanite: A hydrous borate of lime occurring in transparent colorless or white crystals, also massive, in Southern California.
clamydospore: a thick-walled asexual resting spore of certain fungi and algae.
cuckoo-bumblebee: a bee that is parasitic in the nests of bumblebees.
Counterponderate: To equal in weight; to counterpoise; to equiponderate.
Cordage: Ropes or cords, collectively; hence, anything made of rope or cord, as those parts of the rigging of a ship which consist of ropes.
Cypraeidae: a natural family of marine gastropods comprising the cowries.
Causidical: Pertaining to an advocate, or to the maintenance and defense of suits.
Cupellation: The act or process of refining gold or silver, etc., in a cupel.
cheekbone: the arch of bone beneath the eye that forms the prominence of the cheek.
Cotyledonous: Of or pertaining to a cotyledon or cotyledons; having a seed lobe.
czarevna: The title of the wife of the czarowitz.
Corrupt: To become putrid or tainted; to putrefy; to rot.
Countersecure: To give additional security to or for.
Continental glacier: A broad ice sheet resting on a plain or plateau and spreading outward from a central névé, or region of accumulation.
Chirographist: A chirographer; a writer or engrosser.
change-of-pace: a baseball pitch thrown with little velocity when the batter is expecting a fastball; -- called also change-up.
Consubstantiality: Participation of the same nature; coexistence in the same substance.
Cynocephalus: the type genus of the family Cynocephalidae.
Cajun: In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent.  Also used attributively, as in Cajun cooking.
Calipash: A part of a turtle which is next to the upper shell. It contains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a dull greenish tinge, much esteemed as a delicacy in preparations of turtle.
Crosshatching: In drawing and line engraving, shading with lines that cross one another at an angle.
Cato-cathartic: A remedy that purges by alvine discharges.
Cack: To ease the body by stool; to go to stool.
cedarwood: The durable aromatic wood of any of numerous cedar and cedarlike trees; especially the wood of the red cedar, often used for cedar chests.
Cyprian: A native or inhabitant of Cyprus, especially of ancient Cyprus; a Cypriot.
Customary: A book containing laws and usages, or customs; as, the Customary of the Normans.
Colossal: Of enormous size; gigantic; huge; as, a colossal statue.
Citraconic: Pertaining to, derived from, or having certain characteristics of, citric and aconitic acids.
Cementatory: Having the quality of cementing or uniting firmly.
Chariotee: A light, covered, four-wheeled pleasure carriage with two seats.
cross-linguistic: of, relating to, or derived from more than one family of languages; as, cross-linguistic evidence.
Cassava: A shrubby euphorbiaceous plant of the genus Manihot, with fleshy rootstocks yielding an edible starch; -- called also manioc.
Cohabitation: The act or state of dwelling together, or in the same place with another.
Crapulence: The sickness occasioned by intemperance; surfeit.
Centaury: A gentianaceous plant not fully identified. The name is usually given to the Erytheræa Centaurium and the Chlora perfoliata of Europe, but is also extended to the whole genus Sabbatia, and even to the unrelated Centaurea.
Chemical: A substance used for producing a chemical effect; a reagent.
Compactly: In a compact manner; with close union of parts; densely; tersely.
Carouse: To drink up; to drain; to drink freely or jovially.
Clearage: The act of removing anything; clearance.
coattail: the loose back flap of a coat that hangs below the waist.
Convincer: One who, or that which, convinces; one who wins over by proof.
Craft: To play tricks; to practice artifice.
combo: a small band of jazz musicians.
Colophonite: A coarsely granular variety of garnet.
counter-balanced: brought into equipoise by means of a weight or force that offsets another.
Chlorine: One of the elementary substances, commonly isolated as a greenish yellow gas, two and one half times as heavy as air, of an intensely disagreeable suffocating odor, and exceedingly poisonous. It is abundant in nature, the most important compound being common salt (Sodium chloride). It is powerful oxidizing, bleaching, and disinfecting agent. Symbol Cl. Atomic weight, 35.4.
Consolidant: Serving to unite or consolidate; having the quality of consolidating or making firm.
Cowleech: One who heals diseases of cows; a cow doctor.
Contourn\u00e9: Turned in a direction which is not the usual one; -- said of an animal turned to the sinister which is usually turned to the dexter, or the like.
Crock: To lay up in a crock; as, to crock butter.
Clinometry: That art or operation of measuring the inclination of strata.
Chance-medley: The killing of another in self-defense upon a sudden and unpremeditated encounter. See Chaud-Medley.
Constringe: To dawn together; to contract; to force to contract itself; to constrict; to cause to shrink.
Cuckoldom: The state of a cuckold; cuckolds, collectively.
Considerer: One who considers; a man of reflection; a thinker.
Citron: A fruit resembling a lemon, but larger, and pleasantly aromatic; it is produced by the citron tree (Citrus medica).  The thick rind, when candied, is the citron of commerce.  The fruit was once called the lime.
Crantara: The fiery cross, used as a rallying signal in the Highlands of Scotland.
Catboat: A small sailboat, with a single mast placed as far forward as possible, carring a sail extended by a gaff and long boom. See Illustration in Appendix.
Centennial State: Colorado; -- a nickname alluding to the fact that it was admitted to the Union in the centennial year, 1876.
Chafing: The act of rubbing, or wearing by friction; making by rubbing.
Clear-seeing: Having a clear physical or mental vision; having a clear understanding.
Cystocele: Hernia in which the urinary bladder protrudes; vesical hernia.
Cheyennes: A warlike tribe of indians, related to the blackfeet, formerly inhabiting the region of Wyoming, but now mostly on reservations in the Indian Territory. They are noted for their horsemanship.
Campanero: The bellbird of South America. See Bellbird.
Corody: An allowance of meat, drink, or clothing due from an abbey or other religious house for the sustenance of such of the king's servants as he may designate to receive it.
Curvinerved: Having the ribs or the veins of the leaves curved; -- called also curvinervate and curve-veined.
Center seal: A compound hydraulic valve for regulating the passage of the gas through a set of purifiers so as to cut out each one in turn for the renewal of the lime.
Cingalese: A native or natives of Ceylon descended from its primitive inhabitants
Condyle: A bony prominence; particularly, an eminence at the end of a bone bearing a rounded articular surface; -- sometimes applied also to a concave articular surface.
Cribbage: A game of cards, played by two or four persons, in which there is a crib. (See Crib, 11.) It is characterized by a great variety of chances.
Communicable: Capable of being communicated, or imparted; as, a communicable disease; communicable knowledge.
Calorimotor: A voltaic battery, having a large surface of plate, and producing powerful heating effects.
Chockablock: Hoisted as high as the tackle will admit; brought close together, as the two blocks of a tackle in hoisting.
Cycle: To pass through a cycle{2} of changes; to recur in cycles.
Carbazol: A white crystallized substance, C12H8NH, derived from aniline and other amines.
Chastise: To inflict pain upon, by means of stripes, or in any other manner, for the purpose of punishment or reformation; to punish, as with stripes.
Craniotomy: The operation of opening the fetal head, in order to effect delivery.
candlemaker: a person who makes or sells candles.
Complutensian: Of or pertaining to Complutum (now Alcala de Henares) a city near Madrid; as, the Complutensian Bible.
Crosshatch: To shade by means of crosshatching.
Consubstantially: In a consubstantial manner; with identity of substance or nature.
Calistheneum: A gymnasium; esp. one for light physical exercise by women and children.
Colorific: Capable of communicating color or tint to other bodies.
Cavo-rilievo: Hollow relief; sculpture in relief within a sinking made for the purpose, so no part of it projects beyond the plain surface around.
clogged: obstructed so as to prevent or hinder flow of a fluid; -- of conduits; as, clogged pipes; clogged arteries.
Copartner: One who is jointly concerned with one or more persons in business, etc.; a partner; an associate; a partaker; a sharer.
CD-ROM: a compact disk that is used with a computer (rather than with an audio system); a large amount of digital information can be stored and accessed but it cannot be altered by the user.
Cheeked: Having a cheek; -- used in composition.
Catherine wheel: Same as Rose window and Wheel window. Called also Catherine-wheel window.
Carlist: A partisan of Charles X. of France, or of Don Carlos of Spain.
Conclusion: The last part of anything; close; termination; end.
Clathraceae: a antural family of fleshy stinkhornlike fungi.
Compassionateness: The quality or state of being compassionate.
Chlorination: The act or process of subjecting anything to the action of chlorine; especially, a process for the extraction of gold by exposure of the auriferous material to chlorine gas.
Choragus: A chorus leader; esp. one who provided at his own expense and under his own supervision one of the choruses for the musical contents at Athens.
Cheirosophy: The art of reading character as it is delineated in the hand.
Coalmouse: A small species of titmouse, with a black head; the coletit.
Curbstone: A stone set along a margin as a limit and protection, as along the edge of a sidewalk next the roadway; an edge stone.
Chain tie: A tie consisting of a series of connected iron bars or rods.
Curdle: To change into curd; to cause to coagulate.
Caparro: A large South American monkey (Lagothrix Humboldtii), with prehensile tail.
Confirmator: One who, or that which, confirms; a confirmer.
Claytonia: An American genus of perennial herbs with delicate blossoms; -- sometimes called spring beauty.
Ceratospongi\u00e6: An order of sponges in which the skeleton consists of horny fibers. It includes all the commercial sponges.
Credit: To confide in the truth of; to give credence to; to put trust in; to believe.
Creasing: A layer of tiles forming a corona for a wall.
Credence: To give credence to; to believe.
An abbreviation for Confédération Générale du Travail (the French syndicalist labor union).
Clotheshorse: A frame to hang clothes on.
Compellative: The name by which a person is addressed; an appellative.
Culmiferous: Containing, or abounding in, culm or glance coal.
Castled: Having a castle or castles; supporting a castle; as, a castled height or crag.
Contour: The outline of a figure or body, or the line or lines representing such an outline; the line that bounds; periphery.
Combbroach: A tooth of a wool comb.
Clachan: A small village containing a church.
curettement: surgery to remove tissue or growths from a bodily cavity (as the uterus) by scraping with a curette.
Climatologist: One versed in, or who studies, climatology.
Confine: Common boundary; border; limit; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Cacomixle: A North American carnivore (Bassaris astuta), about the size of a cat, related to the raccoons. It inhabits Mexico, Texas, and California.
Cyclades: the pre-Mycenaean civilization on the Cyclades islands in the S Aegean sea.
clerihew: a witty satiric verse containing two rhymed couplets and mentioning a famous person.
Ceratodus: A genus of ganoid fishes, of the order Dipnoi, first known as Mesozoic fossil fishes; but recently two living species have been discovered in Australian rivers. They have lungs so well developed that they can leave the water and breathe in air. In Australia they are called salmon and baramunda. See Dipnoi, and Archipterygium.
chiropter: any mammal belonging to the order chiroptera; a bat.
Copeman: A chapman; a dealer; a merchant.
Cracker State: Georgia; -- a nickname. See Cracker, n. 5.
Caperclaw: To treat with cruel playfulness, as a cat treats a mouse; to abuse.
containerized: placed and transported in a container{2}.
Craftiness: Dexterity in devising and effecting a purpose; cunning; artifice; stratagem.
Calpe: the Rock of Gibraltar, a limestone promontory at the southern tip of Spain; associated with Britain.
Choke: A stoppage or irritation of the windpipe, producing the feeling of strangulation.
Choky: A station, as for collection of customs, for palanquin bearers, police, etc.
Conjunctiva: The mucous membrane which covers the external surface of the ball of the eye and the inner surface of the lids; the conjunctival membrane.
Comminatory: Threatening or denouncing punishment; as, comminatory terms.
Charbon: A small black spot or mark remaining in the cavity of the corner tooth of a horse after the large spot or mark has become obliterated.
Clastic: Pertaining to what may be taken apart; as, clastic anatomy (of models).
Conformity: Correspondence in form, manner, or character; resemblance; agreement; congruity; -- followed by to, with, or between.
Calculous: Of the nature of a calculus; like stone; gritty; as, a calculous concretion.
Crouton: Bread cut in various forms, and fried lightly in butter or oil, to garnish hashes, etc.
Cockaleekie: A favorite soup in Scotland, made from a capon highly seasoned, and boiled with leeks and prunes; -- called also cocky-leeky.
Chafer: A kind of beetle; the cockchafer. The name is also applied to other species; as, the rose chafer.
C\u00e6sarism: A system of government in which unrestricted power is exercised by a single person, to whom, as Cæsar or emperor, it has been committed by the popular will; imperialism; also, advocacy or support of such a system of government.
Calisthenics: The science, art, or practice of healthful exercise of the body and limbs, to promote strength, gracefulness, and  general fitness; light gymnastics.
camel: A large ruminant used in Asia and Africa for carrying burdens and for riding.  The camel is remarkable for its ability to go a long time without drinking.  Its hoofs are small, and situated at the extremities of the toes, and the weight of the animal rests on the callous. The dromedary (Camelus dromedarius) has one bunch on the back, while the Bactrian camel (Camelus Bactrianus) has two. The llama, alpaca, and vicuña, of South America, belong to a related genus (Auchenia).
Chechoslovak: a native or inhabitant of Czechoslovakia; a Czechoslovakian.
Cannabis: A genus of a single species belonging to the order Uricaceæ; hemp.
Crocodilian: Like, or pertaining to, the crocodile; characteristic of the crocodile.
Contrariety: The state or quality of being contrary; opposition; repugnance; disagreement; antagonism.
Coronule: A coronet or little crown of a seed; the downy tuft on seeds. See Pappus.
curtained: furnished or concealed with curtains or draperies; as, a curtained alcove.  Opposite of curtainless.
Contradistinguish: To distinguish by a contrast of opposite qualities.
Cadaverous: Having the appearance or color of a dead human body; pale; ghastly; as, a cadaverous look.
Countertrippant: Trippant in opposite directions. See Trippant.
Consanguine: related by blood; descended from a common ancestor; -- used as a term of relation between two people.
Calorimeter: An apparatus for measuring the amount of heat contained in bodies or developed by some mechanical or chemical process, as friction, chemical combination, combustion, etc.  For combustion processes, a bomb calorimeter may be used.
Chameck: A kind of spider monkey (Ateles chameck), having the thumbs rudimentary and without a nail.
Chemosmosis: Chemical action taking place through an intervening membrane.
Caltrop: A genus of herbaceous plants (Tribulus) of the order Zygophylleæ, having a hard several-celled fruit, armed with stout spines, and resembling the military instrument of the same name. The species grow in warm countries, and are often very annoying to cattle.
Cuttle bone: The shell or bone of cuttlefishes, used for various purposes, as for making polishing powder, etc.
creamcups: a California plant (Platystemon californicus) with small pale yellow flowers.
Chancre: A venereal sore or ulcer; specifically, the initial lesion of true syphilis, whether forming a distinct ulcer or not; -- called also hard chancre, indurated chancre, and Hunterian chancre.
cartroad: any road or path affording passage especially a rough one.
Confucianism: The political morality taught by Confucius and his disciples, which forms the basis of the Chinese jurisprudence and education. It can hardly be called a religion, as it does not inculcate the worship of any god.
Country bank: A national bank not in a reserve city.
Compactness: The state or quality of being compact; close union of parts; density.
Crucifixion: The act of nailing or fastening a person to a cross, for the purpose of putting him to death; the use of the cross as a method of capital punishment.
compounded: combined into or constituting a chemical compound.
Chamois: A small species of antelope (Rupicapra tragus), living on the loftiest mountain ridges of Europe, as the Alps, Pyrenees, etc. It possesses remarkable agility, and is a favorite object of chase.
cochin: an Asian breed of large fowl with dense plumage and feathered legs.
Citrullus: a genus of vines including the watermelons (Citrullus lanata).
Cadgy: Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also, wanton.
cocks-eggs: a weedy vine of Argentina (Salpichroa organifolia) having solitary white flowers followed by egg-shaped white or yellow fruit.
Cogware: A coarse, narrow cloth, like frieze, used by the lower classes in the sixteenth century.
Consignee: The person to whom goods or other things are consigned; a factor; -- correlative to consignor.
Comprisal: The act of comprising or comprehending; a compendium or epitome.
Circuiter: One who travels a circuit, as a circuit judge.
Conciliabule: An obscure ecclesiastical council; a conciliable.
Corium: Armor made of leather, particularly that used by the Romans; used also by Enlish soldiers till the reign of Edward I.
cock of the rock: a bird of the Andes (Rupicola peruviana) similar to Rupicola rupicola.
Convictism: The policy or practice of transporting convicts to penal settlements.
Chrismal: Of or pertaining to or used in chrism.
Corfiote: A native or inhabitant of Corfu, an island in the Mediterranean Sea.
chiropteran: nocturnal mouselike mammal with forelimbs modified to form membranous wings and anatomical adaptations for echolocation by which they navigate.
Contraremonstrant: One who remonstrates in opposition or answer to a remonstrant.
Causeuse: A kind of sofa for two persons. A tête-à-tête.
Cathedra: The official chair or throne of a bishop, or of any person in high authority.
Costean: To search after lodes. See Costeaning.
cunnilingus: Stimulation of the vulva or clitoris of one person by the tongue of another, for the purpose of giving sexual gratification.
Chested: Having (such) a chest; -- in composition; as, broad-chested; narrow-chested.
Calyculate: Having a set of bracts resembling a calyx.
Concentrative: Serving or tending to concentrate; characterized by concentration.
Chemistry: That branch of science which treats of the composition of substances, and of the changes which they undergo in consequence of alterations in the constitution of the molecules, which depend upon variations of the number, kind, or mode of arrangement, of the constituent atoms. These atoms are not assumed to be indivisible, but merely the finest grade of subdivision hitherto attained. Chemistry deals with the changes in the composition and constitution of molecules. See Atom, Molecule.
Constipate: To crowd or cram into a narrow compass; to press together or condense.
Cyclamin: A white amorphous substance, regarded as a glucoside, extracted from the corm of Cyclamen Europæum.
Cortile: An open internal courtyard inclosed by the walls of a large dwelling house or other large and stately building.
Camphretic: Pertaining to, or derived from camphor.
Connaturality: Participation of the same nature; natural union or connection.
Carica: the type genus of the Caricaceae; consisting of tropical American trees; the papayas.
Chalybeate: Any water, liquid, or medicine, into which iron enters as an ingredient.
Conylene: An oily substance, C8H14, obtained from several derivatives of conine.
Cutpurse: One who cuts purses for the sake of stealing them or their contents (an act common when men wore purses fastened by a string to their girdles); one who steals from the person; a pickpocket
Castellany: The lordship of a castle; the extent of land and jurisdiction appertaining to a castle.
Crinkle: A winding or turn; wrinkle; sinuosity.
chalk line: a string impregnated with powdered chalk, used in construction to mark a straight line on a surface, such as a wall.  The string is held taut on the surface between the two end points of the line to be made, the center of the line is drawn away from the surface, and the string is released and snapped against the surface, leaving a line of chalk in the desired location.
Classically: In a classical manner; according to the manner of classical authors.
Corrovaline: A poisonous alkaloid extracted from corroval, and characterized by its immediate action in paralyzing the heart.
Castries: The capital city of St. Lucia.  Population (2000) = 13,600.
Calycifloral: Having the petals and stamens adnate to the calyx; -- applied to a subclass of dicotyledonous plants in the system of the French botanist Candolle.
Covenant: To grant or promise by covenant.
Charales: a small order of macroscopic fresh and brackish water algae with a distinct axis; the stoneworts.
Contest: Earnest dispute; strife in argument; controversy; debate; altercation.
Cashier: To dismiss or discard; to discharge; to dismiss with ignominy from military service or from an office or place of trust.
Claude Lorraine glass: A slightly convex mirror, commonly of black glass, used as a toy for viewing the reflected landscape.
Canker: To waste away, grow rusty, or be oxidized, as a mineral.
Circumspectness: Vigilance in guarding against evil from every quarter; caution.
Condition: To invest with, or limit by, conditions; to burden or qualify by a condition; to impose or be imposed as the condition of.
Cottonade: A somewhat stout and thick fabric of cotton.
Cantrap: A charm; an incantation; a shell; a trick; adroit mischief.
Carl: A rude, rustic man; a churl.
Ceiba: a genus of tropical American trees with palmately compound leaves and showy bell-like flowers.
Cornet-\u00e0-piston: A brass wind instrument, like the trumpet, furnished with valves moved by small pistons or sliding rods; a cornopean; a cornet.
Cats-paw: A light transitory air which ruffles the surface of the water during a calm, or the ripples made by such a puff of air.
Charmer: One who charms, or has power to charm; one who uses the power of enchantment; a magician.
Consumer: One who, or that which, consumes; as, the consumer of food.
Commando: In South Africa, a military body or command; also, sometimes, an expedition or raid; as, a commando of a hundred Boers.
Colewort: A variety of cabbage in which the leaves never form a compact head.
Chamaeleonidae: a natural family comprising the Old World chameleons; in some classifications Rhiptoglossa is considered a superfamily of Sauria.
Chivalry: A body or order of cavaliers or knights serving on horseback; illustrious warriors, collectively; cavalry.
Charg\u00e9 daffaires: A diplomatic representative, or minister of an inferior grade, accredited by the government of one state to the minister of foreign affairs of another; also, a substitute, ad interim, for an ambassador or minister plenipotentiary.
Countrywoman: A woman born, or dwelling, in the country, as opposed to the city; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with another native or inhabitant.
Censer: A vessel for perfumes; esp. one in which incense is burned.
Cocker: A rustic high shoe or half-boots.
Cocket: A customhouse seal; a certified document given to a shipper as a warrant that his goods have been duly entered and have paid duty.
Chromium: A comparatively rare element occurring most abundantly in the mineral chromite. Atomic weight 52.5.  Symbol Cr.  When isolated it is a hard, brittle, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty. Its chief commercial importance is for its compounds, as potassium chromate, lead chromate, etc., which are brilliantly colored and are used dyeing and calico printing. Called also chrome.
Casuariiformes: an order of ratite birds comprising the cassowaries and emus.
Crownland: In Austria-Hungary, one of the provinces, or largest administrative divisions of the monarchy; as, the crownland of Lower Austria.
Clangorous: Making a clangor; having a ringing, metallic sound.
Catstitch: To fold and sew down the edge of with a coarse zigzag stitch.
Comatula: A crinoid of the genus Antedon and related genera. When young they are fixed by a stem. When adult they become detached and cling to seaweeds, etc., by their dorsal cirri; -- called also feather stars.
Chinaman: A native of China; a Chinese.
Cossack post: An outpost consisting of four men, forming one of a single line of posts substituted for the more formal line of sentinels and line of pickets.
Cururo: A Chilian burrowing rodent of the genus Spalacopus.
Canton crape: A soft, white or colored silk fabric, of a gauzy texture and wavy appearance, used for ladies' scarfs, shawls, bonnet trimmings, etc.; -- called also Oriental crape.
Congealment: The act or the process of congealing; congeliation.
Contributor: One who, or that which, contributes;
Congiary: A present, as of corn, wine, or oil, made by a Roman emperor to the soldiers or the people; -- so called because measured to each in a congius.
Commote: To commove; to disturb; to stir up.
Chitterling: The frill to the breast of a shirt, which when ironed out resembled the small entrails. See Chitterlings.
Categoricalness: The quality of being categorical, positive, or absolute.
Crotchety: Given to crotchets; subject to whims; as, a crotchety man.
Coach: To drive or to ride in a coach; -- sometimes used with
chaetognath: any worm of the Chaetognatha; transparent marine worm with horizontal lateral and caudal fins and a row of movable curved spines at each side of the mouth.
Codon: a sequence of three nucleotides in a genome or a DNA or messenger RNA molecule, which specifies the incorporation of one amino acid or is a stop signal, during the biosynthesis of proteins.  Codons occur within the protein-coding segments of the DNA or RNA genome of living organisms.  The amino acid sequence of proteins synthesized on ribosomes is thus determined by the sequence of the nucleotides in the genome.
Competitive: Of or pertaining to competition; producing competition; competitory; as, a competitive examination.
Couch\u00e9: Not erect; inclined; -- said of anything that is usually erect, as an escutcheon.
Crinoidea: A large class of Echinodermata, including numerous extinct families and genera, but comparatively few living ones.  Most of the fossil species, like some that are recent, were attached by a jointed stem.  See Blastoidea, Cystoidea, Comatula.
Calcaneum: One of the bones of the tarsus which in man, forms the great bone of the heel; -- called also fibulare.
Cockneydom: The region or home of cockneys; cockneys, collectively.
Carpophyll: A leaf converted into a fruit or a constituent portion of a fruit; a carpel. [See Illust. of Gymnospermous.]
Coact: To act together; to work in concert; to unite.
